DOC.HEAD: Crew of Greenpeace Protest Ship Presses Fight to Ban Driftnets
LaserPhoto SE11
DOC.TEXT: Driftnets meant to catch tuna and squid are sweeping up and killing huge numbers of other fish and birds that are just thrown away, the leaders of a Greenpeace Foundation protest voyage said Thursday. In a news conference following the return of the Rainbow Warrior from a Pacific voyage, expedition leader Ben Deeble said the crew had found at least 30 species of dolphins, birds and fish dead or dying in the huge driftnets. Shark alone accounted for 30 percent of the catch in one net, Deeble said. ``Generally, they cut the fins off the sharks and throw the rest away,'' said Roger Grace of Auckland, New Zealand, an underwater photographer on the mission. Pomfret, a small but tasty fish, ``is thrown away by the thousands,'' Grace said. The group plans to use videotapes and photographs of marine life caught in a plastic monofilament mesh and a 3-mile driftnet that it seized to campaign for tougher sanctions by the United States and United Nations against driftnet fishing. ``I think the video is the most complete ever shot of the (driftnet) fleet,'' Grace said. Deeble said the Rainbow Warrior crew saw or monitored on radar about 200 of the more than 1,000 driftnet vessels from Japan, Taiwan and Korea believed to be operating in the North Pacific. He said plans were being made to unfurl the seized net in the downtown area of a U.S. city, a process he said would require about 200 people. ``I think that's one reason we've had so much trouble getting these driftnets banned,'' he said. ``People can't comprehend the size of these things.'' The Rainbow Warrior, a 181-foot converted trawler, departed July 19 from Hawaii with 32 people on a six-week mission covering more than 6,000 miles to monitor and protest driftnet fishing for tuna and squid. The nets hang like a curtain more than 30 feet below the surface and stretch as far as 35 miles. Critics say they indiscriminately trap and kill fish, thousands of marine mammals and 800,000 birds a year. At times the protesters brought inflatable motorized launches close enough to the fishing vessels to see the faces of the crew, Deeble said. He said he was invited aboard a Taiwanese ship and had dinner with the skipper. ``It was a very sociable meeting where we discussed our views on driftnets,'' Deeble said. ``He's looking at changing his technology ... changing to long lines to fish for tuna.'' The skipper claimed he caught no whales and rarely found marine mammals or birds in the nets although those aboard the Rainbow Warrior saw dolphins and many birds being hauled aboard, Deeble said. A federal judge in San Francisco on Tuesday ordered a ban on imports of tuna caught by five nations until they can show that they are not killing more dolphins than U.S. law allows. U.S. District Judge Thelton Henderson said the Bush administration had given foreign fleets too much time to comply with a 1988 federal law requiring an embargo of any nation whose dolphin-killing rate was more than twice the rate of the U.S. tuna fleet. Some commercial fishing fleets deliberately drop their nets on dolphins, which swim above yellowfin tuna.

DOC.HEAD: Ayatollah Najafi, Iranian Religious Scholar, Dies at 96
DOC.TEXT: Ayatollah Marashi Najafi, one of Iran's top Islamic authorities, has died of a heart attack, Tehran radio reported Thursday. He was 96. The broadcast, monitored in Nicosia, said he died Wednesday in his home in Qom, an Islamic holy city in western Iran. Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani declared a three-day national mourning period in Najafi's memory. Najafi was born in 1894 the city of Najaf, Iraq. He came to Iran in 1923 on a pilgrimage to the shrine of the Shiite Moslem saint Imam Reza. After a three-month stay in Tehran, he was invited to teach at the renowned Qom Theological Seminary. He remained in Iran and came to be regarded as a grand ayatollah, or supreme Shiite Moslem authority, in recognition of his learning. During his years in Iran, Najafi wrote many treatises on Islam and Shiism.

DOC.HEAD: Crowd Backing Decriminalization Decries Report Censorship
DOC.TEXT: Leaders of a Capitol rally Thursday demanded that the governor and Legislature decriminalize drugs as suggested in an advisory panel report, parts of which were barred from publication by the attorney general. ``It's censorship. And he has the nerve to call himself a liberal,'' shouted rally coordinator Richard Geiselhart. ``We don't need a war on drugs. We need a war on greed, corruption, waste and stupidity, but above all we need a war on hypocrisy.'' Regina Birdsell, a spokeswoman for Attorney General John Van de Kamp, denied the allegation of censorship. She said recommendations of decriminalization were deleted because they were contained in individual members' statements and not in a collective panel opinion. The seven-member commission was created by the Legislature to study drug abuse and possible remedies, Birdsell said. Its report explains where people can write for the individual panel members' opinions, she said. Panel members said they recommended that the Legislature legalize cultivation of marijuana for personal use, consider decriminalization of other drugs on an individual basis and legalize possession of hypodermic needles. The state panel said current anti-drug laws have been ``manifestly unsuccessful in that we are now using more and a greater variety of drugs, legal and illegal.'' Many of the 300 people who flocked to the noon rally outside the state Capitol sported long hair and the tie-dyed look of the 1960s. Marijuana smoke wafted through the crowd. Speakers from the National Organization to Reform Marijuana Laws and other groups said laws against drugs are unconstitutional and do more harm than good. Eric Garris of Mountain View, a Republican candidate for the state Assembly, drew a huge cheer from the crowd when he said he was running for office on a platform of decriminalizing drugs. ``All the money, time and energy we spend on this unconstitutional, unworkable hypocrisy via law enforcement, courts and prisons should be spent to help take the despair out of peoples' lives through education, job training, jobs, affordable housing and medical care,'' Geiselhart said. A large federal raid of marijuana plantations in the mountains 180 miles northeast of San Francisco last month drew criticism from many local officials, who said it achieved little other than to anger residents who said they were mernaced by Army troops toting automatic weapons.

DOC.HEAD: Energy Secretary Says He'll Launch Conservation Ad Campaign
DOC.TEXT: The federal government will raise domestic oil production and launch its first energy conservation advertising campaign in more than a decade, Energy Secretary James D. Watkins said in Friday's New York Times. He described the campaign as a response to the Persian Gulf crisis. The United States imported about 700,000 barrels a day from Iraq and Kuwait before the United Nations embargo went into place. That will be made up by December by increasing production from Prudhoe Bay in Alaska, Watkins said in an interview. The Energy Department also is seeking another 30,000 barrels a day from Texas and 50,000 barrels more from companies that have developed oil reserves off the coast of Santa Barbara, Calif. The new advertising campaign will begin in mid-September. It will urge Americans to conserve oil by doing things like inflating their tires to the maximum pressure, driving more fuel-efficient cars and observing speed limits. If everyone responded to those measures, almost 200,000 barrels of oil could be saved daily, Watkins said. The department also will promote the use of gasohol. Drivers of the Energy Department's more than 12,000 cars and trucks were directed Thursday to begin buying alcohol-blended fuels in an experiment to measure fuel savings. Watkins said he hoped the program would ``send signals to the private sector that we'd like them to do likewise.'' The department has decided not to speed up its drafting a new national energy policy for making the country more fuel self-sufficient. That policy is to be delivered to the White House in December and to Congress in the spring.

DOC.HEAD: Group Indicted on Charges of Illegal Gambling: Government
DOC.TEXT: A Chinese businessman's association has been indicted on charges it ran a multimillion-dollar illegal gambling operation from several U.S. cities, the federal government announced Thursday. The 34-count indictment names the National On Leong Chinese Merchants Association in New York and its Chicago, Houston and New York Chapters, as well as 29 individuals, said Fred L. Foreman, U.S. attorney for the northern district of Illinois. ``The National On Leong ... directed and controlled illegal casino-style gambling games such as fan tan, pai gow and 13 card maintained by several of the local chapters,'' said the 98-page indictment handed down Wednesday. The 29 individuals are listed as residents of Detroit, Minneapolis, Pittsburgh, Houston, Atlanta, Chicago and New York, according to a statement released with the document. The group allgedly used a New York street gang, the Ghost Shadows, for protection and to resolve disputes. The association and some of the individuals were charged with racketeering conspiracy, conspiracy to bribe a witness and conspiracy to bribe a Chicago area judge. Some also were charged with illegal gambling and conspiracy to defraud the U.S. government by obstructing the Internal Revenue Service. The government sought to seize On Leong buildings in Chicago, New York and Houston, as well as $11.5 million in proceeds the indictment said came from illegal gambling. Foreman said in a telephone interview that On Leong has run a gambling operation for at least six years and that the indictments resulted from a 2{-year investigation.

DOC.HEAD: Low-Level Alert Issued At Beaver Valley II
DOC.TEXT: Accidentally vented carbon dioxide triggered an alert at the Beaver Valley II nuclear power plant. There were no injuries or release of radiation and the plant continued operating during Thursday's incident, said Duquesne Light Co., the plant's operator. The release occurred during maintenance testing of valves, one of which leaked carbon dioxide and decreased the oxygen level below safe levels, Duquesne said. Oxygen levels returned to normal after the area was vented, the utility said. The alert lasted two hours. An alert is the second lowest of four levels of emergency classification designated by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission. Beaver Valley II is an 833 megawatt reactor located 22 miles northwest of Pittsburgh.

DOC.HEAD: What's Missing from Maine Lunch Boxes? `Aseptic' Packaging
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: A back-to-school quiz: What lunch box fixture will be history in school lunchrooms across Maine? Answer: The juice box, that soft-sided, single-serving container. The Legislature has outlawed it because the bonded layers of plastic, paper and aluminum that keep the contents fresh defy recycling. Maine's unique ban on sale of most beverages in aseptic packaging takes effect Saturday, just as children prepare to return to school and parents think about what to pack in their kids' lunch boxes. While the timing of the law was, by all accounts, coincidental, it has left parents scrambling to replace the drinks packed in convenient 8{-ounce containers that come with straws. ``I don't know what we're going to do,'' said Linda Ball of Portland, as her 3-year-old son, Billy, selected a three-pack of fruit juice at a supermarket. ``Those glass things,'' she said, pointing to a nearby display of single-serving juice bottles. ``We're afraid they'll hurt his teeth.'' Still, Ms. Ball and other parents who stocked up on the popular juice boxes before the ban took effect indicated they were prepared to sacrifice convenience in order to counter the state's buildup of solid waste. ``I'm concerned about the environment, so I'll make do with something else if it's that much of a problem,'' she said. Supermarkets say they will no longer have the same variety of fruit juices and punches available. Cans or bottles take up more shelf space and have higher handling costs than ``brick packs'' of boxes. ``We estimate that it's going to cost consumers in Maine about 17 cents more per unit _ for each single item they purchase,'' said Margaret McEwen, consumer information director at Shaw's Supermarkets. Juice boxes have surged in popularity since they were introduced to American supermarkets in the early 1980s. Their advantages are obvious: less weight, unbreakable, safer than metal or glass, easy to stash in backpacks and lunch boxes, and easily crushed and discarded. But juice boxes have become a prime target of environmentalists because they replace containers that can be recycled easily with current technology, observed Jeanne Wirka of the Environmental Action Foundation in Washington, D.C. Maine, with a goal of recycling half its solid waste by 1994, banned the boxes in an expansion of a law enacted more than a decade ago to require deposits on bottles and cans of soda and beer. The revised law made all beverage containers, except those used for dairy products, subject to deposits. Liquor bottles came under the law last January, wine bottles become returnable on Saturday and all other non-carbonated beverages will require deposits by year's end. The only brick packs permitted under the new law are those that contain milk products or juice concentrates. Tetra Pak Inc., the company that pioneered ``aseptic'' packaging, says juice boxes are environmentally sound because they are lighter and smaller than bottles and cans. ``We have so much less material in our packages that it creates a lot less waste,'' said Edward Klein, Tetra Pak's vice president for environmental affairs. Juice boxes remain legal in the other 49 states. Lawmakers in Massachusetts and Vermont last year rejected bans. Rhode Island took a different tack, enacting a bill that requires the aseptic packaging industry to work with the state to develop a pilot recycling program. Recycling projects also are under way in Massachusetts, New York and Canada as well as in Rhode Island, Klein said. Sharon Treat of the Natural Resources Council, which fought to include the ban in Maine's law, expressed skepticism about such pilot projects, saying they turn out a compound for which there may be only limited demand.

DOC.HEAD: Pay Squeeze Turns Brazil's Labor Unrest to Violence
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Labor unrest is growing in Brazil, and acquiring a tone of violence and sabotage that could threaten the government's ambitious anti-inflation program. If his members continue to lose buying power, said union leader Vicente Paulo da Silva, the result might be a ``major social convulsion with unpredictable consequences.'' In late July, hundreds of auto workers went on a three-day rampage at the Sao Paulo subsidiary of Ford Motor Co., where a strike shut down production for more than a month. They destroyed more than 50 cars, smashed windows and doors and set fires in the plant administration buildings. A strike by power workers this month caused a 10-hour blackout in Brasilia, the capital, and shut off electricity for two hours in the northeastern state of Bahia. In Brasilia, the lights went out in government ministries and the residence of President Fernando Collor de Mello. Ozires Silva, infrastructure minister of the national government, told reporters ``signs of sabotage'' were found at power stations and authorities might sue the power workers' union for damages. Labor leaders say the violence is a sign of rebellion against the pay restrictions Collor's government contends are vital to its anti-inflation plan. ``The incidents at Ford were merely a sign of the future violence that could erupt as a result of the workers' despair,'' da Silva, president of the Sao Bernardo do Campo Metalworkers Union, said in an interview. ``Their wages are not enough to feed, clothe, educate or house their children decently.'' Most foreign-owned auto plants are in Sao Bernardo do Campo, an industrial suburb of Sao Paulo, Brazil's financial center and largest city. Da Silva's union, which says it represents 140,000 workers, is considered Brazil's most militant and politicized. Da Silva said the government was ``trying to control inflation by provoking recession and unemployment, and slashing our purchasing power.'' More than 500 strikes have occurred since Collor announced a radical austerity program March 16, one day after taking office, aimed at reducing annual inflation of nearly 5,000 percent. His plan included an 18-month freeze on savings and money market accounts, elimination of subsidies and incentives, the sale of government mansions and cars, and mass layoffs of public employees. Inflation came down from nearly 100 percent a month to about 11 percent in July, but the economy headed toward recession, and unemployment soared. The Brazilian Institute of Geography and Statistics said nearly 1 million employees of private companies had lost their jobs since March 16 and more than 100,000 federal employees had been dismissed. Industrial output dropped 7.1 percent during the first six months of 1990, said the institute, whose statistics the government considers official. In May, Collor's government ended automatic cost-of-living wage adjustments and said workers must negotiate pay raises with employers. Indexed pay increases had been a traditional Brazilian hedge against inflation. Hundreds of thousands of workers have gone on strike in an effort to recover at least part of the purchasing power lost to inflation. Labor leaders want raises of more than 100 percent for their members to compensate for the wild inflation before Mar. 16. ``These losses must be replaced in the worker's paycheck,'' da Silva said. ``Then we could negotiate real wage hikes based on productivity. ``The government must adopt a wage policy that guarantees wages will be adjusted to inflation.'' Collor said in a radio interview he would veto any congressional attempt to reinstate automatic wage adjustments because they would ``plunge Brazil back into a hyperinflationary spiral.'' Workers interviewed by The Associated Press said raises obtained through negotiations had not closed the gap. Josemar de Medeiros, a 30-year-old maintenance worker at Ford, got a 59 percent raise after the strike and earns the equivalent of $915 a month. That is excellent pay in Brazil, where the monthly minimum wage is about $62. ``This salary makes me a member of the elite of Brazil's work force, yet I can't buy new clothes for my children, can't pay a day-care center, can barely pay the rent for a cramped two-bedroom apartment and can't even dream of buying what I help produce,'' Medeiros said. Millions of lower-paid workers are in serious trouble, he said, and told a reporter: ``Our purchasing power is declining day by day and we are angry. If this situation continues, the wave of strikes will certainly grow.'' Some economists are puzzled by the widespread labor trouble. During a recession, they say, workers usually are more concerned with keeping their jobs than getting more pay. Da Silva's response: ``Workers are fed up with footing the bill for economic stabilization programs. The mass dismissals and the loss in purchasing power prove the Collor government lied when it said its austerity program would not sacrifice the working class. ``Today, the worker feels he has nothing to lose except his fear of getting fired, and he's losing that rapidly.''

DOC.HEAD: Five Years Later, Ramirez Case Haunts Legal System
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gainesville Slayings, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The serial killings in Gainesville, Fla., recall the terror that gripped Californians during the ``Night Stalker'' murders, a reign that ended five years ago today. On Aug. 31, 1985, Texas drifter Richard Ramirez was captured by an angry mob that recognized him from news photos, capping a summer of random, nocturnal attacks. The grisly string of satanic crimes still haunts the legal system and those who became entwined in one of the most complex prosecutions ever. ``It's not over. People think because they're not reading it in the paper anymore that it's over,'' said Deputy District Attorney P. Philip Halpin, whose career became captive to the Ramirez case. ``There will be many more anniversaries before this case reaches its resolution, unfortunately.'' The appeal process has just begun for the 30-year-old Ramirez, convicted of 13 murders and 30 felonies. Ramirez also faces trial soon in San Francisco in a single slaying there. In spite of winning Ramirez's conviction and death sentence last September, Halpin remains assigned to the case full-time. He works in an office filled with transcripts of marathon court proceedings for use in the appeal, which is automatic in death-penalty cases. How long will it take to resolve the appeal? ``We're talking years,'' said Halpin. Ramirez is being held in the county jail in San Francisco, where Deputy District Attorney Eugene Sweeters said, ``He hasn't caused any trouble there as far as I know.'' Ramirez's reign of terror ended when East Los Angeles residents captured him after he tried to pull a woman from her car. By the time police arrived, a crowd was shouting ``Kill him! Kill him!'' Officers formed a human chain to protect Ramirez from the mob. Residents said the ``Night Stalker'' held all of them captive throughout that steamy summer when they kept windows and doors shut tight in fear. As in the Gainesville slayings, it was through unlocked windows and doors, that the Stalker entered homes. He raped, killed and mutilated his victims. A woman's eyes were gouged out after she was killed by the ``Night Stalker.'' A man was murdered in his bed and his wife was raped beside the dead body. There were signs of devil worship _ a pentagram drawn on the wall at one murder scene and survivors' accounts of being ordered to ``swear to Satan.'' A preliminary hearing in 1986 disclosed the horror of the victims' ordeals and resulted in witness-stand identifications of Ramirez as the killer. Legal maneuvers by a series of defense attorneys delayed Ramirez's trial. A succession of judges presided before Superior Court Judge Michael Tynan took charge and saw the case through a yearlong trial. At the very end, a juror was slain during deliberations. Defense lawyers sought a mistrial, but the judge ruled the killing in a domestic dispute was unrelated to the case and ordered jurors to proceed. They recommended the death penalty, which Tynan imposed. Ramirez passed up the opportunity to testify, preventing hoped-for glimpses of the killer's mind and motivation. He chose to remain a mystery, spouting slogans of devil-worship. ``I am beyond good and evil. I will be avenged. Lucifer dwells in us all. That's it,'' Ramirez said before he was led off to prison. Halpin said he has concluded the serial killer was really a small-time burglar out of control. He noted that Ramirez failed to fit the usual serial killer profile of someone who always kills with the same weapon and whose victims are similar. Halpin suggested that investigators in the Gainesville case may be facing problems similar to those that stymied the ``Night Stalker'' task force for months. ``Frankly, law enforcement wasn't ready for a `Night Stalker,''' said Halpin. ``Every study of serial murderers led to conclusions that didn't apply to this case.''

DOC.HEAD: College Enclave Considers Banning `Fighting Words'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Militant attitudes may be the new fashion for many Americans, but townsfolk here are chewing over a proposal to muzzle ``fighting words'' on the streets of this college enclave. The proposal, designed to silence racial slurs, is part of a long line of efforts to promote harmony in a town that has voted against every war since 1812. It is already drawing fire from civil rights advocates. ``This is a caring community. It's a community of people who really have some deep and genuine humane values,'' said Paul Rogers, a member of the Citizens Review Committee, which has written a first draft of the bylaw. Rogers said he's not sure whether the proposal will succeed. It was inspired by an incident last May in which a white youth reportedly shouted racial slurs and knocked a black teen-ager down. In Amherst, a town of about 34,000 where residents have marched for peace and against war scores of times, debating Constitutional rights is nothing new. A University of Massachusetts at Amherst sociology professor credited the nature of Amherst politics to old-fashioned Yankee outspokenness at regular and well-attended Town Meetings and having two colleges and the university. ``These are people who are familiar with the use of the tongue in a situation politically which puts a premium on it,'' said Jay Demerath. In keeping with tradition, a group of residents this month marched to the Town Common to protest U.S. military buildup in Saudi Arabia and suggest that President Bush turn to alternate methods to resolve the invasion of Kuwait. Two years ago, a group of senior citizens staged a sit-in at the University of Massachusetts chancellor's office to protest research on the anthrax disease that they feared could somehow be put to militaristic use. The proposal doesn't give a list of ``fighting words.'' It defines them as those that ``by their very utterance inflict injury upon the person or group of persons to whom they are directed or which tend to incite an immediate breach of peace.'' John Roberts, head of the Civil Liberties Union in Boston, said the proposal is a bad idea. ``Obviously it's well-intentioned,'' he said, noting that racial harassment is on the rise. ``It is ugly and you want to deal with it. I think this is not a way to deal with it.'' Rogers said the bylaw doesn't apply to expression of ideas, but rather to certain offensive forms of speech. He likened prosecution for shouting racial slurs to a people who get too raucous at a late-night party. ``If we can regulate hooting and hollering and whistling we can certainly regulate these kinds of words that are not protected by the Constitution,'' he said. ``I know people are going to be concerned about protecting free speech and they ought to be.'' The proposal may go before a Town Meeting this fall if it gets approval from Town Counsel Alan Seewald, who declined comment on the bylaw Thursday. The bylaw's wording comes from a 1942 Supreme Court case, Chaplinsky vs. New Hampshire, in which a state law prohibiting use of ``fighting words'' was upheld, Rogers said. In that case a selectman had referred to a man as a ``damn fascist,'' he said. But Roberts said that case applies to specific confrontations, which are already prohibited under civil rights statutes. ``I think they're going to be in trouble,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Comic Dog Dies After Six Years on the Road
LaserPhoto EV1
DOC.TEXT: Few nightclub comics have the nerve to jump off the stage and snatch a steak from a fan at a front-row table. Winston the Wonder Dog did. Winston's routine was not sophisticated; dog acts rarely are. But his impression of Barbara Bush was a crowd pleaser. And audiences roared when he lay on his back and punched the air with boxing glove-clad feet. The Old English sheepdog who traveled the nation's comedy clubs and college campuses for six years, died at Wednesday at age 11. ``He was the straight guy, and I just had to make whatever he did funny,'' Seattle comedian Earl Burks said Thursday as he prepared for his first show since Winston's death. Winston was humanely destroyed by a Henderson veterinarian after suffering symptoms of old age that forced his retirement four months ago and worsened steadily since, Burks said. A younger sheepdog took over Winston's act. Winston the Wonder Dog performed in Las Vegas, 47 states and Canada, where he once spent a night in jail and entertained the local police, Burks said. The dog's photograph appeared in Rolling Stone and People magazine and dozens of local newspapers. He was on the nationally televised show ``Star Search.'' Winston's talents included dancing on his hind legs and ``answering'' questions, such as ``What's the top of a house called?'' Answer: ``Roof.'' ``It was just real stupid but it was funny,'' Burks said. ``Sometimes when he would bark into the microphone he would just keep on and on, because he could hear himself. It was so goofy that people would laugh.'' With a wardrobe of wigs, sunglasses and masks, Winston also impersonated the political personalities of the day, including the Ayatollah Khomeini and the first lady, and celebrities such as Sammy Davis Jr., Stevie Wonder and Zsa Zsa Gabor. The shaggy gray-and-white dog's large, pliable mouth leant itself to manipulation by Burks, whose humor sometimes took a bawdy turn. Burks bought Winston as a puppy. When he needed material to fill time at a comedy club, someone suggested he take his pet on stage. ``There was a guy at a front table with a big steak,'' Burks said. ``I turned my back and he was up on this guy's table eating this steak. They were laughing and applauding and I was thinking, `Oh no, I'm gonna get sued.''' A dog star was born.

DOC.HEAD: Families of Oil Workers Stranded in Persian Gulf Face Loss of Paychecks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The families of some American oil workers trapped in Iraq or Kuwait have another worry: A company says it can't afford to keep paying their salaries. At least six contract workers for the OGE Drilling Inc. remain in Kuwait or Iraq. Ten other workers and their dependents left, according to T.B. O'Brien, president of O'Brien, Goins, Simpson Inc. in Midland. OGE Drilling is its Houston subsidiary. ``You've got to understand, we're not a big company,'' O'Brien said Thursday. ``Essentially, 90 percent of its income and business is business in Kuwait. Now it's not a company. That company is broke because we are out about $470,000 that hasn't been paid to us.'' OGE provided drilling supervisors and superintentents to Kuwait Oil Co. and Kuwait National Petroleum Co. for 10 years. Both companies were owned by the goverment of Kuwait, which was dissolved after Iraq invaded the neighboring country on Aug. 2. ``Our contract with these people terminated when our contract with Kuwait Oil Company terminated,'' O'Brien said. ``That's just the way the contract was written. And the company doesn't have any money to pay them.'' He said if the company tried to absorb the loss, soon it wouldn't be able to pay the stranded workers or its other 40 employees. ``It's not by our choice that any of them were there. We have a number of them who used good judgment to get out and a number used poor judgment to stay and two got captured and didn't have any choice in the matter.'' O'Brien said the stranded workers included people from Texas, Louisiana and Canada. Two were taken to Baghdad and four, plus a worker's wife, are believed to have remained in Kuwait. O'Brien said his company is going directly to Kuwait Petroleum Co., which has set up operations in London, to try to get its payment. He also is seeking guidance from the Texas Employment Commission in hopes of getting the workers unemployment benefits from the state. Bill Grossenbacher of the Texas Employment Commission said the state has asked for information on the workers and will examine each case. ``There may be a way we could interpret our laws so some of these individuals could qualify. If so, we would mail their checks to their families,'' he said from Austin. The checks would amount to no more than $214 per week. ``That wouldn't even begin to touch our responsibilities,'' said Patricia Hale, of nearby Spring, whose husband, Edward, is being held. ``I really don't know yet what I'm going to do. I have no other income. Donnita Cole, of Odessa, whose husband, John, is a captive, said $214 ``won't even pay my telephone bill.'' ``I just can't believe they would do this to us. I never heard of a company that would do this to dependents,'' she said. ``My husband did not quit and did not get laid off, so there's no need to call the Texas Employment Commission.''

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutor Slain in Drive-By Shooting in Bronx
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf, `Milton Mollon...' with suspect surrendering
DOC.TEXT: A prosecutor was shot in the head and killed Thursday in a drive-by slaying as he picked up doughnuts at a store near the Bronx County Courthouse, but authorities said he was not the target of the gunman. Also Thursday, a former state senator, 49-year-old Vander Beatty, was fatally shot in his office in the Brooklyn borough. The prosecutor, 30-year-old Sean Healy, was hit once as he bent over to take a box of doughnuts from a store shelf, said Michael Philbin, chief of Bronx detectives. ``He certainly was not a target. He happened to be in the wrong place at the wrong time,'' Philbin said. Philbin said police had been summoned to a location a block from the store about an hour before the shooting but no one was there when they arrived. He said police theorized that the shooting and the dispute were linked but they did not know for certain. Late Thursday, a suspect in the shooting voluntarily surrendered to police in the Bronx and was being questioned, said Officer Mark Warren, a police spokesman. No charges were brought immediately, Warren said. Beatty's killing was announced by Mayor David Dinkins, who has campaigned recently against firearms. ``Somehow, we're going to have to get the citizenry of this country outraged at the proliferation of guns,'' Dinkins said, after a news conference at City Hall. Beatty, a Democrat who left the state senate after being convicted of forgery and racketeering in 1984, was shot once in the head at his office. Police spokesman Tina Mohrmann said Beatty was killed by an unidentified man who fled in a blue Oldsmobile. Former U.S. Rep. Shirley Chisholm, with whom Beatty feuded politically over Brooklyn matters, learned about her former colleague's death from a reporter. ``Oh, God. On the eve of his election coming up,'' Chisholm said, referring to Beatty's run for district leader in his old senatorial district. ``I just got the shock of my life.''

DOC.HEAD: Papal Trip to Africa to be Marked by Blessing of Controversial Site
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II arrives Saturday on the start of a four-nation African tour to be climaxed by the blessing of a huge, costly and controversial basilica in Ivory Coast. The trip, which will take the pope across the bulge of the continent, will be his 49th foreign tour and his seventh visit to Africa, where declining economies and rapidly rising populations spell misery for millions. As in previous visits, the pope is expected to call for Christian harmony and preach against artificial birth control and extramarital sex, with its attendant threat of AIDS, a particularly deadly scourge in Africa. The World Health Organization estimates 5 million sub-Saharan Africans are infected with the virus that can cause the disease. That is double the number three years ago. Pope John Paul will carry his messages from Dar es Salaam to three other major cities in Tanzania, an East Africa nation of about 23 million people. Most of them are Moslems. About 20 percent of Tanzanians subscribe to the Roman Catholic faith. After five days in Tanzania, he will fly to Burundi and Rwanda, tiny neighboring and predominantly Catholic countries to the northwest. They are the most densly populated nations in Africa and their recent history has been marked by clashes between their two main ethnic groups, the Hutus and the Tutsis. The pope will spend two nights each in Burundi and Rwanda before going across the continent to Ivory Coast, where he will end his trip Sept. 10 by consecrating the immense Basilica of Our Lady of Peace. Rivaling St. Peter's Basilica in the Vatican in size, the structure was built by President Felix Houphouet-Boigny in his hometown of Yamoussoukro. The government said it cost $133 million. Critics say the real cost could be twice as high and bemoan the extravagance in a country undergoing its worst economic crisis in 30 years of independence. Only about 11 percent of Ivory Coast's 11 million residents are Catholics, with the majority practicing native, tribal religions. Houphouet-Boigny has said he is paying for the basilica out of his own pocket. Published reports have alleged the sale of 16,000 state-owned apartments helped cover the cost. Pope John Paul initially refused to bless the basilica, which was completed last September after four years of work. But in June, the Vatican said the pope had relented, noting at the same time that Houphouet-Boigny had agreed to build a hospital next to the basilica. The basilica is modeled after St. Peter's and is the only one in Africa. With a seating capacity of 7,000 people and standing room for 11,000 more, it also is the continent's biggest center for Christian worship.

DOC.HEAD: Gulf Crisis Could Create New Palestinian Refugee Problem
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Amin, a Palestinian electrician who fled Kuwait after working there for 21 years, returned home this week with three small bags and little hope for the future. It was the second time Amin had fled a military occupation. The first time was after the Israeli conquest of the West Bank and Gaza Strip in the 1967 Middle East war. ``This time it's more difficult for us than in 1967,'' said Amin on Wednesday, noting that he lost $65,000 in savings and property in Kuwait and had little chance of finding a job in his hometown of Ramallah in the West Bank. Amin, who would only give his first name, said he hoped to return to Kuwait but was fearful political turmoil would keep him away. He is one of thousands of Palestinians set wandering by the gulf crisis, and many have no home to go to. Amin is one of the lucky ones since he has the Israel-issued permit needed to live in the West Bank and Gaza. Palestinian leaders estimate that of the 320,000 Palestinians in Kuwait, only about 100,000 have permits to live in the occupied lands. Many others are stuck in Iraqi-occupied Kuwait. ``Seventy percent of the Palestinians in Kuwait have refugee documents. They have no home to turn to, no resident status in the West Bank and Gaza Strip, no place to go,'' said Saeb Erakat, a pro-PLO West Bank university lecturer and newspaper editor. Zuhaira Kamal, another prominent West Bank Palestinian, added: ``They have to stay in Kuwait. If there is war, it will be a danger for everyone.'' Israeli military officials said they are issuing short-term visitors' visas to Palestinians without residence permits but will not let them return permanently to live with relatives in the occupied territories. ``They can come to these areas as visitors. After three months, they should leave. If we reach the conclusion that it is a real humanitarian case, we could extend the visit for another month or two,'' said Brig. Gen. Freddy Zach, deputy coordinator for policies in the West Bank and Gaza Strip. Zach said the number of Palestinians in Kuwait with Israeli-issued residence permits was only 30,000. He spoke to reporters during an army-arranged tour of the Allenby Bridge, a rickety wooden crossing over the Jordan River that divides Jordan and the West Bank. One of those making the trip from Jordan on Wednesday was 69-year-old Rifka al Kurd of Jerusalem. She had traveled to Amman shortly after Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait to find out about her son Nabil, a 46-year-old Health Ministry official in Kuwait, and daughter Nabiha, a 38-year-old teacher. Mrs. Kurd said she was unable to make contact with her children and decided to return home. ``I cannot sleep at night, I'm very worried and very sad,'' said Mrs. Kurd as she waited for an Israeli soldier to dump the contents of her suitcase on a table and check the items one by one. Both Nabil and Nabiha were born in Arab east Jerusalem but were outside the country during the 1967 Middle East war and a subsequent Israeli census of the occupied lands. Only those present for the census are entitled to residence permits. Mrs. Kurd said she has applied for permits for her children repeatedly but was always turned down. Like many other Palestinians in Kuwait, Nabil and Nabiha have Jordanian passports. But the invasion left them stranded without money needed to start a new life in Jordan, and there are few jobs in the kingdom. Another Palestinian caught without papers is Bassel Ishtayeh, 31, a math teacher in Kuwait. Even though he was born in Kuwait, Ishtayeh was denied citizenship and passports by the Kuwaitis. Ishtayeh, his wife and 1-year-old son were visiting his wife's family in the West Bank village of Salfit near Nablus when Iraq invaded Kuwait. Mrs. Ishtayeh and her son have West Bank residence permits, but her Kuwaiti-born husband does not. With his tourist visit expiring next week, he could move to Jordan on his Jordanian passport but would have to leave behind his wife and child who as West Bank residents do not have the right to live in Jordan.

DOC.HEAD: Investigators Release Details of Gruesome Killings
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 10 grafs with new reports of suspects; picks up 8th graf pvs, `University of ...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MH2
DOC.TEXT: Investigators have been dispatched across the state to question possible suspects in the grisly slayings of five students that have paralyzed this college town, police said Thursday. Lt. Sadie Darnell, a Gainesville police spokeswoman, said some of the 600 law enforcement officials involved in a manhunt for the killer have been dispatched around the state to speak to suspects jailed for other crimes. Others were examining reports of other crimes, including a gory slashing in Ohio earlier this month. But ``we don't see an imminent arrest,'' Lt. Spencer Mann of the Alachua County Sheriff's Department cautioned. Police do not have a ``hot suspect,'' he said. Authorities were especially eager to find a man identified as Warren Virgil Tinch, of Franklin, Ohio, who is wanted for the stabbing death and mutilation of a 52-year-old Middletown, Ohio, woman, according to The Gainesville Sun. Witnesses allegedly spotted Tinch, 58, in Gainesville and nearby Ocala about a week before the five murders, and the former auto dealership employee is alleged to have stolen cars from two lots by posing as a doctor or veterinarian, the Sun reported Friday. ``He is a possible suspect. Where he fits in on the hierarchy of suspects, I don't know,'' said Darnell. Investigators were sent to Bartow, where the Polk County Sheriff's Department was holding a man arrested for burglary who discussed the killings after turning himself in to police. But spokeswoman Lynn Breidenbach said he could have learned the information from news reports. In Brevard County, also in central Florida, police questioned an 18-year-old, first-year University of Florida student arrested Thursday on charges of battering his grandmother. Authorities, meanwhile, were struggling to contend with an active rumor mill in this city about the ``lust killer'' _ who according to the one report stole body parts of some victims. University of Florida President John Lombardi said the school was operating normally and would not be ``held hostage to lunacy.'' But flags on campus flew at half-staff and the city was being combed by an army of local police, state investigators and FBI agents. ``We're trying to put a security blanket over this city,'' said Police Chief Wayland Clifton. Despite efforts by police and school officials to provide a safe and sane environment in the opening week of classes, the discovery of the murdered students on Sunday, Monday and Tuesday released a virus of fear. The fear was fed by published reports that the killer stole flesh from some of the mutilated victims and left the head of a decapitated victim sitting on a shelf. Police have given few details about the mutilations. But the St. Petersburg Times reported that pieces of flesh from the first three victims were missing. The Orlando Sentinel reported that the nipples of the first two victims had been removed and had not been found. Clifton said it was the work of a ``lust killer.'' Fear affected at least one school assignment. Anne G. Jones, an English professor, said a class chose to put off reading ``Paris Trout,'' a novel by Pete Dexter about a psychotic murderer stalking a small town. ``They decided they didn't want to be reading this novel in the middle of the night,'' she said. The rumor mill generated endless false leads and terrifying new possibilities that hindered the investigation. ``I've never seen it this bad. It's out of control,'' said Mann. A 24-hour rumor-control hot line at the Alachua County Crisis Center had racked up more than 4,000 calls since Monday's initial fright. ``They're in full panic,'' said a female counselor, a UF graduate student who did not want her name used. ``The kids are claiming that they're not getting enough information from the authorities.'' The most persistent rumors involved the discovery of more mutilated bodies _ but there also were reports of satanism, stolen police uniforms and phony delivery men. Police categorically denied the stories. Wednesday's discovery of two bodies in Melrose, a small town 20 miles to the northeast of Gainesville, set off a brief panic until police said the slayings were not related to the student killings. Many students left town early for the Labor Day weekend, but Lombardi asserted that things were returning to normal. School officials said the frightened departure of some hundreds of students had little impact on the student body of 34,000. Other state universities said they were getting inquiries about transfers. Students attended a memorial service Thursday at the St. Augustine Catholic Center, while individual services were planned in the dead students' hometowns. More than 1,000 friends and family members attended a memorial service for one of the victims, Sonja Larson. ``Was it just last week that we sat and talked about the future?'' said the Rev. Ken Smith, pastor of First Baptist Church in Pompano Beach, where Sonja and her family went to church for years. Sonja's boyfriend, Mic Ocasio, 18, of Margate, wept throughout the half-hour service, as did hundreds of other friends from Ely High School and the University of Florida. Funeral services were scheduled Friday for Ms. Larson's roommate Christina Powell, 17, in Jacksonville, for Christa Hoyt, 18, in Newberry and for Tracy Paules, 23, in Coral Gables. A service for 23-year-old Manuel Taboada, the only male victim, was set for Friday in Miami. Police have said the killer appears to be methodical and chooses his victims carefully, focusing on petite brunettes with shoulder-length hair. Police have said three of the victims died from multiple stab wounds and that their bodies were mutilated. Autopsies have not been completed on the bodies of two students found Tuesday, sheriff's spokesman Mann said.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Alex Haley says he may not have become a writer if his parents and grandparents had not given him a foot-thick slice from a California redwood as a gift 60 years ago. The tree slice had small white markers illustrating the tree's growth, Haley says in the Sept. 2 issue of Parade magazine. ``I was told that, if I read all I could, whenever I found something notably historic, then that could become another marker in my slice of tree,'' he said. ``From then on, I read every book I could handle, along with my grandpa's newspapers for black people,'' he said. ``Today, I absolutely believe that the reading inspired by the tree slice greatly influenced my becoming an author. It is also why I like most of all to write about historical subjects.''

Folk singer Richie Havens, who founded an environmental group on the East Coast earlier this year, has opened a chapter in Southern California. Havens, 49, planted tree seeds Wednesday at the Angeles National Forest, 40 miles northwest of Los Angeles, to inaugurate the Southern California branch of Natural Guard. ``You give kids something to do, and there is no gang ... no street-corner drugs,'' said Havens, perhaps best known for his performance of ``Freedom'' at the 1969 Woodstock music festival. Havens started the Natural Guard to augment his Northwind Undersea Institute, an organization that offers marine education and environmental programs to 30,000 New York schoolchildren. He has already begun Natural Guard chapters in New Haven, Conn., and Baltimore, and another chapter is expected to open soon in Washington, D.C.

An obsessed fan pleaded guilty to sending more than 200 threatening letters to actress Stephanie Zimbalist. In a plea bargain deal calling for a sentence of no more than one year in prison, Michael Shields, 42, of Plymouth, Mich., pleaded guilty Thursday to seven counts of mailing threatening communications. Sentencing is Oct. 22. U.S. District Judge John G. Davies also will place Shields on five years' probation, order psychiatric care and tell him to stay at least 500 feet away from the actress. Miss Zimbalist, 34, the star of the old ``Remington Steele'' TV series, could not be reached for comment. Prosecutors said Shields received letters to Miss Zimbalist from August 1988 until Shields' arrest in March. Most of them were short missives signed ``Your Secret Admirer.''

Rachel Ward believes being British and living in Australia has limited her acting career in the United States, but that better roles are coming her way. ``Not being American, I really had to broaden my horizons,'' Ward says in the Sept. 2 issue of Parade magazine. ``It's not just a matter of accents _ it's the whole culture. ``Most of the female roles here are squeezed between the hardware and the special effects,'' she said. ``But in the past seven years, I've done quite a selection of roles, and now I'm getting a lot of scripts out of America, more varied scripts. So I guess it's a matter of chipping away at the block of misconception.'' Ward has appeared in such films as ``Against All Odds,'' ``The Good Wife'' and ``Dead Men Don't Wear Plaid,'' and co-stars with Bruce Dern in the recently released ``After Dark, My Sweet.''

Glenn Ford plays an aging policeman not unlike himself in ``Raw Nerve,'' a murder mystery being filmed in coastal Alabama. The character, Captain Gavin, is ``just as much like me as possible, I guess. I can't play roles which require me to be someone other than myself,'' the 74-year-old Canadian-born actor said Wednesday. Ford said it takes ``real nerve'' for him to appear before the camera. ``I never wanted to be an actor,'' he said. ``I just got lucky.'' ``Raw Nerve'' is expected to be released in about a year. It also stars Sandhal Bergman, Randall ``Tex'' Cobb, Ted Prior, Traci Lords and Jan Michael-Vincent.

DOC.HEAD: Study: Even Placebo Takers More Likely to Live
DOC.TEXT: People who take their pills, even if they are sugar pills, are more likely to live than those who don't follow the doctor's orders, according to a study in a British medical journal. Dr. Ralph Horwitz of the Yale University School of Medicine, author of the Lancet study published Thursday, said researchers cannot explain why people who take their medicine, even placebos, are more likely to live. ``We need a better measure of the social and psychological features to explain why it is,'' he said. Horwitz said his team of researchers analyzed a 1978 test on Beta Blockers, often given after a heart attack to reduce the likelihood of further damage. Half of the study's participants were given the drug and the other half were given placebos. Horwitz's analysis of the study found that those who took their medicine _ placebo or drug _ had a higher survival rate than those who did not.

DOC.HEAD: Portuguese Supply Ships To Join Gulf Force
DOC.TEXT: Portugal has committed a naval supply ship and two civilian support vessels to the international armada in the Middle East. The ships will be the first Portuguese contribution to the multinational force opposing Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Defense Minister Fernando Nogueira announced the decision Thursday after meeting with military officials. He said naval supply ship, Sao Miguel, will help enforce the United Nations embargo on trade with Iraq and occupied Kuwait. The two civilian ships are ready sail in answer to a U.S. request for support vessels to back warships in the Persian Gulf, Nogueira said. Portugal is also sending a frigate to participate in NATO exercises in the Mediterranean Sea beginning Sept. 10, the minister said. The exercises are not directly linked to the imposition of sanctions against Iraq, Nogueira added.

DOC.HEAD: Parliament Passes Bill to Loosen Control on Television, Radio
DOC.TEXT: The lower house of Parliament has approved a bill to loosen government control of television and radio, which can reach all of the country's 880 million people. The bill was passed unanimously Thursday by the Lok Sabha, the lower house of Parliament, Press Trust of India reported. Approval is also needed by the Rajya Sabha, the upper house, and President Ramaswamy Venkataraman before it becomes law. The bill proposes that control of the air waves switch from the government's Information and Broadcasting Ministry to a 15-member board that will include some government representatives. A 22-member parliamentary committee, drawn from both governing and opposition party members, will be empowered to monitor the running of the television and radio networks. Because about two-thirds of the people are illiterate, radio and television are extremely powerful media. The government has often been accused of using the broadcast media for propaganda.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: At Last, Americans Feeling Comfortable with the U.N.
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: In American eyes, the United Nations has come a long way since those days a generation ago when signs sprouted along the nation's highways carrying a succinct message: ``The U.S. Out of the U.N. and the U.N. Out of the U.S.'' That was a time when the U.N. was a target of widespread ridicule, seemingly incapable of doing much to keep the peace. The image of the grim-faced Soviet envoy casting veto after veto was a topic of many a political cartoon. But the ability of Washington and Moscow to get along has breathed new life into the long-beleaguered world body, which is coming off one of the best months of its 45-year history. Without much fanfare, the Security Council this week laid the groundwork for an end to the 11-year-old civil war in Cambodia. Such agreement had been impossible beforehand because three of the five Security Council members _ the United States, the Soviet Union and China _ had been backing different factions in that conflict. Even more impressive have been the council's labors on the Persian Gulf crisis. The lengthening bread lines in Baghdad these days are partly the result of the mandatory worldwide economic embargo the Security Council approved for Iraq. When it comes to regional conflicts, unanimity has been as rare in the council as an August snow in the Saudi Arabian desert. But since Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, the council has virtually been working in lockstep, approving even the use of military power to enforce its economic embargo. It helps, of course, for the U.N. to have the luxury of confronting a situation in which there is almost no ambiguity. Normally, when one country interferes in the internal affairs of another, it does so quietly, through support for subversive groups or other covert means. But Iraq's Saddam Hussein is not a man given to subtlety. He had a gripe with Kuwait and, after overrunning the place with 100,000 troops, he annexed it. If he was counting on a limp U.N. response, he guessed wrong. If he had tried to work his will on Kuwait a few years ago, when the Cold War was still simmering, the United Nations might have responded with its customary indecisiveness. But with Moscow and Washington getting along better, it is much easier for the U.N. to stand up to Saddam. ``Many of the Cold War obstacles have dissipated and permitted the council to function as it was supposed to,'' says John Bolton, who heads the State Department office responsible for United Nations affairs. One measure of the changed attitude of the Soviet Union is that, since the accession of President Mikhail Gorbachev, the Kremlin has not cast a single veto in the Security Council. Before that, the Soviets had vetoed 114 resolutions since the U.N.'s founding in 1945. The United States used its veto power 69 times during that period. Americans came to see the U.N. as a rat hole through which billions were squandered each year, much of it compliments of the American taxpayer. The U.N. couldn't seem to take a stand against terrorism. When the Soviets invaded Afghanistan, the General Assembly couldn't bring itself to denounce the Soviets by name. The assembly was considered little more than a forum for Third World demagoguery. While bloody police states escaped censure, Israel was treated as a pariah state. In the view of many Americans, the U.N. reached a low point 15 years ago when the assembly equated Zionism with racism. It was just three years ago that columnist Charles Krauthammer wrote: ``The U.N. is more than just a failed instrument. It is a bad instrument. We have the power to see it shelved. We should use that power.'' Not many would agree with that sentiment nowadays, except perhaps Saddam Hussein.
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: George Gedda has covered foreign affairs for the Associated Press since 1968.

DOC.HEAD: Gas Prices Up, Travel Expected Down for Labor Day Weekend
DOC.TEXT: Labor Day weekend travelers will be taking the summer's last fling on the most expensive fuel in years, and travel experts say a few may just decide to stay home. The estimated 25.5 million who do travel could find other obstacles. A nationwide traffic reporting service issued a list of highways that motorists might want to avoid, and several states planned to use random checkpoints to nab drunken drivers. The American Automobile Association expects a 2 percent decline in air, train, bus and car travel from last year _ partly due to rising gasoline prices following Saddam Hussein's invasion of Kuwait and partly due to an economic downturn that predates the Middle East crisis. AAA, based in Heathrow, Fla., says Americans are expected to travel 100 million miles by all modes of transportation during the three-day weekend, during which more people are traditionally killed on highways than any other holiday period. Safety groups are hoping that energy and cost concerns will slow down drivers and decrease traffic enough to bring a death toll lower than last year's 560, which was a decline from the previous three-year average of 600. AAA's survey of gas prices Thursday showed a plentiful supply of gas, with unleaded regular averaging $1.30 a gallon. The Lundberg Survey, which says it checks more stations than AAA, put the average for regular unleaded at $1.21 a gallon and the average for all grades of automotive fuel at $1.30 in its latest survey Aug. 24. Trilby Lundberg of Los Angeles, whose family business has been charting gas prices since the 1950s, said the increases so far are remarkably similar to those that occurred after the Exxon Valdez oil spill last year. ``And yet, total U.S. consumption slightly exceeded that of 1988,'' she said. ``It's clear that the amount of increase is not necessarily enough to greatly alter our consumption patterns.'' Neither AAA nor Lundberg was projecting pump prices for the weekend, but both indicate that motorists are paying from $2 to $4 more to fill up an average car's tank. That should not be enough to affect long-planned trips, said AAA spokesman Jerry Cheske, but he said some people who travel on impulse may have second thoughts. Air travel is not expected to be significantly affected by the increase in jet fuel prices, because most travelers purchased tickets before the Kuwait invasion, said Philip Davidoff, president-elect of the American Society of Travel Agents. Airlines have announced some fare increases, but many rolled them back to keep planes filled, and bargain fares have been available on advance fares up to early December. ``We might see a greater impact on Christmas travel,'' said Davidoff, who runs a travel agency in Bowie, Md. The Trump and Pan Am shuttles that fly between some Eastern cities have discount fares available for the weekend, because they won't be carrying the usual business passengers. But by far the most travel would be by private car, with 23.5 people traveling on highways 100 miles or more from home, said AAA. The figure was based on past data and a telephone survey of 1,500 Americans. An additional 2 million will ride buses, trains or planes, AAA said. For motorists, higher gas prices won't be the only obstacle. Metro Traffic Control, a national traffic reporting service based in Houston, Texas, listed 48 areas in 23 states were highway construction or heavy congestion were expected to tie up holiday traffic. It was the first time the service had issued a list of road problems. Among the worst, according to spokesman Jim O'Neill, were the detour around earthquake-damaged Interstate 880 in Oakland, Calif.; I-10 between Lafayette and Baton Rouge, La.; U.S. 50 leading to Maryland beaches; stretches of Interstate 75 in North Monroe County, Mich.; I-80 at Parsippany, N.J., and in Clearfield and Jefferson counties, Pa.; I-5 from Vancouver, Wash., into Portland, Ore., and all routes into Virginia Beach, Va., which police planned to close off due to violence sparked by college fraternity revelry last year. Drunken drivers also are getting special attention. Police in 27 states were setting up sobriety checkpoints under a Supreme Court ruling that allows police to make random checks for drunken drivers, according to the American Alliance for Rights and Responsibilities, which surveyed state public safety officials. Most other states planned to step up enforcement for the weekend, the group said. President Bush also declared it National Drive For Life Weekend to push efforts against drunken driving, which figures in about half of all traffic fatalities.

DOC.HEAD: District Focuses on Picking a New Leader Now That Barry Trial Over
DOC.TEXT: Residents of the nation's capital finally are focusing attention on who will be their city's next leader after spending months preoccupied with the drug and perjury trial of outgoing Mayor Marion Barry. While Barry's trial dominated the news, the mayor's would-be successors did little or no campaigning, saving their efforts for a time when they would have the voters' full attention. Five Democrats and one Republican are running for mayor, with the winner of the Sept. 11 Democratic primary considered the prohibitive favorite in a city where Democrats outnumber Republicans by almost a 9-1 margin. ``Until last week, the press wasn't paying any attention to this campaign,'' said City Council Chairman David Clarke, who is one of the Democratic contenders. ``Finally, we can get the issues out before the voters.'' The campaign was forced offstage until Aug. 10, when Barry was convicted of one misdemeanor cocaine possession charge and acquitted of another. U.S. Attorney Jay B. Stephens has not said whether he will retry Barry on 12 other perjury, conspiracy and cocaine possession charges on which the jury reached no decision. ``There was some distraction because of the trial, no question,'' said candidate Sharon Pratt-Dixon. ``Now they are paying attention to the candidates and the issues. I feel like I'm getting my point across now.'' Barry announced as his trial began in June that he would not seek a fourth four-year term as mayor, saying ``now is the time for healing, for me personally and for you politically.'' He maintained he was unfairly singled out for prosecution, partly because he is black. Barry filed petitions this week to run as an independent candidate for an at-large seat on the city council, where he served for four years before being elected mayor in 1978. Barry faces a maximum penalty of one year in prison and a $100,000 fine on the misdemeanor cocaine possession conviction. The mayor, whose trial featured videotaped evidence that showed him smoking crack cocaine during an FBI sting operation, made frequent appearances at school anti-drug rallies as part of his mayoral schedule. Some of the next mayor's biggest challenges will be problems linked to the district's flourishing drug trade. More than 400 people were murdered in 1989 and another 200 in the first half of 1990 _ more than half of the deaths blamed on drugs. The city's infant mortality rate was more than double the national average in 1988, a problem city officials attributed in part to drug abuse among women of childbearing age. The candidates also are calling for repairs to the city's deteriorating public housing units, shrinking the district's bureaucracy and improving its much-maligned public school system. As the primary campaign entered the final stretch, council member John Ray was increasing the advantage he had over his opponents when the mayor's case went to court in June. Ray's rivals criticize him for his close ties to developers, his efforts to do away with rent control and for omitting mention of his first wife _ a white woman _ from his official biography. Ray, who is black, had the support of 33 percent of registered Democrats surveyed for a Washington Post poll released this week. Council member Charlene Drew-Jarvis was second at 17 percent, followed by Dixon and Walter Fauntroy, the district's non-voting delegate to Congress, with 10 percent and Clarke with 9 percent. The survey had a 3 percentage point margin of error. Two in 10 voters interviewed were undecided, 48 percent of those who expressed a preference said they were not solidly behind that candidate, and 48 percent said it was fairly important that Barry's successor be black. Seventy percent of the district's residents are black. Clarke is the only white candidate in the mayoral race. The only Republican in the race is former D.C. police chief Maurice T. Turner, who announced he was leaving the Democratic Party in a highly publicized meeting with President Bush last year.

DOC.HEAD: Libya Denies Involvement in May 30 Terror Attack on Israel
DOC.TEXT: Libya has denied U.S. allegations that it played a role in an aborted terrorist attack on Israeli beach resorts. On Monday, the State Department said the Libyan government ``provided direct support in all phases of preparation'' for the May 30 attack near Tel Aviv. Four Palestinian guerrillas were killed and 12 captured by Israeli forces in the seaborne raid. The official Libyan news agency, monitored in Rome, on Thursday quoted an unidentified source in the Foreign Ministry as describing the accusations as ``baseless.'' JANA said Libya had previously denied any involvement.

DOC.HEAD: Scientist Says Rat Tests for Low-Level Chemical Exposures Useless
DOC.TEXT: When rats are stuffed with the maximum non-lethal dose of a chemical and then develop cancer, it may be the dose and not the chemical that causes the disease, researchers say in reports published today. Bruce N. Ames, professor of cell biology at the University of California, Berkeley, said government-supported cancer tests on rats are ``useless'' because they depend upon the concept that high doses fed to rats over the short rodent lifetime produce the same results as very low exposures over a long period of time in humans. Ames said cancer may develop in test rats through a process of ``chronic wounding'' caused by the dose and not as a direct effect of the chemical. Animal cancer tests, said Ames, are conducted at the maximum tolerated doses which kill cells and cause nearby cells to divide to replace the loss. Each time replacement cells are grown, said Ames, there is a risk of a cancer mutation. The more cells that are replaced over a lifetime, the higher the odds of a cell mutating into cancer. Thus, he said, the cancer may be caused by the dose, not by the chemical action itself. ``Government dependence on animal testing for carcinogens is pretty much useless for protecting us against low levels of chemicals,'' Ames said in an interview. ``When you test chemicals on rats at very high doses, the maximum tolerated doses, half of them will come out positive (develop cancer), but the reason is that it is killing cells.'' Such tests, he said, are ``chronic wounding experiments and chronic wounding is a risk factor for cancer.'' Ames said that people are unreasonably afraid of synthetic chemicals, but that humans eat many natural cancer-causing chemicals in their everyday diet. He said 77 chemicals that occur naturally in foods have been tested on rats at maximum tolerated doses and 37 have been found to be carcinogens. Ames said about the same proportion of carcinogens have been found in synthetic chemicals tested _ 212 out of 350. A simple cup of coffee, said Ames, has 826 volatile chemicals. Scientists have tested 21 of these chemicals using high doses and found that 16 are rodent carcinogens, he said. ``You get more carcinogens in a cup of coffee than in all of the (synthetic) pesticide residues you absorb in a year,'' said Ames. The scientists said there is a public fear about minute quantities in the diet of man-made pesticide residues, but he noted, ``99.9 percent of all pesticides we eat are natural.'' he said. And 27 out of 52 tested pesticides that occur naturally in plants have been found to be rodent carcinogens. In another paper in Science, Samuel M. Cohen of the University of Nebraska College of Medicine said that in studies on mice he and his collaborators demonstrated that there can be both a dose and a chemical effect in developing cancer. For some chemicals, said Cohen, cancer developed in laboratory animals only at very high levels, while other chemicals at very low doses can trigger mutations that can lead to cancer. Cohen said, however, that federal law requires all chemicals that cause cancer in test animals, no matter what the dose, to be regulated. ``A large proportion of the compounds, perhaps 50 percent, listed in the National Toxicology Program (which evaluates chemicals), cause cancer only at high doses,'' he said. Cohen said the government now classifies chemicals as cancer-causing or noncancer-causing. He said there needs to be a third category for those compounds that cause cancer only at very high doses. Ames said many people demand regulation of synthetic chemicals that may be in the environment at only one part per billion. This, he said, is not realistic. ``One part per billion is one person in all of China,'' he said. ``It's one drop of vermouth in five tank cars of gin. ``People should stop spending all the time and money on such trivial levels and start getting after the important cancer risks,'' such as smoking, preventable infections and high fat diets, said Ames. Sydney Green, director of toxicological studies for the Food and Drug Administration, said the views expressed by Ames and Cohen about the value of animal cancer tests are not universally accepted. But he admitted that some government scientists are starting to question past scientific assumptions on cancer tests. Cancers may be caused by dose alone in some cases, said Green, ``but that's uncertain at this point and ... you cannot extrapolate some findings to all substances.'' Dr. Bernard D. Goldstein, chairman of the department of environmental medicine at the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey, said he is convening a panel at the National Academy of Science to examine the use of animal tests in determining human cancer risk. ``The issues are open to scientific debate,'' he said. ``There is a fair amount of interest developing in the issue of maximum tolerate dose'' in evaluating the risk of cancer. Science, which published papers by Ames and Cohen, is the journal of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

DOC.HEAD: Gulf Crises A Long Way from Camel Market
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: In this kingdom's oldest inhabited oasis, the Middle East crisis that brought the American armed forces to Saudi Arabia seems far away and the future is placed in ``God's hands.'' Khalid Al-Lataibi shook his head after the weekly camel auction at the oasis, 100 miles south of the oil capital of Dhahran. ``The market was tired,'' he said. Few of the meat camels for sale reached the top price of $400. He did not attribute the low prices to Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait and the subsequent war tension on his country's northern border. ``It's the heat,'' said the 27-year-old electrician with the ARAMCO oil giant who tends camels in his native village on weekends. August temperatures soar to 120 degrees. But war was on everybody's mind, Al-Lataibi conceded. ``It's all the people talk about. First let's talk about peace, then if there's no peace, we can talk about war,'' he said. As he spoke, young camels yowled in the background. But the sellers seemed more intent on discussing the merits of a $13,000 racing camel than the conflict. The government has recently encouraged the breeding of racing camels by supporting prizes of up to $26,000 and four-wheel drive vehicles. The racing season starts in October. A 10-year-old boy said he now had four camels. His father had given him one to start trading with. He said his ambition was to make money and ``be a pilot.'' The skies over Houfuf were free of the huge C-5 Galaxy transports and F-15 jet fighters that roared over Dhahran, capital of Saudi Arabia's oil-rich Eastern Province and operations center for the airlift of U.S. men and equipment. The mud brick past of the town is long-buried. Its main street is a strip of carpet stores, auto dealers and fast food restaurants. Favorite cars include General Motors Suburbans and Chevrolet Silverados. People downtown said there was a run on food in the first days after Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's troops overran Kuwait and massed along the emirate's border with Saudi Arabia. ``They were afraid, but now with the American army any rocket or any plane Saddam sent could be destroyed,'' said an 18-year-old, who gave only his first name, Ibrahim. People still plan for escaping any fighting, but the mood is calmer now, said shopkeeper Abdullah, 22. ``I have my passport. I have my money, but I'm here. We're safer here,'' he said. Escape plans include flight across hundreds of miles of desert to Mecca and Medina, the holiest cities in Islam. But in the palm groves of the surrounding villages the people are not worried about war. ``If there's fighting it would be in Khafji and that's far away,'' said Haji Fahd Mubarak, selling watermelons at one roadside stand. Khafji lies 240 miles to the north, on the border with Kuwait. The fruit sellers, like the camel farmers, said the sitaution was out of their control. ``I'm not worried,'' said camel farmer Bakhit Salah, 36. ``I leave it in God's hands.''

DOC.HEAD: ``Macho Man'' Bravado Masks Fear
DOC.TEXT: Fraternity brothers and other male students in this college town say they've assumed a special responsibility following five killings, but sometimes bravado masks fear. ``A lot of the guys are feeling the John Wayne macho man kind of thing,'' said Todd Silberman, 20, a junior at the University of Florida who volunteered for the Student Nighttime Auxiliary Patrol to escort women students at night. ``My fraternity ... we volunteered to help out with SNAP, but, you know, we're scared ourselves,'' he said. ``Some of our guys are going home.'' When the bodies of the first three victims, all women, were found early this week, many men at the university say they quickly phoned female friends to offer escorts or other aid. Two fraternities offered their entire memberships as volunteers to SNAP. ``Males suddenly were a pillar of strength,'' said Tom Santilli, president of the university's Inter-Fraternity Council. After two more bodies were found, one of them male, fear spread among men, Santilli said Thursday. But he added, ``I still think there's a sense that males protect.'' In the midnight darkness Wednesday, freshman Peter Dodzik kept as much as possible in the light spilling from a parking garage as he returned from escorting a friend back to her dormitory. ``Even before the panic really started,'' said the 18-year-old from Fort Wayne, Ind., ``I called all the girls I know, to make sure they were OK.'' Joe Cannistra, 21, a senior, said, ``I've been on the phone many nights talking to my women friends, making sure they're OK. I'd say there's an extra responsibility to the women.'' At the SNAP office, calls for escorts have increased from the usual 40 or so a night to as many as 200. There are about 23 escorts, screened by campus police, said Brett Hodgson, a SNAP supervisor and a senior. What about fear? ``I don't think any of our guys are really that concerned,'' Hodgson said, crediting that mainly to training that teaches them how to ``get a sense of trouble before it would happen.'' Stacy Tuerpe, who works in the SNAP office, said men on campus were making an effort. ``I know lots of guys that are staying with girls they don't know that well,'' she said. ``They just live next door _ the girls just didn't want to stay alone.'' At a Gainesville rally Wednesday evening to protest violence against women, one speaker, Sallie Ann Harrison, criticized the creators of horror films. ``They know what they're doing. They're reinforcing male rage,'' she said. Authorities on serial killers have said the Gainesville killer is almost certainly a man, probably a loner in his 20s or 30s. Santilli said some of the male students' actions may be attempts to negate the view that the killer was doing ``a male thing. ``I don't think there's that many people like that,'' he said. ``He was just a sick person.''

DOC.HEAD: Yemen On Spot Over Iraq Sanctions
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Persian Gulf crisis has placed major strains on Yemen's new unity, underscoring the deep ideological divide between its once-rival states and jeopardizing relations with neighboring Saudi Arabia. Iraq, which has close ties to Yemen, invaded Kuwait only three months after the May 22 merger of conservative North Yemen and Marxist South Yemen. The merger ended nearly three decades of rivalry on the southwestern tip of the Arabian peninsula. The new nation of 12 million sits astride the Bab el Mandeb Strait, the southern gateway to the Red Sea. The sea became more important after the 1980-88 Iran-Iraq spilled into the Persian Gulf. Western diplomats say the new Persian Gulf crisis has brought out smoldering ideological differences inside Yemen. There had been opposition to the merger from Islamic militants in the north and diehard Marxists in the south. Thousands of Yemenis have mounted demonstrations to support Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. Many have reportedly volunteered to fight for Iraq against the United States and its allies who are building up forces in Saudi Arabia. Gen. Ali Abdullah Saleh, president of the new Yemen republic, has been put on the spot. He is trying to support Iraq while avoiding a collision with Saudi Arabia, analysts say.
