A Yemeni newspaper editor, speaking on condition of anonymity, said: ``We're in a difficult situation ... because of our close ties with Iraq.'' Saleh, the former president of North Yemen, is one of Saddam's main allies. He has refused to join Arab moderates in their stand against Iraq. He has also objected to the thousands of U.S. and other troops deployed in Saudi Arabia to counter Iraq. However, Yemen has also said it will abide by economic sanctions imposed by the United Nations on Iraq. British sources said Yemen could become a staging post for an air bridge into Iraq to get around the quarantine, but aviation experts think it unlikely. Some Arab diplomats find Saleh's stance inexplicable and even self-destructive. They contend no Yemeni leader can afford to offend the Saudis, one of the country's main benefactors. But like King Hussein of Jordan, another Saddam ally, Saleh faces serious damage to his shaky economy if trade ties with Iraq are severed. ``If Iraq comes out victorious in this crisis, Yemen will look good. If Iraq loses, Yemen will be in a difficult position in all respects _ politically, militarily and economically,'' said one Arab diplomat who spoke on condition of anonymity. The invasion of Kuwait was an economic blow in itself to Yemen. Kuwait, like Saudi Arabia, provided financial aid and crude oil to Yemen's oil refinery at Aden. Iraq has an agreement to provide 30,000 barrels a day. Oil industry sources, indicating that Yemen is abiding by the embargo, reported that oil is now being pumped from the north to Aden to make up for the loss of Iraqi and Kuwaiti supplies. British Royal Air Force sources have reported that some Iraqi combat jets have been flown to Yemen for use if Iraqi air bases are hit. Saleh has denied that. Yemen emerged as a potential flashpoint when U.S. warships began shadowing Iraqi oil tankers to Aden, enforcing the U.N.-sanctioned trade embargo against Iraq. Yemen's Information Minister Mohammed Ahmed Garhoum denied British allegations that Yemen violated the U.N. sanctions by allowing an Iraqi tanker, the Ain Zalah, to unload at Aden. He said in a telephone interview that the tanker partially unloaded before the sanctions, but unloading stopped after the embargo resolution. Yemen last week ordered the expulsion of Britain's consul-general in Aden, Douglas Gordon, after he was arrested photographing shipping at Aden. But the Yemenis relented after strong British protests. Garhoum insisted: ``It's not true that Yemen supports Iraq. ... Yemen wants Iraq to withdraw its forces from Kuwait. ``Our position is clear. Our government underlines the necessity of respect for national sovereignty, and we reject the use of force. It's only a summer cloud that will soon go away,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Budget Problems May Erode Soil And Water Conservation
DOC.TEXT: If Congress and the White House don't solve the government's budget problems, soil and water conservation programs will suffer along with other Agriculture Department services. An analysis by the department's budget office says a ``sequester'' plan to cut federal spending would result in unpaid furloughs for thousands of Soil Conservation Service employees. Overall, about 90 percent of the department's 100,000 fulltime employees would be affected one way or another by the layoffs and other savings measures. The White House, citing the Gramm-Rudman deficit-reduction law, has ordered the across-the-board cut of federal spending to begin in October if no budget agreement is reached. By law, the Soil Conservation Service is responsible for defining highly erodible land and wetlands, and for helping farmers develop and install conservation plans in order to continue qualifying for USDA program benefits. The agency said planning of the necessary projects has been completed but that only about 30 percent of the necessary measures have been installed. Under the law, farmers have until Dec. 31, 1994, to install approved conservation systems. Swampbuster provisions require the Soil Conservation Service to have wetland determinations completed by Dec. 31, 1991, and an inventory of wetlands ready by the end of 1992. Besides these mandated timetables, the conservation service also must provide technical assistance for the vast Conservation Reserve Program, which now has about 34 million acres under 10-year contracts. The program provides financial assistance to convert highly erodible cropland into protective grass or trees. It also provides annual rental payments over the 10-year contract, averaging almost $50 per year per acre. A sequester of 31.9 percent in the USDA spending for the fiscal year that will begin Oct. 1 would cut about $7.3 billion from programs that otherwise would cost $22.9 billion in 1990-91. Food stamps, school lunches and other entitlement programs costing around $23 billion next year would mostly be exempt from the cuts. Under a 31.9 percent sequester used in the analysis _ and officials say it could go higher _ the conservation money still available for 1990-91 would be used mainly to help meet the deadlines ordered by law. That would be done ``at the expense of other conservation operations such as the water quality initiative, soil mapping and other operations, the USDA report said. ``Continued assistance to the nearly 3,000 conservation districts would also be jeopardized, and it would be necessary to reduce services at most SCS field offices,'' it said. ``Even with the best efforts to meet the higher priority needs, it is unlikely that many of the ... conservation targets could be met.'' The Conservation Reserve Program last year was determined to be subject to a federal cutback, and if this is upheld for 1990-91 it could mean reductions in the payments farmers get for program land under contract, the report said. Reneging on such monetary incentives would be harmful to the cause of conservation and environmental improvement, said Kenneth Cook of the Washington-based Center for Resource Economics. ``Conservation, along with research, seem to be always the first things to go, while the entitlements are protected above all else,'' Cook said Thursday in a telephone interview. At the start of this year, he said, everyone, including the administration and Congress, was saying that incentives were needed to deal with water quality and pollution problems.

The Agriculture Department has notified the nation's 6,300 meat and poultry plants that budget cuts will force the withdrawal of federal inspection services this fall. Lester M. Crawford, administrator of the department's Food Safety and Inspection Service, said Thursday layoffs of inspection personnel will effectively close the plants during those periods. The layoffs, or furloughs, would begin Oct. 1 under an initial sequester order by President Bush, he said. A final determination would be made by Oct. 15 if Congress and the White House fail to reach a budget agreement. Crawford said the initial furloughs would be for a maximum of 36 hours during the Oct. 1-14 period.

DOC.HEAD: Western Refugees Tell of Survival in Occupied Kuwait
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Westerners caught in Kuwait survive day by day in a harrowing hide-and-seek game with Iraqis intent on finding yet more hostages for their human shield, say some escapees at this border post. ``Spirits are good, but people are trapped in their homes, hiding out and hoping for the best,'' said Ayman Aziz, a Greek engineer who also has an Arab nationality he would not specify. He slipped out of Kuwait on Tuesday but waved off questions on how he did it. ``Let's just say there is more than one way to falsify papers,'' he said Thursday at Ruweishid, 210 miles northeast of Amman. Each day, troops tighten the circle, he said, with roadblocks every few streets. ``They are starting to seal off neighborhoods and search house-to-house in the city,'' he said. About 21,000 Westerners, including 3,000 Americans, were in Kuwait when Iraq invaded on Aug. 2. An unknown number escaped, mostly into Saudi Arabia. But some others were taken to Baghdad. Iraqi agents rounded up 32 more Britons, the Foreign Office said Thursday in London, bringing to 197 the total of British subjects detained in Kuwait. Also, authorities seized the passports of six Italians at a hotel. Many Western families live in the suburbs, where they elude capture by staying behind drawn curtains, living in the dark at night, and husbanding their dwindling reserves of food. ``They can't go outside, they can't communicate with their embassies,'' said Aziz, the engineer. ``All they can do is listen to BBC every hour. They are waiting for the Marines to rescue them, but they are afraid of what might happen if the Marines try.'' In Kuwait City itself, the game is grimmer. Iraqis are beginning to examine bank records to find foreigners' home addresses, other refugees said. ``I stayed in hiding like a rat eating nothing but rice and lentils,'' said J.M. Sharma, a 55-year-old American agricultural scientist of Indian origin. He flew to Amman from Baghdad on Thursday using an Indian travel document. Sharma said he moved to an Asian working class neighborbood to escape detection. He and some friends hid food in air ducts to be sure of a future supply. He said he was saddened he could not have take an American colleague with him. ``A white American is different from a brown American,'' he said. ``I could pass. This (man) was as white as they come. If I had some way of making his skin dark, I would have brought him. Otherwise, they would have spotted him right away.'' Only a few Westerners in Kuwait have heeded Iraqi instructions to report to hotels. Some are in hotels under strict controls. Aziz was one of the few Westerners among the 250,000 refugees who have streamed through Ruweishid. Egyptians, Bangladeshis and other Asians are being processed at a steady rate of about 20,000 a day. About 25,000 more sprawl listlessly in makeshift tent cities, awaiting their turn. The scene ranges from abject misery to good humor. On Thursday, children jumped up and down with excitement, laughing and pointing, when Jordanian fighters streaked overhead on a surveillance mission. Among the sea of abjectly poor refugees, three little girls looked in dazed confusion from the rear window of a cinnamon Rolls Royce. It was in mint condition, except a smashed ``RR'' hood ornament. Nearly everyone has left behind all family holdings in Kuwait. Workers fled without their meager savings or their last paychecks. Other refugees abandoned property worth millions. But the Western refugees said people left behind would be happy to trade their fortunes for freedom. ``The biggest worry is that they might cut off the water and electricity,'' Sharma, the agricultural scientist, said in Amman. If the multinational force poised in Saudi Arabia attacks Kuwait to oust Iraq, he said, utilities would go first. ``That's the first thing he (Saddam Hussein) will do,'' Sharma. ``He has put dynamite around the plants, and he'll dynamite the whole shebang.'' But Aziz said power and water supplies were normal, and people could use their air conditioning. Most families still had food stocked in freezers, he said. ``But they're out of booze,'' he added. ``If you have a beer, I'd be grateful.''

DOC.HEAD: Americans Are New Breed of Hostage in Iraq
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The thousands of Americans held in Iraq constitute the largest group of U.S. hostages since plane hijackings and kidnappings became widespread instruments of political persuasion in the Middle East. However, they're in a new kind of bind. Unlike the blindfolded hostages held in closets or at gunpoint in Lebanon and Iran in recent years, the Americans in Iraq have generally received acceptable physical treatment, according to reports reaching the West. In addition, they are being held by the Iraqi government _ not factions with links to a national leadership _ and used to deter any air attack on the country. Beyond that, little is known of the Americans trapped in Iraq and occupied Kuwait. In the first days after the Aug. 2 invasion, it was estimated there were 3,000 Americans in Kuwait and 500 in Iraq among the 21,000 Westerners in the two countries. But these figures are obsolete because many have fled, most of them Americans of Arab or Asian extraction. Officials in Washington say about a third of the Americans in Kuwait before the invasion were Arab Americans or Asian Americans. ``A white American is different from a brown American,'' said J.M. Sharma, an American agricultural engineer of Indian origin who flew to Jordan on Thursday. After the United States and other nations began sending forces to the region to counter Iraq, Iraqi President Saddam Hussein announced that foreigners from ``aggressive nations'' would not be allowed to leave the country. He said they must remain as ``guests'' placed at strategic locations to protect against a possible attack on Iraq. Many Americans were rounded up and taken to Baghdad. Officials said at least five dozen were known to have been used as ``human shields.'' Polish workers returning home from Iraq told a newspaper last week they saw about 35 Americans arriving under guard at the Chemadex chemical factory in Al-Qaim, where they worked. Other Americans have remained behind, staying inside to avoid detention, fearful of trying to contact their embassies, and living off dwindling food supplies, according to refugees reaching Jordan. Some of the Americans work for large U.S. firms under contract to Kuwaiti enterprises, such as oil companies. Some work as teachers or in small businesses. Other Americans, like Elizabeth Linoff, were traveling when Iraq invaded Kuwait. Ms. Linoff, 50, was among 237 Western women and children gathered Thursday at a hotel in Baghdad awaiting exit visas. Saddam announced earlier this week he would release foreign women and children. Ms. Linoff said she was working as an English teacher in Casablanca, Morocco, and was en route from France to Kuala Lumpur at the time of the invasion when her British Airways flight was stranded. ``I'm happy that it's now all over,'' she told a reporter. But it was unclear if it was all over. Saddam's announcement Tuesday said the women and children would be allowed to leave starting Wednesday. Western governments complained Thursday that an undue amount of paperwork was required for the exit visas. Margaret Tutwiler, a State Department spokesman, said there are about 500 American women in Kuwait as well as 410 children under age 18. She indicated the number of women and children in Iraq is less than 100. The Baghdad government said 28 foreign ``guests'' had opted to stay. Diplomats in the Iraqi capital said they were mostly those with government contracts or businesses in Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: Guardsmen of the 265th Start Service _ With a Trip to the Dentist
Laserphoto XSAV2
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: The 265th Quartermaster Detachment of the South Carolina National Guard is one of the reserve units called up for possible duty in Saudi Arabia. National Writer Fred Bayles is following these 14 Guardsmen as they prepare for deployment overseas.

When the men of the 265th Quartermaster Detachment crossed the boundaries of this huge military base, their teeth became the property and responsibility of the U.S. Army. The tiny National Guard water purification unit of 14 men has been activated for possible duty in Saudi Arabia. The South Carolina guardsmen face the potential of blazing desert heat and the uncertainties of geo-politics. But first came the picks and pliers of a dentist known lovingly on base as ``The Prince of Pain.'' Six men had teeth pulled or cavities filled. At the end of their first day of mobilization most were muttering and lisping through Novocain and cotton gauze. ``I guess y'all have some pretty bad teeth,'' said the unit's leader, a sergeant named Ronnie who is a probation officer in civilian life. Army security rules prohibit publication of the men's last names. ``Huh uhh ahh,'' Ernie, another sergeant, said, opening his mouth to display the fact the bad teeth were no more. Thursday's tooth torture was an ignoble beginning for the 265th, which received an emotional sendoff Wednesday from Allendale, S.C. All the men are from Allendale or the outlying communities of Brunson and Fairfax, small towns about three hours drive from Fort Stewart. Despite the oppressive heat, more than 1,000 people, nearly 20 percent of Allendale's population, turned out for a red, white and blue bannered celebration of speeches and church choir songs. Each man of the unit was presented with a Bible. The celebration spilled into the next morning. Students from the local elementary and high schools lined the road to wave as the unit left for Fort Stewart with its three 1.5-ton trucks fitted with equipment that uses filters and chemicals to purify water. The callup of the 265th is a source of local pride. South Carolina has guard units that drive M-1 tanks and fly Apache helicopters. But only the 265th has been activated, an indication of the value clean drinking water will have for U.S. troops in the Mideast. ``We know we can get the mission done,'' said William, a 44-year-old construction worker who served a tour of duty in Vietnam 20 years ago. There is another Vietnam vet in the unit; nearly half have seen duty in the regular military. The men of the 265th represent a cross section of the civilian-soldiers being called to duty in the Gulf crisis. They range from Henry, a 51-year-old retired football coach to James, a 20-year-old marketing major at the University of South Carolina. Some have served in the unit for 18 years. ``When I got out of the Army, I wanted to stay part of the military, so I joined the Guard,'' William said. Until now, that meant giving up a weekend every month, two weeks each summer and occasional special duty, like last year's Hurricane Hugo. But on Sunday they lost their Weekend Warrior status when they were placed on alert. For at least the next 90 days, the guardsmen will be regular soldiers assigned to the U.S. 2nd Army. Other guard and reserve units from Georgia and Florida have been sent to Fort Stewart, normally a bustling base of 14,000 where empty parade grounds and parking lots testify to the deployment of regular forces to the Persian Gulf. But the reservists are mostly ``housekeeping units'' of clerks and typists needed to keep the giant base going. Only the 265th has been set for overseas service. That prospect was the subject of jokes among the men as they bounced in the back of a truck on its way from the mess hall back to the stifling hot barracks they will live in until they go home or overseas. One man wondered aloud how fast and deep you could dig a foxhole in the sand. The black soldiers kidded about the prospect of suntans. They speculated about how long it would be before they will be deployed. ``A week,'' said one. ``Three weeks,'' said another. ``Ninety days sounds good to me,'' said a third. William, the Vietnam veteran, said no one was too concerned about the future. ``I don't worry,'' he said. ``I learned that if you follow the rules and regulations and pay attention to your training, it'll be all right.''

DOC.HEAD: Democrats And Incumbents Reap Rich PAC Harvest For Fall Elections
DOC.TEXT: Political action committees are donating record amounts to congressional candidates, favoring Democrats over Republicans and _ by a wide margin _ incumbents over challengers. New Federal Election Commission figures showed Thursday that candidates running for Congress in the 1989-90 election cycle collected a record $93.7 million from PACs from Jan. 1, 1989 through last June 30. The total compares to $88 million in the first 18 months of the 1987-88 election cycle and is a dramatic increase from the $71 million given to congressional candidates in the 1985-86 cycle. Democrats, who control Congress, easily outdistanced Republicans, receiving more than $59 million from PACs compared to more than $34 million for GOP candidates. Most PAC contributions, $79 million, went to incumbents, while $6.5 million went to challengers and $8.1 million to those running for open seats. Fred Wertheimer, president of the congressional watchdog group Common Cause, said, ``The extraordinary ratio of incumbents to challengers just reaffirms that PACs are an incumbent re-election machine today, and a central part of what is wrong with the current campaign finance system. ``They are playing a major role in making it exceedingly difficult for challengers to have a chance to run competitive races, and they are obviously continuing to use their money to try to influence congressional decisions.'' Each house of Congress passed legislation to curb spending for congressional campaigns. However, the versions have major differences, and it is unclear whether a compromise can be worked out this year. Wertheimer said he favors the two-tiered approach in the Senate bill: ban PACs altogether, but if that provision is ruled unconstitutional, severely limit PAC contributions. The Senate fall back provision would limit PAC money to 20 percent of a candidate's campaign contributions, and limit a single PAC's contributions to $1,000 per candidate for each election. Current law only limits individual PAC contributions, with $5,000 allowed per candidate for each election. The House bill would impose an aggregate PAC limit of $275,000 for each candidate. The current $5,000 contribution limits would be retained. Most PACs are formed by special interest groups, labor organizations and corporations. In the 18-month FEC figures, corporate PACs led in al categories of donations, contributing $35 million to federal candidates, followed by the $26 million contributed by PACs in the combined category of trade associations, membership organizations and health groups. Labor PACs were next with $20 million. The study also showed that overall PAC spending for federal candidates increased by 8.3 percent, to $233 million, in the first 18 months of the current cycle. Total PAC receipts rose 3.3 percent to $275 million. More than $66 million of the PAC contributions went to House candidates, while $27 million went to candidates for the Senate. The FEC said the most money collected by a PAC was $8 million, by the Teamsters-run Democratic Republican Independent Voter Education Committee. The American Medical Association Political Action Committee was next, collecting $4.7 million. The Teamsters organization also spent the most, $6.4 million, followed by the AMA's PAC, which spent $3 million. American Telephone & Telegraph's PAC led corporate committees, collecting more than $2 million, followed by the Federal Express Corp. PAC with just over $1 million. The two PACs also led corporate disbursements.

DOC.HEAD: Regulator Sees Growing Difficulty in Moving on Ailing S&Ls
LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: The nation's top S&L regulator says it is becoming increasingly difficult to decide which troubled thrifts should be taken over by the government. ``The job is going to get much tougher,'' Timothy Ryan, director of the Office of Thrift Supervision, told a news conference Thursday. The savings and loans seized by the government in the months following the enactment of legislation a year ago were blatantly clear cases of failure, Ryan said. They ``were like pornography,'' he said. ``You know it when you see it.'' Now, however, many troubled S&Ls are in borderline financial situations and ``much more difficult to identify,'' Ryan added. Since the S&L bailout bill became law, the government's Resolution Trust Corp. has taken over 475 ailing institutions. The Office of Thrift Supervision has recently taken a new approach, seeking to sell crippled S&Ls to outside investors while they are still under private ownership, rather than transferring them to the Resolution Trust Corp. Once they are taken over by the government, the institutions become more difficult to sell, Ryan noted. He made the comments as he released an Office of Thrift Supervision report showing that the financial conditions of more than 200 savings and loans have worsened since the agency made its last such report in May. At least 246 S&Ls are expected to fail and are likely candidates for government takeover, the Office of Thrift Supervision said in its new report. ``If current economic conditions continue or get worse, it's very possible we will see additional deterioration when we report ... again in three months,'' Ryan said. He noted that the sharp increase in oil prices caused by the Persian Gulf crisis had heightened the economic uncertainty. The thrift industry, already suffering from a slowing economy and real estate market, could be jolted further by rising oil prices. ``Anything that's bad news for the economy is bad news for the (S&L) cleanup,'' said Bert Ely, a financial institutions analyst in Alexandria, Va. The thrift agency's latest report provides additional evidence that ``we clearly have a deteriorating condition in these institutions,'' Ely said. The government has estimated the cost of the savings and loan bailout at about $500 billion, or $2,000 for every U.S. taxpayer over the next 30 years. In its latest quarterly report, the Office of Thrift Supervision detailed the changes in its classification of the nation's S&Ls into four categories of financial health. There was a ``modest'' shifting of S&Ls from one category to another based on financial results for the period from Jan. 1 through March 31, the agency said. The categories are: _Group I, institutions considered by regulators to be profitable and with sufficient capital (currently 1,175 S&Ls). _Group II, S&Ls that meet or are expected to meet capital requirements (680). _Group III, troubled thrifts with poor earnings and low capital (352). _Group IV, institutions expected to fail and be taken over by the Resolution Trust Corp. (246). The report showed a net decline of 89 in the healthiest S&Ls, those in Group I. Nearly all the 106 institutions that left the category got worse, but 17 institutions from lower ratings improved. There was a net decline of 64 in the shakiest thrifts, including 51 that were seized by the Resolution Trust Corp. Thirty-four of the shaky S&Ls improved their position and moved into a healthier category, mainly by getting new infusions of capital from outside investors, the Office of Thrift Supervision said. Group IV institutions continue to be concentrated in a few states: Texas had the greatest number with 29, followed by Florida with 25, California 22, Illinois 18, New Jersey 17, and Ohio and Louisiana 11 each. In addition, thrift assets among the shakiest institutions continue to be concentrated in a relatively few large institutions, with 73 percent of the assets held by 41 S&Ls with assets of at least $1 billion.

DOC.HEAD: `Ghost' No. 1 in a Spooky Summer Movie Season
DOC.TEXT: The curtain drops on the summer movie season this weekend with the spectral romance of ``Ghost'' winning the most moviegoers' hearts, surpassing such big-budget thrillers as ``Total Recall'' and ``Die Hard 2.'' Tom Cruise's ``Days of Thunder'' faded early. The much-hyped ``Dick Tracy'' failed to fire up the box office for long. Bruce Willis' ``Die Hard 2'' did well, but wasn't tops. And ``RoboCop 2'' quickly ran out of power. Not even the industry's most prescient prognosticators picked ``Ghost'' to scare up the most business. A modest supernatural thriller starring Demi Moore, Patrick Swayze and Whoopi Goldberg, ``Ghost'' today should pass Arnold Schwarzenegger's ``Total Recall'' to reach the box-office's top spot with more than $115 million at the gate, Paramount Pictures says. ``It's so far away from what's out there this summer,'' said ``Ghost's'' maker, producer Howard W. Koch. ``The audience said, `No more four-letter words. I don't want to see anybody blown up.' It's about time people can be in love with one another and not feel embarrassed.'' Said Bruce Corwin, president of Southern California's Metropolitan movie theater chain: ``This summer had an abundance of action-orieneted films and they just fought each other....`Ghost' was huge, a pleasant surprise to everyone.'' Koch admitted the Paramount film, budgeted around $20 million, was an unlikely hit. The audience was attracted by positive word of mouth and a strong story by writer Bruce Joel Rubin and director Jerry Zucker. Barry London, president of Paramount's Motion Picture Group, said the film was marketed for a select audience. ``We attempted to take advantage of the perceived lack of programming for women,'' London said. ``We elected to focus on the romance of the film, rather than the action or comedy.'' He said, too, that the film's stars tirelessly promoted their work. Koch hopes the film's smashing showing will prove to Hollywood deal makers that $12 million acting contracts _ the going rate for Schwarzenegger _ don't necessarily guarantee success. Indeed, in a season loaded with several overblown sequels and richly budgeted action films, most performed only moderately well. Paramount's ``Days of Thunder,'' for instance, has made $79 million, just a few million more than Cruise's 1988 ``Cocktail.'' The studio's ``Another 48 HRS.,'' with Eddie Murphy and Nick Nolte, grossed $78.7 million. Universal's ``Back to the Future Part III'' made $83.6 million, compared to the $110 million collected by ``Back to the Future Part II.'' Jeffrey Logsdon, an entertainment industry analyst with Seidler Amdec Securities Inc., said that such grosses should not be seen as inadequate. ``Anytime you can do movies around $80 million or more, by `Batman' standards that's not considered successful, but by industry standards that's very successful,'' Logsdon said. Warner Bros., whose ``Batman'' clobbered the competition last summer with $233.7 million in domestic receipts, was not a factor this season, competing faintheartedly with ``Gremlins 2: The New Batch'' and the late comer ``Presumed Innocent.'' As is certain in a season as crowded as this summer, there were a number of bombs. They included Jack Nicholson's ``The Two Jakes,'' the Middle East drama ``Navy SEALs,'' Bill Cosby in ``Ghost Dad'' and ``Betsy's Wedding.'' According to the trade newspaper Daily Variety, the Walt Disney Co. will edge Paramount for the largest slice of the summer pie. Counting the continued strong performance of the spring release ``Pretty Woman,'' Disney will wrap the season with about 20 percent of all tickets sold. Boosted by ``Ghost,'' ``Another 48 HRS.'' and ``Days of Thunder,'' Paramount will collect slightly less. Universal, with 16 percent and a surprise performance from the critically panned ``Problem Child,'' will finish third. 20th century Fox _ led by ``Die Hard 2'' and ``Young Guns II'' _ claims fourth place and Tri-Star fifth. The 1990 summer, Daily Variety said, should be the second best in Hollywood history, with about $1.85 billion in tickets sold. It trails only the 1989 season of $2.04 billion. According to Exhibitor Relations Co. Inc., this summer's Top 10 films were, in order, ``Ghost''; ``Total Recall''; ``Die Hard 2''; ``Dick Tracy''; ``Back to the Future Part III''; ``Days of Thunder''; ``Another 48 HRS.''; ``Bird on a Wire''; ``Presumed Innocent''; and ``Arachnophobia.'' ``It's been a strange summer, there's no question about it,'' said John Krier, president of Exhibitor Relations. ``But it's been a very good year.''

DOC.HEAD: Program to Combat Motion Disorders in Workplace
DOC.TEXT: The Labor Department is launching a program to reduce repetitive motion disorders in the workplace, starting with plants that process red meat, where the rate is 10 times that of other industries. These sometimes crippling disorders account for nearly half of all occupational disorders in the United States. Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole, in announcing the initiative Thursday, said the department has drafted, with the help of unions and meat industry representatives, a set of guidelines to help companies deal with the problem. ``It's really a common sense approach'' that combines proper workplace engineering, job design, effective employee training and education, she said. The guidelines will be voluntary, but companies that agree to follow them would avoid special inspections targeted at repetitive motion problems, beginning in January 1991, she said. ``We think it's a positive agreement,'' said J. Patrick Boyle, president of the American Meat Institute, which represents 450 meat processing and packing companies that make up about 95 percent of the red meat industry. Repetitive motion trauma results from repeated motion or awkward positioning of the hand, arm, back or leg for extended periods. Disorders include lower back injuries, tendon disorders and carpal tunnel syndrome, a nerve disorder of the hand and wrist. In the meat industry, which employs about 140,000 nationwide, workers often perform repetitive motions, such as cutting and lifting. In 1988, an estimated 20,000 to 25,000 meatpackers and processers were among an estimated 140,000 U.S. workers reported to have repetitive motion disorders, officials said. Experts believe that half or fewer of the disorders actually are reported. The Labor Department is beginning the process of drafting rules to cover workers in all industries, but she said that could take years to complete. In the meantime, she said, the guidelines for the red meat industry are an effort to ``eliminate as many illnesses as possible as quickly as possible.'' The guidelines will be sent to each red meat plant in the United States. The 16 largest companies, which each have more than 1,000 employees, and later the approximately 20 companies that have more than 500 workers at a single plant, will be asked to agree to adopt the guidelines, said Alan McMillan, deputy assistant labor secretary. That would cover more than half of the workers in the beef and pork industries, he said. Smaller businesses will be able to request training and other technical assistance from the Occupational Safety and Health Administration. Companies that agree to the guidelines will be monitored and OSHA will conduct inspections in response to complaints. But the companies would not be cited for violations if monitoring showed they were making progress in eliminating repetitive motion hazards, Mrs. Dole said. Some recommended solutions to repetitive motion problems include proper design of work stations, employee training, slowing production rates, limiting overtime and rotating workers among different jobs.

DOC.HEAD: Tens of Thousands Die Each Year From Work-Related Illnesses
DOC.TEXT: Tens of thousands of Americans every year die from diseases they contracted in the workplace, a private research organization reports. ``Occupational disease is the most neglected public health problem in the U.S. today,'' said the report by the Chicago-based National Safe Workplace Institute, released Thursday. This kind of illness ``is essentially invisible to the public. Because occupational disease has a long latency period and mimics other illnesses, most who suffer from it do not even know they contracted their disease in the workplace,'' the report said. The researchers blame much of the problem on the federal government through what it argued was under funding of enforcement agencies and inadequate standards. The report estimated that occupational diseases _ including cancer and pulmonary, neurological and cardiovascular diseases caused by hazards on the job _ killed between 47,377 and 95,479 Americans in 1987. The estimate was based on a study of data collected by the National Center for Health Statistics, a government agency. The study did not consider on-the-job injuries, which in 1987 killed about 11,100 people and disabled 1.8 million, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The report said its estimate is consistent with others. It noted that a 1985 study by the congressional Office of Technology Assessment estimated that American workers get 390,000 job-related illnesses every year, and 100,000 die. ``Even though it is not recognized as such, occupational disease is clearly one of the most significant causes of premature death in the U.S. today,'' said the report. Dr. Stephen Hessl of the University of Illinois School of Medicine and Dr. Howard Frumkin of Emory University directed the study for the institute, a nonprofit research and education organization financed by foundations and individual donations. The institute said the federal government's response to the problem has been ``timid.'' Federal spending on workplace health and safety failed to keep pace with inflation during the Reagan administration in the 1980s, it said. From 1981 to 1989, spending in this area increased just 12 percent, from $429 million to $481 million, while the Consumer Price Index rose 36 percent. The researchers also criticized the Occupational Safety and Health Administration for often setting permissible workplace levels of air pollution and exposure to poisons higher than recommended by the National Institute of Occupational Safety and Health or permitted by the Environmental Protection Agency for society at large, they said. ``It is outrageous, for example, that it is permissible for workers to be routinely exposed to levels of sulfur dioxide in the air that are over 62 times that which is considered a healthy level for nonworkers,'' the researchers said. The Occupational Safety and Health Administration is part of the Labor Department. The National Institute of Occupational Safety and Health is part of the Department of Health and Human Services. Alan McMillan, deputy assistant labor secretary in charge of OSHA, said the report overall raised important issues, but he said he had not read the report thoroughly yet and could not comment further in detail. However, McMillan said OSHA and the National Institute of Occupational Safety and Health face different legal requirements in setting exposure standards. The institute is responsible for recommending safe exposure levels based solely on the worker's health. OSHA, however, must also consider technical feasibility and economic impact. ``For that reason, in most cases you'll likely see a difference in an OSHA standard and a NIOSH recommendation,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: New Reserve Callups Announced By Pentagon
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Five new reserve units that will boost transport and public affairs activities in Operation Desert Shield have been called to active duty, according to the Pentagon. That brings to about 8,870 the number of reservists called in the first wave of notifications, Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams said Thursday. The Secretary of the Air Force has called three units: _68th Military Airlift Squadron, Kelly AFB, Texas, with 228 personnel involved in support of C-5A transport planes. _301st Military Airlift Squadron, Travis AFB, Calif., with 249 personnel involved in support of C-5A and C5B transports. _326th Military Airlift Squadron, Dover AFB, Del., with 244 personnel involved in support of C-5A transports. The Secretary of the Army has ordered to active duty the following units: _382nd Public Affairs detachment of the National Guard from Raleigh, N.C. _314th Public Affairs Detachment of the Army Reserve from Birmingham, Ala. No personnel figures were given. The Pentagon announced last week that about 46,700 reserves would be called to duty by Oct. 1 and that most of the part-time soldiers would be posted in or near Saudi Arabia. At that time, Williams had projected that about 9,800 reserves would be called to leave their civilian jobs by the end of August. Williams said fewer than expected have been called as the services have looked more carefully at the need for the reserves. He gave the following breakdown for the call up by service: Army: 4,292; Navy 2,584; Air Force 1,723; Coast Guard 271. No Marine reserves have been called, as expected, Williams added. Meanwhile, Sen. Lloyd Bentsen, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, wrote Defense Secretary Dick Cheney on Thursday, asking that the Pentagon take additional steps to protect the credit ratings of servicemen and women sent to the Middle East. The Texas Democrat said the 50-year-old Soldiers' and Sailors' Civil Relief Act merely protects newly activated personnel from foreclosures or repossessions of property in cases where their military activity caused late payments or interruptions in payments. But Bentsen said that law makes no provision for protecting the credit ratings of service personnel whose financial standing could be adversely affected by overseas military duty. ``I believe you have authority under existing law to help military personnel who may face this situation,'' the senator told Cheney. Bentsen suggested that men and women activated for service duty be give an opportunity to authorize the Defense Department to notify credit bureaus that ``the person's military service may affect his or her ability to meet previously incurred financial obligations.''

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Close up in Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 25,978.37, up 308.41 points or 1.2 percent, on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Friday.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Infant Mortality Rate Down; Still High Among Industrialized Nations
DOC.TEXT: Infant mortality in the United States inched downward last year to the lowest level ever recorded, but the U.S. rate is still higher than many industrialized nations, officials said. ``Although we've made progress in reducing this nation's infant mortality, we must do better,'' Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan said Thursday. The provisional data released by the National Center for Health Statistics would rank the United States below 21 industrialized countries on a list comparing 1986 rates, center spokeswoman Sandra Smith said. The ranking is probably still accurate, she said. ``We make progress, but so do other countries,'' she said. The new data shows that U.S. infant deaths for 1989 were 9.7 per 1,000 live births, down from 9.9 per 1,000. The 1989 data for infant mortality was not broken down for blacks and whites, but final data from 1987 shows that while white infant deaths amounted to 8.6 per 1,000, the rate for blacks was 17.9. Sullivan said the United States ``must continue to direct prevention, education and health care opportunities to our minority and poor citizens where infant mortality strikes hardest.''
DOC.HEAD: Salvadoran Family Ordered Deported to Third Country
DOC.TEXT: Immigration authorities have been ordered by an administrative judge to deport members of a Salvadoran family to a third country rather than their strife-torn nation. A refugee advocacy lawyer hailed the ruling as an important step toward changing the government's policy of forcing aliens to return to homelands beset by civil war if they can't prove they are likely to be harmed. ``What this decision stands for is an articulated justification under international law for a generic approach for providing protection to those who otherwise would be returned to a civil war,'' Arthur C. Helton, director of the refugee project for The Lawyers Committee for Human Rights, said Thursday about the Aug. 24 decision. Helton estimated there are as many as 500,000 Salvadorans living in the United States. The INS last year granted 337 applications for asylum status while denying 13,861. ``It's a promising decision and if upheld on appeal would have a substantial impact on U.S. practice,'' Helton said. But he conceded that the decision is based on international law rather than federal immigration law. Helton noted that an attempt by an immigration judge several years ago to invoke an international treaty to stop the deportation of Salvadorans was overturned on appeal. INS authorities are confident that the decision by Immigration Judge Paul A. Nejelski would be overturned by the Board of Immigration Appeals, said an official, who spoke on condition of anonymity.
DOC.HEAD: Congressional Agency Questions Benefits of Capital Gains Tax Cut
DOC.TEXT: A capital gains tax reduction ``could not be counted on'' to significantly boost American economic growth, the Congressional Budget Office said Thursday. ``It is unlikely that the increase in income would generate enough additional tax revenue'' to offset losses to the Treasury, said the report requested by the congressional tax- and budget-writing committees. During his campaign for the presidency in 1988, President Bush called cutting the tax rate on capital gains one of his top priorities. But the Democratic-controlled Congress has refused to enact the proposal. The administration has pressed for a reduction in the capital gains tax rate during this year's budget negotiations with lawmakers. Rep. Dan Rostenkowski, D-Ill., chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, called the study ``an objective assessment'' of previous reports on the capital gains tax cut Bush proposed in his fiscal 1991 budget. Rostenkowski has been a foe of reducing the capital gains tax rate.

DOC.HEAD: Aboard The Independence: ATMs, a Wait For Mail, And Beer Day
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The crew of hundreds aboard the aircraft carrier USS Independence listens intently when the day's weather forecast comes over the loudspeaker. It's not the forecast they're waiting for _ it's hazy, hot and humid in the waters of the Middle East just about every day. But when that formality is out of the way, the announcer offers the day's mail update _ on Thursday the mail weighed 1,300 pounds. ``The mail, that's what everybody waits for,'' said Dan Hamilton, an officer in the carrier's combat room. ``Everybody needs a note from home.'' For one lucky soldier, a note from California also included a newspaper, a 10-pack of chewing gum and other goodies.

The Independence has brought 24-hour banking to the waters of the Middle East. Many sailors aboard the carrier never see a paycheck _ their money is automatically deposited in their accounts and available through shipboard machines. There are six cash machines aboard the Independence, an 88,000-ton carrier.

The ground troops deployed in Saudi Arabia might have a long wait for their next beer _ alcohol is illegal in Saudi Arabia. But on the Independence, Sept. 5 is Beer Day, and the crew is already looking forward to it. The ship had been headed for port when it was abruptly ordered to steam to the Gulf of Oman to help enforce economic sanctions against Iraq after that country's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. A supply ship headed toward the carrier is bringing enough beer for each crew member to have two. Pizza is also on the day's menu.

DOC.HEAD: Sense of Gloom Spreads in Philipines
DOC.TEXT: Political storm clouds are gathering over the Philippines, creating the perception that President Corazon Aquino's government faces a grave and perhaps final crisis. Such fears have long plagued the Aquino government, which came to power in the heady days of the 1986 ``people power revolution'' that deposed the late President Ferdinand Marcos. But in the past three weeks, public confidence has plummeted. Rumors of a new coup attempt are rampant. Commentators believe the nation is facing a political showdown that may spell the end of Philippine democracy. ``Four years after its restoration, constitutional democracy in the Philippines is heading toward collapse ahead of the end of President Aquino's term in 1992,'' wrote Amando Doronila, editor of the pro-government newspaper, The Manila Chronicle. ``The truth is that Philippine democracy today is in imminent and mortal danger of being overthrown.'' During four tumultuous years, Mrs. Aquino's government has weathered numerous crises, including Communist and Moslem insurgencies and six coup attempts, most recently last December. The Iraqi invasion of Kuwait _ expected to increase oil prices _ a series of natural disasters, and a spate of bombings have brought the nation to the brink of yet another crisis. ``I've never seen anything like this,'' said one Western diplomat, who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``The public mood is just awful. It seems like the government is tottering, just waiting for a push.'' Following a meeting of newspaper executives, most major Manila dailies published front-page appeals today to defend democracy against a new coup attempt. But the daily Malaya said the only way out of the crisis was for Mrs. Aquino to resign and call new elections. Philippine presidents served four-year terms under the constitution in effect when she took office. But the constitution drafted under the Aquino government granted presidents a single six-year term. ``Given her demonstrable inability to govern ... the country needs new leadership,'' Malaya said. In its editorial, The Manila Standard said that while it opposes military rule, ``the administration must recognize that the idea has gained some currency because the many crises that confront us seem to call for extreme solutions.'' Natural disasters include the July 16 earthquake _ which killed more than 1,600 people _ typhoons and a devastating flood that dumped nearly three feet of rain on the capital Aug. 24. The government's clumsy response to the tragedies highlighted the administration's failures in the business of governing. Earthquake recovery operations were hampered by poor communications and a lack of planning. The torrential rains flooded large areas of Manila because tons of uncollected garbage had clogged the drainage systems. The Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait threatens the jobs of more than 500,000 Filipino workers in the Persian Gulf region who pump $1.3 billion into the national economy each year. It also promises to raise fuel prices in a country that relied heavily on Iraq and Kuwait for oil. In the Philippines oil prices are regulated by the government and although they have not yet been raised, increases are expected. The spate of bombings in Manila _ 17 since Aug. 13 _ has prompted fears that military dissidents are poised for a new coup attempt. One foreign businessman said on condition of anonymity that many people ``are no longer talking about whether there will be a coup but when.'' Faced with the crisis, Mrs. Aquino reversed a long-standing policy and said Wednesday she was willing to negotiate a cease-fires with Communist and military rebels. The Cabinet meets Saturday to discuss prospects for a truce. But there has been no clear statement from either military dissidents or the Communist Party on whether they would go along with a cease-fire. Furthermore, political sources say Defense Secretary Fidel Ramos strongly opposes a truce, saying it would undercut morale in the armed forces. This apparent split has fueled rumors the armed forces may be planning a ``constitutional coup,'' establishing some sort of military-run emergency commission that would run the country, with Mrs. Aquino as a figurehead. Ramos, who crushed the six coup attempts, has strongly denied the rumors and said Thursday they were spread by dissidents to foment division in the government. On Thursday, Mrs. Aquino's national security adviser, retired Lt. Gen. Rafael Ileto, said he opposed military rule. But he said martial law was a viable option ``if the very life of the state is at stake.'' ``Each day we become witnesses to the groping for and clutching at solutions by our leaders,'' wrote left-wing historian Renato Constantino in the Daily Globe. ``We desperately need a new kind of politics to restore the morality of power and to revive our national purpose.''

DOC.HEAD: Adultery Law Surfaces in Connecticut
DOC.TEXT: Connecticut has rediscovered a relic from its Puritan past: Police this summer have charged four people with adultery. In a state known for progressive laws on abortion rights, education and the environment, use of the rarely enforced state adultery law is raising eyebrows. ``It's a dinosaur,'' said New Haven attorney Hugh Keefe. ``What a spouse needs if she has a cheating husband is a divorce lawyer, not a cop.'' Under the law, a married person commits adultery by having sexual intercourse with someone other than his or her spouse. Single people cannot be charged. Conviction on the misdemeanor charge carries up to a year in prison and a $1,000 fine. Connecticut authorities say they have no choice but to enforce the law. Before this year, just two people were charged with adultery since 1985. The latest cluster of arrests ``is basically just a coincidence,'' said Chief State's Attorney John J. Kelly. ``People have to realize that we do have a law on the books.'' Adultery as a criminal offense in America dates from the arrival of the Puritans in Massachusetts in the 17th century. Twenty-seven states still have adultery laws on the books, a survey by the Harvard Law Review found, but legal scholars say few states make much effort to enforce them. For example, in New York, where adultery is a misdemeanor, the last recorded prosecution was in 1944. ``These laws never get repealed,'' said Ronald J. Allen, a professor at Northwestern University School of Law in Chicago. ``What politician is going to come out in favor of adultery?'' The first Connecticut arrest this year occurred in Norwich on June 1, when a man locked in a divorce battle claimed he witnessed his wife through a window of a house having sex with another man, police said. On Tuesday, police in East Lyme arrested a man and a woman, both married but not to each other, after receiving a complaint from the man's wife. Police in New London made another arrest Tuesday when they broke up a domestic squabble over a woman's alleged infidelity, and arrested the woman after she admitted having an affair. For years, divorce lawyers have used the law to keep their clients' sexual affairs secret. They can do that by having their clients invoke their Fifth Amendment rights against self-incrimination. But lawyers say criminal application of the law is a different matter altogether. ``What are we going to do with these people,'' asked Patty Jenkins Pittman, a New Haven lawyer. ``Put them on probation? What would the probation be? Celibacy?'' Lou Buonfiglio, a private detective in New Haven, agreed. ``I hope they don't have any witch-burning statutes left on the books,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: NASA Cancels Shuttle Launch
DOC.TEXT: A broken electronic part caused NASA to scrub Saturday's scheduled launch of space shuttle Columbia, extending the bad luck that has dogged the space agency all year. NASA officials waited until late Thursday night before halting the countdown for a scientific mission that was to last nine or 10 days. Another attempt won't be made before Wednesday. The culprit was in an electronic box that routes electrical power and telemetry between the spacecraft and an X-ray telescope mounted at the rear of its cargo bay. The launch control center had been unable to issue commands to the telescope since the shuttle's cargo bay doors were closed Wednesday evening. Engineers suspected a cable might have been pinched and they sent technicians into the shuttle crew compartment to look at the electronic box with high-powered binoculars. They saw nothing amiss. Another problem cropped up during the countdown that might also have been _ _ in a favorite NASA phrase _ a show-stopper. A mid-deck instrument that measures acceleration and vibration also was faulty. Now, replacement is likely. The space agency is under pressure to get the Astro mission under way by mid-September because of the approaching launch of the shuttle Discovery with a space probe that is to go into orbit around the sun. For its long journey, the Ulysses probe needs a gravity boost gained by whipping around the planet Jupiter. Earth and Jupiter will be in proper alignment for that task between Oct. 5 and Oct. 23 and not again for 13 months. On Columbia, officials aren't sure which of two components in the Broad-Band X-Ray Telescope control box is at fault and the date of the next launch attempt depends on what they find when they enter the cargo bay this weekend, NASA spokeswoman Lisa Malone said. ``We're looking at maybe routing a cable outside the electronic box which will give us a midweek launch,'' she said. ``If that doesn't solve the problem, then we'll go inside the box to replace a component. That would give us a weekend launch.'' The postponement further damages NASA's frayed shuttle schedule _ and its reputation. The agency has suffered from the embarrassments of launching the fuzzy-eyed Hubble telescope, in-and-out communications with the Magellan spacecraft orbiting Venus, damaging reports about its proposed space station, and two leaky shuttles. Columbia had been scheduled to be launched on the Astro mission on May 30, but that attempt was scratched when the hydrogen leak was discovered during fueling. Later, the shuttle Atlantis also was found to leak and the fleet was grounded. The space agency had hoped to launch nine shuttle flights this year. To date there have been only three. When it finally lifts off, Columbia will have a crew of seven, the largest since the Challenger accident on Jan. 28, 1986. Four of the crewmen are astronomers who have trained for the event since the early 1980s. They were to have flown with the observatory in March 1986, in time to study the comet Halley, then returning from a 76-year round trip through the universe. But the Challenger explosion, on Jan. 28, 1986, stopped all manned-space activity for 32 months and the mission was put in line behind higher-priority flights. Once in space, the four telescopes on the $150 million observatory will view some of the hottest objects in the universe, chronicling the life cycles of stars by measuring their radiation. Scientists promise that the observatory will make measurements never before possible with ground-based telescopes. ``We really want a success,'' said Ed Weiler, who is the NASA scientist in charge of the Astro project as well as that of the Hubble Telescope. ``We really want the public to know we can do space astronomy and we can do it right, and it's something worth doing,'' he said. ``The Hubble problems really give scientists more motivation to be successful on this mission.''

DOC.HEAD: Author of Provocative Soviet Article Discloses His Identity
DOC.TEXT: ``Z,'' the author of a provocative article arguing that Mikhail Gorbachev's reforms are doomed, is Martin Malia, a Russian historian at the University of California at Berkeley. Malia unmasked himself in an opinion page article in today's New York Times. His controversial article appeared in the winter issue of Daedalus, published by the American Academy of Arts and Sciences; excerpts appeared in the Times in January. The article argued that Gorbachev was pursuing only halfway measures that would not reform the Soviet Union, which labors under the twin burdens of centuries of Russian authoritarianism and 70 years of communist totalitarianism. The article was viewed as flying in the face of the support that the United States was giving to Gorbachev's policies. Malia, a specialist on 19th century Russian intellectual history, said he signed the article ``N. Perestroikin,'' an obscure allusion to Vladimir Lenin's pseudonym. But the ``N'' signature was changed to ``Z'' in the editing process. Malia wrote that he had decided to remain anonymous so he wouldn't compromise his friends in the Soviet Union and because ``the fall of the Berlin Wall and central European communism had not yet demonstrated that Leninist regimes are mortal.'' Malia said the pseudonym was no longer necessary because communism has been defeated in the Soviet Union. ``It is manifest that the Soviet Union, modestly aligning itself with the U.S. and the United Nations, is no longer a superpower,'' he wrote in The Times. ``Less obviously, this is so because `the Soviet Union no longer exists,' as one now hears in Moscow, either as a coherent polity or economy. And this stunning fact will weigh on world affairs for years after the Persian Gulf crisis.'' He cited the March elections that brought to power Soviet reformers such as Boris Yeltsin who advocate a transition from totalitarianism to a civil society by dismantling most of the system as structured by the communists. They also call for a pluralistic democracy, reinstatement of private property and even independence for Soviet republics. ``In short, in the past six months the Soviet Union has gone the way of Central Europe during six weeks last year,'' Malia wrote. ``It has been a slow-motion implosion, just as portentous as the collapse as the Berlin Wall.'' Speculation about the identity of ``Z'' had been rampant in academic and government circles. Some had focused on Malia. Others suspected were Zbigniew Brzezinski, former national security adviser under President Carter; former Secretary of State Henry Kissinger; and retired Lt. Gen. William Odom, former head of the National Security Agency.

DOC.HEAD: Energy Secretary Says He'll Launch Conservation Ad Campaign
DOC.TEXT: Americans will be urged to drive more fuel-efficient cars and obey speed limits when the federal government starts its first energy-conservation advertising campaign in more than a decade. If all Americans took those and other steps, the country could save 200,000 barrels of oil a day, Energy Secretary James D. Watkins told The New York Times in an interview published today. The new conservation campaign is set to start in mid-September, Watkins said. He said it is a response to the Persian Gulf crisis. At the same time, the government will boost domestic oil production, Watkins told the Times. Before the United Nations embargo went into effect, the United States imported about 700,000 barrels of oil a day from Iraq and Kuwait. One-third of that deficit will be resolved by December by increasing production from Prudhoe Bay in Alaska, Watkins said. The Energy Department also is seeking another 30,000 barrels a day from Texas and 50,000 barrels more from companies that have developed oil reserves off the coast of Santa Barbara, Calif. Watkins said the Bush administration would try to mediate a dispute between California, Santa Barbara County and oil companies over how crude petroleum is to be transported to shore. As well as being an environmentally delicate area, the coastline is an important tourist attraction. The department also will encourage the use of gasoline that includes alcohol or methanol, which could save 10,000 barrels of oil a day if millions more drivers used the fuel.

DOC.HEAD: Billy Graham Official Accused Of Improperly Influencing Donor
DOC.TEXT: An official of the Rev. Billy Graham's organization, which has escaped the scandals that have dogged other ministries, has been accused of improperly influencing an elderly donor, a published report said today. The allegation was made by a Canadian woman's heirs, who sought a larger share of the $3 million estate of their great aunt, The Washington Post reported. The newspaper said the claim had been settled before going to trial. The Billy Graham Evangelistic Association had stood to gain more than one-third of Jessie Geneva Latta's estate through a foundation named for Latta and established by Carl W. Green. The 63-year-old Green left his post as a senior Canadian fundraiser for the Graham organization last year, the Post said. Latta's will was contested by four of her six heirs _ three great-nieces and a great nephew _ who said in a claim settled in Brockville, Ontario Monday that Green began to gain Latta's confidence more than 10 years ago, after her husband died and while she was in her 80s. Brockville is across the St. Lawrence River from New York. The heirs accused Green of improperly influencing Latta to rewrite wills in which she had left more money to the heirs than was specified in the contested will. The newspaper said a Graham association spokesman denied the allegations and Green could not be reached for comment. ``I'm very pleased,'' said Dianne Hickling, one of the contesting heirs. ``We accomplished what we set out to do.'' The case was settled after the heirs produced reports from Green to his superiors in which he detailed repeated visits with Latta. In the reports, included in the settlement, Green noted Latta's increasing dependence on him, and his certainty that she would funnel a significant amount of money to the Graham organization. Under the settlement, half of Latta's estate was awarded to the heirs and half to the foundation with the stipulation that Hickling replace Green as a director. The Graham organization received no money in the settlement and the heirs were allowed to seek retrieval of about $750,000 in gifts from Latta to the Graham association before she died in 1988 at age 93. A $100,000 bequest to the association remains in dispute.

DOC.HEAD: CDC Reports Isolating Contaminant in Controversial Diet Supplement
DOC.TEXT: Researchers have identified a chemical compound contaminating some batches of the food supplement L-tryptophan, which has killed 27 and sickened hundreds. The compound was discovered during chromatography tests of contaminated L-tryuptophan, the national Centers for Disease Control said Thursday. CDC researchers said they still don't know exactly how the contaminant got in the product. They also have yet to determine whether the chemical compound is itself the cause of the illness or just a ``marker'' of another substance. Another advance in tracing the cause of the rare blood disorder called eosinophilia-myalgia syndrome, or EMS, was reported at the National Institute of Mental Health in Bethesda, Md. A model of the disorder was reproduced there in rats. Nationwide, CDC has received reports of 1,536 cases of EMS, which has been linked to consumption of L-tryptophan, an amino acid. But the CDC said the number of cases may be higher as many EMS cases don't meet the official case definition, but still appear to be related to L-tryptophan. ``Maybe our figures might be missing half the cases. I'd say 3,000 to 5,000 is a reasonably good estimate,'' said Dr. Edwin Kilbourne, chief of health studies at the CDC's Center for Environmental Health. Twenty-seven patients have died from EMS, whose symtoms include pains, fever, rash and shortness of breath. The Food and Drug Administration ordered all L-tryptophan products off the market this spring. The products were sold through health food stores as a remedy for conditions including weight problems, sleeplessness and depression. The chemical compound is known as a di-tryptophan aminal of acetaldehyde. It was identified ``in trace amounts'' in chromatography tests of 50 lots of L-tryptophan produced by the implicated manufacturer, said Dr. Larry Needham, toxicology chief for the CDC's Center for Environmental Health. Reports have identified the manufacturer as Japan's Showa Denko K.K. ``It's an impurity,'' Needham said. ``It's not supposed to be in the product.'' Lab investigations have found no signs of bacteria or viruses contaminating the product. But data ``indicate that implicated L-tryptophan-containing products were contaminated'' with the chemical compound, the CDC said after nearly a year of investigation. A New England Journal of Medicine report earlier this month concluded Showa Denko, whose product has been linked to most cases, made two changes in manufacturing which could have caused the problem: introduction of a new strain of genetically altered bacteria, and alteration of its filtering process.

DOC.HEAD: Korean Premiers to Meet For Two Days
DOC.TEXT: Archrivals North and South Korea have set the details for historic talks between their prime ministers, opening the way for negotiations on easing four decades of hostilities, officials said today. North Korean Prime Minister Yon Hyong Muk and about 90 others are scheduled to cross the heavily fortified border on Tuesday for two days of talks with South Korean officials, the Information Ministry said. It will be the highest-level contact between the Communist North and capitalist south since the Korean peninsula was divided in 1945. And security was expected to be tight for the talks, to be held on Wednesday and Thursday. About 3,000 police will ring the hotel where South Korean Prime Minister Kang Young-hoon and his North Korean counterpart will meet, the ministry said. Thousands more police will be posted around government buildings and along routes where the delegations are expected to travel, police said. It was agreed that a second round of talks will be held in the North Korean capital of Pyongyang Oct. 16-19, the ministry said. Travel plans and other details were finalized late Thursday between officials of the two Koreas meeting in Panmunjom, a border village inside the Demilitarized Zone that separates the two nations. The North Korean delegation, consisting of eight delegates, 33 assistants and 50 reporters, will walk over the border into the South at Panmunjom and will be driven the 35 miles to the South Korean capital. The Communist delegation is scheduled to leave South Korea on Sept. 7. Although South Korean officials attach great significance to the talks, observers doubt substantial progress will be made in the talks because the premiers of both nations are mostly figureheads without policy-making roles. North Korea has said the talks should cover mainly ways to ease political and military tensions. South Korean officials insist priority be given to non-political exchanges to promote mutual confidence. North Korea has proposed drastic arms reductions, cutting the troop level to 100,000 each. North Korea has more than 1 million troops, while South Korea has 650,000. The North Koreans also demand withdrawal of the 43,000 U.S. troops stationed in South Korea under a mutual defense treaty. But South Korea opposes any drastic measures such as arms cuts before an extended period of confidence-building. In an unprecedented move, South Korea proposed an unrestricted five-day border opening in mid-August for the 62 million residents of the two Koreas but North Korea failed to meet Seoul officials to discuss the matter. The Korean peninsula was divided into the Communist north and capitalist south in 1945. The nations fought a three-year war in the early 1950s. Their border is sealed and direct communication between their peoples is forbidden.

DOC.HEAD: U.S., Other Nations Agree Humans Cause Global Warming
DOC.TEXT: The United States for the first time has joined with other nations in declaring that human activity is causing global warming, in a U.N.-sponsored conference that ended early today. After four days of meetings to consider the most extensive scientific investigation of the Earth's climate, the 74 delegations unanimously adopted a report that will be a basis for negotiations on future climate treaties. The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Changes spent two years preparing the document, under the auspices of the U.N. Environment Program and the World Meteorological Organization. Scientists and environmentalists described the consensus as a breakthrough because the United States for the first time acknowledged human activity is producing gases that are changing the climate and warming the globe. But agreement on the future impact of global warming and recommendations on possible action to prevent it were not achieved at the conference. ``As far as effective action and impacts, the report is weak,'' said Jeremy Legget, science director for Greenpeace International. ``But the significant achievement is that finally the United States has acknowledged the global warming is actually happening.'' Fred Bernthal, head of the National Science Foundation and the American delegation, said late Thursday that U.S. acceptance of global warming theories in the document marked a step forward in climate policy. ``We are certain of the following: ... Emissions resulting from human activities are substantially increasing the atmospheric concentrations of the greenhouse gases,'' Bernthal said. ``All things being equal, it (the greenhouse effect) might lead to global warming,'' he said. Bernthal said there is still uncertainty about the magnitude of the problem, and questions about when and where the effects would be felt. The United States, the largest producer of carbon dioxide, has blocked any international agreement to place mandatory restrictions on emission of the gases that lead to the so-called greenhouse effect. Carbon dioxide, produced from the burning of fossil fuels such as oil and coal, helps trap warm air around the Earth, scientists say. The meeting was marked by extensive argument behind closed doors between the Americans, who insisted more research is needed, and European nations committed to an international agreement on restricting carbon dioxide emissions. The scientific conclusions will form the basis for discussions at the November climate convention in Geneva. The scientists said they hoped an agreement on action will be ready for signing at the June 1992 U.N. Conference on Environment and Development in Brazil.

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper: Officials Listing Alleged Saddam Hussein War Crimes
DOC.TEXT: U.S. officials are compiling a list of alleged violations of international law to use against Iraqi President Saddam Hussein in a Nuremberg-style war crimes trial, a newspaper reported today. The Bush administration could cite the alleged violations to justify any military action against Iraq, according to administration sources quoted by the Los Angeles Times. The administration also might make the capture of Saddam and his key advisers for trial one of the objectives of the U.S. buildup in the Persian Gulf, officials told the Times. ``Some (legal) action has to be taken, both because we have a right to bring him to justice and to deter him from further violations,'' said an administration official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. In the short term, administration officials said the preparation of charges was intended to deter Saddam from taking further action against thousands of civilian hostages in Iraq and Kuwait. The report did not state whether plans were being made for Saddam's capture or in what venue the administration would want to try the Iraqi leader. Among the alleged violations cited by officials is that Saddam has waged a war of aggression by invading Kuwait on Aug. 2. That charge formed the basis of the war crimes trials of Nazi leaders in Nuremberg after World War II. Other possible allegations include using chemical weapons, taking hostages, kidnapping diplomats, violating embassies and holding captives at military installations, officials said. Those actions constitute violations of the 1949 Geneva Convention and the 1973 New York Convention protecting embassies, diplomats and their families, the officials said. ``Saddam has really put himself in a situation of dire jeopardy by using civilians,'' said Abraham D. Sofaer, a former State Department legal adviser. ``It's a clear violation of the laws of war. To intentionally expose civilians for military purposes is a clear violation of the Geneva Convention.''
