DOC.HEAD: She Gets to the Reserve Command On Time
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The green battle clothing Spec. 4 Carlotta Coleman donned to exchange her vows wasn't exactly what she planned to wear on her wedding day _ until she got a call to report to active duty. More than 150 members of the 461st Adjutant General Company stood in formation Thursday outside the 81st Army Reserve Command to witness the wedding of the reservist and civilian Charles Andrews, said Annie Simmons, a command spokeswoman. After the ceremony, conducted by a reserve chaplain, Coleman and other members of the personnel service unit in East Point left in a convoy for Fort Stewart, near Savannah. ``The fact that I have to leave alone is unsettling,'' said the new Mrs. Andrews, a personnel specialist who will spend 90 days at Fort Stewart processing soldiers headed to the Middle East. ``At least this way I've done what I wanted to do,'' she said. The groom, 43, is an Army retiree who served in Vietnam. ``It's kind of distressing to get married, then watch your wife get on the bus and leave,'' Andrews said. ``We'll make the most of it. The main thing is that we get it done.'' After the marriage vows and a prayer, Andrews saluted his new wife once, then two more times while fellow reservists voiced their approval. Members of the 461st were the first full unit of military reservists expected at Fort Stewart to begin taking over the post's day-to-day operations after its regular troops went to Saudi Arabia.

DOC.HEAD: President Borja Threatens to Shut Down Radio Station Over Report Or Resign
DOC.TEXT: President Rodrigo Borja has threatened to shut down a radio station if it can't prove its report that his brother was involved in an illegal weapons deal. If there is evidence, Borja says he'll resign. ``I give Radio Sucre and its staff five days to come up with proof,'' Borja said Thursday on nationwide television and radio. ``If they do, I will present my resignation to the Ecuadorian people. But if they do not, I will exercise my powers as president and will order the immediate cancellation of Radio Sucre's broadcasting license,'' he said. Radio Sucre, a frequent critic of the Borja government owned by a right-wing opponent, accused one of Borja's brothers of taking part in a $52,000 arms deal with the armed forces. The radio station did not specify which of Borja's four brothers was involved, and details of the alleged arms deal were not immediately clear. Borja, a leftist who has served two years of his four-year term, said he had to defend the dignity of both the presidency and the armed forces. ``I have maintained total respect for the freedom of expression of all Ecuadorians,'' Borja said. ``But everything has a limit.'' Radio Sucre's accusation, he said, ``transgresses the limits of democratic tolerance.'' Radio Sucre of Guayaquil, 170 miles southwest of Quito, is owned by Vicente Arroba, congressman for the rightist Social Christian Party. The party, led by ex-president Leon Febres Cordero, is Borja's main opposition in Congress. The station has frequently accused Borja's ministers of corruption. The accusation came one day before the Supreme Court on Wednesday found Febres Cordero and his son-in-law, Miguel Orellana, innocent of embezzlement charges. Febres Cordero was president from 1984 to 1988. In 1987, Orellana, who was also Febres Cordero's private secretary, received $150,000 in cash from Ecuador's Central Bank. He later said the money was payment to Israeli anti-terrorism expert Ram Gazit for advice in fighting a small leftist guerrilla movement then active in Ecuador. Orellana said he could not present proof of how the funds were used because Gazit was unable to appear in his defense for security reasons. Febres Cordero accused ``political enemies,'' among them Borja, of being behind the charges. He said his rivals wanted to discredit him with a smear campaign.

DOC.HEAD: Cruzan Family Faces Renewed Right-to-Die Court Battle
DOC.TEXT: Nancy Cruzan's parents again are seeking satisfaction from the legal system that has blocked their three-year battle to let the comatose woman die. Joe and Joyce Cruzan say they have new evidence that their 33-year-old daughter wouldn't want to continue living in her condition. Nancy Cruzan has been in a persistent vegetative state since a January 1983 car crash, and is kept alive at a state hospital by a surgically implanted feeding tube. Three witnesses have come forth ``who had specific discussions with Nancy Cruzan regarding her wishes about life-sustaining medical treatment,'' attorney Bill Colby, who represents the parents and their daughter, said in a petition filed Thursday with Charles Teel, a Jasper County probate judge. No date for a hearing was immediately set, Colby said. In July, in its first ruling in a ``right-to-die'' case, the U.S. Supreme Court barred the removal of the life-sustaining tube. It said a state's interest in preserving life may overcome the wishes of family members seeking to end the life of a patient in an irreversible, coma-like condition. ``I feel this is a wrong that has to be righted,'' Joe Cruzan said in an interview from his home in Carterville in southwest Missouri. ``We don't feel this is right for every family, but we feel we're doing what Nancy would want.'' ``I don't know where it's going to end,'' he said. ``I hope we're successful. I gave up being enthusiastic a long time ago, when I learned the legal system doesn't work very fast.'' In Thursday's petition, Colby said the Supreme Court ruled ``the discovery of new evidence regarding the patient's intent'' could allow for modification or reversal of the ban on removing her feeding tube. The petition said the court ruled that Missouri can require ``clear and convincing'' evidence as a legal standard of proof of Ms. Cruzan's wishes before medical treatment is terminated. Colby declined in an interview to disclose the identities of the three people, other than to say two were people Ms. Cruzan had worked for and the third was a co-worker. The conversations took place about three years before the car crash, he said. Missouri Attorney General William Webster, who handled the state's challenges to the Cruzan family, had no immediate comment on the filing, said his spokeswoman, Mary Jenkins. Cruzan said of his legal battles: ``I feel frustrated, and some degree of anger, but primarily frustration at the system.'' The 55-year-old sheetmetal worker said he considered taking his daughter to a state that might allow termination of artificial feeding, but rejected the idea because ``I thought it was wrong.'' The Cruzans visit their daughter weekly at the Missouri Rehabilitation Center in Mount Vernon. Ms. Cruzan's body is rigid with her hands and feet bent into claw shapes. She can breathe on her own, and at times her eyes are open and move randomly.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar, Stocks Higher in Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rose against the Japanese yen and stocks closed higher today, despite the previous day's increase in Japan's official discount rate. The dollar finished the week at 144.50 yen, up 0.40 yen from Thursday's finish. The U.S. currency opened at 144.45 yen and ranged between 144.13 yen and 144.55 yen. The dollar gained despite Thursday's discount rate hike because the increase was smaller than expected, said Yoshitsugu Hanada, a dealer with Mitsui Taiyo Kobe Bank. On Thursday, the Bank of Japan raised its official discount rate, its lending rate to commercial banks, to 6 percent from the previous 5.25 percent, effective immediately. Local media and financial markets had expected the bank would raise the rate by as much as 1 percentage point. Higher interest rates generally make a nation's currency more attractive to investors and discourage stock purchasers. ``Investors have sold the dollar for a while because of the lack of developments in the Middle East crisis, but I think the dollar's downtrend has reversed,'' Hanada said. The U.S. currency is frequently seen as a safe haven in times of crisis, and earlier worry about the Gulf situation had sent it higher, despite basic concerns about the U.S. economy, traders said. Market players were buying the U.S. currency to make up for their recent oversold positions, Hanada said. Trading was inactive, with about $7 billion trading hands in spot dealings. Investors were reluctant to make major moves ahead of a three-day weekend in New York, dealers said. U.S. financial markets will be closed Monday for Labor Day. On the stock exchange, the 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average gained 308.41 points, or 1.2 percent, ending the day at 25,978.37. The index rose 775.17 points on Thursday following the announcement of the discount rate increase. Trading was moderate, with 600 million shares traded on the first section. Stock prices started lower today, with many investors discouraged by an overnight decline in the Dow Jones Industrial Average and the yen's downturn against the dollar, traders said. They said the index started recovering as institutional investors made arbitrage purchases in the spot market to take profits from the price gap between spot and futures values. Kozo Hasunuma, a trader with Yamaichi Securities Co., said bargain hunting also helped the index today. ``But selling by some investors to reduce holdings before the weekend prevented the index from rising further,'' he said. Satoru Nagayoshi, a trader with New Japan Securities Co., said stability in the bond market reassured investors and helped support the stock market. In bond dealings, the yield of benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds closed at 8.105 percent, down from Thursday's 8.120 percent. Their price rose to 83.07 from 83.00.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``This emotional roller coaster is inhumane and disgraceful.'' _ State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler on Iraq's delays after promising to free foreign women and children hostages.

``A lot of the guys are feeling the John Wayne macho man kind of thing.'' _ Todd Silberman, a junior at the University of Florida, where young men are beefing up escorts of women students at night after a serial killer stabbed five people to death.

``It's so far away from what's out there this summer. The audience said, `No more four-letter words. I don't want to see anybody blown up.' It's about time people can be in love with one another and not feel embarrassed.'' _ Producer Howard W. Koch on his film ``Ghost,'' expected to surpass ``Total Recall'' as the summer's top box office hit.

DOC.HEAD: Radar System That Might Have Warned of Twisters Wasn't Working
DOC.TEXT: A tornado-warning radar system had been disabled by lightning hours before killer twisters struck several towns in northern Illinois, a National Weather Service forecaster said today. But the forecaster said he didn't believe the system could have forecast the tornadoes that killed 27 people and injured more than 300 Tuesday across a region known as ``Tornado Alley,'' about 35 miles southwest of Chicago. The weather service's Chicago office issued a severe thunderstorm warning for the area, but did not alert residents to the tornadoes until six minutes after they had touched down in the communities of Plainfield and Crest Hill. The office is equipped with an early version of Doppler radar, which might have provided five to 10 minutes advance warning of the twisters, said forecaster Carl Williams. ``But there's just no way that you can say that it could have done that,'' Williams said in a telephone interview. ``It's a primitive system and I don't think it's being out had any effect at all.'' Williams said the Doppler radar has not been in wide use in most weather service offices, but an ``add-on'' Doppler was installed in 1974 on radar equipment dating back to 1957. But the Doppler radar in Chicago was knocked out by lightning hours before Tuesday's storms. The Doppler system can detect both those winds that are approaching and moving away. When winds are detected moving in both directions at the same time and at high speeds, meteorologists can quickly determine that they are dealing with a tornado. A newer system called NEXRAD is being tested at the weather service's National Severe Storms Laboratory, officials said. But that system may not be installed until 1995, Williams said. The New York Times reported today that the weather service has dispatched a team of researchers from the National Severe Storms Laboratory at Norman, Okla., to assess the effectiveness of its forecasters and timeliness of the alerts they issued Tuesday. ``We will do a complete assessment of the event,'' Robert Maddox, director of the laboratory, told the newspaper. ``We will look at the weather observations and the data available to forecast offices, and if the team can agree on them we will offer recommendations for improvements.'' Calls to the Oklahoma lab went unanswered early today.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Court Rverses Huge Libel Award
DOC.TEXT: A federal appeals court overturned Wayne Newton's record $5.2 million libel judgment, saying the jury didn't prove NBC News was deliberately false or reckless in suggesting the singer had ties to the mob. In dismissing Newton's lawsuit, the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals ruled 3-0 Thursday that any false impressions in the 1980 broadcast did not result from the type of journalistic misconduct required for libel lawsuits by public figures. The U.S. Supreme Court has ruled public figures must prove that defamatory statements were either deliberate falsehoods or recklessly disregarded the truth. Newton's lawyer, Morton Galane, said he would not comment until he could reach Newton. A jury in Las Vegas found that NBC's story falsely implied that the Mafia had helped Newton buy the Aladdin Hotel and Casino in exchange for a hidden interest. It awarded Newton $19.3 million, but that was reduced to $5.2 million, mostly in punitive damages, after U.S. District Judge Myron Crocker found that Newton's income and reputation had not suffered. Thursday's ruling said most of the broadcast's factual statements were true: Newton had a friend with purported mob ties who had done him a favor, and had then talked with an associate about the possibility of profiting from Newton's ownership of the Aladdin; a federal grand jury had investigated that subject; and Newton had testified falsely to the Nevada Gaming Board. Although the broadcast did not specify the favor that had been done for Newton _ according to Newton, getting a criminal organization to stop threatening him and his daughter _ the court said the omission was not libelous. The reporters had reason to doubt the story of the threats, which had been denied by Newton's lawyer in Newton's presence, the court said. Among the reasons NBC gave for challenging the verdict was Crocker's refusal to transfer the trial out of Las Vegas, where an annual Wayne Newton Day is celebrated and a street is named after him. ``Wayne Newton's case poses the danger that First Amendment values will be subverted by a local jury biased in favor of a prominent local public,'' said the opinion by Judge William Norris. ``I don't think the jury was as much biased against NBC as it was prone to support Wayne Newton,'' Floyd Abrams, a prominent libel lawyer representing NBC, said Thursday. He said the decision would not have been rendered outside of Las Vegas. NBC News president Michael Gartner called the ruling ``a sound victory for investigative journalism.''

DOC.HEAD: `Pre-Crisis Prices' Draws Huge Lines
DOC.TEXT: A gasoline station that promoted ``Pre-Crisis Prices'' drew two half-mile-long lines of cars rolling past an effigy of Iraq President Saddam Hussein. The wait for gas at 97.3 cents per gallon at Autotronics Amoco Garage lasted about an hour in 90-degree weather. Regular unleaded has been selling for about $1.31 a gallon at the station. For three hours, the station lowered prices to near their levels before Saddam's invasion of Kuwait pushed costs up a month ago. The difference was enough for Keith Jones' one-hour wait. ``I figure you got to go to the gas station anyway. You got to get out and pump it. That'll take you 15 minutes. And it'll save you 43 cents,'' Jones said. ``I've always got more time than money.''

DOC.HEAD: Thunderstorms Expected in Southeast, Clear Skies in West and Northeast
DOC.TEXT: The West and Northeast had clear skies today, with the prospect of sunshine and warmth through Labor Day. Thunderstorms were expected to sweep through the Southeast. Winds gusting to near 60 mph caused damage around Daytona Beach and elsewhere in Florida on Thursday, large hailstones pelted parts of Alabama and Georgia and five people were injured by a lightning strike on the Cape Fear River near Wilmington, N.C. Nearly 2 inches of rain fell in six hours Thursday in the Wilmington area and an 1}-inches of rain was recorded at Valparaiso, Fla., as heavy rainfall soaked the South. Rain also fell in parts of Texas, Oklahoma, Arizona, Indiana, Illinois, Colorado, Nebraska, Utah, Wyoming, Montana and Washingston state. Heat records for the date were tied or broken in cities from Wyoming to Florida. The high temperature for the nation was 114 degrees at Borrego Springs, Calif. The Labor Day weekend forecast calls for hotter than average temperatures in most areas, with high humidity in the South and Plains states. More rain is likely in the South, with scattered thunderstorms elsewhere. The holiday should be sunny and warm throughout the West, Northeast, and many other areas of the nation, with low to moderate humidity. DOC.HEAD: Ministers to Echo Summit Call For Iraqi Withdrawal from Kuwait
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Arab League has urged member nations with ideas for a diplomatic way out of the Persian Gulf crisis to come forward, and said any settlement of the crisis must include Iraq's withdrawal from Kuwait. But Arab diplomatic sources said the league would likely be unable to come up with a viable diplomatic solution to the month-old conflict in its two-day emergency session, at which eight of 21 members were absent. Arab foreign ministers were expected to end the meeting today by condemning for a second time Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait and demanding Baghdad's immediate and unconditional withdrawal from its oil-rich neighbor. Iraq has declared Kuwait part of its territory. The sources said the main aim of the meeting was to embarrass Iraqi President Saddam Hussein for ignoring the Aug. 10 appeal by Arab leaders at the Cairo summit. At the summit, 12 Arab nations also said they regarded the deposed emir of Kuwait as the nation's legitimate ruler, and agreed to send troops to Saudi Arabia to protect it against a possible Iraqi invasion. Egypt, Syria and Morocco have sent small troop contingents to coordinate with U.S. and other forces countering Iraq in the Persian Gulf region. Under Arab League rules, resolutions accepted by simple majorities are binding only on members voting for them. League Secretary-General Chadli Klibi said Thursday's meeting had reviewed reports on efforts by some Arabs to achieve a settlement. He was apparently referring to peace proposals by the Palestine Liberation Organization. Kuwait has rejected that initiative because it involves some form of federation between Kuwait and Iraq. Other Arabs states, included Jordan and Sudan, are involved in diplomatic efforts. In its statement Thursday, the league asked any members with peace initiatives to propose them, but said any solution must involve both an Iraqi withdrawal and restoration of Kuwait's deposed government. Klibi read the statement to reporters following a three-hour meeting of officials from 13 Arab League nations. In addition to Iraq, those staying away were Jordan, Sudan, Yemen, Algeria, Tunisia, Mauritania and the PLO. They all opposed, abstained or expressed reservations in the vote on the summit resolution. The ministers Thursday formed a six-nation committee to draft a resolution. The panel comprised of Bahrain, Libya, Kuwait, Egypt, Syria and Saudi Arabia. Syrian Foreign Minister Farouk al-Sharaa said the committee also would ``look at the initiatives taken by some Arab countries.'' Attending the conference were the 12 League members who supported the summit resolution, plus Libya. The 12 were Egypt, Syria, Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, Qatar, Bahrain, the United Arab Emirates, Oman, Morocco, Lebanon, Somalia and Djibouti. Libya had been expected to boycott the ministerial meeting. Egyptian officials said Cairo requested the ministerial session in line with a stipulation of the summit resolution that Klibi report within 15 days on its implementation.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mixed, Gold Lower
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was mixed in European trading today. Gold was mostly lower. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 144.50 yen, up 0.40 yen from Thursday's finish. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 144.06 yen. ``Investors have sold the dollar for a while because of the lack of developments in the Middle East crisis, but I think the dollar's down-trend has reversed,'' said Yoshitsugu Hanada, a dealer with Mitsui Taiyo Kobe Bank. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Thursday: _1.5616 German marks, up from 1.5561 _1.2940 Swiss francs, down from 1.2950 _5.2415 French francs, down from 5.2492 _1.7575 Dutch guilders, down from 1.7645 _1,159.50 Italian lire, down from 1,160.50 _1.1491 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1455 In London, the the British pound was quoted at $1.9010, compared with $1.9225 late Thursday. Gold dealers in London fixed a recommended price of $388.10 this morning, down from late Thursday's $389.60 bid. In Zurich, the bid price was $387.80, down from $389.05 late Thursday. Gold in Hong Kong rose $2.52 an ounce today, to close at $387.80. Silver in London was quoted at a bid price of $4.85 a troy ounce, down from Thursday's $4.86.

DOC.HEAD: Rebel Leader Confirms Holding Thousands of African Nationals
DOC.TEXT: A Liberian rebel leader claims his forces hold several thousand citizens of countries participating in the five-nation West African force sent to Liberia to end the tribal war. A force of 3,000 men from Nigeria, Ghana, Sierra Leone, Guinea and Gambia landed in Monrovia's port last weekend. The force hopes to end the 8-month-old war between President Samuel Doe and two rebel factions. One rebel leader, Charles Taylor, opposed the force and attacked it shortly after its arrival. Reporters traveling with the force say the rebels were driven off by the task force's heavy weaponry. Taylor, who on Thursday telephoned the British Broadcasting Corp. in London from Liberia, said he is holding nationals of countries participating in the multinational force. ``What we are we doing right now is not unlike what other countries have had to do to protect the lives of citizens of countries involved in wars with other countries,'' Taylor said. The rebel leader said his rebels evacuated several thousand people, mostly Nigerians and Ghanaians, from front-line areas to stop ``angry mobs of Liberians from killing them. It is for their security and for our security.'' Taylor denied he had threatened to kill the foreign nationals if any of his rebels were killed by the force but said he could not be expected ``to kiss Nigerians on the cheek.'' Taylor said, ``What I am saying to you is that I am not going to tolerate any nation coming into Liberia and killing Liberians.'' Meanwhile, a conference of opposition groups, churchmen and business leaders, meeting in Banjul, Gambia, was expected to make a recommendation on who should head any interim government, pending fresh elections. Leaders of the five-nation military force have said an interim government would be installed as soon as fighting ended. Neither Taylor, the second rebel leader, Prince Johnson, nor Doe would be in the government, the leaders said. Taylor's forces invaded from neighboring Ivory Coast in December and advanced largely unchecked until they reached the outskirts of the capital of Monrovia. They have been unable to dislodge troops loyal to Doe. Johnson's rebels, who split with Taylor, have taken control of much of the capital. Johnson and Doe have agreed to a truce and both support efforts to end the war. They both want the resignation of Doe.

DOC.HEAD: Convicted Killer Executed by Injection
DOC.TEXT: A man convicted of five murders was put to death by injection early today for killing an elderly woman 11 years ago. George C. Gilmore, 44, was declared dead at 12:10 a.m. at the maximum-security Potosi Correctional Center. ``He had no last words,'' said prison spokesman Dale Riley. A brother, a niece and a fiancee who were not identified wept and covered their faces with their hands as officials announced the fatal delivery of sodium pentothal, Pavlon and potassium chloride into a tube in Gilmore's arm. Strapped to a gurney and covered to his chin by a blanket, Gilmore strained at first to see his friends and mouthed what appeared to be ``I love you.'' Then he turned his head to the side and was still. Two minutes later he was declared dead. Gilmore was executed for killing 83-year-old Mary Luella Watters in August 1979. He also had received the death sentence for three other murders and was given a life prison term for a fourth. His partner in crime, Leonard Laws, was executed May 17. Authorities say Gilmore and Laws killed five people in a St. Louis-area crime spree, targeting elderly or helpless people for robbery and murder. Law enforcement officials expressed little sympathy for Gilmore. Richard D. Moore, director of the state Department of Corrections, told official witnesses that the method of execution was humane and ``a far cry from the terror and horror George Gilmore put each of his victims through.'' ``It's pretty sad when it takes 11 years,'' said St. Louis County Prosecutor George ``Buzz'' Westfall. A series of appeals Thursday failed to stop the execution, the 137th nationwide and the fifth in Missouri since the U.S. Supreme Court in 1976 let states resume use of the death penalty. The U.S. Supreme Court refused by a 6-1 vote to block Gilmore's death. Justice Thurgood Marshall, who opposes the death penalty in all circumstances, dissented. Justice Antonin Scalia did not take part in the case. U.S. District Court Judge Edward L. Filippine and the U.S. 8th Circuit Court of Appeals also dismissed Gilmore's appeals Thursday. Appeals filed for Gilmore by lawyers Kevin Collins and James Delworth alleged mitigating evidence had not been considered earlier. Gilmore, the son of two alcoholics, suffered fetal alcohol syndrome and organic brain damage, Delworth said. Missouri Attorney General William Webster's office rejected those arguments.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Admiral: Both Sides Playing It Safe In The Gulf
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Despite earlier reports of cat-and-mouse maneuvers, U.S. Navy officers say American and Iraqi fighters have been steering clear of each other and are careful not to cross boundary lines. Officers aboard the aircraft carrier Independence said Thursday that U.S. Navy forces were operating cautiously so as not to provoke a confrontation as the United Nations tries to negotiate a resolution to the standoff caused by Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. U.S. pilots are stopping short of waters off Kuwait and Iraqi pilots appear to be staying well behind Kuwaiti and Iraqi borders as well, said Rear Adm. Jerry Unruh, commander of the USS Independence battle group. F-14 and F-18 jets launched from the Independence are conducting missions in the gulf. Iraq has also not lately taken any steps that would indicate ``hostile intentions,'' he said. Unruh attributed Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein's strategy to the strong deterrent forces in the region and economic sanctions on Iraq. Last week there were reports American pilots locked their weapons radar on Iraqi planes in what one crew chief described as ``a little cat-and-mouse,'' although they said the Iraqis had refused go along with the game. The reports were not confirmed by the Pentagon or by U.S. commanders in Saudi Arabia. Unruh spoke to a group of reporters aboard the Independence, a Forrestall-class aircraft carrier stationed just south of the gulf. The F-14s and F-18s are being launched north into the gulf to protect other naval vessels patrolling the area. Unruh said Iraq has Exocet and Silkworm missiles in Kuwait ``but we have no indication that they are ready to employ them for use against our ships or aircraft.'' As for the embargo, Unruh said, U.S., British and French ships surrounding the Arabian peninsula were tracking 50-75 ships a day in their efforts to block any commercial ships from leaving Iraq and any ships except those carrying medicine from delivering goods to Iraq. Unruh said there were few problems associated with the crowded airspace in the gulf area, which in addition to commercial traffic includes hundreds of military jets and transports used for the multinational defense of Saudi Arabia. But one of the carrier's squadron leaders said fighter pilots were carrying fewer long range missiles on their missions because they wanted to make visual identification of all targets. ``One of our worries is fratricide,'' said Commander Sel Laughter of the Black Knights F-14 squadron. Another squadron commander, Dave Nickle, paused when asked how he would feel if assigned to attack an Iraqi target knowing the site might also be the holding place of Western hostages. Nickle glanced down at the floor for several seconds before saying, ``Our job is to go hit that target and that's what we're going to do. Somebody else has to worry about hostages.''

DOC.HEAD: Woman Accused of Illegal Silicone Injections
DOC.TEXT: Authorities said a woman illegally injected liquid silicone into the breasts of several women, one of whom may have to go undergo a mastectomy. Authorities are looking for Sookie Y. Ricketts, 42, who is charged with two misdemeanor counts of practicing medicine without a license, District Attorney John Suthers said Thursday. An arrest warrant was issued Aug. 6 for Ricketts, 42, whose last known address was in Marietta, Ga., he said. Ricketts allegedly charged several women thousands of dollars each to perform the procedure at her Colorado Springs home in late May, Suthers said. ``It was the equivalent of a Tupperware party,'' he said. Doctors in the United States discontinued use of silicone injections in the 1960s, and now use sealed bags of sterile silicone or saline, said Dr. Lawrence Ketch, chief of plastic and reconstructive surgery at the University of Colorado Health Sciences Center. Silicone that is injected is likely to break up and move to other parts of the body, causing grotesque and sometimes painful lumps under the skin, Ketch said. The practice of having an unlicensed person inject unpurified silicone into the body is accepted in many countries, but is illegal in this country, he said. A woman who sold a diamond ring worth thousands of dollars to pay for the treatment suffered an acute infection several days after being injected by Ricketts, Ketch said. She was treated with antibiotics, he said. ``It's not life threatening to her, but sooner or later she will have to have her breast removed,'' Ketch said.

DOC.HEAD: Baby's Marrow Donation to Ailing Sister Postponed
DOC.TEXT: Doctors will wait until at least next year before attempting a bone marrow transplant from a baby conceived as a possible donor for her leukemia-stricken sister. Doctors had said 5-month-old Marissa Eve Ayala could safely donate sufficient bone marrow for her 18-year-old sister, Anissa, as early as 6 months of age. But a decision was made to wait until early 1991, to give the 12-pound Marissa time to grow and because her sister's leukemia is stabilized. As long as Anissa's leukemia remains stable, ``physicians would prefer to let Marissa grow and mature until about a year of age,'' Charlie Mathews, spokesman for the City of Hope Medical Center, said Thursday. The decision by Mary and Abe Ayala to have a baby as a potential donor for their daughter drew attention from medical ethicists, who voiced concern about creating one child to save another. Waiting until Marissa is larger will allow for the extraction of more bone marrow. There is little risk for the baby, doctors have said. Mrs. Ayala said doctors had suggested performing the marrow transplant in December but the family wanted to wait until after Christmas. The chance that a bone marrow transplant will cure Anissa of the leukemia, a cancer of white blood cells, has been reported as between 70 percent and 80 percent. The family had been unable to find a suitable donor. Fetal cells withdrawn during amniocentesis, pre-birth testing, showed ``virtually 100 percent that Marissa would be a perfect match for Anissa,'' Mathews said.

DOC.HEAD: Family Reveals Identity of Hostage Who Died in Iraq
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf to CORRECT spelling of Colombia.
DOC.TEXT: The American hostage who died this week in Iraq was banker James L. Worthington Jr., his family disclosed. Worthington, 53, a native of Marathon, Texas, died Monday, his daughter told the Daily Freeman of Kingston on Thursday. ``He was taken hostage in Kuwait and moved to Basra where he died of a heart attack,'' said Maggie Jean Neilson, 27, of Woodstock. She said that information came from the U.S. State Department. State Department spokeswoman Gloria Berbena would not confirm the dead hostage's identity. Earlier this week, the Iraqi Foreign Ministry said the body of an American who died in the city of Basra would be turned over to the U.S. Embassy in Baghdad. Worthington had been working as a consultant for the Alahi Bank of Kuwait and lived in the Hilton Hotel in Kuwait City, family members said. The State Department notified his wife, Katharine W. Worthington, of his death. When not overseas, Worthington lived with his wife, two children, and mother-in-law in Woodstock, about 90 miles north of New York City. Before moving to Kuwait, Worthington worked for 28 years in various foreign branches of Citibank. He was stationed, with his family, in Colombia, Brazil, Liberia, Indonesia, Singapore and India. He worked at the bank's main branch in New York City just before his tenure in Kuwait, Neilson said.

DOC.HEAD: Report: U.S. Warship Stops Sri Lankan Vessel Outside Aqaba
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with today's report. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A freighter that was stopped, searched and boarded by the U.S. Navy as part of the enforcement of the embargo against Iraq is trying to find a port that will accept its cargo, a shipping newspaper said today. Lloyd's List International said Pacific International Lines of Singapore, owner of the Kota Wirama, intended to make a second attempt to send the freighter to the Jordanian port of Aqaba. Aqaba had been Iraq's last major link to world trade, and U.S. officials have said the flow has largely come to a halt as a result of the embargo, imposed after Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. The paper quoted unidentified sources in London as saying the ship was suspected of carrying chemicals for Iraq as well as food and other goods. U.S. military sources have said that U.S. warships have intercepted about 170 ships and boarded at least 10 in the Persian Gulf and Red Sea since President Bush issued his Aug. 16 order to enforce the embargo. The military sources said that while most ships were allowed to continue, Navy boarders found at least two with Iraq-related cargo and persuaded them to change their sailing plans. The newspaper quoted an executive with Pacific International Lines as saying he ``had no knowledge of chemicals on board Kota Wirama or whether the cargo included items for Iraq.'' The Kota Wirama's cargo came from various ports, including Shanghai and Singapore, and it was bound for for the Red Sea, Aden, Mombasa and Dar es Salaam, the paper said. Lloyd's List International _ a daily paper that reports on shipping, insurance, energy, trade and finance _ is published in London by the Lloyd's of London insurance market.

DOC.HEAD: Report: European Hostages May Benefit From Events
DOC.TEXT: A reputed leader of captors holding Westerners in Lebanon said recent actions by European nations could hasten the release of some European hostages, a newspaper reported today. The Ad-Diyar newspaper quoted Hussein Musawi saying factions holding six Americans and seven Europeans ``distinguish between'' the stance of the United States and some European countries regarding events in the Mideast since the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. Musawi, who heads a pro-Syrian wing of the fundamentalist Hezbollah, or Party of God, also cited Britain's acknowledgment that ``The Satanic Verses'' novel could offend Moslems and France's release of a Lebanese prisoner accused of trying to assassinate an Iranian diplomat. ``Moslem factions concerned with the European and American hostages distinguish between the American and European stands,'' the newspaper quoted Musawi as saying. He gave no indication when any hostages might be freed, but noted ``Europeans would be in a more favorable position than others.'' Hezbollah, Iran's closest ally in Lebanon, is believed to have links to factions holding six Americans, four Britons, two West Germans and an Italian. Three European hostages have been freed in recent weeks. Two American hostages, Frank Reed and Robert Polhill, were freed in April. Swiss Red Cross workers Elio Erriquez and Emanuel Christen were freed earlier this month. They were kidnapped in south Lebanon Oct. 6, 1989. Brian Keenan, a teacher with dual Irish-British citizenship, was released Aug. 24 after nearly 4{ years in captivity. French President Francois Mitterrand recently released Anis Naccache, who was serving a life sentence for the 1980 attempted assassination of former Iranian Prime Minister Shahpour Bakhtiar in Paris. British officials this month noted that Salman Rushdie's ``The Satanic Verses'' could be offensive to Moslems. Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini issued a death sentence on Rushdie in February 1989 for blaspheming the Moslem religion in the book. Rushdie has been in hiding. Musawi said that ``such stands would undoubtedly be understood as goodwill gestures by the Europeans and, therefore, it must affect positively the situation of the European hostages.'' Musawi said in a telephone interview with The Associated Press on Aug. 16 that he believed no American hostages would be freed because of the U.S. military intervention in the gulf. After Iraq invaded Kuwait and massed tens of thousands of soldiers on the Saudi border, the United States began deploying troops to defend Saudi Arabia.

DOC.HEAD: Shooting Brings Boston's Homicide Toll to 100
DOC.TEXT: The shooting death of a 20-year-old man pushed Boston's homicide toll to 100, equal to the number of killings in all of 1989, police said. The victim, Terry Mercer, was shot three times Thursday by a gunman after parking his car outside a home in the Mattapan neighborhood, a witness told police. Police Sgt. James Kelley said there had been no arrests. From January to August last year, there were 66 homicides in Boston. The city's record yearly homicide toll was 135 in 1973.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Jordanian Planes Spying For Iraq, Israeli Leaders Urge Calm
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Jordanian military planes are flying spy missions along the Saudi border to supply Iraq with information on troop movements, an Israeli military source said today. The source, who briefed reporters on condition of anonymity, said the Jordanian reconnaissance flights are being flown by U.S.-made F-5 jets, giving a view of troop movements dozens of miles into Saudia Arabia. The source described the areas reportedly being watched by the Jordanian craft as sectors along the Saudi-Jordan border that Iraq cannot cover without being obvious or risking confrontation. It said Jordanian military aircraft also have stepped up flights along the Jordanian-Israeli border to watch for Israeli troop movements. Throughout the Persian Gulf crisis, Israel has warned that any entry by Iraqi troops into Jordan would bring Israeli military retaliation. Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, meanwhile, warned Iraq today against attempting to strike Israel. President Chaim Herzog tried to calm public fears by saying the Iraqi army is ``not the mighty monster'' it is made out to be. They were reacting to an Iraqi air force commander's threat a day earlier ``of dealing smashing blows to the nests of the Israelis.'' Also, a leading Israeli military analyst said the latest threat marked an escalation in the war of words with Iraq and called for a reassessment of the dangers facing the Jewish state. ``Up until now Israel considered an Iraqi attack only a low probability,'' said Zeev Schiff, military writer for the Hebrew daily Haaretz. ``Now we have to reassess and consider an Iraqi attack on Israel as an act of desperation.'' He added: ``Although Saddam Hussein has up until now only threatened to attack Israel if Israel attacks him, now the Iraqis are announcing that in the event of a war they will attack Israel missiles and planes even if Israel doesn't lift a finger.'' Israel has been keeping a low profile since the gulf crisis was set off Aug. 2 with the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. But it has also made it clear that it is worried about the Iraqi threat and prepared to handle any Iraqi aggression. Israel fears that any settlement in the gulf may leave Saddam in place, where he will continue to be a threat to the Jewish state. Officials here also have objected to planned arms sales to Saudi Arabia, saying that the sales of U.S.-made fighter jets, tanks and Stinger anti-aircraft missiles would reduce Israel's ``qualitative edge'' in Middle East weaponry. The crisis is expected to be a topic of discussion Wednesday in Washington between Foreign Minister David Levy and Secretary of State James A. Baker III. The Jerusalem Post said ``partial answers'' have been received on enhancing U.S. weapons packages for Israel, which receives $1.8 billion a year in U.S. military aid. Shamir warned Saddam that ``any aggressor would live to regret his actions.'' Herzog, in the text of a speech to be broadcast nationwide today, urged the public to remain calm. ``True, we are dealing with a cruel tyrant,'' Herzog said. ``But the picture as of now is not of a man trying to widen his field of combat.'' He added: ``I am not saying the Iraqi army, in these conditions, is a paper tiger. ... But it is certainly not the mighty monster described by so many in the media.'' Defense Minister Moshe Arens told Israel radio ``We are prepared, ready and calm.'' The military source, meanwhile, contended today that Jordan was helping Saddam in several ways in addition to the reconnaissance flights. The source claimed that Jordan is importing food and medicine, then passing it on to Iraq to help subvert the Western embargo. ``They can import for themselves and then send these goods to Iraq ... and this is what they are doing,'' he said. In answer to a question, he said there was no evidence Jordan was sending military equipment to Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: Study Finds No Link Between TMI Radiation and Cancer
DOC.TEXT: There is no evidence that radiation emissions during the 1979 nuclear accident at Three Mile Island affected the health of area residents, an independent study released today concludes. The study by Columbia University scientists said there was no sign that the radiation caused leukemia or childhood cancers among people living within 10 miles of the plant. Those illnesses are more sensitive to low-level radiation than other diseases and are the first to appear after exposure, the scientists said in a briefing several miles from the nuclear plant near Harrisburg. The findings were published today in the American Journal of Epidemiology. They match the conclusions of a 1985 report, released by the state Health Department, that found no evidence of increased cancers in a 20-mile radius. In the latest study, Columbia epidemiologists Mervyn Susser and Maureen Hatch studied the health records of 160,000 residents of 69 areas within the 10-mile radius. They also compared cancer rates between 1975 and 1985. The accident, the worst at a U.S. commercial nuclear plant, happened in 1979. During the accident, which crippled the Unit 2 reactor, radioactive gases were vented into the atmosphere. The study expands on a report given in June to the American Society of Epidemiologists. That report found no association between TMI accident emissions and childhood cancers in a 10-mile radius around the plant. Hatch said the June report was withheld from the public until today because of a release embargo set by the scientific journal that published the findings. The study was funded by the Three Mile Island Public Health Fund, which was established to study issues related to the accident. The fund was established as part of a $5 million settlement of a 1981 class-action lawsuit against the owners of TMI. In 1986, the fund's administrators subpoenaed hospitals for health records used in the study. The report has been complete for a number of months, but publication was delayed because of revisions by the authors and peer review. The accident at TMI 2 occurred after a combination of human and mechanical errors caused protective cooling water to be drained from the reactor. Some of the reactor's cache of nuclear fuel melted, and radiation was released into the environment. The accident was the worst to happen at a commercial nuclear power plant in the United States. Despite the findings of government reports, some community members continue to assert the accident left a legacy of illness that has yet to be officially recognized. Kay Pickering, a spokeswoman for Three Mile Island Alert, a citizens group, said she doubted that a statistical study would go far enough to fully disclose health effects possibly linked to the accident. She said a better approach would be to track a sample of residents who lived within a 5-mile radius of the plant at the time of the accident. She said a similar survey was done the summer after the accident. ``The people in the community are suffering. ... They believe they have been affected,'' she said. The 1985 Health Department study, which was the first of its kind after the accident, found no pattern of increased cancer cases or deaths, but it did turn up isolated instances of higher-than-expected cancer cases in several communities downwind from the plant. The study dismissed those cases as statistically insignificant. A 1984 survey, conducted door-to-door, found cancer deaths up to seven times higher than expected in sections of Newberry and Fairview townships near the plant. The Health Department judged that invalid because it appeared to focus on streets where cancer victims lived. A 1986 GPU Nuclear Corp. summary of government-sponsored studies said the 8 millirem average radiation exposure for individuals within 10 miles of the plant was less than the 10 millirems generated by a single chest X-ray. The highest possible exposure, for someone who stood naked at the plant boundary throughout the accident, would have been less than 100 millirems, said the review by GPU, the plant's operator.

DOC.HEAD: Gulf Area is World's Leading Weapons Destination
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Subs graf 5, Saudi Arabia, to CORRECT $300 million to $300 billion. Janne is cq in 17th graf
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf-Bush, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Persian Gulf crisis is occurring in a region that has become the world's leading destination for increasingly sophisticated weaponry, from tanks to fighter planes and ``smart'' missiles. The arms that flowed into the area's two leading buyers _ Iraq and Saudi Arabia _ during the last 15 years are now aimed across their common border in a dispute that in some ways echoes the now-diffused Cold War. ``Both we and the Soviets thought we were creating allies, forging relationships on our team in the global bipolar power struggle,'' said Michael T. Klare, a professor of peace and world security studies at Hampshire College in Massachusetts. ``But that's not what they thought they were doing,'' said Klare, who wrote a prescient article in May about the emergence of ``regional superpowers'' like Iraq. ``At no point did any of these countries think they were playing on either team. They have their own agenda.'' Saudi Arabia and Iraq received nearly one-third of more than $300 billion in arms sold to Third World countries from 1982 through 1989, according to a Congressional Research Service analysis of U.S. intelligence data. The United States and the Soviet Union accounted for more than 60 percent of that total weapons trade. The soldiers of Iraqi President Saddam Hussein carry Soviet assault weapons and fight with tanks and artillery from Moscow and Beijing. The fighter planes overhead may come from France or the Soviet Union. Their multiple-launch rocket systems and some surface-to-surface missiles are made in Brazil. Still other arms come from Czechoslovakia, Egypt and South Africa. Across the border, the Saudis have F-15 fighters, tanks, anti-tank missiles and air-to-air missiles from the United States. The British sold the Saudis fighters, as well; the French provided anti-aircraft batteries. And President Bush has agreed to sell the Saudis another $2.3 billion worth of weapons: more F-14s and tanks, as well as Stinger anti-aircraft missiles and depleted-uranium anti-armor rounds that had been banned from Riyadh's shopping list. While the superpowers have used arms as a foreign policy tool to reward allies, the rest of the world has engaged in the trade for purely commercial reasons. Hoping to rid themselves of dependence on the superpowers, Third World countries have been developing indigenous weapons industries, defense analysts say. While they once were limited to making small arms and ammunition, that is no longer the case. Brazil can build its own tanks and fighter planes, and is eager to market them. India builds large warships, artillery and missiles. Countries from Argentina to South Korea, China and South Africa also have home-grown weapons capability. In 1978-79, the United States and the Soviet Union conducted talks aimed at clamping controls on the spread of new conventional weapons technology, but the discussions broke off after the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan. It would be far more difficult for such an effort to be effective in today's wide-open weapons mart. In Iraq, Saddam's domestic weapons industry is among the biggest worries for U.S. military strategists. Using mercenary Western expertise, he has been able to improve the range of Soviet-provided SCUD-B missiles and may have developed chemical warheads for them. Saddam also is believed to be well along in developing nuclear weapons. ``It's a tribute to what you can do with money,'' said Janne Nolan, a fellow at the Brookings Institution, a Washington research group. While the United States did not directly arm Iraq, it bears major responsibility for Saddam's military strength, said Stephanie Neuman of Columbia University. ``We were encouraging it,'' she said, by providing Iraq with intelligence information during its eight-year war with Iran and looking the other way while the Soviets and Europeans armed Saddam. Klare said Iraq also was quietly permitted to buy U.S. computers and other high-technology items with defense uses, in part with the aim of luring the country out of the Soviet orbit. Driving the United States was a fear that Iran's Islamic fundamentalism would grow to dominate the region, and lingering hatred from the 1970s hostage crisis. ``It wasn't a mistake at the time. We had to do it,'' Neuman said. But each U.S. response to a crisis seems to help sow the seeds of the next crisis where weapons are concerned, analysts said, not only by selling arms but also through the lingering superpower lesson that building an arsenal is the way to acquire world influence. ``We're going to have more Iraqs down the road,'' Klare said. ``It may be Brazil, it may be Taiwan, it may be Indonesia. We're contributing to the emergence of these regional superpowers.''

DOC.HEAD: Romanian Prime Minister Wants to Visit Washington
DOC.TEXT: Romanian Prime Minister Petre Roman wants to visit Washington this fall and has been dropping hints to the Bush administration for an official invitation, The New York Times reported today. ``I want to go because I want to be questioned by the congressmen and senators. I want to be really there to answer every question and every criticism directly in the pure American style,'' Roman said in an interview conducted with the Times in Bucharest. It is not clear whether the Bush administration, which has repeatedly criticized the Romanian government, will endorse a visit by Roman. The prime minister was to meet with Sen. Bob Dole, Republican minority leader, and six other U.S. representatives today. A U.S. embassy official said the administration was closely watching how the Romanian government handles anti-government demonstrations before making a decision. The United States has strongly criticized the Romanian government for its conduct during a June demonstration when a call for help resulted in miners flooding the capital and beating up anti-government protesters.

DOC.HEAD: Korean Premiers to Meet For Two Days
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 1 graf after 2nd, `North Korean...' to ADD report of meeting with South Korean president. Pickup 3rd graf, `It will...'
DOC.TEXT: Archrivals North and South Korea have set the details for historic talks between their prime ministers, opening the way for negotiations on easing four decades of hostilities, officials said today. North Korean Prime Minister Yon Hyong Muk and about 90 others are scheduled to cross the heavily fortified border on Tuesday for two days of talks with South Korean officials, the Information Ministry said. Yon is also scheduled to visit with South Korean President Roh Tae-woo, according to government officials who spoke on condition of anonymity. It will be the highest-level contact between the Communist North and capitalist south since the Korean peninsula was divided in 1945. And security was expected to be tight for the talks, to be held on Wednesday and Thursday. About 3,000 police will ring the hotel where South Korean Prime Minister Kang Young-hoon and his North Korean counterpart will meet, the ministry said. Thousands more police will be posted around government buildings and along routes where the delegations are expected to travel, police said. It was agreed that a second round of talks will be held in the North Korean capital, Pyongyang, on Oct. 16-19, the ministry said. Travel plans and other details were completed late Thursday between officials of the two Koreas meeting in Panmunjom, a border village inside the Demilitarized Zone that separates the two nations. The North Korean delegation, consisting of eight delegates, 33 assistants and 50 reporters, will walk over the border into the South at Panmunjom and will be driven the 35 miles to the South Korean capital. The Communist delegation is scheduled to leave South Korea on Sept. 7. Although South Korean officials attach great significance to the talks, observers doubt substantial progress will be made because the prime ministers of both nations are mostly figureheads without policy-making roles. North Korea has said the talks should cover mainly ways to ease political and military tensions. South Korean officials insist priority be given to non-political exchanges to promote mutual confidence. North Korea has proposed drastic arms reductions, cutting the troop level to 100,000 each. North Korea has more than 1 million troops, while South Korea has 650,000. The North Koreans also demand withdrawal of the 43,000 U.S. troops stationed in South Korea under a mutual defense treaty. But South Korea opposes any drastic measures such as arms cuts before an extended period of confidence-building. In an unprecedented move, South Korea proposed an unrestricted five-day border opening in mid-August for the 62 million residents of the two Koreas but North Korea failed to meet Seoul officials to discuss the matter. The Korean peninsula was divided into the Communist north and capitalist south in 1945. The nations fought a three-year war in the early 1950s. Their border is sealed and direct communication between their peoples is forbidden.

DOC.HEAD: Toy Rocket Ignited Fire, Teen-ager Charged
DOC.TEXT: A 15-year-old boy whose toy rocket touched off a 7,040-acre blaze has been charged with a misdemeanor count of recklessly setting a fire, authorities said. The youth told officials the rocket malfunctioned July 12 and crashed into dry brush at Chino Hills State Park. After attempting to stamp out the flames, the boy called 911. He suffered minor burns on his lower right leg. Model rockets are restricted in certain wilderness areas. The Orange County District Attorney's Office filed the charge Wednesday. Deputy District Attorney David Hickey declined to identify the youth because of his age. Three inmate firefighters were overcome by smoke and a fourth fractured an elbow in a fall. No structures were damaged in the blaze, but officials estimated the cost of putting out the fire at $500,000. The park is about 40 miles southeast of downtown Los Angeles. County fire officials have said they were considering filing a civil lawsuit against the boy's parents to recover costs. County Counsel Adrian Kuyper said pursuit of damages and reimbursement for the cost of extinguishing a fire is standard policy.

DOC.HEAD: Report Says Massive Airstrikes Planned in Gulf
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The United States has given up any U.S. diplomatic efforts to settle the conflict with Iraq and is planning massive air attacks if economic sanctions fail, a newspaper reported today. ``The administration must now wait to see whether the sanctions and the diplomatic initiatives work, but obviously, there are other options,'' Newsday quoted an senior administration official as saying. The official was not named. ``If the sanctions and diplomacy don't work, the U.S. does not intend to let things stand,'' said a source, identified as having intimate knowledge of U.S. military thinking. ``In eight to 10 weeks, if Hussein doesn't show a serious willingness to withdraw from Kuwait, the administration is prepared to make a decision to use the military to increase the pressure on him to get out.'' The newspaper said government officials and other knowledgeable sources believe the timetable for the start of an attack was four to 10 weeks, depending on military and political factors. Administration officials told the newspaper that U.S.-led military action also depends on allowing enough time to pass for world onlookers to conclude that economic sanctions imposed against Iraq were given enough time to take hold. The same is said of peace initiatives sought by U.N. Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar and Arab leaders, including Jordan's King Hussein. Newsday says administration officials apparently believe Iraqi President Saddam Hussein is not serious about an offer to withdraw his troops from Kuwait in exchange for a lifting of economic sanctions and other concessions. To date, the United States has rejected any compromise, insisting on complete withdrawal.

DOC.HEAD: Angry Passengers Seize Plane After Delays
DOC.TEXT: Air travelers frustrated by delays seized control of a jetliner and demanded to be flown home, but the plane could not land because of bad weather, a newspaper reported today. The group was stranded for several days at an airport in Yuzhno-Sakhalinsk in the Soviet Far East and passengers became angry when the plane's flight crew went home, Pravda reported. The travelers, led by a local official, forced a pilot to make the 300-mile flight to the Kuril island of Iturup. But when the AN-24 plane approached the Iturup runway, it was unable to land because of the weather and returned to Yuzhno-Sakhalinsk, Pravda said. The newspaper also noted that runways in the region are generally in poor condition. The article did not indicate when the incident occurred or whether the passengers were armed. It also did not say if the passengers were arrested. Pravda said the attempted hijacking was led by Vladimir Kashpruk, deputy chairman of the Kuril local council. Meanwhile, the official Tass news agency reported that pilots and passengers foiled two separate hijacking attempts in central Russia on Thursday. One involved a drunken passenger with a knife and the other was a 20-year-old man who grabbed a stewardess and demanded to be flown to West Germany. Both men were arrested upon landing, Tass said. Tass did not give additional details on the incident.

DOC.HEAD: De Klerk Wants Ruling Party Opened to All Races
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with background, protest march. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: In a major turnabout, President F.W. de Klerk called today for the whites-only ruling National Party to be opened to all races in the drive to end apartheid. De Klerk said the National Party must open its ranks to all South Africans who shared its basic values and hopes for a multiracial democracy. He said the party had to prepare for major changes confronting the country. ``The new South Africa demands that those who belong together through inner conviction should come together,'' he told a party provincial congress in Durban. The opening of the National Party to all races would be a historic change for the party that created apartheid and attempted to exclude non-whites from political power. The party has for decades been the main voice of Afrikaner nationalism, representing whites of mostly Dutch descent who dominate South African politics. The president, who also heads the party, asked the congress to give party leaders the authority to amend its constitution to admit all races. The congress was expected to approve, clearing the way for similar action at other provincial party congresses. De Klerk said South Africans of all colors who want a free-market economy, guaranteed human rights and other protections must band together to work for their common goals. ``The requirement of no (racial) domination means that power has to be shared in such a way that a majority will neither have absolute power nor be able to abuse its power to the detriment of minorities or for their suppression,'' he said. De Klerk has pledged to end apartheid and share power with the black majority. But he wants guarantees on rights for the white minority under any future black-majority government. The government is looking for allies among black political groups to buttress its position in negotiations with the African National Congress on sharing power. Also today, the government declined to confirm reports that scores of political prisoners would be released Saturday. The government and the ANC agreed Aug. 6 on a review process to free political detainees starting from Sept. 1. In a speech earlier today to the congress, Law and Order Minister Adriaan Vlok warned that black factional fighting which has claimed more than 500 lives could resume at any time and push South Africa into a spiral of violence and bloodshed. Vlok, who heads the police, also warned that rising crime could trigger violence between whites and blacks. He said police were doing all they could to prevent violence. Factional fighting in black townships around Johannesburg has left at least 518 people dead, and Vlok said tension was being stoked by strikes, black consumer boycotts and terrorist attacks. ``These tendencies are unacceptable. In a new South Africa, South Africans will just have to exercise more tolerance towards one another,'' Vlok told a provinicial congress of the governing National Party in Durban. Police said today the Johannesburg townships were quiet. The violence began Aug. 12 between Xhosas linked to the African National Congress and Zulus tied to the conservative Inkatha movement. Fighting raged in the townships for more than two weeks with rival groups battling with axes, spears, guns and knives. The government last week imposed emergency restrictions on the townships and sent in troops to aid police. The ANC, the largest black opposition group, church leaders and others have accused police of bias during the fighting. Vlok challenged the ANC and other groups to present evidence to support the claims. He said if police officers were implicated in fighting they would be punished. Meanwhile, about 500 university students marched today to police headquaters in Cape Town to protest the recent Johannesburg fighting. Police made no effort to block the students, who presented a statement to police commanders charging that police had sided with Inkatha. Police fired shotguns and tear gas Thursday and Wednesday to break up protests at the University of the Western Cape in Cape Town when students demonstrated against the violence in Johannesburg.

DOC.HEAD: Schwarzkopf: Iraqi Attack Would Be `Awfully Stupid Mistake'' ^With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The commander of U.S. forces in the Middle East said today there will be no war unless Iraq starts one, a move he said would be ``an awfully stupid mistake.'' Army Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, in his first news conference since moving his command post to Saudi Arabia, repeatedly ducked questions about specific U.S. military options under consideration. But he said the United States was not looking to start hostilities. ``There's not going to be any war unless the Iraqis attack,'' Schwarzkopf told reporters after spending the day visiting American troops in northeast Saudi Arabia. Schwarzkopf called the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait ``not only a mugging but a rape.'' He said said Iraqi forces in Iraq and Kuwait appeared to be in defensive posture but were capable of taking the offense. ``They certainly have the capability to attack, although I think if they were to do so it would be an awful stupid mistake,'' Schwarzkopf said. The general glanced at the floor before answering a question about how much impact Iraq's holding of American and other Western hostages had on his military planning. ``I would tell you that obviously I am just as concerned as anyone else about every single human life,'' Schwarzkopf said. But, he added: ``What I have to do is plan the military component and not concern myself with the hostages.'' He refused to answer a question about whether his early declaration about war prospects meant that the United States would not make an offensive push to drive Iraqi forces from Kuwait. He also refused to say whether the military was aiding the Kuwaiti resistance. There have been reports that Army special operations forces are helping the resistance movement. There has been speculation that the United States would seek a permanent military foothold in Saudi Arabia regardless of the outcome of the current staandoff _ a delicate subject because of anti-American sentiment in parts of the Arab world. When asked about such prospects, Schwarzkopf said: ``We have no intention of establishing a permanent base in Saudi Arabia.'' Schwarzkopf laughed when asked who was in charge of the multinational forces. ``This is not NATO,'' he said. ``This is not a single command and there doesn't need to be.'' The United States has by far the biggest military presence in Saudi Arabia and many nations that have committed forces to the region have not yet sent them, or sent only small contingents. Asked by a French reporter if France should send more forces, Scwarzkopf said only: ``I would like all the help I can get.'' Schwarzkopf is a bear of a man and can be gruff at times. But he was grandfatherly during stops at several U.S. staging areas, filling the troops in on the latest developments in the crisis and promising them more newspapers and radios. After a briefing by commanders of the 101st Airborne Division's air assault brigade, Schwarzkopf walked into a garage area and immediately encountered Staff Sgt. John Frady, of Sylva, N.C., a member of a maintenance platoon who was in the process of receiving a haircut. The general asked him: ``Ready to do the job?'' Frady answered: ``Ready to go to war, sir.'' He next visited the 354th Tactical Fighter Wing from Myrtle Beach, S.C., telling them the arrival of the wing's A-10 tank-killers had made him more confident of the deterrent power of the U.S. deployment. He said the United States was there to defend Saudi Arabia but ready to fight back if Saddam Hussein ordered Iraqi forces to invade the kingdom. ``Let's face it, if he dares come across that border and comes down here, I'm completely confident that we're going to kick his butt when he gets here,'' Schwarzkopf said. Speaking to a group of officers in an air-conditioned tent at the same airstrip, Schwarzkopf said. ``Every now and then people have to go to war and ask themselves whether they are on the right side or the wrong side. There is no doubt that we are on the right side now, because the whole world is telling us that.'' His next and last stop was a Marine support camp in northeast Saudi Arabia, where Schwarzkopf received yet another briefing and visited with Marines digging a sandbag-lined foxhole. ``Our attitude has to be to be in this for the long haul,'' Schwarzkopf told a small group of Marines who had asked him about the latest developments in the crisis. One Marine said he had heard a rumor about the C-5 crash in Germany this week. Schwarzkopf told the group the transport indeed had crashed, killing 13 people. As the Marines shook their heads, Schwarzkopf said: ``That's 13 more counts against Saddam Hussein.''

DOC.HEAD: Quebec Premier Breaks Off Latest Talks with Mohawks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 6 grafs to UPDATE on removal of barricades. Pickup 5th graf, `Premier Robert...'
DOC.TEXT: Government and Mohawk work crews today further dismantled a series of barricades around a heavily traveled bridge, but other Indian roadblocks nearby remained intact. The destruction of the five barrier sites near the Mercier Bridge and Kahnawake reservation resumed despite a breakdown of talks between provincial officials and Mohawks concerning the seven-week standoff. The bridge, a principal link between Montreal and suburbs, was blocked by Mohawks at the reservation in sympathy with the Indians in Oka, who objected to a proposed golf course expansion on land they consider ancestral. The conflict began July 11 when the Quebec provincial police stormed a Mohawk barricade in Oka, about 18 miles west of Montreal. The police were repulsed and one officer was killed, but it is still not clear who shot him. Canadian Forces Capt. Richard St-Louis said today that work crews had not yet reached the Mercier Bridge. ``We don't have any timetable to get on the bridge. We are moving day by day,'' he said. Premier Robert Bourassa issued a terse statement late Thursday saying he was going back to the original plan of using the army to dismantle barricades. ``The government of Quebec maintains its position concerning the intervention of the army, announced last Monday,'' Bourassa said. He said he was withdrawing from talks because negotiators for the Six Nations Iroquois Confederacy had announced they were pulling out. Last-ditch talks between Mohawks and government officials this week included delegates from the confederacy, the highest-ranking traditional leadership of the Iroquois, which includes the Mohawks. ``Dismantling barricades is our mandate. We are to act on our own as we see fit. Our mandate has no limit,'' said an army spokesman, Capt. Yvon Desjardins. Mohawk Chief Joe Norton alleged ``harassment'' and said shipments of food and medicine were being blocked from entering the Kahnawake reserve by angry residents and police. Chief Billy Two Rivers said Mohawks have been asked to give up too much. ``Maybe some of the white people didn't see Indian blood, but unfortunately we can't give them everything,'' he said. Quebec provincial police and an army spokesmen denied the charges of harassment or that food into the reservation was blocked. ``I can categorically state that no food is being kept out of Kahnawake whatsoever,'' said Army Capt. Donald Roy. The dispute has touched off an anti-Indian backlash among residents angered by the barricades. Most of Kanesatake's 1,500 residents have left as a result of the confrontation. An estimated 200 to 300 remain.

DOC.HEAD: Barry Re-Trial Possibility in the Virgin Islands, TV Station Reports
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS lede to CORRECT that he could, not will, face charges in Virgin Islands
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Marion Barry may face another trial, this time in the Virgin Islands, on the remaining counts of his federal drug indictment, a Washington television station reports. Judy Smith, spokeswoman for the U.S. Attorney's Office in Washington, declined to comment on the report Thursday by WRC-TV. But law enforcement sources told The Associated Press that the prosecutors had discussed the possibility of bringing a case against Barry in the Virgin Islands, where some of the alleged offenses took place. The sources, who spoke only on condition of anonymity, said no decision has been made on whether to proceed. In the Virgin Islands Thursday, a federal judge sentenced a figure in the Barry case to probation and community service for his conviction on drug charges. U.S. Attorney Jay Stephens has until Sept. 17 to decide whether to try Barry again on the 12 counts on which a District of Columbia jury failed to agree Aug. 10. That jury acquitted Barry on one misdemeanor count of cocaine possession and convicted him on a similar count. The judge declared a mistrial on the remaining counts _ three felony perjury counts and nine misdemeanor possession or conspiracy counts. Former city government employee Charles Lewis was a key witness against the mayor. Lewis, 50, a former Virgin Islands government employee, could have received a maximum 80-year prison term on his Virgin Islands conviction in April 1989 for possessing and selling crack cocaine. Instead, U.S. District Judge Stanley Brotman sentenced Lewis on Thursday to five years of probation during which he must perform 1,000 hours of community service and undergo periodic tests for drug use. The judge said Lewis had extensively cooperated with the Barry investigation. The U.S. attorney's office began to build its case against Barry in December 1988 after District of Columbia police called off an attempt to make an undercover drug buy from Lewis after finding that the mayor was in Lewis' hotel room.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Precede ABIDJAN
Report: Rebels Kill 200 Civilians in Liberia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with news agency report that Taylor's men have killed 200 people from countries that sent troops to end Liberia's civil war.
DOC.TEXT: Rebels have killed about 200 foreigners in Liberia whose governments contributed soldiers to a West African force sent to end the nation's civil war, the Ghana News Agency reported today. The news agency, which has a reporter with the West African force, quoted witnesses as saying the civilians, including many Ghanaians and Nigerians, were killed after the military force landed in Monrovia, Liberia's main port. The agency quoted unidentified Ghanaians who said they had escaped the attack by guerrillas loyal to rebel leader Charles Taylor, who has vehemently opposed intervention by the West African force. About 3,000 soldiers from Ghana, Nigeria, Guinea, Sierra Leone and Gambia arrived in Monrovia on Aug. 25 on troop transport ships under orders to end the eight-month tribal war in Liberia. The report suggested that the killings occurred after the force landed in Liberia but did not give a specific date. Taylor's fighters have attacked the force on several occasions. The news agency quoted Kweku Egyir, 52, a Ghanaian who has lived in Liberia since 1963, as saying Taylor's men were singling out Ghanaians and Nigerians because their countries' soldiers have inflicted many casualties on the rebels. Egyir was quoted as saying the rebels were able to identify the Ghanaians and Nigerias by their their accents and tribal scars. ``The marks on our faces are called identity cards in this country,'' he said. No other information was available on the reported civilian killings, and they could not immediately be independently verified.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: No Immediate Progress Reported in Perez de Cuellar Talks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 5 grafs to UPDATE with second session of talks beginning. Pickup 6th pvs, `A senior...'
DOC.TEXT: U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar and Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz met privately today but reported no immediate progress in defusing the explosive Persian Gulf crisis. They met for two hours at midday, then after a short break opened a second round of talks attended by their aides. ``I met with my friend, Tariq Aziz, and we discussed the present crisis,'' Perez de Cuellar told reporters at the end of the first session. Aziz, who stood next to the secretary-general, said he was happy ``to meet an old friend and we have confidence in him.'' He said they would provide details of their talks after the second round. The two officials know each other well from meetings during negotiations for a formal peace treaty at the end of the eight-year Iran-Iraq war. A senior Jordanian official, who had met with the U.N. chief before the talks with Aziz began, said there was a ``strong possibility'' that Perez de Cuellar will travel to Baghdad for talks on a settlement of the crisis. No such decision has been made, the official said. But the U.N. chief was prepared to fly to the Iraqi capital to meet President Saddam Hussein if the talks with Aziz fail to produce any significant progress. Aziz declared on arrival at Amman's airport that Iraq ``will achieve victory despite the international conspiracy against it.'' His defiant statement contrasted with the hopeful comments by the U.N. chief on his arrival the previous day. Perez de Cuellar said he believed ``Iraq is as eager as we all are to find a just and lasting solution of the problem. ``I can't understand anyone in the world prepared to sacrifice human lives,'' Perez de Cuellar said Thursday. In his arrival statement, Aziz said: ``Our struggle is a historic one and we have all undertaken it in honesty and manliness. Victory will be ours and the Arab nation's, God willing.'' He added said he would discuss ``all gulf issues'' with the U.N. official and that he was ``optimistic about the future of the Arab nation.'' Aziz also said Iraqi authorities will ``allow all Western women and children to leave Iraq as of Saturday.'' Saddam had announced on Tuesday that Western women and children held hostage in Iraq to fend off a potential U.S. attack could leave the country, but only a few have since been granted the necessary exit permits. When he arrived at Amman airport, Perez de Cuellar told reporters ``I am not a merchant to negotiate. I came here to discuss ways and means of finding a solution to the problem.'' He reiterated earlier statements that he was not in a position to ``make concessions'' on the requirement that Iraq implementat resolutions approved by the Security Council after the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. ``These are not my resolutions...I cannot make any concessions on these,'' he said. The resolutions demand that Iraq unconditionally withdraw from Kuwait and restore the deposed royal family. He welcomed as a ``good step'' Saddam's decision Tuesday to allow foreign women and children among those held hostage in Iraq to leave.
