Saddam's troops invaded Kuwait in a dispute over oil, land and money, then annexed the fallen kingdom. The invasion and the movement of Iraqi troops close to the Saudi Arabian border prompted the creation of a U.S-led multinational force to protect the kingdom against further Iraqi expansion.

DOC.HEAD: Gustav Stronger, But Is Expected To Bypass Bermuda
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Rewrites throughout to update with noon strength, position.
DOC.TEXT: Hurricane Gustav was over the Atlantic this morning with wind blowing at up to 110 mph but appeared certain to bypass Bermuda, the only land threatened by the storm system since last weekend, forcecasters said. ``We're expecting (Gustav) to take a turn towards the northeast'' during the day today, missing Bermuda altogether, said Daniel Petersen, hurricane specialist at the National Hurricane Center in suburban Coral Gables. Gustav, which weakened to 80 mph Wednesday, gained strength steadily since, but some decrease in strength was expected today, he said. At noon EDT, the hurricane's center was located near latitude 32.8 degrees north and longitude 56.8 west, or about 485 miles east of Bermuda. It was moving north at 18 mph. A tropical storm becomes a hurricane when winds reach 74 mph or more. The Atlantic hurricane season runs from June through November.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Rebels Kill 200 Civilians in Liberia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with additional news agency reports on killings, background on past attacks. Edits to tighten. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Rebels have killed about 200 foreigners in Liberia whose governments contributed soldiers to a West African force sent to end the nation's civil war, the Ghana News Agency reported today. The news agency, which has a reporter with the five-nation force, quoted witnesses as saying the civilians, including many Ghanaians and Nigerians, were killed after the military contingent landed in Monrovia, Liberia's main port. The agency quoted unidentified Ghanaians who said they escaped the attack by guerrillas loyal to rebel leader Charles Taylor, who has vehemently opposed intervention by the West African force. About 3,000 soldiers from Ghana, Nigeria, Guinea, Sierra Leone and Gambia arrived in Monrovia on Aug. 25 on troop transport ships under orders to end the eight-month tribal war. Taylor's fighters have attacked the force on several occasions. The news agency quoted a 36-year-old Ghanaian teacher, Kwasi Kwateng, as saying rebels attacked a community of 2,500 Ghanaians in Barnesville, about three miles from Monrovia's port. But it was not immediately clear how many caity of the 5,000 people estimated to have died in the war have been civilians. Diplomatic sources said today that the five-nation force seized control of Monrovia's major airfield and began to advance toward three beseiged embassies. The capture of the Spriggs Payne Airfield could allow flights of supplies and additional troops for the contingent, said the sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Soldiers at the airport today were trying to reach the Ghana, Nigeria and Guinea embassies on the city's outskirts in territory held by Taylor's men, said sources in touch with the regional forces by radio. Taylor claims his forces hold several thousand citizens of countries participating in the military force. ``What we are we doing right now is not unlike what other countries have had to do to protect the lives of citizens of countries involved in wars with other countries,'' Taylor told the British Broadcasting Corp. on Thursday in a telephone interview from Liberia. The rebel leader said his fighters have evacuated several thousand people from front-line areas to stop ``angry mobs of Liberians from killing them. It is for their security and for our security.'' U.S. Marines based on warships off Liberia have evacuated Americans and other foreigners from Monrovia and have deployed around the U.S. Embassy. However, U.S. forces have refused to intervene in the fighting. Meanwhile, a conference of opposition groups, churchmen and business leaders, meeting in Banjul, Gambia, was expected to make a recommendation on who should head any interim government, pending new elections. Leaders of the five-nation military force have said an interim government would be installed as soon as fighting ended. Taylor's forces invaded from neighboring Ivory Coast in December and advanced largely unchecked until they reached the outskirts of Monrovia. They have been unable to dislodge troops loyal to Doe. Johnson's rebels, who split with Taylor, have taken control of much of the capital. Johnson and Doe have agreed to a truce, and both support efforts to end the war. It is unclear what role Doe would play in an interim government.

DOC.HEAD: German Leaders Sign Final Unification Accord
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 4 grafs to ADD that the treaty is the final blueprint for unity framework. Pickup 4th graf, ```Today we...'
DOC.TEXT: German leaders met in a palace of German princes today and signed a treaty meant to reconcile the stark differences between their two nations just 33 days before they become one. The document was signed by West German Interior Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble and East Germany's top unity negotiator, Guenther Krause. Earlier, the cabinets of West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl and East German Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere formally approved the pact. The treaty is the final blueprint for the framework of a united nation, although it leaves many crucial issues to be decided by a united German government. ``Today we are fulfilling one of the last remaining hurdles to German unification,'' de Maiziere said moments before the pact was signed in a 17th century palace in East Berlin. The sweeping accord preserves East Germany's liberal abortion law, calls for a united Berlin to be the capital of the new nation, and guarantees some social programs for jobless East Germans. It gives Western investors first claim to East German property, a major development that economists say is necessary to revive the nation's shattered economy. The pact also allows East Germany to maintain some control over the 6 million files of the former Communist secret police, a potentially explosive compilation of sinister secrets from the nation's dark past. Overall, the treaty reconciles fundamental legal and political differences between two nations that followed vastly different paths after they were carved from the conquered Nazi empire. The signing ceremony was held in the stately Berlin Palace, the home of German crown princes who laid the foundation for the Prussian empire of the 18th century. Like Germany, the palace was destroyed during World War II and then rebuilt. The signing took place on the eve of 51st anniversary of World War II. On Sept. 1, 1939, Hitler's forces invaded Poland, and France and England declared the war that eventually split Germany. The German states will become one on Oct. 3, when East Germany's Parliament invokes a clause that will allow it to accede to the larger nation. Germans in both territories will then elect a common government on Dec. 2. That impending election date has created an enormous campaign battle between Kohl's conservative Christian Democrats and his main rival in the elections, the left-leaning Social Democrats. Key aspects of the treaty _ particularly the sharp differences between East Germany's liberal abortion law and West Germany's tough one _ were held up by debate that threatened the pact's passage. Although such a treaty was not necessary for German unification, failure to approve it would have meant that West German laws would have become automatically the law of a greater German land. The treaty was considered an important psychological necessity for an East German nation that has been buffeted by enormous political and economic change in less than a year, and which is about to lose its sovereignty and its identity. The treaty is a companion piece to the economic pact that merged the currencies and economies of the German states on July 1, when East Germany formally became a free market after four decades of socialism. East German joblessness since then has skyrocketed as factories collapse in the face of Western competition. The document includes an important provision for the distribution of East German property. Tens of thousands of West Germans who fled what is now East Germany after the Soviet invasion of World War II have filed claims on their former property. A prolonged process is planned to determine the validity of those claims on an individual basis. The uncertainty of those many claims _ and who will be the potential owner of much East German property _ has been blamed for inhibiting Western investment needed to provide jobs and replace the dying sectors of the East German economy. Under a previous agreement, West Germans are allowed to claim property in East Germany that was seized from their families by the Communists or lost when they fled to the West. Under the treaty signed today, anyone who buys land in East Germany for development purposes is protected from claims by previous owners or their heirs. There will be a system worked out later to compensate people who don't get their land back because it is being developed commercially or because their claim would displace people living there. The pact also includes a compromise on the volatile abortion question. East Germany's permissive law will remain in effect until a new German government passes a law for both nations in 1992. It also settles, at least for now, a dispute between the two Germanys over the disposition of the files compiled by the notorious secret police, which kept sensitive information about millions of people, some of them now leaders in the democratic government. East Germany and West Germany both wanted control of the files, a gold mine of espionage and terrorist intelligence. Under the compromise, the united Parliament will make the decision. In the meantime, the files will temporarily remain in what is now East Germany under the custody of a West German official to be chosen by East Germany.

DOC.HEAD: House-Buying Power Falls Slightly; Greater Decline Expected
DOC.TEXT: The typical American family's ability to buy a house fell slightly in July and is expected to drop substantially in August because of rising mortgage rates linked to the Persian Gulf crisis, a real estate trade group said Friday. The National Association of Realtors said its housing affordability index declined from 102.9 in June to 102.3 last month. That means a family with a median income of $34,358 had 102.3 percent of the income needed to buy a median-priced existing home costing $98,400. The median income was $34,250 in June, while the median price was $97,500. The median means half of the families earn more and half earn less, or that half of the houses sell for more and half for less. However, Realtors President Norman D. Flynn said mortgage rate increases resulting from developments in the Middle East will cause a substantial loss in housing affordability in August. ``Home buyers in America will get hit by Iraq's invasion of Kuwait,'' he said. ``First-time buyers will get hit hardest. Unfortunately, entry-level buyers who might have just qualified to purchase a home in June or July may now find themselves priced out of the market.'' Although the median price rose $900 in July, the index decline was offset by a decrease in the interest rate used to calculate the index and the $108 gain in median family income. The rate, a composite of fixed-rate and adjustable-rate mortgages, edged down from 10.16 percent to 10.15 percent in July. The changes resulted in a $6 increase in the monthly mortgage payment, to $700. The July median income exceeded the $33,579 needed to qualify for a median-priced home. A family earning that amount actually would qualify to buy a home priced at $100,500 using conventional financing covering 80 percent of the cost. Under July's affordability conditions, a family earning $20,000 would have sufficient income to qualify for a $58,500 home using a $46,800 loan. A family earning $30,000 would qualify for an $87,800 home with an 80 percent loan. A family earning $40,000 would have sufficient income for a $117,000 home and a family with $50,000 income would qualify for a $146,300 home.

DOC.HEAD: Poland Establishes Peace Prize
DOC.TEXT: A committee to award a Polish peace prize has established an office with Solidarity leader and Nobel Peace prize winner Lech Walesa as its chairman. ``In reference to the Polish tradition of tolerance, reflected in Solidarity's ethics, and in view of the contemporary threats stemming from nationalism and chauvinism, we are establishing a Polish Peace Prize,'' Walesa's committee said in a statement. The statement apparently referred to a recent surfacing of nationalism and anti-Semitism in Europe. The Polish Peace Committee will be based in Lublin, in southeastern Poland. It is composed of two groups: the first, headed by former U.S. National Security Adviser Zbigniew Brzezinski, will promote protection of religious and ethnic peace and the other, headed by Nobel Literature laureate Czeslaw Milosz, will foster efforts to achieve unity in Europe.

DOC.HEAD: East Germany's Sorbs Get Special Place in New Treaty
With AM-Germany-Unification, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: An obscure group of Slavic-speakers who escaped centuries of repression in their forested homeland have earned a special place in the German unification treaty signed Friday. The Sorbs, who number about 100,000 and live in East Germany's Spree Forest, asked for legal protection of their unique culture and got it. ``The preservation and continuation of Sorb culture and of Sorb traditions will be guaranteed. Members of the Sorb people have the freedom to preserve their language in public life,'' states one part of the treaty. The Sorbs are native residents of a remote swath of East Germany stretching 56 miles north of the Czechoslovak border. Centuries ago their marshy, wooded homeland was called Lusatia. They are colorful in customs and in dress. The traditional way for Sorbs to get to their fields or visit neighboring villages is in long, thin wooden boats that are pushed with a pole along small waterways crisscrossing the Spree Forest. Many Sorbs are farmers, but eel-fishing is also a customary livelihood. The Sorbs withstood German invasions in the sixth, eighth, 10th and 12th centuries. Ultimately, German invaders swallowed up their homeland, but not their customs until Adolf Hitler ordered their language not be spoken. East Germany's Communist rulers generally allowed the Sorbs to preserve their ways and actually helped the Sorb culture thrive by virtually sealing off much of East Germany from Western influences. Now, with East Germany opened up to the outside world and Westerners flooding in, the Sorbs worry their unique traditions could be endangered.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutor, Former State Senator Gunned Down
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf, `Police early...', to UPDATE with arrest.
DOC.TEXT: A prosecutor out in a Catholic environment and being part of our religious education curriculum we can assist Sarabeth in forming her conscience according to Catholic teaching. That's what we're all about,'' Ms. Doyle said. Ms. Eason drew the attention of Catholic officials four years ago after she was interviewed on television about her opinion of parental notification when a teen-ager seeks an abortion. Her name also appeared in a local newspaper advertisement supporting the 1973 U.S. Supreme Court decision legalizing abortion. She was about to enter the sixth grade when the Rev. Richard Miller told Mrs. Eason the girl would have to write a letter renouncing her views on abortion or be expelled. Ms. Eason refused and was expelled. She enrolled in Maumee Valley County Day School, a private, non-sectarian institution. Mrs. Eason said she sent her daughter to the Catholic school because she could no longer afford to send her to Maumee Valley and preferred not to send her to a public school.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Sets New Conditions For Foreigner Release
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 1 grafs after 3rd, `This is...' to UPDATE with spokesman saying linkage with Iraqis in Europe not a condition. Pickup 4th, `Britain's...'
DOC.TEXT: Iraq said today it was sending more foreign men to potential military targets and linked the release of some Western women and children to the return of Iraqis stranded outside the country. Iraqi government spokesman Naji al-Hadithi said more than 200 foreigners were waiting to leave for London and Paris on Iraq Airways. He said Iraq wanted the same planes used to bring back an unspecified number of Iraqis stranded in the two capitals by the ``brutal Amercican sanctions.'' ``This is a humanitarian request, and we hope the two governments will reply quickly and positively,'' al-Hadithi said at a news conference. Later, al-Hadithi said meeting the request was not a precondition to Iraq's allowing foreign women and children to leave the country. But if it is not met, he said, they might have to leave by land. Britain's Foreign Office said it would have no objection to Iraqis returning to Baghdad aboard the flights. ``We would have no objection to that. If a plane is coming out here with British nationals on it, and is going back to empty to Baghdad, Iraqi nationals want to go on it, of course they can go,'' a Foreign Office spokesman said. ``We do not have hostages. Any Iraqi in this country is free to leave,'' said the spokesman, speaking on condition of anonymity. Al-Hadithi said the foreign women and children now awaiting departure include 123 Britons, 66 Japanese, 19 French, 14 Americans, two Australians and four of unspecified nationalities. He said an unspecified number of women and children from other countries that he did not name were ``in principle'' free to leave immediately. He said their governments had to make arrangements for their departure. However, he said the foreign men still held in Iraq have been taken to potential military targets all over the country. ``Every place, every town that has a vital installation will host our guests,'' he said. ``We're relocating the foreign men all over the country at airports, air bases, military bases, industrial plants, communications centers, power centers and oil refineries _ wherever Iraq considers it has a vital installation, one exposed to the American threat in Saudi Arabia.'' The spokesman did not say how many foreigners were being taken to installations. Earlier today, a few foreigners were able to leave Iraq. Nineteen Italians arrived safely in Jordan, and the Finnish Foreign Ministry said today that three Finnish women left Iraq for Turkey. In Athens, a government spokesman said five Greek women and children were expected to leave Iraq on a flight from Baghdad. Sweden's Foreign Ministry said today that the 50 Swedish women and children stranded in Iraq have received exit permits and may leave Baghdad on Saturday. Spokeswoman Anita Matejovsky said citizens from Denmark, Norway, Finland and Iceland might travel with the Swedish group in a Nordic airlift. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's announcement Tuesday said the women and children would be allowed to leave starting Wednesday. Western governments complained Thursday that an undue amount of paperwork was required for the exit visas. There was no immediate word on the hundreds of American women and children waiting to leave. Margaret Tutwiler, a State Department spokesman, said there are about 500 American women in Kuwait as well as 410 children under age 18. She indicated the number of women and children in Iraq is less than 100. Italian Ambassador Franco Dacourtan said the 13 Italian women and six children were in good health and would be flown to Rome on Saturday. The Italian group made a seven-hour road journey across the Iraqi desert to the Jordanian border outpost of Ruweishid, and then continued on to Amman, 150 miles to the southwest. About 21,000 Westerners, including 3,000 Americans, were in Kuwait when Iraq invaded on Aug. 2. An unknown number escaped, mostly into Saudi Arabia. But some others were taken to Baghdad, and Saddam threatened to use them as human shields to protect Iraqi installations against possible attack. The Baghdad government said 28 foreign ``guests'' had opted to stay. Diplomats in the Iraqi capital said they were mostly those with government contracts or businesses in Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: Police Escort Garbage Trucks in `War' Linked to Mafia
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Retransmitting a0575 to delete garble.
DOC.TEXT: Police have taken to escorting garbage trucks in the Naples area because of what they say appears to be a Mafia-style campaign to intimidate private collectors into paying protection money. Officials in the anti-terrorist police squad in Naples said Friday they were investigating a string of attacks to see if they are linked to the Camorra, a crime syndicate based in the Naples area that is compared to the Sicilian Mafia. On Thursday, two hooded youths on a motorcycle stopped a garbage truck at gunpoint in Portici, a township on the outskirts of Naples. The youths forced the driver and his partner to leave the truck and shot eight times at it, damaging the windshield and hood. They youths sped away, shouting threats at the trash collecting company. Recent attacks on trash collection firms include an armed robbery of two garbage men on duty and the shooting at another truck. A Naples magistrate has been investigating how the city awards contracts to trash collectors to see if the Camorra has influenced contract bidding.

DOC.HEAD: Express Passenger Train Hit By Robbers
DOC.TEXT: Bandits pulled the emergency brake on a high-speed express train en route from Prague, Czechoslovakia to Munich on Friday, sprayed tear gas and robbed the passengers, officials said. The West German federal railroad office in Munich said several robbers were involved in the attack between Prague and Pilsen in Czechoslovakia. Several passengers were injured when tear gas was used in the robbery, the statement said. It did not say how many people were aboard.

DOC.HEAD: Health Center to be Named After Challenger Astronaut
DOC.TEXT: A proposed $40 million women's health center will be named after an Akron native who died in the 1986 explosion of the space shuttle Challenger, builders said. The Judith A. Resnik Women's Health Center will provide services such as radiation therapy, gynecological examinations and in-vitro fertilization to women of all ages, said Trudy Kapper, spokeswoman for the Summa Corp., which will build the center. Ms. Resnik, the second woman astronaut in the space program, was an outstanding student and had a biomedical fellowship at the National Institutes of Health, Ms. Kapper said Friday. ``If you look at her history and values, she strove for excellence.'' The center, to be built next to Akron's St. Thomas Medical Center, is part of a $79 million expansion and renovation project announced this month by Summa, a holding company created by the hospital.

DOC.HEAD: Author Edmund G. Love Dies
DOC.TEXT: Edmund G. Love, a novelist and author of the book on which the Broadway musical ``Subways Are for Sleeping'' was based, has died. He was 78. Love died Thursday at St. Joseph Hospital after suffering a heart attack at his Flint apartment. He published about 20 books, and his writings appeared in many anthologies and textbooks on writing. ``Subways Are For Sleeping'' was adapted from Love's 1957 book of the same title about experiences sleeping on New York subway trains when he couldn't afford lodging. Love also was known for ``The Situation in Flushing,'' a 1965 book about a boy's love of trains in the early 1900s. The book was excerpted in The Saturday Evening Post. ``Hanging On,'' about how his family survived the Depression in Flint, has been used in University of Michigan classes on American history. One of his stories inspired the feature film ``Destination: Gobi.'' After Army service during World War II, Love headed a team that wrote military histories of the war in the Pacific Theater and then became a freelance writer. Survivors include his wife, Ann; a son and four grandchildren. Mrs. Love said her husband didn't want a funeral. Burial arrangements were incomplete.

DOC.HEAD: Italy to Require Visas For Turks, North Africans
DOC.TEXT: Italy will start requiring visas for Turks and citizens of several North African countries next Monday under a law intended to limit immigration, the Foreign Ministry said. Algerians, Maroccans, Mauritanians, Tunisians and Turks will all have to have visas, the ministry said. In April, Italy imposed visa requirements on citizens of Senegal and Gambia. Italy gets an estimated 100,000 illegal immigrants a year. The government passed a law last spring aimed at curbing the rise in the immigrant population and providing benefits to immigrants who declared their presence.

DOC.HEAD: Proposal Lost in Mail Amid Rush to Gulf Duty
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: RHEIN-MAIN AIR BASE, West Germany (AP) _ Somewhere out there is a woman named Kathy who has an important question to answer. And somewhere, probably in Saudia Arabia, there's a U.S. soldier hoping it will be yes. But a postcard with the question for Kathy is stuck at Rhein-Main Air Base in West Germany. The soldier, whose name appears to be Chris, had to rush away just he was scribbling her a proposal, Stars and Stripes newspaper said Friday. ``He slapped a stamp on the postcard, handed it to a woman working at the store where he bought it and asked her to mail it for him,'' the newspaper said. Then he ran away. He was gone before the woman could tell him there was no address on the card. Just a message that said: ``Hello, sweetheart! I love you! ``Just a little note to say howdy and let you know I'm OK. So, now you know one of the spots I stopped at on my way to this little adventure. ``How about getting engaged when I get home? I'm serious and I'll write more later. Take care!'' Then he wrote ``I love you'' again, scratched his name on the card and scurried to catch his flight. ``Kathy, we think you should say yes,'' Stars and Stripes wrote.

DOC.HEAD: You Could Look it Up _ Encyclopedia Sellers Say Image Has Improved
DOC.TEXT: The World Book Encyclopedia devotes six pages to the topic of salesmanship, but the company's sales force devote their lives. About 2,000 World Book sellers are in town this week, hearing pep talks on how to move the weighty volumes and trying to dispel some myths about the image of door-to-door salespeople. ``They don't consider themselves salespeople, though they are some of the most dynamic salespeople anywhere,'' Vito Mazza, a World Book salesman from New York City, said during a break Thursday at the company's annual conference. ``They consider themselves educators, counselors. And perception is reality.'' Mazza said he knows firsthand the misconceptions about his profession. When he started with World Book 17 years ago, Mazza said, his job choice made his father uncomfortable. ``My father would tell people, `He's going to be a teacher _ but he's selling World Book encyclopedias right now,''' Mazza said. Though they occasionally have to battle the stereotype of the high-pressure door-to-door salesman, the World Book sellers, who call themselves ``World Bookers,'' appear to have no problem with self-image. Their four-day meeting, which concludes Saturday, is a mix of feel-good speeches, award presentations and sales tips that hammer home the idea that these people are not just selling books _ they're contributing to the education of the world. They also enjoy themselves. Diana Bauer, a Baltimore resident who has sold World Books for 12 years, said she enjoys door-to-door selling, known in the trade as ``cold calling.'' ``It's a lot of fun,'' Ms. Bauer said. ``You don't know who's on the other side of that door. It's a wonderful opportunity to practice your craft.''

DOC.HEAD: Barr Named London News Editor
DOC.TEXT: Robert Barr has been appointed as news editor for The Associated Press in London, succeeding Marcus Eliason, whose promotion to chief of bureau in Jerusalem was announced earlier. Barr, 43, a newsman on the London staff since 1988, joined the AP in 1971 in the Honolulu bureau. He transferred to New York in 1977, first to World Services, and then to the General Desk, where he worked as supervisor before moving to London. He is a native of Denver and a graduate of the University of Colorado.

DOC.HEAD: 10 Miners Killed in Underground Blast
DOC.TEXT: An explosion in an underground mine shaft Friday killed 10 miners and injured 20, the Anglo American Corp. mining company said. The blast occurred more than a mile underground at the President Steyn gold mine near Welkom, about 110 miles southwest of Johannesburg. Anglo American said in a statement that a preliminary investigation indicated an electrical fault ignited explosives in the shaft.

DOC.HEAD: Man Parties Too Hard, Wakes up in Garbage Truck
DOC.TEXT: He remembers leaving the bar. He remembers drinking the six tequila slammers and any number of rum colas. But he doesn't have a clue as to how he got mashed in with a ton of trash in the back of a garbage truck. ``I'm not sure if I put myself in there or if I was put in there,'' the unidentified, 26-year-old man told the Grand Rapids Press on Thursday, apparently after passing the night in the garbage truck. Don Kraai, who drives the truck for Pete's Disposal Inc., discovered his passenger during his rounds on the morning after the night before. He became disconcerted when he heard a knocking sound in the trash compartment. ``I pounded the truck and it banged back at me,'' Kraai said. After calling a dispatcher, Kraai began emptying the truck by hand and found the moaning man. ``He was just mixed in there with bags of trash,'' Kraai said. ``It looked kind of weird.'' Thomas Boss, a fire department battalion chief, said the man likely would have been killed had he crawled into a larger truck, where the packing mechanism is more powerful. Peter Edema, owner of Pete's Disposal, said it was a good thing Kraai heard the man when he did. ``Otherwise, he'd be in the incinerator.'' ``I thought I was going to die,'' the man said. He said he'd been awake for about 30 minutes before his rescue, but was unable to get the driver's attention. ``I have bumps and bruises, but I'm lucky to be alive.'' After firefighters arrived, the man was taken to Blodgett Memorial Medical Center, where he was treated and discharged.

DOC.HEAD: 14 Die as Boat Sinks in Bangladeshi River
DOC.TEXT: A boat sank in the Arilkha river in southwestern Bangladesh, killing 14 passengers, police said Friday. Police at Madaripur, the site of Wednesday's accident, said 20 passengers swam ashore. Madaripur is 45 miles southwest of Dhaka. The bodies of five children and nine men have been found, said a police official who was contacted by telephone. The official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the boat was carrying at least 10 people more than its capacity.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Phones Leaders of Britain, France and Saudi Arabia
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS new grafs 21-22, bgng, Brady will... to UPDATE with information on Brady schedule, picks up 21st graf pvs, Japan announced ...
DOC.TEXT: President Bush today lobbied allies to help pick up the tab for the Persian Gulf buildup, making phone calls to leaders of Saudi Arabia, Britain and France. Sources said some allies and congressmen were pressuring the White House to move militarily against Saddam Hussein. These administration sources said the pressure for a military move was building from various quarters, which they declined to identify beyond describing them as allies and members of Congress. But they said the pressure by no means constituted a consensus. The sources said Bush continued to weigh all options, but at this point there was no clearcut case to be made for a U.S. attack in the absence of a new provocation. The sources spoke on condition they not be identified. The administration refused to comment publicly on prospects for military action. Meanwhile, the U.S. military presence in the waters surrounding Iraq and on the ground in Saudi Arabia grows daily. White House spokesman Roman Popadiuk dismissed news reports suggesting growing pressure for a military strike as ``uninformed speculation.'' Bush spoke to Saudi Arabia's King Fahd, British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and French President Francois Mitterrand in a series of morning phone calls, presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said in a statement. ``All the leaders agreed to stay in close communication regarding each other's efforts in the Persian Gulf,'' Fitzwater said. The president is seeking international donations to help pay for preparations for a possible war in the gulf with a ``burdensharing'' plan he announced on Thursday. ``All the leaders emphasized the need for continued cooperative efforts to maintain the international community's steadfast stand against the Iraqi aggression in Kuwait,'' the written White House statement said. The Washington Times today quoted sources as saying some U.S. allies fear that anything less than crushing Iraqi military forces would leave Baghdad's conventional, chemical and nuclear weapons intact and would put Saudi Arabia and the smaller Gulf nations at Iraq's mercy once U.S. and other foreign troops are withdrawn. ``There is no doubt that the Saudis and the Israelis fear that the United States will accept a deal that leaves a wounded rather than a defeated tiger in place in Baghdad,'' the newspaper said it was told by a ``well-placed'' U.S. source. The Times quoted its sources as saying Turkey, the exiled Kuwaiti government, the United Arab Emirates, Qatar, Bahrain and Oman were among the nations urging the United States to use force to resolve the crisis. Sen. Patrick Leahy said today the United States should not depend on other countries to pay for its massive military deployment but should consider higher taxes instead. ``I don't want to leave any impression in the world that we pay for our soldiers and our sailors, if we send them into another part of the world, only through another country's money,'' the Vermont Democrat said on NBC-TV's ``Today'' show. ``This is not a rent military. It's not a mercenary force.'' Separate House and Senate delegations left Andrews Air Force Base today for five-day visits to the troubled region. Both groups planned to meet with U.S. troops and their commanders and with government leaders in Saudi Arabia and Egypt. The United States wants to try to raise enough money to cover the $1-billion-per-month cost of the U.S. military buildup in the region, an administration official said. ``It is important that the considerable burden of the effort be shared by those being defended and those who benefit from the free flow of oil,'' Bush said. Bush announced that he is seeking money for Egypt, Turkey and Jordan _ which are suffering severe economic effects from the trade embargo with Iraq and from a flood of refugees _ while also soliciting contributions for U.S. military costs. Bush also talked by phone with West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak, United Arab Emirates President Sheik Zayed bin Sultan al-Nahyan, Turkish President Turgut Ozal and the Kuwaiti emir, Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, said Fitzwater. The calls were intended to coordinate the countries' efforts as Bush prepares to dispatch Secretary of State James A. Baker III, Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady and other officials to the Persian Gulf, Europe and Asia. They are to work on signing up U.S. friends for what Bush called an ``action plan'' to round up financial aid. Brady will leave next week on a trip which will take him to London, Paris, Seoul, South Korea, and Tokyo, according to an administration source who spoke on condition that he not be named. The source said that Brady's schedule called for him to meet with officials from Europe to the Far East within a five-day time period, returning to Washington by Sept. 8. Japan announced Thursday that it would contribute $1 billion in assistance, and some other countries have indicated a willingness to make donations. Leahy said the U.S. could pay for its role in the Persian Gulf crisis in one of three ways: by adding the cost to the ever-expanding budget deficit, by cutting other programs, or by ``paying as you go,'' the method the lawmaker said he preferred. ``I don't like to vote for taxes ... but I think we ought to be honest about what we're doing,'' he said. Twenty-two countries are involved in the military effort against Iraq. About 60,000 U.S. combat troops have moved to battle stations in the gulf in the past three weeks and their number is expected to reach 100,000 soon. Bush told reporters n Washington that his analysts have a hard time determining whether the standoff with Saddam Hussein over the Iraqi president's invasion of Kuwait will end up in a shooting war. ``It's so hard to answer that question because of the unpredictable nature of Saddam Hussein himself,'' Bush said at a White House news conference.

DOC.HEAD: Moslems Burn Bush Effigy to Condemn U.S. Force in Gulf
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of Moslems emerged from their weekly prayers at India's largest mosque Friday and burned an effigy of President Bush to protest the American presence in the Persian Gulf. A cloth-and-stick effigy decorated with two American flags and ``Bush'' written across its face was set on fire by Moslem youths outside the Jama Masjid, or the Jama mosque. ``Down with America!'' and ``Long live Arab unity!'' the men screamed as they pounded the effigy with fists and sticks. Then it was lit by leaders of the All India Muslim Youth and Students' Council, the group that organized the protest. The council ``fully supports the Iraqi President Saddam Hussein and people of Iraq in their struggle against America and Israel,'' its president, Mohammad Younus Siddiqui, said. His speech was greeted with wild cheers by about 200 demonstrators surrounding the burning effigy. In a separate statement, the council condemned the Saudi rulers for ``inviting the unholy Americans and Jews on the holy land.'' The statement did not specifically comment on Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: ``Today'' co-anchor Joe Garagiola will be off the NBC show for four weeks to have elective surgery for a problem that is ``not life-theatening,'' a spokeswoman for the show said Friday. Garagiola, 64, declined to disclose the nature of the surgery, said spokeswoman Mary Neagoy, and his medical leave from the program starts Tuesday. After changes that led to Jane Pauley's exit from ``Today'' after 13 years, NBC hired Garagiola, a former ``Today'' co-host, to return to the show as a third co-anchor with Deborah Norville and Bryant Gumbel. The gregarious former baseball catcher returned to the show in June, and has been appearing on it on Tuesdays through Thursdays.

Federal marshals waited for the show to be over before giving a real show stopper to country singer David Allen Coe, picking him clean down to his earring. The marshals Wednesday night confiscated Coe's guitar, $150 in cash, his silver and turquoise belt and some jewelry, including the earring, to help satisfy a 1988 court judgment against him from Florida. ``He was very cooperative,'' said Don Benson, chief deputy marshal. ``We had no problems out of him.'' Coe, who lives in Missouri, was sued for breach of contract on a lease he had guaranteed on a building in Florida, said Herbert Moncier, the plaintiffs' attorney. The building apparently was owned by a company in which Coe has part interest, Moncier said. The judgment is about $152,000 including interest. Benson said the marshals waited for the end of Coe's show at the nightclub in the World's Fair Park before they moved in. The nightclub was ``really rocking. They were dancing on the tables,'' Moncier said. ``We heard he put on a good show,'' Benson added.

Singer-songwriter Harry Nilsson pleaded innocent to misdemeanor counts of drunken driving and driving without proper insurance. The Grammy-winning singer of ``Everybody's Talkin' '' and ``Without You'' entered the pleas Thursday in Municipal Court. A hearing was scheduled for Sept. 26. Nilsson, 49, was stopped by the California Highway Patrol at 3:40 a.m. July 6. Authorities said his blood alcohol level was three times the legal limit of 0.8 percent. Nilsson, whose real name is Harry Edward Nelson III, won the male pop vocalist Grammy in 1972 for ``Without You'' and he sang ``Everybody's Talkin','' the theme from the Oscar-winning film ``Midnight Cowboy.''

Former ABC News correspondent Sylvia Chase says she will return to the network in New York as a correspondent for ``Prime Time Live,'' the magazine show anchored by Sam Donaldson and Diane Sawyer. She said her interest in returning to reporting was sparked by last year's events in Tiananmen Square and later, the reunification of Germany. ``I felt almost this pain of wanting to be involved as a reporter every morning when I picked up The New York Times,'' said Chase, 52, who came to KRON-TV about five years ago from eight years on ABC's news program ``20-20.'' Though no specific dates were given in her announcement Thursday, Chase is expected to leave her job as 6 p.m. news co-anchor at KRON this fall. Last year, KRON won the broadcasting's prestigious Peabody Award for Chase's report on homeless children.

Four-year-old Wade Cowper was really enjoying his first overnight camping trip with his dad, Gov. Steve Cowper, until they got to the part about the bears. The two camped on a canal north of Juneau on Wednesday night to celebrate Wade's birthday. They pitched a tent, built a fire and cooked hot dogs. When Cowper wouldn't let his son take a hot dog into the tent, Wade asked why. Southeast Alaska is bear country, Cowper explained, and bears sometimes take an interest in food kept in tents. ``He wanted to go home right then and there,'' Cowper said Thursday. ``He said he was scared of bears and he didn't want to be in that tent with bears, and he was going home. ``So I told him, `Look, don't worry. The bears are not going to be around.'' Wade toughed out, but there were some anxious moments before he fell asleep. ``Every time there was a noise you could see his eyes pop open like saucers, but he was all right,'' Cowper said. Thursday morning, Cowper crawled outside and looked down onto the beach below the bluff where they had staked their tent. And there was a black bear. ``I told him it was there and to come look at him, but he wouldn't come out of the tent,'' Cowper said. ``He never did see the bear.''

DOC.HEAD: Opposition Rally Dispersed by Force
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Leads with 3 grafs to update with protesters allowed to leave embassy courtyard. Pickup 4th graf, `Some of...
DOC.TEXT: Security forces charged opposition party marchers Friday, clubbing the crowd with batons and firing tear gas to break up a rally near the residence of President Felix Houphouet-Boigny. Several hundred demonstrators briefly sought refuge in the courtyard of the French Embassy, climbing its walls to escape police. French Ambassador Michel Dupuch spoke with authorities who permitted him to escort the demonstrators out of the embassy grounds without incident. At least five people suffered minor injuries when the demonstration was dispersed, witnesses said. Some of the marchers shouted for the resignation of Houphouet-Boigny, who has ruled this West African nation since independence from France in 1960. Defense Minister Jean Konan Banny had issued a warning Thursday that security forces would ``use all necessary measures'' to prevent the opposition parties from threatening public order. The rally occurred four days before the scheduled reopening of public schools, which were closed in mid-term in April after students and teachers joined demonstrations demanding the legalization of opposition parties. Ivory Coast, once considered the economic showcase of sub-Saharan Africa, has been experiencing grave economic problems. The over-valuation of the French-backed West African franc has made its products too expensive to compete with other countries. Tax rates are among the highest in the world. Attempts to raise taxes even more and cut government pay checks earlier this year sparked the worst wave of unrest since independence. Many government workers, including police officers, firefighters, soldiers and customs agents, went on strike. Houphouet-Boigny was forced to withdraw some austerity measures and grant demands to permit opposition parties to form. Though the parties were legalized, they say their efforts to hold public meetings have often been blocked by government officials. Houphouet-Boigny also has been criticized for construction of a Roman Catholic basilica in his native town of Yamossoukro. The government says the basilica cost about $133 million and was paid for from Houphouet-Boigny's personal funds. Pope John Paul II is to consecrate the basilica Sept. 10.

DOC.HEAD: Police Say No Prime Suspect; Bond Set at $1 Million For Arrested Student
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 12 grafs to UPDATE with bond set for college student at $1 million, police sealing his Gainesville apartment, funerals under way. Picks up 11th graf, `On Thursday....'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MH1
DOC.TEXT: Bond was set at $1 million today for a University of Florida student charged in an assault in another county. But police insisted they didn't have a prime suspect in the slayings of five college students. Police in Gainesville today sealed an apartment near the University of Florida. Neighbors identified the apartment as that of Edward Lewis Humphrey, an 18-year-old freshman. Humphrey was arrested Thursday at the home of his 79-year-old grandmother in Indialantic, 180 miles to the southeast. He was charged with aggravated battery on a person over 65. Brevard Circuit Judge Dean Moxley today set bond at $1 million. Sheriff's spokeswoman Joan Heller wouldn't comment on the high bond, saying the case was being directed by the Florida Department of Law Enforcement, a state investigation agency. About 600 law enforcement officials are involved in a hunt for the killer, who investigators have said is a ``methodical maniac'' with a sick grudge against petite brunettes with shoulder-length hair. The victims _ students at either the University of Florida or Santa Fe Community College _ were stabbed to death in off-campus apartments in three attacks discovered since Sunday. Police said three of the four women were mutilated. Alachua County Sheriff's Lt. Spencer Mann emphasized today that ``at this particular time, we continue to have a pool of suspects ... to say that we have a prime suspect or prime two suspects or three suspects is very premature.'' Police Lt. Sadie Darnell said today there had been ``no significant'' developments in the investigation. Humphrey reportedly once lived in the Gatorwood apartment complex where the latest two victims were found Tuesday and he left Gainesville on Wednesday. Investigators interviewed Humphrey on Thursday, Brevard authorities said today. Humphrey ``appears to be a suspect in some pretty serious crimes in Alachua (County),'' said Randy Moore, an assistant public defender in Brevard County. Moore did not elaborate. Funerals were being held today for four of the victims in their hometowns. They are Christina Powell, 17, of Jacksonville; Christa Hoyt, 18, of Newberry; Tracy Paules, 23, of Coral Gables; and Manuel Taboada, 23, of Miami. On Thursday, more that a thousand friends and family members gathered at a Pompano Beach church to mourn Miss Powell's roommate, 18-year-old Sonja Larson. ``It is so untimely that one so young, made of all the dreams she was made of, would be taken from us,'' said the Rev. Ken Smith, pastor of the First Baptist Church. Police were interviewing possible suspects already in custody and checking out others who aren't, including a man sought for a gory slashing in Ohio earlier this month, said Darnell. The Miami Herald reported today that investigators suspect the killer is a white man in his late 20s to early 30s. The newspaper, quoting unidentified sources, said the preliminary profile drawn up by investigators also concludes that the killer may have law enforcement or health care ties, such as a job as a security guard or hospital orderly, who likely frequents student hangouts. The Gainesville Sun reported today that authorities were eager to find a man identified as Warren Virgil Tinch, wanted for the stabbing death and mutilation of Phyllis Elam, a 52-year-old woman from Middletown, Ohio. Elam's body was found in woods near her home, her face stabbed so many times she was identifiable only through dental records. ``He (Tinch) is a possible suspect. Where he fits in on the hierarchy of suspects, I don't know,'' Darnell said. Edwin Boldt, a spokesman for the Cincinnati FBI office, said any connection between Tinch and the Florida slayings was ``definitely a long shot.'' Witnesses allegedly spotted Tinch, 58, of Franklin, Ohio, in Gainesville and nearby Ocala about a week before the murders, the newspaper reported. He allegedly stole vehicles from car dealerships in the towns on Aug. 16 and Aug. 17. Investigators were sent to Bartow in central Florida, where the Polk County Sheriff's Department was holding a man arrested for burglary who discussed the killings after turning himself in to police. But spokeswoman Lynn Breidenbach said he could have learned the information from news reports. Authorities also said they interviewed men in Polk and Hernando counties, then dismissed both as suspects. The killings have released a wave of fear in this college town, exacerbated by published reports that the killer stole flesh from some of the mutilated victims and placed a decapitated victim's head on a shelf. Police have given few details about the mutilations. A 24-hour rumor-control hot line at the Alachua County Crisis Center has racked up more than 4,000 calls since Monday. Many students left town early for the Labor Day weekend, but University of Florida President John Lombardi asserted that things were returning to normal. School officials said the frightened departure of some hundreds of students had little impact on the student body of 34,000 in its opening week of classes. Other state universities said they were getting inquiries about transfers.

DOC.HEAD: General: Iraqi Invasion `International Rape'
LaserPhotos NY20, DHA3
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The commander of U.S. forces in the Persian Gulf described the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait as ``international rape'' Friday and said war can be averted if Iraqi troops stay out of Saudi Arabia. Calling Iraqi generals ``a bunch of thugs,'' Army Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf also said he could not let the fate of hostages in Iraq affect his strategy. ``I am just as concerned as everyone else about the hostages, but I am planning a military campaign and I can't concern myself with the hostages. That's the honest answer,'' said the four-star general, who arrived in Saudi Arabia this week to set up military headquarters. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein has kept about 21,000 Westerners _ including 3,000 Americans and 4,500 Britons _ from leaving the country. The United States and other Western governments have accused the Iraqi leader of using the foreigners as ``human shields'' against attack. Schwarzkopf, a hulking man known to aides as ``The Bear,'' met with reporters following a tour of forward troop positions and port facilities. He said the U.S. units were well-equipped and prepared to repel any Iraqi attack and protect themselves from chemical weapons. ``I am confident of our ability to defend right now,'' Schwarzkopf said. ``Nothing is ever 100 percent guaranteed, but if the Iraqis are dumb enough to attack, they are going to pay a terrible price.'' He added, ``If the Iraqis use chemical weapons, they'll pay for it big time.'' It was Schwarzkopf's first visit to the troops since moving the regional military Central Command headquarters from MacDill Air Force Base near Tampa, Fla., to the Saudi capital of Riyadh. The command was established in 1983 to be responsible for U.S. military affairs in 19 countries in the Middle East, southwest Asia and northeast Africa. It was based in the United States because no nation in the three regions was willing to act as host. The general reacting sharply to a question about whether U.S. troops were being told they were ``defending oil.'' ``It's not just a question of oil,'' he said. ``There's not a single service member out there who thinks this _ not any I've met ... anybody who has any doubt in their mind about what Iraq has done should get into another line of work. ``What you have here is a situation where not only is this a mugging, but a rape has occurred ... an international rape of the first order.'' Schwarzkopf admitted he was surprised by Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. ``We knew their capability but misjudged their intention,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Mail to the Gulf Becomes a Torrent
DOC.TEXT: The flood of American soldiers to the Persian Gulf is being followed by a torrent of mail from home. Besides letters of love and assurance, what are the items most in demand? Officials of the U.S. Postal Service report that callers asking for information about sending parcels to members of the military in the Middle East say four items are most popular _ audio tapes, suntan lotion, Life Savers candy and chewing gum. The Postal Service reports it's handling 50,000 items daily intended for servicemen and women in the gulf area.

DOC.HEAD: Biologists Find Ancient Aleut Burial Cave
DOC.TEXT: An ancient burial cave containing the mummified remains of more than 30 people has been found in the Aleutians. The discovery is being called one of the most important in Alaska in years. A volunteer working for the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service discovered the cave in June while looking for fox dens on an uninhabited island, Chuck Diters, the agency's regional archaeologist, said Friday. Foxes are being eradicated to protect a rare species of goose. ``This discovery is unquestionably one of the most important archeological finds in Alaska in a half-century,'' said Diters. Well-preserved artifacts found in the cave include weapons, household goods, and artwork, and some toys that were buried with children. The location was not disclosed. ``They were real closed-mouth about it, very careful in order to protect it from pot hunters. They didn't even radio information about the find. We didn't know about it until they got back to Adak in June.'' Since then, archaeologists have been studying the cave's contents. The Aleut Corp., the regional native corporation that has rights to the remains and artifacts under the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act, authorized their removal to the University of Connecticut and Vassar College for further examination. All will be returned to Alaska when the studies are complete to become the property of the Aleut Corp., Diters said. ``This does not represent the discovery of any new culture,'' he said. ``But it gives us a chance to look at a previously uninvestigated area that has the full range of its occupation materials in a single area not previously disturbed. ``Most sites in the Aleutians and in other areas of the state are overlaid by other cultures, so they're fragmentary through other disturbance. With this, we've got a chance to see a more tightly focused and cleared (cultural) picture.'' ``The last previous work in this area was done in the '30s, in a hasty fashion and without regard for information that can be determined in a careful, controlled examination,'' Diters said. Scientists suspect the area around the cave was a village and they hope to expand their investigation next year. ``It's rare we get the opportunity to excavate the burial and village site in same situation,'' Diters said. Although not totally preserved, the human remains had been ceremonially mummified and wrapped for burial in finely woven grass mats, in accordance with Aleut burial rites, Diters said. ``We found bodies of both sexes and all ages, from less than one-year-old infants to old, toothless elders,'' said Lucy Lewis Johnson, an archaeologist on the faculty of Vassar in Poughkeepsie, N.Y. ``This cave has given us a priceless glimpse of a realm of culture,'' she said. ``It is unique not just because of the number of bodies, but also because it has so many well preserved organic artifacts.'' That includes a finely carved, wooden sculpture of a whale or fish, with a sea otter or small human on its snout and a bird in flight at the tip of its jaw.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Using More Foreign Men As Defense Shields
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 1 graf for 7th, `Britain said...' to UPDATE with France rejecting any conditions on hostage release. Pickup 8th, `The White...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NY6,WX7,LON1,2
DOC.TEXT: Iraq placed new demands on the West today that delayed the departure of 237 women and children from Baghdad. Iraq also announced that it was sending more foreign men to military targets to shield the sites from attack. The developments came as the U.N. secretary-general met with Iraq's foreign minister in Jordan to try to negotiate a solution to the Persian Gulf crisis. Iraqi spokesman Naji al-Hadithi said the 237 foreigners can be flown to London and Paris on Iraq Airways if the airline is allowed to retrieve an unspecified number of Iraqis stranded in the two European capitals by the ``brutal American sanctions.'' Asked about the fate of the women and children if Britain and France rejected the request, al-Hadithi replied only: ``We hope that the two governments respond quickly and positively to this humanitarian request.'' Later, al-Hadithi said meeting the request was not a precondition to Iraq's allowing foreign women and children to leave the country. But if it is not met, he said, they might have to leave by land. The international trade sanctions the United Nations imposed on Iraq do no place restrictions on Iraqis living in other countries. Britain said it would not object to Iraqi nationals returning on flights that take foreigners to London. France said all foreigners must be freed from Iraq unconditionally and that it would not trade French citizens for Iraqis. The White House said President Bush spoke to Saudi Arabia's King Fahd, British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and French President Francois Mitterrand in a series of phone calls today on the crisis. Bush is urging wealthy allies to help foot the $1 billion-a-month cost of deploying U.S. forces in Saudi Arabia and the gulf region. In Moscow, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said today that the military buildup in the Persian Gulf ``makes the situation explosive, very dangerous.'' ``We have to act responsibly, all of us, to prevent a large-scale conflict,'' Gorbachev said. In other developments, six more warships from the United States, Britain and the Netherlands entered Egypt's Suez Canal en route toward the gulf. Dozens of ships have assembled in the region since Iraq invaded Kuwait Aug. 2. Nineteen Italians, meanwhile, arrived safely in Jordan today from Iraq. They are believed to be among the first Westerners to go free under Iraq's offer to release women and children hostages. About 60,000 U.S. combat troops have moved to battle stations and their number is expected to hit 100,000 soon to face the estimated 265,000 soldiers of Iraqi President Saddam Hussein who are stationed in and around Kuwait. The commander of U.S. forces in the Middle East, Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, said today that U.S. deployment there is ahead of schedule, though he gave no figures. He also said there will be no war unless Iraq starts one, a move he said would bring swift retaliation and prove to be ``an awfully stupid mistake.'' Schwarzkopf, in his first news conference since moving his command post to Saudi Arabia, repeatedly ducked questions about specific U.S. military options under consideration. But he said the United States was not looking to start hostilities. ``There's not going to be any war unless the Iraqi's attack,'' Schwarzkopf told reporters after spending the day visiting American troops in northeast Saudi Arabia. He also said his military plans were made without regard to the issue of Westeners being held hostage in Iraq. Also today, an Israeli military source said that Jordanian military planes are flying spy missions along the Saudi Arabian border to supply Iraq with information on troop movements. The Jordanian reconnaissance flights are being flown by U.S.-made F-5 jets, and are giving a view of troop movements dozens of miles into Saudia Arabia, the source said. The U.N. chief and Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz met twice today at the Royal Palace in Amman, Jordan. No immediate progress was reported, but the negotiators were expected to issue a statement later. A senior Jordanian official, who had met with the U.N. chief before the talks with Aziz began, said there was a ``strong possibility'' that Perez de Cuellar will travel to Baghdad for talks. He said no such decision has been made, but the U.N. chief was prepared to fly to Iraq to meet President Saddam Hussein if the talks with Aziz fail to produce any significant progress. Perez de Cuellar had said the current talks would be within the framework of U.N. resolutions passed after the invasion. The resolutions demand that Iraq withdraw from Kuwait and imposed economic sanctions on the Baghdad government. Aziz declared on arrival at Amman's airport that Iraq ``will achieve victory despite the international conspiracy against it.'' His defiant statement contrasted with hopeful comments by Perez de Cuellar on Thursday. The U.N. chief said then he believed ``Iraq is as eager as we all are to find a just and lasting solution of the problem.'' Also today, sources in Baghdad said Iraq has issued coupon books and set up centers to distribute food when national rationing begins Saturday. On the 25th day of a U.N. embargo against Iraq, long lines snaked out of bakeries in the Iraqi capital, residents said. Refugees fleeing Iraq earlier this week reported lines outside food shops in smaller desert towns. Al-Hadithi said the 237 foreign women and children include 123 Britons, 66 Japanese, 19 French, 14 Americans, two Australians and four others of unspecified nationalities. He also said an unspecified number of women and children from other countries that he did not name were ``in principle'' free to leave immediately. He said their governments had to make arrangements for their departure. However, he said the foreign men still held in Iraq are being held at potential military targets all over the country. ``Every place, every town that has a vital installation will host our guests,'' he said. In addition to the Italian nationals, three Finnish women left Iraq for Turkey, the Finnish Foreign Ministry said today. In Athens, a government spokesman said five Greek women and children were expected to leave Iraq on a flight from Baghdad. And Sweden's Foreign Ministry said the 50 Swedish women and children stranded in Iraq have received exit permits and may leave Baghdad Saturday. Britain's Foreign Office said Iraq has issued exit visas to 139 British women and children, all now detained at a Baghdad hotel, to leave on an Iraqi jet. But British officials do not know when the Iraqi jet will leave. Iraq assembled more than 200 foreign women and children hostages at Baghdad's Menia Hotel on Thursday after promising to release them. Some were held earlier at Iraqi military and civilian targets, used as human shields by Saddam to discourage possible U.S. attacks. The foreigners at the hotel were mostly from the United States, Britain, France, Japan and Australia. The Baghdad government said this week that foreign women and children would be allowed to depart as of Wednesday, but still required exit visas. State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said Americans still awaited the permits, adding: ``This emotional roller coaster is inhumane and disgraceful.'' Since today is the Moslem sabbath, exit visas were not expected before Saturday. The U.N. Security Council has denounced Iraq for preventing 21,000 Westerners _ including 3,000 Americans and 4,500 Britons _ and other foreigners from leaving.

DOC.HEAD: Milwaukee County Mulls `Cashless Welfare' System
DOC.TEXT: Milwaukee County officials trying to reduce welfare fraud are considering a unique program that would leave recipients with little discretionary cash. The program would require direct payment of welfare recipients' housing, utility and food bills through vouchers, electronic fund transfers or government-appointed third parties. The plan's sponsor said he hoped the program would end abuses of Aid to Families with Dependent Children in which cash benefits are spent wrongly by adults and children are left to suffer. ``I'm not embarking on a course of welfare bashing,'' said County Supervisor Richard D. Nyklewicz. ``I'm trying to be a responsible representative and ensure the money is used for its intended purpose.'' But a lawyer for Legal Action of Wisconsin, an advocacy group, said she would also oppose the cashless system. ``I think it's terrible,'' said Shirin Cabraal. ``It's a real patronizing type of attitude toward welfare recipients _ the whole idea that welfare recipients are not capable of handling welfare benefits.'' If approved by Milwaukee County, Nyklewicz's experiment still would need state and federal approval. The Milwaukee County Social Services Committee began its review of the proposal this week but delayed a decision until next month. Supervisor Elizabeth Coggs-Jones asked for the delay to allow the County Health and Social Services Department to research whether there are viable alternatives that won't take free choice away from welfare recipients. ``I'm not a proponent of cashless voucher systems. I think it's not true welfare reform,'' she said. ``True welfare reform is educating people and training them to get decent jobs with decent wages and benefits.'' The federal government already permits the use of welfare benefit vouchers to pay vendors like landlords and utility companies but only in cases where a recipient has mismanaged funds or needs special assistance. Gary Ashcraft, director of the Division of Program Evaluation for the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services in Washington, said the Milwaukee program would be the nation's first to not use cash for general welfare in ordinary cases. Jason Turner, director of the department's Office of Family Assistance, said he disliked the idea because ``welfare recipients, generally, should receive the money and make their own decisions with it.'' Gov. Tommy G. Thompson, who has initiated two state welfare experiments, said he would support the Milwaukee County plan and help obtain the necessary state and federal approval. ``If we can have this cashless system set up to assist people better, then ... from what people tell me, it's a step in the right direction,'' he said. Thompson urged approval in 1987 of Wisconsin's Learnfare program, which allows the state to cut a welfare family's monthly AFDC benefits if one or more of its teen-agers have been consistently absent from school. The program was suspended in Milwaukee this summer by a federal judge who said families were being unfairly sanctioned by inaccurate attendance records in Milwaukee schools. The Thompson administration also has experimented with a program called Workfare, which requires welfare recipients to participate in job training or work part-time to keep their benefits. Milwaukee County, the state's largest with a population of about 970,000, distributes $6.4 million per month in food stamps and $16.6 million in AFDC benefits. One AFDC recipient, Calvin Hopson, 43, said he believed there was too much mismanagement. ``In a way, I think vouchers would help,'' Hopson said.

DOC.HEAD: Coupons Issued, Food Points Open as Iraq Prepares for Rationing
DOC.TEXT: National rationing takes effect Saturday in Iraq, and authorities have issued coupon books and set up centers to distribute food, sources in Baghdad said. But the Iraqi capital was already feeling the squeeze. Long lines snaked out of bakeries in Baghdad, residents said. Refugees fleeing Iraq earlier this week reported long queues outside food shops in smaller desert towns. Flour, rice, dried beans, grain, and powdered milk had dissapeared from shops, the Baghdad sources said, and meat vanished days ago. Pharmacy shelves were empty of medicines, and hospital officials spoke of dwindling supplies of antibiotics and anesthesia, said sources contacted by telephone from Nicosia. Iraq has two to four months stock of staple food, according to U.S. government and trade estimates. Some experts speculate that if the country tightens its belt, it could stretch its stocks to withstand a six-month siege. Trade Minister Mohammed Mehdi Saleh earlier this week reassured his countrymen via the government-controlled media that Iraq had enough food to last a long time. He did not say how long. Rationing coupons issued in Iraq entitle each person to a monthly allocation of 13 pounds of flour, 3.3 pounds of rice, 2.2 pounds of sugar, 3.5 ounces of tea, 1.1 pounds of oil, 17 ounces of detergent and one bar of soap. Children under a year old receive three tins of powdered milk each month, but older children receive none. Fresh fruit and vegetables from summer crops remained plentiful, sources said. ``It's also pretty well accepted that Iraqis store more basic foods than would be expected in other countries, and no one has any idea what people have at home,'' said Andrew Bellingham, a farm trade analyst with World Perspectives Inc., in Washington D.C. ``It's a natural tendency to keep extra stock in any situation of instability _ such as Iraqis faced during the gulf war _ and you also have had the Iraqi government encouraging it,'' he said in a telephone interview. President Saddam Hussein announced 10 days after the invasion of Kuwait that the country would have to prepare for austerity. Since then, hoarding and profiteering have been punishable by death. Iraqi people have been better fed in recent years than their neighbors in Turkey, Syria, Iran and elsewhere. U.S. officials estimate that the average Iraqi consumes 3,300 calories each day and could cut back without health difficulties to the same 2,500-2,900 consumed by people in nearby countries. Consumption in Iraq is above the top end of the range for a healthy diet recommended by U.S. dieticians. As final preparations were under way to begin rationing, Iraq on Friday sought to barter oil for food. It offered an undetermined amount of crude oil in return for 50,000 metric tons of sugar, officials in Manila said. The offer was under study by the Philippines, which relied heavily on Iraq and Kuwait for its oil needs. Baghdad's offer to barter was evidence of a worsening cash shortage stemming from the Aug. 6 U.N. trade embargo that has cut off the export of oil, Iraq's main source of revenue. Experts have said the oil embargo is a more powerful weapon than the embargo of food. Much of the food consumed by Iraq's 17 million people, especially rice and flour, was purchased from the United States and has not yet been paid for. Baghdad still owes the United States about $2 billion for food delivered before the invasion of Kuwait. Last year, Iraq spent $2.9 billion importing about 75 percent of its food from the United States, Canada, Australia, Turkey, Sri Lanka and elsewhere. Decades of central planning, the eight-year war with Iran and the forced relocation of rebellious Kurdish peasants in the fertile north have decimated Iraqi agriculture. Attempts had been under way before the invasion to try to repair some of the damage and encourage individual enterprise. This week, Agriculture Minister Abdelwahab Mahmoud said the government was considering new measures to encourage production of more food. Despite the embargo, there have been reports of some supplies getting through to Iraq by air and by truck from Jordan. A senior British military official, Air Chief Marshal Sir Patrick Hine, suggested earlier this week to reporters in Dharan, Saudi Arabia, that the embargo might have to be strengthened by blocking the airspace around Iraq. Military experts pointed out it would more difficult and dangerous to stop aircraft than ships. Reports filtering out of Kuwait City said Iraqi troops had emptied warehouses near Kuwait's port and hauled the contents on tractor-trailer rigs to Baghdad. Poultry, canned goods and frozen meat were said to have been taken from the warehouses, according to the unconfirmed reports.

DOC.HEAD: Justice Refuses to Block Extradition
DOC.TEXT: A Supreme Court justice Friday refused to block extradition to Israel of an American citizen accused of being a Palestinian terrorist. Justice Harry A. Blackmun denied an emergency request by Mahmoud El-Abed Ahmad, who is charged in Israel with participating in a machine-gun attack on a bus traveling through the Occupied West Bank. U.S. officials have said they would move promptly to extradite him to Israel if the courts did not intervene. Ahmad, 37, who hasn't been charged with a crime in this country, has been in jail since his arrest three years ago while lawyers argued over whether he could get a fair trial in Israel. His lawyers said he would be tortured by Israeli security officers if sent there. The 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in New York City on Aug. 10 rejected Ahmad's argument that the alleged crime was a political act not covered by an extradition treaty with Israel. The appeals court said political motivation does not convert every crime into a political offense. Ahmad is represented by former U.S. Attorney General Ramsey Clark. Ahmad, who Israeli authorities sometimes refer to as Mahmoud Abed Atta, is charged with taking part in an April 12, 1986, attack in which three Palestine Liberation Organization terrorists hurled firebombs and then opened fire with machine guns on a bus carrying Jewish settlers en route to Tel Aviv. The bus driver was killed and a passenger was injured. Ahmad left Israel after the attack and was arrested by FBI agents in 1987 on a flight from Venezuela.

DOC.HEAD: Life Magazine Names Most Important Americans of the 20th Century
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS next-to-last graf to CORRECT spelling to Wernher, sted Werner, change Prussia to Germany
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Influential-List
DOC.TEXT: Elvis Presley, yes; Marilyn Monroe, no. Albert Einstein, yes; Al Capone, no. Babe Ruth, yes; Magic Johnson, no. Life Magazine unveiled its list Friday of the 100 Most Influential Americans of the 20th century, and those among the missing are as interesting as those who made it. No Madonna, no Magic, no Michael Jordan. No Clark Gable. No Greta Garbo. No Al Jolson. Where have you gone, Joe DiMaggio? Not on this list. Not a single U.S. president _ and there were 17 since 1900. So who did make it? Elvis, Albert and the Babe. Polio vaccine inventor Jonas Salk and infant care guru Dr. Benjamin Spock. The king of rock 'n' roll is joined by a half-dozen other musicians: Louis Armstrong, Irving Berlin, Leonard Bernstein, Bing Crosby, Bob Dylan and Richard Rodgers. ``It's a list of the most influential people of the past 100 years, not the famous,'' said Mary Steinbauer, editor of the special issue. ``In making our selections we looked at how our lives would be different if each of our honorees didn't live.'' More than 60 historians and other experts were consulted by Life in making the list. Only three people received unanimous support, the magazine reported: the Wright Brothers and Henry Ford. Missing completely are the 17 presidents of the 20th century. ``Every president is important to us _ that's the nature of the job,'' said Steinbauer. One first lady made the list: Eleanor Roosevelt. More than half of the list was born in the 19th century, and only 21 of the honorees are still living. Marlon Brando was the lone actor to make the list; from the world of sports, Muhammad Ali, Billie Jean King, Jackie Robinson joined the Bambino. Activists-advocates was second to the sciences in producing honorees. Thirteen of them were cited, including civil rights leader Martin Luther King Jr., Alcoholics Anonymous founder Bill W., and feminist Betty Friedan. As a group, the 100 captured 11 Nobel Prizes, five Pulitzer Prizes and four Academy Awards. Twenty of them never graduated high school, including Walt Disney, William Faulkner, Jackson Pollock and Malcolm X. Thirteen were born in a foreign country and later became U.S. citizens, such as choreographer George Balanchine (Russia) and scientist Wernher von Braun (Germany). New York was the state that produced the most honorees, 14, double that of runner-up Illinois. The list also included Life's founder, Henry Luce. Life said the 100 were selected from a field of 636 people under consideration.

DOC.HEAD: Congressional Delegations Leave for Mideast
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf pvs `Secretary of...' with 1 graf to ADD that Baker also will testify before House committee
DOC.HEAD: With AM-US-Gulf, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Two congressional delegations left Friday for the tense Middle East, signaling that Capitol Hill plans to assume a larger role in U.S. policy dealing with Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. ``We're moving from a process in which this was mostly presidential to one where there is more congressional involvement,'' said Rep. Mickey Edwards, R-Okla., a member of the House GOP leadership. When the House and Senate return to regular session beginning the week of Sept. 10, there will be a round of hearings that will include reviews of U.S. foreign policy in the Middle East, military deployment and energy policy, and the impact of all of them on the federal budget. Secretary of State James A. Baker III will be among the first to testify, appearing Tuesday before the House Foreign Affairs Committee and Wednesday before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. ``The members of our delegation will be making decisions over the next several weeks ... all of which are affected by the crisis in the gulf,'' said House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., who was leading the 22-member House delegation. Leaving about the same time in a matching blue-and-white Air Force version of the Boeing 707 was a 14-member Senate delegation led by Foreign Relations Committee Chairman Claiborne Pell, D-R.I. The separate delegations had similar itineraries: briefings by U.S. officials in Saudi Arabia, including military commanders, and visits with U.S. troops in the field at Dhahran and Air Force units stationed in Bahrain. On Sunday the two groups were to meet in Jiddah, Saudi Arabia, for discussions with Kuwaiti and Saudi officials. On Monday, both groups were scheduled to meet in Cairo with Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak. The House delegation is scheduled to return to the United States on Monday, while the senators were to meet with officials in Oman and the United Arab Emirates and return Tuesday. ``We may be there for a long time, and the morale of our troops is absolutely critical,'' said Sen. Carl Levin, D-Mich., a member of the Armed Services Committee. Referring to alternately raised and lowered hopes for the release of hostages by the Iraqi president, Levin added: ``We cannot be used as a yo-yo by Saddam Hussein, and that means our willpower must remain strong.''
