Lawmakers said they were interested in assessing what additional troops allies might commit to the military buildup and progress toward cost-sharing by countries that benefit from the continued flow of Middle East oil. Concern also was voiced about Arab solidarity against Saddam. ``I'm particularly anxious to learn ... what the impact of a long-term standoff would be, to what degree Saddam Hussein has the ability to create dissension within the Arab world,'' said Sen. John Kerry, D-Mass. Another goal, said Sen. William Cohen, is to deter a flood of members of Congress to the region that might distract U.S. forces from their primary mission. ``It would be very inconvenient for them to have to deal with'' such an influx, Cohen said. This group will share what it learns with colleagues on Capitol Hill and hope to discourage further congressional travel, he said. The Senate delegation also included: Jesse Helms, R-N.C.; John Glenn, D-Ohio; Alan Cranston, D-Calif.; John Heinz, R-Pa.; David Durenberger, R-Minn.; Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y.; Paul Sarbanes, D-Md.; Larry Pressler, R-S.D.; Christopher Dodd, D-Conn.; and Conrad Burns, R-Mont. Others in the House contingent were: Reps. Robert Michel, R-Ill.; Steny Hoyer, D-Md.; Newt Gingrich, R-Ga.; Les Aspin, D-Wis.; Sonny Montgomery, D-Miss.; Beverly Byron, D-Md.; William Dickinson, R-Ala.; Robert Kastenmeier, D-Wis.; Dave McCurdy, D-Okla.; Bud Shuster, R-Pa.; Billy Tauzin, D-La.; Edolphus Towns, D-N.Y.; William Dannemeyer, R-Calif.; Dan Rostenkowski, D-Ill.; Sam Gibbons, D-Fla.; Guy Vander Jagt, R-Mich.; David Obey, D-Wis.; Robert Mrazek, D-N.Y.; Dante Fascell, D-Fla.; and William Broomfield, R-Mich.

DOC.HEAD: 200,000 Children Will Be Hurt on the Job, Group Says
DOC.TEXT: Thirteen-year-old Matthew Garvey was taking a break from his summer job at the car wash when his leg was sucked into a drying machine and severed from his body. The company was fined $400. According to a report released Friday by the American Youth Work Center, a youth advocacy group, an estimated 200,000 children will be injured this year on the job. ``On Labor Day, we celebrate the efforts of working men and women,'' said Linda Golodner of the National Consumers League. ``But we also need to focus attention on the young workers of our country.'' The American Youth Work Center predicts some 40,000 cases of child labor violations will be reported this year, almost double the number found in 1989. ``Deaths and injuries are increasing dramatically and yet are spread thinly across the country,'' said AYWC's William Treanor. ``And so all that people have are anecdotal stories. Everybody can think of one gruesome, horrible incident that they're aware of and they think that that's some sort of freak occurrence. ' Quality Car Wash in Laurel, Md., had hired Matthew to dry cars with cloths, though Matthew had no work permit and was underage. Matthew said several other children also worked there, including an 8-year-old. Matthew received $400 from the company because the dryer had no lid covering the fan blades. The car wash also was fined $10,000 for child labor law violations, but the money went to the state. The car wash has since gone out of business. ``There were no cops on the beat to say to that employer `you cannot employ these young people,''' said Golodner. She said it was very tempting for employers to violate child labor laws because the chances of getting caught are slim, and even if they do get caught they'll only get a ``slap on the wrist.'' ``In any way you look at it child labor is cheap labor.'' Golodner said. ``Many don't know they're being exploited, and because it may be their first job they want to please their employer.'' The Department of Labor conducted a one-day sweep of businesses in June this year, uncovering 3,800 cases of child labor violation. Most of the cases involved youngsters working more hours than the laws allow, but many were using dangerous machinery. As a result of the sweep, the Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole announced that the administration would back legislation to increase fines from $1,000 to $10,000 the maximum penalty for violations. The legislation, co-sponsored by Reps. Charles Schumer, D-N.Y., and Don Pease, D-Ohio, will go to the floor when Congress gets back to work this fall. But Treanor said it was likely the bill would be held up by other priorities facing Congress and added that it wasn't far-reaching enough to be effective. One area not covered by proposed legislation is agricultural. An estimated 300 children are killed every year in farm work, and more than 23,000 are injured. In July this year, investigators from the Department of Labor found children as young as 3 years old working as migrant laborers in Northern California. The National Consumer's League and AYWC are calling on Congress and the Labor Department to update the child laws on the books since 1938, create stiffer penalties for violations and to step up reporting and enforcement efforts. Treanor said businesses themselves should develop and enforce standards for working youths. ``If MacDonalds started serving green cheese or something, they're going to go nuts at MacDonalds' headquarters,'' said Treanor. ``Why don't these companies go nuts when they find out that a 14-year-old just sliced her hand off in one of their fast food joints?''

DOC.HEAD: De Klerk Proposes Opening Governing Party to Blacks
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Leads with 13 grafs to ADD ANC, Conservative Party reaction. Pickup 13th pvs, `In his...
With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: President F.W. de Klerk called Friday for the governing National Party, which implemented apartheid four decades ago, to accept non-whites as members. De Klerk said the all-white party's restrictions were at odds with its goal of creating a democracy free of domination by any race or group. ``The new South Africa demands that those who belong together through inner conviction should come together,'' he told a party provincial congress in Durban. The African National Congress and other anti-apartheid groups called de Klerk's proposal welcome but overdue. The leader of the right-wing Conservative Party denounced it. The government is looking for political allies among black political groups to buttress its position in negotiations with the ANC, the main black opposition movement, on sharing power. The ANC seeks a one-man, one-vote system, virtually guaranteeing a black majority government. De Klerk wants protection for whites and other minority groups, a free market economy and guaranteed rights, such as the right to own property. The congress and three other upcoming provincial meetings are expected to approve accepting non-whites. Even with the change, black party members would not be able to vote for the party's candidates in national balloting because apartheid bars them from voting in national elections. ``Better late than never,'' ANC spokesman Pallo Jordan said of the proposed change. ``I'm sure there are some blacks who would join, but I can't imagine why.'' Conservative Party leader Andries Treurnicht, an opponent of power sharing, said the National Party had committed political suicide because, he said, people want nationalism, not integration. Accepting blacks and other races would reverse the National Party's heritage as the architect of apartheid. It won power in 1948 on a platform of white dominance and has been the main voice of Afrikaner nationalism, representing whites of mostly Dutch descent who dominate South African politics. Under apartheid, the country's 5 million whites control the government and economy while the 30 million blacks have no voice in national affairs. Since replacing P.W. Botha as president in 1989, de Klerk has pushed for repeal of apartheid laws and held talks with the ANC. His efforts have caused more whites to leave the National Party for the right-wing Conservative Party and extremist groups. In his speech, de Klerk accused Treurnicht of advocating violence to prevent change in South Africa. He said the Conservative Party sought continued policies of oppression, which would bring the country ``to its knees.'' ``Racism and discrimination in South Africa is gone forever,'' de Klerk said. ``The National Party accepts there will be an inevitable realignment in the party political sphere in the new South Africa it is building,'' he said. It also believes ``the basis for future cooperation should be laid now; otherwise, valuable opportunities will be lost.'' In an earlier speech to the congress, Law and Order Minister Adriaan Vlok said fighting between black factions could resume at any time and push South Africa into a spiral of violence. Vlok, who heads the police, also said rising crime could trigger violence between whites and blacks. He said tension was being stoked by strikes, black consumer boycotts and terrorist attacks. Fighting erupted Aug. 12 in black townships near Johannesburg and raged for almost two weeks. Zulu followers of the conservative Inkatha movement fought Xhosas and other blacks loyal to the ANC with axes, spears, guns and knives. The two groups oppose South Africa's apartheid system of racial separation but are divided by leadership rivalry, tribal loyalty and differing visions of a future South Africa. The government last week imposed emergency restrictions and sent in troops to aid police in the areas of violence. Police said Friday the Johannesburg townships were quiet. About 500 university students marched Friday to police headquaters in Cape Town to protest the recent unrest. Unlike the previous two days, police made no effort to block the students, who presented a statement charging police had sided with Inkatha. The ANC, church leaders and others also have accused police of bias during the fighting. The government has rejected the accusations. In Lusaka, Zambia, ANC leader Nelson Mandela said Friday he is not ready to meet with Inkatha leader Mangosuthu Buthelezi to try to end the fighting. ``We can not meet a man who wants to see the blood of black people, that we can not do,'' Mandela told reporters on his arrival at Lusaka airport. In the past, Mandela has blamed Buthelezi for the violence. In other developments Friday, the government confirmed that 15 prisoners would be released sometime after the weekend. The government and the ANC agreed Aug. 6 on a review process to free political detainees starting Sept. 1.

DOC.HEAD: German Leaders Sign Treaty Bridging Two Nations
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs grafs 6 and 13 to CORRECT minister's surname to Schaeuble. ^LaserPhoto BER7
DOC.TEXT: One day before the anniversary of the war that drove them apart, the German states signed a sweeping treaty Friday meant as a final blueprint for bringing them together. German leaders met in a 17th century palace of German princes to sign the document, which seeks to reconcile the stark differences between two societies that will form one nation Oct. 3. The pact will allow East Germany to retain its liberal abortion law and gives Western investors more rights to buy East German land, a measure economists say is necessary to rescue the nation's dire economy. It also calls for Berlin to become the capital of a united Germany, guarantees some social programs for jobless East Germans, and recognizes the five states East Germany will become in a united nation. The treaty leaves many crucial decisions on uniting the nations to the new government that will be elected to lead both nations Dec. 2. The 900-page document was signed by West German Interior Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble and East Germany's top unity negotiator, Guenther Krause. Earlier, the cabinets of West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl and East German Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere formally approved the pact. ``Today we are fulfilling one of the last remaining hurdles to German unification,'' de Maiziere said. The parliaments of the two nations likely will approve the treaty next week. The signing took place on the eve of the 51st anniversary of World War II. On Sept. 1, 1939, Hitler's forces invaded Poland, and France and England declared the war that eventually split Germany. The treaty promises that the new united Germany will respect the borders of its European neighbors. The pact reconciles some fundamental legal and political differences between two nations that followed vastly different paths after they were carved from the conquered Nazi empire. Schaeuble said the goal of the broad accord ``was to again standardize what had been 45 years of of developing separate systems of laws and differing economic and living conditions.'' The treaty was the product of intense negotiations between West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl's conservative Christian Democrats and the left-leaning Social Democrats, who are campaigning to win the Dec. 2 elections. Key aspects of the treaty _ particularly the differences between East Germany's liberal abortion law and West Germany's strict one _ were held up by intense politicking that threatened the accord. The treaty itself was not necessary to German unification because East Germany already has voted to merge with West Germany. But failure to approve it would have meant that West German laws would have become the law of both lands without accommodating the vastly different society reared on socialism. Although Berlin has been designated the capital, it is still undecided whether it, or the current West German capital, Bonn, will be the seat of the new government. Germany also must decide what to do with the massive East German bureaucracy still largely composed of functionaries from the old regime ousted last autumn. The treaty is a companion piece to the economic pact that merged the currencies and economies of the German states on July 1, when East Germany became a free market after four decades of socialism. East German joblessness since has skyrocketed as factories collapse in the face of Western competition. The document includes an important provision meant to lure more Western companies into East Germany. Tens of thousands of West Germans who fled what is now East Germany after the Soviet invasion of World War II have filed claims on their former property. The uncertainty of who owns what in East Germany has been blamed for inhibiting Western investment needed to provide jobs and replace the dying sectors of the East German economy. The treaty gives Western investors who buy East German land protection from any claims made by former owners or their heirs, who would instead be compensated with cash under a system to be worked out later. On the abortion question, East Germany will be allowed to retain its abortion-on-demand law until at least 1992, deadline for a united parliament to write a new law for the entire nation. The nations also agreed the new Parliament will decide what to do with the files compiled by the notorious secret police, which kept sensitive information about millions of people. In the meantime, the files will remain in what is now East Germany under the custody of a West German official to be chosen by East Germany. In a related matter, the West German Cabinet on Friday decided to grant amnesty for small-time East German spies who operated in West Germany, although it exempts those who are found to have taken part in murders, threats or other nefarious activities.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-US-Gulf, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The State Department said on Friday that an autopsy conducted with an American doctor present confirmed that an American banker died of a heart attack after being rounded up by authorities in Iraq. But the department said the fact that a heart attack killed bank executive James L. Worthington, 56, ``in no way diminishes the inhumane treatment which may have contributed to his death.'' ``He was clearly under stress,'' said Margaret Tutwiler, the department's press secretary. ``He didn't have access to decent medical facilities. ``We want to make clear to Iraqi officials that we hold them responsible for the safety and well-being of all Americans,'' she said. Ms. Tutwiler said Worthington's family lives in New York state.

DOC.HEAD: Arab League Echoes Earlier Call For Iraqi Pullout From Kuwait
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Arab foreign ministers ended a two-day emergency session Friday with a new condemnation of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait and a call for Iraq to immediately release foreign hostages, conference sources said. Only 13 of the League's 21 members attended the emergency meeting and only 10 of them were represented by foreign ministers, reflecting the deep split that Iraq's invasion of Kuwait has created in the Arab world. Egypt's foreign minister, Esmat Abdel-Meguid, said the resolutions would be announced at a news conference Saturday. Sources close to the conference, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said five resolutions were approved. They called for the immediate release of all foreign hostages held by Iraq, and for compensation to be paid to Kuwait for losses resulting from the invasion, the sources said. Other resolutions call for all civilians to be well-treated and compensated for losses; reiterate the League's condemnation of Iraq for the invasion Aug. 2; and call for the return of the rule of Kuwait's emir, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, the sources said. No explanation was given for the delay in announcing the resolutions. Foreign Ministry sources insisted it was only to allow time for the resolutions to be translated into English and French. The state minister for Cabinet affairs in Kuwait's deposed government, Abdel-Rahman Awady, expressed satisfaction with the resolutions but refused to elaborate. At an emergency Arab summit held in Cairo on Aug. 10, a dozen members condemned Iraq and agreed to send Arab troops to Saudi Arabia. So far only Egypt, Syria and Morocco have sent contingents. It was those same 12 states, plus Libya, that accepted Egypt's invitation for the latest emergency meeting. On Thursday, the League secretary-general, Chadli Klibi, told reporters the ministers had reviewed reports on efforts by some Arabs to defuse the crisis. Klibi emphasized that any plan had to include the unconditional withdrawal of Iraqi troops from Kuwait and the restoration of Sheik Jaber as ruler. He was apparently referring to a reported initiative by the Palestine Liberation Organization, which Kuwait has rejected. The PLO plan envisages a federation between Kuwait and Iraq in which the emirate would be the junior partner. Other Arab states including Libya, Jordan and Sudan are involved in diplomatic moves. A six-nation committee comprised of Egypt, Syria, Saudi Arabia, Bahrain, Libya and Kuwait drafted the resolutions and presented them to the ministers Friday. In addition to Iraq, League members boycotting the meeting because of their varying levels of support for President Saddam Hussein were Jordan, Sudan, Yemen, Algeria, Tunisia, Mauritania, the PLO and Iraq.

Health Secretary Louis Sullivan sent Congress on Friday a preliminary outline of a plan that will change the way physicians are paid by the Medicare program. The package includes a preliminary fee schedule covering about 1,400 physician services, shifting payments to primary care and away from procedure-based services like surgery. Under the new system, physician fees will be based on the time, skill level and resources needed to perform the service, as well as practice costs and malpractice insurance costs. More than 500,000 physicians will be affected by the change scheduled to be impelemented Jan. 1, 1992. It will be the largest change in the Medicare program since its inception 25 years ago. In his letter to health committee and subcommittee chairmen and ranking members, Sullivan cautioned that the numbers in the fee schedule are ``very preliminary ... Many and perhaps all of these values will change.'' ``Important policy and technical questions ... are unresolved,'' he said. Under the current Medicare system, physicians are paid their actual charge, customary charge or the prevailing local charge for a service, whichever is lowest. The system has resulted in large variations in payments among localities and services. The new system will pay physicians either the actual charge or a fee based on the value scale, whichever is lower. A geographic adjustment will account for differences in practice costs, but overall payments will increase for many physicians in rural areas who are paid less than urban physicians under the current system. A spokesman for the American Medical Association said the group's officials were looking over the preliminary fee schedule but could not comment in detail on the proposal yet. The information was to be published in the Federal Register soon.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Soldier Acquitted in Combat Slaying
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS three grafs of background; AMer upcoming
DOC.TEXT: A military jury Friday acquitted a veteran paratrooper on charges that he unnecessarily killed a Panamanian during the 1989 invasion of the country. The jurors deliberated nearly two hours before returning clearing Master Sgt. Roberto Bryan. The verdict was greeted by applause from other soldiers in the courtroom. Bryan sighed with relief. He had no immediate comment but a news conference was scheduled for after the courtroom proceedings ended. Bryan, a 19-year Army veteran and member of Fort Bragg's 82nd Airborne Division, was charged with unpremeditated murder. A conviction would have carried a sentence of life in prison. The defense rested its case Thursday. The Army said Bryan, 42, shot a Panamanian with his M-16 rifle without provocation during the invasion. Two soldiers testified Thursday they drew their guns on the unidentified Panamanian who was later killed by Bryan at an American checkpoint following a grenade explosion on Dec. 23. They said they viewed the man as a threat.

DOC.HEAD: Unification Treaty Covers Array of Vital Issues
With AM-Germany-Unification, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: German leaders on Friday signed a treaty to reconcile their legal and constititutional differences before unity. Here are the main points of the 900-page unification treaty: _East Germany will avail itself of Article 23 of the West German Constitution to join its larger neighbor Oct. 3. _West Germany's Constitution takes effect in what is now East Germany on the day of unity. _Berlin is designated the capital of a united Germany. The decision on the location of the all-German Parliament and the seat of government will be determined after unification. _The 6 million files compiled by the Stasi, the former East German secret police, are to remain in East Germany for now. The all-German Parliament is to decide on their future disposition. _The all-German Parliament is required to pass a new abortion law to reconcile the two vastly different rules that now exist in the two states. Each country retains its laws until the new rules take effect. _The two states recognize the inviolability of borders and the territorial integrity and sovereignty of all states in Europe. _Under a previous agreement, West Germans are allowed to claim property in East Germany that was seized from their families by the Communists or lost when they fled to the West. Under the treaty signed Friday, anyone who buys land in East Germany for development purposes is protected from claims by previous owners or their heirs. There will be a system worked out later to compensate people who don't get their land back because it is being developed commercially or because their claim would displace people living there. _Treaties and agreements of the European Economic Community take effect on the former territory of East Germany immediately after unification.

DOC.HEAD: Klansmen Who Want to Wear Masks May Do So in Saturday Rallies
DOC.TEXT: About 250 white supremacists are expected in two northeast Georgia cities for marches and demonstrations Saturday, and they may hide their faces thanks to a court ruling throwing out a 1951 anti-mask law. Georgia Attorney General Michael Bowers has advised state law enforcement officials not to enforce the law against Ku Klux Klan masks and most other concealments in public areas. The law was overturned in May by a judge in Gwinnett County; an appeal to the Georgia Supreme Court is pending. ``Since the law has been declared unconstitutional and not been clarified by the Supreme Court, there is a possibility that officers would be open to civil rights actions if they enforce it,'' Bowers said. Bowers, as attorney general, advises only state agencies. But local police in Gainesville, where Saturday's largest demonstration is planned, said they won't try to stop masked Klansmen, either. ``It's going to be our decision to adhere to the attorney general's decision,'' said Gainesville Police Capt. Marion Darricott. A year ago, about 280 Klan members, skinheads and other white supremacists demonstrated in Gainesville. Officials of the Center for Democratic Renewal, an Atlanta group monitoring Klan activity, expect a similar number this year, said center Executive Director Daniel Levitas. The demonstration was planned by the Invisible Empire Knights of the Ku Klux Klan, but literature this week targeting minority neighborhoods around Gainesville indicated that other Klan factions and white supremacists also would participate, Darricott said. Klan members have a permit for a morning march and rally in downtown Gainesville. Downtown streets will be cordoned off, and businesses agreed to close for the morning to avoid the activities, Darricott said. The enhanced security for this year's events _ tighter than a year ago _ comes ``because of prior Klan activity in this area,'' the captain said. Only police and news media representatives will be allowed access to the supremacists' march and rally. Spectators and counterdemonstrators will be restricted to a designated space near the courthouse, he said. The Center for Democratic Renewal is planning two rallies in Gainesville in opposition to the white supremacist activities: a morning ecumenical prayer service at a Baptist church and a noon ``community unity'' rally at an apartment complex. The locations are away from the downtown KKK activities. After the Gainesville march and rally, some Klan demonstrators are expected in Lawrenceville, about 30 miles away, for a courthouse rally. That courthouse is where Klansman Shade Miller was arrested last year in his one-man challenge of the state's Klan mask law. Gwinnett State Court Judge Howard Cook declared the law unconstitutional in May, agreeing with Miller's contention that the law violated Klansmen's First Amendment right to anonymous free speech and expression. Klan members also plan an annual cross-burning ceremony Saturday night at Stone Mountain on the property of longtime Klan leader James Venable, according to Klan watchers at the Center for Democratic Renewal.

DOC.HEAD: Widow's Heirs Get Billy Graham Bequest Overturned
DOC.TEXT: A woman's heirs have prevented the Rev. Billy Graham's organization from receiving part of her $3 million estate, saying a fundraiser for the TV preacher used undue influence to get the elderly woman to change her will. Under the terms of a pre-trial settlement approved Tuesday by a surrogate court in Brockville, the family will split the estate with a charitable foundation set up in the woman's name. Jessie Latta died in September 1988 at age 93 and left most of her estate to the Jessie Latta Foundation, of which Carl Green, 63, was a director. Green was also a fundraiser for the Minneapolis-based Billy Graham Evangelistic Association. Another $100,000 was left to the Graham association. Green could not be reached for comment Friday and the Minneapolis office of Graham's association was closed Friday afternoon. Latta's great-nieces and nephews did not know Latta had changed her will until she had died. Her previous wills left the estate to the family. The family claimed Green, of Ontario, worked his way into Latta's life and become a close confidant. ``It was so obvious there was some kind of influence,'' said Dianne Hickling, one of the four family members who contested the will. Lawyers for the family produced Green's weekly reports on his visits to Latta, beginning in late 1976. They outline Latta's growing dependence on Green and his certainty Latta would leave a lot of money to the association. Handwritten comments by Green's superiors in the margin of his reports praise his progress, saying ``stay close to her'' and ``very good prospect.'' At one point, Green described his visits to Latta as a ``cultivating job.'' As Latta grew increasingly infirm, she began to watch religious television shows, including Graham's crusades. Green's visits became more frequent. Tuesday's settlement split the $3 million estate equally between six family members and the Latta Foundation. Hickling has replaced Green as a foundation director. The family is considering going to court to retrieve about $750,000 Latta gave the association.

DOC.HEAD: Commodity Prices at Farm Drop in August, Says USDA
DOC.TEXT: Prices farmers get for raw products declined 1.3 percent from July to August, but the overall commodity price index was still 3.4 percent above a year ago, the Agriculture Department said Friday. Lower prices were reported for hogs, grapefruit and corn. Higher prices for cattle, eggs and milk offset part of the decline for the other commodities, the department's Agricultural Statistics Board said in its preliminary report. Beef cattle prices were at a record level, and milk prices set a record for the month of August. Most prices are mid-August averages which will be revised next month. For example, the latest report showed July prices rose 0.7 percent instead of being unchanged as the report indicated a month ago. No new figures were released to show how much farmers pay to meet expenses. Those are adjusted quarterly, and last month's report showed the prices-paid index was up 0.5 percent from April, when the previous estimate was made. Meanwhile, department economists say consumer food prices are going up 5 percent to 7 percent this year, compared with 5.8 percent in 1989, the most since 1981. A new forecast this week put 1990 net cash income of farmers at a record in the range of $59 billion to $63 billion, up about one-tenth from last year. The previous high was $57.2 billion in 1988. Net cash income is the money nationally that farmers have left from gross cash income during a calendar year after deducting cash expenses. It includes government payments and proceeds from crops grown previously but sold during the year. Another method, taking into account changes in inventories, depreciation and other allowances during a calendar year, shows that 1990 net farm income may be in a range of $47 billion to $52 billion, compared with $47 billion last year. Based on the preliminary figures, the August price index for all crops was down 3.1 percent from July and 1.6 percent below a year earlier. Both wheat and feed grains were down from July, while soybeans were up. The August index for livestock and products was up 0.6 percent from July and 8.1 percent above the year-earlier average. ``Compared with July, higher prices for beef cattle, calves, milk and eggs more than offset lower prices for hogs and broilers,'' the report said. Milk prices rose 30 cents in August to an average of $14.40 per l00 pounds. That was up $1.20 from August 1989. The farm price of milk rose to a record $16 per hundredweight in December before easing down and then beginning the current climb. Vegetable prices rose 6.8 percent from July and were up 2.9 percent from a year earlier. Lettuce and tomatoes led the August gains, while lower prices were reported for celery and sweet corn. Fruit prices were down 11 percent from July and 1.1 percent below a year earlier. Grapefruit led the August plunge while apples and strawberries were higher. Wheat prices, pressured by a bumper harvest, dropped 20 cents during the month to $2.59 per bushel. A year earlier wheat was $3.74 per bushel. Corn, at $2.46 per bushel, was down 16 cents from July but was still 19 cents more than in August 1989. The report said: _Cattle averaged $75.40 per 100 pounds of live weight nationally, up from $73.60 in July and $69.70 in August 1989. Those are averages for all types of cattle sold as beef. _Hogs averaged $56 per 100 pounds, down from $60.80 in July but above the average of $45.60 a year earlier. _Corn, at $2.46 a bushel, was down from $2.62 in July but was up from $2.27 a year earlier. _Wheat prices at the farm, according to preliminary figures, averaged $2.59 per bushel, compared with $2.79 in July and $3.74 a year earlier. _Rice averaged $6.76 per 100 pounds, compared with $6.95 in July and $7.42 in August 1989. _Soybeans were $6 per bushel, compared with $5.97 in July and $6.07 a year earlier. _Upland cotton was reported at 65 cents per pound, compared with 62.9 in July and 60.2 a year earlier. _Eggs were 65.6 cents per dozen, compared with 55.6 in July and 71.6 in August 1989. _Milk was $14.40 per 100 pounds, up from $14.10 in July and the average of $13.20 a year ago. _Broilers were 33.2 cents per pound, live weight, compared with 36.9 cents in July and 35.7 cents a year earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Agency to Form Special Team to Prevent Fraud in S&L Sales
DOC.TEXT: The Resolution Trust Corp. plans to hire a special group of employees to watch for possible corruption as it sells hundreds of failed savings and loans, an agency spokeswoman said Friday. The RTC hopes to set up a team of 20 to 30 ``contractor cops'' this fall, spokeswoman Kate Spears said. The team, which will oversee the sale of billions of dollars of S&L assets, will be led by a new assistant director of the RTC to be named in the near future. ``We're going to be hiring people to work nationwide,'' Ms. Spears said. Regulators are haunted by the specter of S&L fraud, since abuse by some thrift operators was partly responsible for the collapse of hundreds of institutions in recent years. It will cost U.S. taxpayers an estimated $500 billion to pay for the bailout of the federally insured thrifts. In June, after weeks of criticism by Democrats, President Bush announced with great fanfare that he was doubling government spending on investigating and prosecuting S&L fraud. Bush established ``rapid response teams'' of investigative lawyers and accountants to be directed by a Justice Department official. ``We need to put those people in jail and call them to account for their conduct,'' the official, James G. Richmond, told The Associated Press in a recent interview. Richmond, formerly the U.S. attorney for northern Indiana, was appointed to the new position of special counsel for financial institution fraud. In addition to fraud by S&L insiders, regulators also are sensitive about allegations of abuse stemming from their own efforts to clean up the mess. Democrats in Congress have accused the regulators of making sweetheart deals with outside buyers of failed thrifts. In a highly publicized case, Congress has been investigating investor James Fail for his purchase of 15 insolvent Texas S&Ls, now known as Bluebonnet Savings Bank, with $70 million in borrowed money and only $1,000 in personal funds. To help prevent future abuses, the RTC's new ``contractor cops'' will coordinate their efforts with the agency's inspector general, John Adair, Ms. Spears said. ``It looks to us like the opportunities for fraud are going to be enormous,'' Adair told The Washington Post. He was not immediately available for comment Friday, RTC spokesmen said. The new RTC team will keep an eye on the various contractors hired by the agency to sell thrift assets and manage them until they are sold. The new watchdogs will watch for kickbacks, rigged bids and other forms of fraud involving the assets repossessed by failed S&Ls, which range from office buildings, hotels and condominium developments to car washes and golf courses. Since the S&L bailout bill became law a year ago, the RTC has taken over 475 ailing institutions. The Office of Thrift Supervision, an agency of the Treasury Department, said Thursday that at least 246 additional S&Ls are expected to fail and are likely candidates to be taken over by the RTC.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Retransmits a0657 to recast summary line since $1 million bond has nothing to do with slayings
DOC.HEAD: Slayings Investigators Seal Youth's Apartment
LaserPhoto DO1
DOC.TEXT: An 18-year-old University of Florida freshman charged with beating his grandmother was held on $1 million bond Friday, and police investigating the deaths of five students sealed his apartment. Task force investigators refused to say whether he is considered to be among the potential suspects in the slayings. ``At this particular time, we continue to have a pool of suspects,'' said Alachua County sheriff's Lt. Spencer Mann. ``To say that we have a prime suspect or prime two suspects or three suspects is very premature.'' Edward Lewis Humphrey was arrested Thursday at his grandmother's house in Indialantic, some 180 miles to the southeast, and charged with aggravated battery on a person over age 65, authorities said. Two Florida Department of Law Enforcement agents spent 12 hours Thursday at the jail in Sharpes where Humphrey was held, and Brevard Circuit Judge Dean Moxley increased Humphrey's bond from $10,250 to $1 million about an hour before the agents left early Friday. The agents returned to the jail Friday. Brevard County sheriff's spokeswoman Joan Heller said Humphrey's first court appearance initially scheduled for early Friday afternoon was delayed for security reasons. ``He's a single-cell prisoner, meaning that he's considered violent,'' she said. About 600 law enforcement officials are involved in a hunt for the killer, who investigators have called a ``methodical maniac'' with a sick grudge against petite brunettes with shoulder-length hair. Authorities have said they are interested in an Ohio fugitive wanted in a mutilation slaying there. Mann said police also were looking for a man wearing camouflage pants who ran away when a state trooper tried to question him in Gainesville early Friday. Investigators are interviewing or watching three or four other potential suspects in central Florida, police said. The victims _ students at either the University of Florida or Santa Fe Community College in Gainesville _ were stabbed to death in off-campus apartments in three attacks discovered since Sunday. Police said three of the four women were mutilated. Gainesville police sealed off Humphrey's apartment Thursday and questioned anyone attempting to enter the property, about three miles west of campus. ``We have investigators interested in that location. We have task force members who are interested in the area,'' said Lt. Sadie Darnell, a police spokeswoman, but she refused to say whether any search warrants had been sought. Police at the scene wouldn't talk about what they were doing there, but a part-time maintenance man at the complex said authorities had not entered Humphrey's apartment _ No. 131. ``They're just watching it to make sure nobody goes in and takes anything out,'' said Joe Lotz, the maintenance man and a University of Florida senior. At Humphrey's apartment complex Friday, six detectives wearing rubber gloves and green smocks combed through six garbage bins and removed some undisclosed items. ``In this kind of investigation, it's important not to overlook any possible kind of trace evidence,'' police investigator Gary Manning said. Humphrey had been under surveillance since Tuesday when the latest two victims were found at the Gatorwood apartment complex. He lived in Gainesville over the summer but was evicted from Gatorwood, The Orlando Sentinel reported. A Florida Department of Law Enforcement plane followed Humphrey as he drove Wednesday from Gainesville to his grandmother's home. Neighbors said he had experienced emotional problems since suffering a severe head injury in a traffic accident more than a year ago. Funeral services were held Friday for four slaying victims in their hometowns _ Christina Powell, 17, of Jacksonville; Christa Hoyt, 18, of Newberry; Tracy Paules and Manuel Taboada, both 23 and of suburban Miami. The killings unleashed a wave of fear in this college town, exacerbated by published reports that the killer stole flesh from some of the mutilated victims and placed a decapitated victim's head on a shelf. Police have given few details about the mutilations. Hundreds of students fled the school earlier in the week, and others skipped class to extend their Labor Day weekend. Larry Humes, a university spokesman, said: ``I think a lot of people headed for the beach. It's probably a desire for suds and surf as much as it is fear.''

DOC.HEAD: Archbishop Encourages Guamanians to Vote Against Pro-Choice Candidates
DOC.TEXT: The fight to keep abortion legal on Guam is being overshadowed in Saturday's primary elections by the possibility that the U.S. territory may have its first woman and non-native governor. Gov. Joseph Ada is unopposed on the Republican ballot as he seeks a second term. Democrats face a choice between Sen. Madeleine Z. Bordallo, a native of Minnesota and widow of Guam's former governor, or former Lt. Gov. Rudy Sablan. The winner will face Ada on Nov. 6. Guam's 21-member unicameral legislature unanimously approved a bill virtually banning abortions March 8 after Archbishop Anthony Apuron threatened in a television interview to excommunicate any Roman Catholic senator who voted against it. Ada signed the bill into law, saying: ``In my heart, I believe that a fetus is a human being.'' The law carried a penalty of up to a year in jail and a $1,000 fine for obtaining an illegal abortion or soliciting a woman to have an abortion. Performing an illegal abortion was punishable by up to five years in prison. Last week, U.S. District Judge Alex Munson struck down the law as unconstitutional. Munson declared that Roe vs. Wade, the 1973 Supreme Court decision establishing the right to an abortion, ``applied with equal force and effect to Guam.'' Ada has not indicated whether he will seek an appeal. Mrs. Bordallo has said she also opposes abortion. Ada said he's running on his record of the past four years. He said he is confident he and his running mate, Lt. Gov. Frank Blas, will win re-election. On Jan. 31, Mrs. Bordallo's husband, Ricardo, chained himself to a statue, wrapped himself in Guam's flag and shot himself in the head. That occurred less than four hours before he was to fly to Los Angeles to begin serving a four-year prison term for witness tampering and obstruction. Ada defeated Bordallo in the 1986 election after Bordallo had been indicted on the federal charges. Mrs. Bordallo wants to be Guam's first woman governor and the first governor who is non-Chamorro, the name for native Guamanians. ``Women are moving ahead today. They are leading countries. Right next door, we have a housewife leading 60 million people,'' said Mrs. Bordallo, referring to Philippine President Corazon Aquino. Some 130,000 people life on Guam, an island about 1,500 miles east of the Philippines. Mrs. Bordallo, 57, came to Guam in 1948 when her father accepted a position as principal of George Washington High School here. Sablan, 58, served as Gov. Bordallo's lieutenant governor from 1974 to 1978, unsuccessfully challenged Bordallo in the Democratic primaries in 1978 and 1982. Sablan, who also opposes abortion, said one of his priorities as governor would be to set up a territorial tax structure that is not tied to the federal tax system. The archbishop issued a pastoral letter published in newspapers this week calling for voters to vote down pro-choice candidates. ``Like a modern day Pontius Pilate, a legislator or official may attempt to wash his or her hands of abortion,'' Apuron said. ``However, the legislator cannot wash away the blood of the innocents he or she has consciously declined to protect. Nor can the voter sit idly by in apathy.''

DOC.HEAD: Man Turned in By Mother Gets Five Years
DOC.TEXT: A University of Connecticut student whose mother turned him into police was sentenced Friday to five years in prison for drug dealing, despite her tearful pleas for leniency. ``He wants to deal with his problem,'' Jean Terrazzano of Madison said of her 21-year-old son, Stephen M. Russo. ``He realizes he could be dead now. Please give him a chance to get treatment.'' Superior Court Judge Richard Damiani said Russo gave up his chance to avoid prison when he was arrested while the original charges were pending. ``That's why you are going to prison today _ because you are a drug seller,'' Damiani said. ``It makes no difference whether you're from a suburb or a city ghetto, you're a drug seller.'' Russo, who was to begin senior year next week, was sentenced to 10 years in prison, suspended after five years, and three years' probation. Clean-cut and wearing a blue suit, Russo looked more like the law student he wanted to be than the drug dealer Damiani said he was. ``All I can said is I'm sorry for all the pain and suffering I inflicted on my family and other kids,'' Russo said, weeping. ``But I can't turn back time. I'm sorry for what I've done.'' Terrazzano called police to her home on June 26, 1989, and officers found Russo with 27 grams of heroin and 7{ pounds of marijuana, court records show. They later found $85,000 in his safety deposit box. In March, New Haven police arrested Russo after finding him with broken fingers, an injured ankle, a cut scalp and 65 packets of heroin. Russo's lawyer, Hugh F. Keefe, said Russo continued to sell drugs because New York drug dealers were threatening his life over money he owed them. Russo accepted a plea bargain in July to all charges pending against him, pleading guilty to two counts of possession of heroin and one count of possession of marijuana with intent to sell. Terrazzano had said she hoped her son would receive treatment, not a prison term. She blamed herself for Russo's problems. His father died when Russo was only a year old and she immersed herself in her legal career. Damiani said Russo's difficult childhood could have contributed to his becoming an addict. ``But I don't think your mother can be blamed for your becoming a drug dealer,'' Damiani said. ``That's greed.'' Damiani said Russo had a choice to make in prison. ``You can say, `My mother put me here and the judge is a bum,' '' Damiani said. ``Or you can be strong and be a man and reflect on what you've done and come out of prison a productive person.'' As her son was led out of the courtroom, Terrazzano sat in the courtroom sobbing as she leaned on the bench in front of her. Her husband, Joseph Terrazzano, tried to comfort her. Outside court, she said that given the same circumstances she would call the police again. ``What other choice did I have?'' She said. ``I'm just thankful he's still alive.''

DOC.HEAD: Persian Gulf Crisis At-A-Glance
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here, at a glance, are Friday's developments in the Persian Gulf crisis:

U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar met twice with Iraq's foreign minister, Tariq Aziz, in Amman, Jordan in an effort to negotiate a solution. The two reported no immediate progress and planned another session Saturday.
Baghdad tied the release of 237 foreign women and children to the return of Iraqis it said were stranded in Britain and France as a result of international trade sanctions.

More foreign men have been taken to potential military targets all over Iraq, Iraqi government spokesman Naji al-Hadithi said. ``We're relocating the foreign men all over the country at airports, air bases, military bases, industrial plants, communications centers, power centers and oil refineries _ wherever Iraq considers it has a vital installation, one exposed to the American threat in Saudi Arabia,'' he said.

National rationing takes effect Saturday in Iraq, and authorities have issued coupon books and set up centers to distribute food, sources in Baghdad said. But the Iraqi capital was already feeling the squeeze. Flour, rice, dried beans, grain, and powdered milk had dissapeared from shops, the Baghdad sources said, and meat vanished days ago.

In Washington, the White House said President Bush spoke to Saudi Arabia's King Fahd, British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and French President Francois Mitterrand in a series of phone calls on the gulf crisis. Bush is urging wealthy allies to help foot the $1 billion-a-month cost of deploying U.S. forces in Saudi Arabia and the gulf region.

U.S. officials said that doubts about effectiveness of economic sanctions in forcing Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait have prompted recommendations from inside and outside the government for direct U.S. military action against Iraq. President Bush's spokesman publicly dismissed such reports, though military and other officials acknowledged that American forces still pouring into Saudi Arabia could switch quickly from defense to offense if so ordered.
Nineteen Italians arrived safely in Jordan from Iraq. They are believed to be the first Westerners to go free under Iraq's offer to release women and children hostages.

An Israeli military source said that Jordanian military planes are flying spy missions along the Saudi Arabian border to supply Iraq with information on troop movements. The Jordanian reconnaissance flights are being flown by U.S.-made F-5 jets, and are giving a view of troop movements dozens of miles into Saudia Arabia, the source said.

Six more warships from the United States, Britain and the Netherlands entered Egypt's Suez Canal en route toward the Persian Gulf. Dozens of ships have assembled in the region since Iraq invaded Kuwait Aug. 2.

The multinational flotilla choking off Iraqi trade kept a ship from unloading supplies believed destined for Iraq, a shipping publication reported. Lloyd's List International said a U.S. warship turned a Sri Lankan freighter away from Jordan's port of Aqaba earlier this week. The paper quoted unidentified sources in London as saying the ship was suspected of carrying chemicals for Iraq as well as food and other goods.

DOC.HEAD: Columbia Launch Depends on Fixing Broken Part
DOC.TEXT: An increasingly frustrated NASA will try again to launch Columbia on Wednesday if a broken electronic part used for one of the telescopes aboard the shuttle can be repaired easily. Workers entered the shuttle cargo bay Friday to try to find what's wrong with an electronic box at the base of an X-ray telescope, one of four in the mission's $150 million Astro observatory. The space agency late Thursday called off a scheduled Saturday launch after spending the day fruitlessly trying to communicate with the telescope inside the shuttle's cargo bay. The broken part is believed to have caused the loss of contact. It was the second time the Columbia countdown had been halted. The first launch attempt, in late May, was scrubbed because of a hydrogen fuel leak. The last space shuttle mission was in April; the current lapse is the longest between shuttle flights since the hiatus following the 1986 Challenger disaster. ``Any time we get close and don't go, like a kid going to the carnival, we're frustrated and we're anxious to get going,'' said William Lenoir, head of NASA's space flight program. ``But we're not going until we're ready. I think we're getting awfully close to ready.'' The latest problem appears to involve a line driver, a component of the electronic box, which routes electrical power and telemetry between the orbiter and the X-ray telescope, said Lennard Fisk, NASA's chief scientist. If that is the case, a cable can be easily installed to a second line driver in the unit, he said. The launch will be delayed until Friday or Saturday, however, if the entire electronic box has to be replaced, Fisk said. NASA expects to know the extent of the problem by Saturday afternoon. Columbia's seven astronauts plan to remain at Kennedy Space Center until then. ``We're calmly taking our time, and when it's ready, we're going to go fly,'' Lenoir said. Saturday's launch also had been threatened by a problem with a mid-deck instrument that measures acceleration and vibration, said launch director Bob Sieck. The instrument failed to activate properly during the countdown and probably will have to replaced. Four astronomers aboard Columbia will operate Astro's three ultraviolet telescopes during the nine- to 10-day flight. The observatory will probe some of the hottest objects in the universe, including a comet and a supernova. The latest delay is not expected to affect Astro's observing schedule, Fisk said. But it is the latest in a series of embarrassments for NASA. Atlantis' classified Pentagon mission was delayed from July to November after the shuttle was found to be leaking hydrogen, and the entire three-shuttle fleet temporarily was grounded. In addition to the leaking shuttles, the space agency has spent the summer contending with the Hubble Space Telescope's flawed mirror and the occasional loss of contact with the Venus-orbiting Magellan spacecraft. NASA had hoped to launch nine shuttle flights this year. Only three have gone, the last one being Discovery's trip in April with Hubble. Discovery is scheduled to be moved to another launch pad on Sunday to await an October flight with the sun-probing Ulysses satellite. Columbia has until Sept. 14 to lift off, otherwise it will be forced to wait until after Discovery's flight, Lenoir said. NASA must launch Discovery between Oct. 5 and 23 to take advantage of the alignment of Earth, the sun and Jupiter, whose gravitational field will slingshot Ulysses back to the sun. The next opportunity for launch will not be for another 13 months. As far as the leaks, Lenoir said the launch team is confident of Columbia's new hydrogen lines. He also said it now appears Atlantis has the same type of leaks as Columbia. Engineers initially believed Atlantis' leaks were in a different place than the ones on Columbia. NASA will rely more on visual evidence of hydrogen leaks during fueling for future flights and use different criteria for sensors, Lenoir said.

DOC.HEAD: The Heat Goes On In The Plains; Thunderstorms Across The Southeast
By The Associated Press
DOC.TEXT: August drew to a close Friday with blazing heat in the Plains and fierce thunderstorms in the Southeast. Temperatures reached into the 90s over much of Nebraska by noon, with 90- to 100-degree readings or higher across the southern half of the Plains. At 3 p.m. EDT, Wichita, Kan., reached 105 to tie its record, and West Palm Beach, Fla., hit a record 94. Afternoon showers and thunderstorms reached along the North Carolina coast and the northern coast of South Carolina, from western North Carolina into southeast Tennessee, through northern Alabama, southern Mississippi, across Florida, Georgia, and over to southeastern Louisiana, eastern Texas, and Arizona. Showers and storms also extended from northern Colorado across southeastern Wyoming, the Panhandle and northern Nebraska, Wisconsin and upper Michigan. The heaviest rainfall during the six hours up to 2 p.m. EDT was 2 inches at Fort Myers, Fla. Friday's low for the Lower 48 states was 31 at Truckee, Calif. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 59 at both Arcata and Crescent City, Calif., to 107 at Waco, Texas.

DOC.HEAD: Liberian Rebels Accused of Killing 200 Foreigners
DOC.TEXT: Liberian rebels have killed 200 foreign civilians from the five nations that make up a West African task force in Liberia, the Ghana News Agency said Friday. The killings came in retaliation for the force's presence there, the agency said. A Ghana News Agency correspondent with the West African force said rebels loyal to Charles Taylor began attacking the civilians shortly after the troops debarked in Monrovia on Aug. 25 to try to end the 8-month-old civil war. Taylor opposes any intervention in the conflict. No immediate response came Friday from Taylor, who confirmed on Thursday that he was holding thousands of foreign citizens. The task force fought its way to the eastern edge of Monrovia and took control of the capital's airport, diplomatic sources said in Freetown, speaking on condition of anonymity. The air strip is big enough to handle military transport planes. Controlling it will make resupplying the force much easier. About 3,000 soldiers from Ghana, Nigeria, Guinea, Sierra Leone and Gambia are under orders to end the conflict, which turned into a tribal war. The Spriggs Payne Airfield had been in the hands of President Samuel Doe's troops but was under fire almost daily from Taylor's rebels, camped less than a mile away. The British Broadcasting Corp. said a spokesman for Prince Johnson, who broke with Taylor and leads a rival rebel group, called Friday to report Doe's troops broke an informal truce and attacked Johnson's men, killing 21 of them. Doe and Johnson had both welcomed intervention by the West African force and declared a truce more than a week ago. The task force pushed eastward toward the embassies of three member states _Guinea, Ghana and Nigeria _ which lay just behind rebel lines. The rebels had rounded up thousands of Guineans, Ghanaians and Nigerians who had taken refuge at their embassies, saying they were being held for their own protection. The Ghana News Agency quoted Ghanaians who it said escaped the attack, and said thousands more were waiting outside Monrovia's port for a ship that would take them home. Ghanaian teacher Kwasi Kwateng, 36, said rebels attacked a community of 2,500 Ghanaians living in Barnesville, about 3{ miles from Monrovia's port. The agency gave no specifics about this or other alleged attacks, however, and there was no confirmation from other sources. Kweku Egyir, 52, a Ghanaian who has lived in Liberia since 1963, said Taylor's men were looking for Ghanaians and Nigerians in particular because their members of the African force had inflicted many casualties on the rebels. Egyir said the rebels could identify Ghanaians and Nigerians by their accents and tribal scars. ``The marks on our faces are called identity cards in this country,'' he said. Few details emerged on the fighting. The task force easily repulsed several attacks by Taylor's men. using its heavy artillery and armored cars, according to Nigerian and Ghanaian correspondents traveling with the force. Taylor invaded from Ivory Coast on Dec. 24, calling Doe's government corrupt and pledging to overthrow it. His fighters quickly overran most of the West African country of about 2.5 million people, but were stopped on the outskirts of the capital. Johnson, who split with Taylor in February, led his men through swamps on Monrovia's northern outskirts in a surprise attack on Doe's troops. Johnson's rebels took control of much of the capital city of about 400,000 Liberians, but were unable to drive Doe from his heavily fortified mansion. U.S. Marines stationed on warships off Liberia evacuated Americans and some other foreigners from Monrovia. Marines also remained posted around the U.S. Embassy. But Washington says U.S. forces will not intervene in the fighting, which has killed about 5,000 people, mostly civilians. The West African group said in sending its task force that the Liberian conflict concerned their nations because their citizens in Liberia were involved and because 400,000 Liberian refugees are straining the resources of neighboring countries.

DOC.HEAD: Cambodia's Government Gives Nod to U.N. Peace Plan
DOC.TEXT: In a major breakthrough in Cambodian peace talks, that country's government said Friday it is ready to accept as a basis for discussion a U.N. proposal already approved by the guerrilla resistance. The announcement capped four days of progress in efforts to reach a settlement of the 11-year-old civil war. On Tuesday, the United States and four other permanent members of the U.N. Security Council proposed a U.N. interim administration with five key Cambodian ministries placed in its hands during the transition. In New York, U.S. officials tried Friday to win Vietnam's approval of the U.N. plan. However, Vietnam, which installed the Cambodian government in a 1978 invasion and remains its main backer, was noncommittal. The State Department has said it is linking Vietnamese cooperation on Cambodia with the possibility of normalizing relations with the United States. In July, the United States, nervous about battlefield gains by a Communist rebel faction, said it was ending diplomatic recognition of the guerrilla alliance and opening talks with Vietnam on ending the war. On Friday, a Cambodian official said his government ``accepts a major role played by the United Nations during the transitional period, notably the right to organize free and fair elections.'' ``I think that it (the U.N. plan) could constitute a basis for the discussions among the Cambodian parties,'' said Hor Nam Hong, the deputy prime minister in charge of foreign affairs, in remarks carried by the official Cambodian news agency and monitored in Bangkok. The five permanent U.N. Security Council members have said up to 20,000 U.N. employees would be sent to shore up the truce and guide the Southeast Asian nation to democracy. The Communist Cambodian government of Prime Minister Hun Sen is battling a guerrilla coalition composed of the Communist Khmer Rouge and two non-Communist groups, one headed by Prince Norodom Sihanouk and the other by Son Sann. The United States has supported the two non-Communist rebel groups and China has armed the Khmer Rouge. When Vietnam invaded Cambodia in late 1978, it ended a nearly four-year Khmer Rouge reign in which hundreds of thousands of people died in execution chambers and slave labor camps. Hor Nam Hong said his governemnt was ready for peace talks anywhere, anytime. He said talks scheduled to take place soon in Jakarta, Indonesia, should finalize the composition of a Supreme National Council, establish where and when it will meet, and discuss the U.N. peace plan. However, Indonesian Foreign Minister Ali Alatas said Friday in Jakarta that he was unsure if the session would occur because of unclear signals from the Cambodian government. He said he expected a definite answer from Cambodia within three days. Alatas said the Jakarta meeting, if held, should take place in the first two weeks of September. In June, Hun Sen and Sihanouk agreed to form a Supreme National Council to arrange a truce and play a role in the period before elections. But the Khmer Rouge has rejected the agreement, demanding that it be given the same number of seats on the council as Hun Sen's government. The guerrillas want either the council or the United Nations as the interim government, while Hun Sen wants to retain power during the transitional period. He had said earlier the U.N. role generally should be limited to organizing elections. In his remarks, Hor Nam Hong said his government agreed that ``certain important ministries'' could be temporarily supervised by the United Nations. The United States has supported the two non-Communist rebel groups and China has armed the Khmer Rouge. The Security Council plan would entail the United Nations' most extensive peacekeeping effort. The plan covers arrangements for running Cambodia during the pre-election period, a temporary military setup, elections under U.N. auspices, human rights protection, and international guarantees that Cambodia will be non-aligned and democratic.

DOC.HEAD: Two States Investigate National Mailing
DOC.TEXT: The fine print in a Republican fund-raising campaign that has sent $25 checks to 700,000 people nationwide is under investigation by attorneys general in at least two states. On the back of the $25 check, the fine print says the recipient authorizes the bank to transfer $12.50 out of his account each month to the National Republican Senatorial Committee. Oregon's Attorney General, Dave Frohnmayer on Friday urged the committee to halt the campaign. Minnesota Attorney General Hubert H. Humphrey III said his office also is investigating the campaign. Frohnmayer, a Republican, was asked Thursday to investigate the matter by Secretary of State Barbara Roberts, his Democratic opponent in the governor's race. ``As I'm sure you will agree,'' Roberts wrote, ``this mailing is an unconscionable attempt to exploit the vulnerability of people who cannot read fine print, or who for some other reason may not succeed in deciphering the real purpose of the mailing, and who will, as a result, suffer financial hardship.'' Frohnmayer concurred. ``This fund-raising gimmick by the National Republican Senatorial Committee is a bad idea,'' he told The Associated Press. ``While our professional staff pursues the consumer protection aspect, I will urge the national committee to pull it. It's bad public policy and it's bad politics.'' In Washington, D.C., GOP Committee spokeswoman Wendy Burnley said the program is explained on the check and the accompanying letter. She said electronic bank transfers _ or Candidate Escrow Fundraising, as the letter describes them _ have become routine and aren't confusing. ``We have a good deal of faith in the American people that they will open this up, read the letter and will understand it,'' she said. ``There's absolutely no possibility whatsoever for people not to realize what they are doing.'' She said the letter includes a toll-free number for people to call for more information or if they want to cancel membership in the program. She also said the committee will give refunds to anybody who asks. Burnley said the committee's lawyers approved the campaign. The solicitation accompanying the check urges people to call the committee at the end of two months if they want to stop the bank transfers. The letter, which the committee sent under the name ``Republican Presidential Task Force,'' says the money will ``give our incumbent and challenger candidates the extra edge they'll need this November to defeat liberal Democrats who oppose President Bush.'' Besides, those who participate in the program will be included in ``Who's Who in the Republican Party.'' The letter said the bank transfer program will allow the committee to reduce mailing, administrative and postage costs. It's the third mailing this year to draw criticism for the Republicans. In February, similar checks were sent to several thousand people. The fine print on those checks said the $12.50 monthly charge would go up by 10 percent a year. The new checks omit that provision and provide the toll-free number. The committee also was criticized for a July fund-raising campaign in which it asked 500,000 people asking for at least $9 to cover processing for an ``Official 1990 National Voter Data Card'' included in the mailing. Sharon Snyder, a spokeswoman for the Federal Election Commission, said a number of election officials and recipients of the mailing complained they were ``confused and concerned because they thought they had to pay to vote.'' Frohnmayer spokeswoman Marla Rae said the current solicitation will be examined to determine whether it violates laws governing trade practices and charitable solicitations. She said she contacted the committee Friday to pass along Frohnmayer's advice. ``As with any solicitation of this sort, we urge folks to make sure they know what they are signing,'' Rae said. `` If a recipient of the letter has any qualms whatsoever, don't sign or deposit the check.''

DOC.HEAD: Iraqis Add Layers of Red Tape
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 4 grafs after 2nd graf pvs `The Iraqis ...' to UPDATE with comment from Iraqi ambassador. Picks up 3rd grav pvs `The government ...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-US-Gulf, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Iraqi government is adding new and confusing layers of bureaucratic red tape to delay the promised departure of American women and children, the State Department said Friday. ``The Iraqis insist on stringing this out and putting all of these innocent people through this cruel ordeal,'' said Margaret Tutwiler, the department's spokeswoman. ``Every time we think we have figured their demands out, they change them.'' But Iraqi Ambassador Mohamed Sadiq al-Mashat said Iraq was arranging the departure of Americans and other Westerners in ``an organized fashion,'' and that Ms. Tutwiler's accusations are ``absolutely not true.'' ``We are in an emergency situation and we have our own priorities,'' al-Mashat told reporters who questioned him after he was summoned to the State Department. ``The priority is to protect the country.'' The news media, he said, is casting Iraq's actions in the worst possible light. ``They are forgetting that Iraq is being held as a hostage and that the threat is against Iraqis,'' he said. The government of President Saddam Hussein has confirmed that his pledge to permit the departure of women and children applies to people in occupied Kuwait as well as those Iraq, she said. However, the nearly 3,000 Americans in Iraq and Kuwait have been divided into categories, each with a different exit requirement, Ms. Tutwiler said. She declined to say what the categories are because of the changing nature of the requirements. ``The information that we have is so convoluted and confusing that it would be unfair to put the information out at this time,'' she said. Dividing the American and other foreign hostages into categories comes on the heels of other newly created Iraqi exit requirements. Under the new government orders, all those wishing to leave must write letters expressing their intentions, have the letters translated into Arabic and obtain official government stamps certifying that all Iraqi taxes have been paid. Ms. Tutwiler said five more Americans had been rounded up by Iraqi authorities. One American woman was granted an exit visa and was allowed to leave for Amman, Jordan. The United States has asked for permission to send a charter aircraft to Baghdad to evacuate Americans but has received no response, Ms. Tutwiler said. Further reports have been received of Americans escaping Iraq on their own, she said. Ms. Tutwiler said Joseph Wilson, the highest ranking diplomat at the U.S. Embassy in Baghdad, was told Thursday he could meet with Americans held at a hotel. But he was not allowed to enter the hotel when he arrived, she said, adding that a consular officer was later permitted to speak to 14 American women and children at the hotel. ``All of the women and children that we saw seem to be well and had their passports,'' she said. Wilson was allowed to visit the hotel Friday morning after lodging a protest with the Iraqi foreign ministry. He met with three Americans _ one man and two women. Ms. Tutwiler said Wilson was told the U.S. Embassy should submit the passports of all Arab-born American men with the passports of all American women and children. But she said that when a U.S. official took the travel documents to an Iraqi government office, ``he was told there had been a change and was sent away.''

DOC.SECOND: Defense Consultant Gets 21 Months in Jail
DOC.TEXT: Former defense consultant Mark Saunders was sentenced to 21 months in prison and fined $5,000 Friday for his role in funneling military procurement data to a defense contractor. Saunders was sentenced by U.S. District Judge Albert V. Bryan Jr. for his role in the Pentagon procurement scandal that is the subject of a longrunning Justice Department investigation dubbed ``Operation Ill Wind.'' The investigation has resulted in nearly 40 convictions of Pentagan officials, consultants and executives of defense firms as well as several corporations. Saunders, 56, was convicted June 5 of conspiracy to defraud the government, wire fraud and conversion of government property. U.S. District Judge Albert V. Bryan Jr. ordered that Saunders, 56, be placed on two years of supervised release after completing the prison term. The former Navy procurement official who became a defense consultant was convicted of participating in a scheme to funnel secret Pentagon bid information to another defense consultant, who sold it to Norden Systems, according to trial testimony. Saunders obtained the information from former Navy procurement official George G. Stone, who pleaded guilty to participating in the scheme, and passed it along to defense consultant Thomas E. Muldoon. Muldoon then sold the bid information about the sophisticated Marine Corps radar and communication system to Norden Systems, one of several companies competing for the $100 million contract, according to testimony. Three Norden executives have already pleaded guilty to taking part in the operation. Muldoon, who was convicted last year of unrelated defense fraud charges, was indicted along with Saunders. But the charges against Muldoon were dismissed by a judge who ruled that prosecutors may have indicted him as punishment for appealing the earlier ``Ill Wind'' conviction. Stone testified that he kept Norden in the competition for the contract at the request of Saunders. Norden dropped out of the competition after the ``Ill Wind'' investigation became public two years ago.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Warns Gulf Crisis `Very Dangerous'
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt ^LaserPhoto MOS3
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev blamed Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein on Friday for the ``very dangerous'' situation in the Persian Gulf, but noted his nation still favors a diplomatic solution. ``We have to understand that an escalation of a military confrontation is always fraught with unpredictable consequences,'' he said. ``That is why we have to act responsibly, all of us, to prevent a large-scale military conflict. I believe this is our common goal, and we are promoting this idea. ``Only those who think illogically can reject such a solution. And I include the president of Iraq in that ... It makes the situation explosive, very dangerous.'' He rebuked assertions that the Kremlin's lack of military presence in the gulf indicated a slip in the nation's world status. ``Some people think we lose our prestige and reputation. It is not so,'' he said. ``I think that everything will depend on whether we are successful in using political measures.'' Deputy Foreign Minister Alexander Belonogov told a parliamentary committee Thursday that ``there are no guarantees'' the United States will remove its troops from the gulf region if the conflict is settled, according to the state news agency Tass. And the Soviet commander of the Warsaw Pact military alliance, Gen. Vladimir N. Lobov, also warned that U.S. forces in the gulf would alter the global strategic balance. But Gorbachev said the U.S. deployment in Saudi Arabia was permissible under the U.N. charter, and said he believed its troops would eventually withdraw. ``I believe that when a solution has been found, we will be able to provide guarantees,'' he added. ``And I believe that the sooner we have a military detente after that, the more calm we all will feel.'' Although the Soviet support for military action in the gulf has been lukewarm, not since World War II has the nation cooperated so fully with the U.S. and other Western nations during a world crisis. The Soviet Union voted in favor of a U.N. Security Council resolution authorizing the use of force to impose sanctions against Iraq, but balked at joining a U.S.-led naval blockade. The Kremlin quickly halted its arms shipments to Iraq, but it has not withdrawn 193 Soviet military specialists and 5,000 construction workers stationed there under contract with the Iraqi government. It pulled its diplomats out of Kuwait after Iraq ordered foreign governments to close their embassies. The United States and several other countries have defied Iraq's mandate.

DOC.HEAD: Science Groups From Eight Countries Sign Arctic Research Agreement
DOC.TEXT: Scientific organizations from eight countries have signed an agreement to found a committee for cooperation and information exchange in research on the north polar region. The groups, all from countries with territories in the Arctic zone, formally agreed this week to found a non-governmental organization to be called the International Arctic Science Committee, the National Academy of Sciences said Friday. Signing the agreement were organizations from Canada, Denmark, Finland, Iceland, Norway, Sweden, the Soviet Union and United States. The founding articles were signed at a remote scientific outpost in Resolute, Canada. The National Academy of Sciences, the U.S. organization that signed the agreement, will help coordinate the research of countries that maintain active arctic science programs and help integrate arctic studies with the research on the global environment. Membership in the IASC is open to all countries with significant arctic science programs, group said in a statement. Representatives from four other countries had observers at the meeting. Improved relations between the East and West and a greater importance given to arctic cooperation between the Soviet Union and the United States were ``decisive factors'' in reaching the agreement, the statement said. Scientific interest in both the north and south polar regions has grown in recent times because of concern about global warming. The statement said changes in the Earth's average temperature caused by the so-called greenhouse effect are expected to be greatest in the polar areas. Experts believe that global warming could lead to shrinkage of the polar sea ice fields, the thawing of permanently frozen soils, melting of glaciers and ice sheets, and a worldwide rise in the sea level. Arctic conditions also influence global weather patterns and ocean circulation, the statement said. Organizations signing the agreement were: the Academy of Finland; the Danish Commission for Scientific Research in Greenland; the Icelandic Council of Science; the Interdepartmental Committee on International Science and Technology Relations of Canada; the Norwegian Academy of Sciences and Letters; the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences; the U.S.S.R. Academy of Sciences; and the National Academy of Sciences.

DOC.HEAD: Environment Minister Seeks Urgent Check Of Chernobyl Safety Cover
DOC.TEXT: Environment Minister Klaus Toepfer said Soviet authorities should urgently check the concrete safety cap encasing the Chernobyl nuclear power plant, a newspaper reported Saturday. The Soviet plant was the site of the world's worst atomic accident, a 1986 fire and explosion that spewed radioactive cesium, strontium and plutonium over a wide area of the Ukraine, Byelorussia and Russia. A reactor at the plant was shut down Monday, the Soviet government newspaper Izvestia reported earlier this week. ``There is certainly an urgent need to precisely pursue and examine the present condition of this security cover,'' the respected newspaper Die Welt quoted Toepfer as saying. On Thursday, the Cologne-based Deutschlandfunk radio station quoted unidentified Soviet ``experts'' as saying they feared the reactor floor could give way from the weight of concrete slabs and release huge amounts of radioactivity. According to Deutschlandfunk, the Soviet experts said the only solution may be to tear down the concrete encasing and build a new one. Izvestia gave no further details on the shutdown of the No. 3 reactor at Chernobyl. It said ``established safety standards were not violated.'' In the Die Welt interview, Toepfer did not indicate whether there was imminent danger. But he did urge the cover be examined, saying a leak ``could lead to widespread contamination very quickly,'' the newspaper reported. ``It (the cover) surrounds a massive inventory of radioactive fission products,'' Die Welt quoted him as saying.
