Toepfer said his ministry is in contact with the Soviets about Chernobyl. He also said the International Atomic Energy Organization in Vienna and nations within the ``international partnership'' should get involved in making sure Chernnobyl is safe, reported Die Welt. It was Chernobyl's Reactor No. 4 that caught fire and exploded on April 26, 1986. Official reports say 31 people were killed in the partial meltdown, but unofficial reports say 250 died. Four years after the accident, more than 2 million people are still living on contaminated lands in the region. The accident sent a cloud of radiation over large parts of northern and central Europe, leading to bans on foodstuffs from several countries. The plant is 80 miles north of the Ukraine capital of Kiev.

DOC.HEAD: Post Office to Keep the Color in Christmas
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf bgng ``Not so'' to note Kansas City postal officials' involvement. SUBS 7th graf bgng ``How did'' to change rumor to misunderstanding.
DOC.TEXT: Postal officials are red-faced about reports that they want Americans to have a white Christmas. Not so, says Richard J. Strasser, senior assistant postmaster general for marketing and customer service. Strasser's comments came after postal officials in Kansas City told area residents earlier this week that they should ``never use red, green or any dark colored envelopes.'' If people buy Christmas cards that come with envelopes that are red or green or some other color, the Postal Service will deliver them happily, Strasser said Friday. Americans send one another some 2 billion cards annually, millions in colored envelopes. White envelopes are easier for the agency's automated machinery to handle, Strasser admitted. Dark-colored backgrounds can make the addresses written on them very hard to read. ``They are a challenge, but we can handle it,'' he said. How did the misunderstanding start? Some postal workers may have been too enthusiastic in discussing the benefits of the new automatic letter sorting equipment, Strasser said. Strasser said the postal service and the makers of greeting cards have been working together to develop envelope colors that are attractive but can easily be handled by automatic sorting machinery. But in the meantime, no envelope that is sold will be rejected, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Report: No Solid Evidence Linking Cancer to Three Mile Island
DOC.TEXT: A study found that people near the Three Mile Island nuclear power plant have a higher risk of some cancers, but saw no solid evidence that radiation from the plant's 1979 accident was a factor, its authors said Friday. The study, which reviewed hospital records of 160,000 people living within 10 miles of the plant, also found no significant relation between exposure to radiation during the accident and childhood cancers or leukemia. The study, which used data from 1975 through 1985, appears to corroborate previous government reports which found no detrimental health effects linked to the accident, which damaged the Unit 2 reactor and led to a $1 billion cleanup. ``Overall, the pattern of results does not provide convincing evidence that radiation releases from the Three Mile Island nuclear facility influenced cancer risk during the limited period of the follow-up,'' the study concluded. But two authors of the report, Columbia University epidemiologist Maureen Hatch and Three Mile Island Public Health Fund investigator Dr. Jan Beyea, acknowledged that some findings showed increased cancer risks. They said those risks did not appear linked to the accident. For example, there were 34 cases of lymphoma cancer in 1984-85 other than Hodgkin's disease. That indicated a twofold increase in the risk for residents who were living in the areas north and west of the plant, where the highest radiation doses occurred at the time of the accident, the report said. But previous studies have not linked lymphoma cancer with radiation, even in high doses, the report pointed out. The study was funded by a $700,000 grant from the health fund, which was established by a 1981 court order to pay for the study of public health issues related to the accident. The findings were published in the September issue of the American Journal of Epidemiology. The study also found there were 1,529 total cases of cancer, excluding lung cancer, from 1975 to 1979. That figure jumped to 2,391 from 1981 to 1985. Ms. Hatch said the disparity might have been caused by faulty record-keeping at hospitals, which were just beginning to computerize records in the mid-1970s. Another increase in risk was noted for lung cancer, but the report concluded that ``an effect of plant emissions in producing the unusual patterns of lung cancer and non-Hodgkin's lymphoma appears unlikely and alternative explanations need to be considered.'' The effect of smoking was one explanation cited for lung cancer. The report was greeted with skepticism by some members of the community around TMI, located about 10 miles south of Harrisburg on an island in the Susquehanna River. Kay Pickering, a spokeswoman for Three Mile Island Alert, a citizens group, said a more exhaustive study was needed before residents could be sure their health was not affected. Marjorie M. Aamodt, who helped conduct a 1984 survey of residents in the area, said the study should have included clinical examinations of people who suffered illnesses at the time of the accident. A 1985 state Health Department study, the first of its kind after the accident, found no pattern of increased cancer cases or deaths, but did turn up isolated instances of higher-than-expected cancer cases in several communities downwind from the plant. The new study dismissed those cases as statistically insignificant. A 1984 survey, conducted by Mrs. Aamodt and her husband, found cancer deaths up to seven times higher than expected in sections of Newberry and Fairview townships near the plant. The Health Department judged that survey invalid because it appeared to focus on streets where cancer victims lived. There are about 2,000 lawsuits pending against the owners of TMI for alleged health effects stemming from the accident. The accident occurred after a combination of human and mechanical errors allowed protective cooling water to drain from the reactor. Some of the reactor's uranium fuel rods melted, and radioactive gases and particles were released to the environment. It was the worst accident at a commercial nuclear power plant in the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Foreign Minister Seeks No-Attack Promise
DOC.NOTE: EDS: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with meeting over, new quotes, color, Saturday session set. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
LaserPhoto AMM13
DOC.TEXT: Iraq's foreign minister said Friday his country ``has no intention of igniting the explosive situation'' and all foreigners in Iraq could leave if the United Nations could produce guarantees against military attack. Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz spoke after emerging from his second meeting of the day with U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar. ``If such guarantees are provided then the situation of the foreigners would be resolved,'' Aziz said. ``Iraq doesn't have any intention of igniting the explosive situation'' in the Persian Gulf, he said. Perez de Cuellar called the talks a ``step forward.'' He said he welcomed Iraq's earlier decision to let Western women and children go free. But, he said, that was not enough. He did not comment on Aziz's call for guarantees against attack by the West. Aziz, asked later if progress was made to defuse the crisis, told The Associated Press, ``Inshallah,'' Arabic for ``God willing.'' Then he added: ``You should advise Mr. Bush to withdraw his troops from Saudi Arabia.'' Aziz and Perez de Cuellar emerged smiling after five hours of talks and agreed to meet again Saturday after experts discussed specific points. They seek to settle the regional crisis set off by Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion and subsequent annexation of Kuwait. Their long-awaited talks created such a stir that one reporter was pushed into a hotel lobby pool in the news media's crush to approach them. Iraq has been holding an estimated 21,000 Westerners, including 3,000 Americans. It said Tuesday women and children would be allowed to go free but men must remain. Iraq's U.S. ambassador, Mohammad al-Mashat, said all foreigners could leave if America gave assurances that the U.S.-led multinational force in the Persian Gulf region would not attack Iraq. A senior Jordanian source, who had access to both sessions, called Friday's talks an excellent meeting with ``so many positive points.'' He said both sides were optimistic about resolving the military standoff but a political settlement could be thorny. ``Iraq insisted on the conviction that there should be a comprehensive peace solution for all Middle East crises,'' said the source, a ranking official who spoke on condition of anonymity. Aziz touched on this at a news conference, denouncing a ``double standard'' against Arabs. He said the Palestine question, Lebanon and other problems must be linked to talks on Kuwait. Perez de Cuellar replied when asked if he would go to Baghdad to see President Saddam Hussein: ``That is not in the cards.'' The U.N. chief made clear upon his arrival in Amman Thursday that his negotiating room was scant. He said his role was defined by U.N. resolutions. The Security Council cut off Iraq with economic sanctions and then, pressed by President Bush, gave Western warships a vaguely defined right to enforce it. U.N. members unanimously condemned Iraq's seizure of Kuwait. The secretary-general said Friday that Iraq's release of foreigners ``would very much help to lessen the tension in the area,'' but that a solution to the complex situation could not be expected in a day of discussions. Aziz made a similar point. ``Pushing for speedy, dramatic things is not the only, or the best, way,'' he said. ``Let us not forget the age of this crisis is only days. You cannot resolve this by magical solutions. We must find patience and we need some quiet diplomacy.'' Perez de Cuellar told reporters that because the first session was useful the second session was arranged with the U.N. and Iraqi delegations present. Aziz, standing next to the secretary-general, said he was happy to meet ``an old friend. . . . We have confidence in him.'' The two men got to know one another during long negotiations for a peace treaty to end the eight-year Iran-Iraq war. A U.N.-brokered cease-fire stopped the fighting in August 1988. Friday's meetings were at the royal palace in Amman. King Hussein meantime flew to London from Madrid on a 10-nation search for peace in the region. Attention focused on a diplomatic solution as both Iraq and the multinational force aligned against it sought to back away from war threats. But both sides held firm in their declarations of resolve.

DOC.HEAD: Hundreds Say Farewell to Blues Guitarist Stevie Ray Vaughan
LaserPhoto staffing
DOC.TEXT: More than 1,000 mourners, led by Bonnie Raitt, Jackson Browne and Stevie Wonder, sang a bluesy version of the ancient hymn ``Amazing Grace'' on Friday at a graveside service for blues guitarist Stevie Ray Vaughan. The singer's fans, some dressed in black, some in T-shirts from his concerts, and some wearing replicas of Vaughan's trademark black felt hat, stood in the sweltering heat for as long as three hours. Vaughan, 35, died Monday in a helicopter crash in Wisconsin after headlining a concert Sunday night with Eric Clapton and Robert Cray. Vaughan's mother, Martha Vaughan, was accompanied by her older son, Jimmie Vaughan, the founder of The Fabulous Thunderbirds, and by Stevie Ray Vaughan's fiancee, Janna Lapidus. Ringo Starr was there, as were members of ZZ Top. Mourners began arriving before 10 a.m. for the noon graveside service, and their numbers swelled steadily. By the start of the service, fans were lined up nine and 10 deep outside restraining barriers across a road from the burial site. They heard the services over a public address system. Stevie and Jimmie Vaughan had just completed an album, ``Family Style,'' set for release in September. Producer Al Rogers played a cut, ``Tick Tock,'' from the album at the service. Many in the crowd got teary-eyed during the song, and applause and whistles broke out when it ended. ``I'm glad you applauded,'' said presiding minister Barry Bailey. ``That was appropriate.'' More applause followed the blues-style version of ``Amazing Grace'' near the end of the half-hour service. ``We grew up with him in Oak Cliff,'' said Pat Beam of Grand Prairie. A friend, Neoma Mayo, said: ``He taught her brother to play the guitar, and we loved him dearly. I appreciate the family sharing this with us. He's given all of us so much.'' ``When he was playing the guitar, you sometimes found yourself caught up more in what he was doing than in your own thing. He was always fun to play with,'' said Damien Womack, 36, a drummer who performed with Vaughan.

DOC.HEAD: 50,000 Demand Holy War Against U.S., Zionists
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: More than 50,000 supporters of the fundamentalist Moslem Brotherhood marched through Amman streets on Friday demanding holy war against ``U.S.-Zionist aggression'' on Arab soil. A Brotherhood leader, Mohammed Owaidah, told them, ``The Jews, the West and the East, together with the powers of disbelief want this nation to remain under the mercy of the Jews!'' Demonstrators chanted slogans, including, ``Humiliation and indignity for America's new lackey, the Soviet Union!'' The Moslem Brotherhood embraces hundreds of thousands of Arabs in the Middle East and North Africa. Chapters in each country operate independently, but often coordinate on policy. The Brotherhood blamed the Persian Gulf crisis, which arose after Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, on a conspiracy between the United States and Israel, with tacit help from the Soviet Union, to colonize Arab lands for the control of oil.

DOC.HEAD: 2 Charged for Shooting of Prosecutor
DOC.TEXT: Two people were charged Friday with shooting to death an assistant prosecutor who happened into the line of fire in a drug turf battle one block from the courthouse where he worked, police said. Jose Diaz, 21, and Ernesto Garcia, 16, were each charged with second-degree murder, second-degree attempted murder and criminal possession of a weapon. Police said Sean Healy, 30, an assistant district attorney in the Bronx, was buying doughnuts at a grocery store Thursday and happened to be standing in the line of fire when three men in a car pulled up and fired seven or eight shots. Healy was struck once in the back. At a news conference Friday, Police Commissioner Lee Brown said the shooting of Healy was the result of a fight over drug turf. The commissioner said Diaz fired the shots from a 9mm automatic. Garcia's role wasn't known. The shooting took place just blocks from Yankee Stadium in a drug-plagued neighborhood of the Bronx where robberies and thefts are common. In his novel ``The Bonfire of the Vanities,'' author Tom Wolfe paints the area as so dangerous that even prosecutors fear for their own safety. Healy was appointed to the district attorney's office on Jan. 16 and was assigned to Bronx Criminal Court, where prosecutions generally involve minor charges which result in jail terms of a year or less, said Steven Reed, a spokesman for District Attorney Robert Johnson. Also Thursday, a former state senator, 49-year-old Vander Beatty, was fatally shot in his office in the borough of Brooklyn. Beatty, a Democrat who left the state Senate after being convicted of forgery and racketeering in 1984 and served 19 months in prison, was shot once in the head at his office. Police said he was killed by an unidentified man who drove away. The car the gunman used was found parked a few blocks away from Beatty's re-election headquarters. Detectives were trying to find the car's owner, Arthur E. Flourney, 51, a retired Corrections Department captain, said police Officer Ralph St. Just.

DOC.HEAD: Rival Shiite Moslem Factions Clash in East Lebanon
DOC.TEXT: Rival Shiite Moslem militiamen, one group loyal to Iran and the other to Syria, battled in this eastern Lebanon town on Friday. Police said 12 were killed and 39 wounded. Fighters of the fundamentalist Hezbollah, or Party of God, and the more secular Amal, Arabic for ``hope,'' traded grenade attacks on each other's command posts in and around Baalbek, setting them on fire, police reported. ``The town is burning. Houses and gasoline filling stations are ablaze,'' said a police spokesman. He said the town's 150,000 inhabitants huddled in basements or fled to neighboring fields as the fighting with machine guns and rocket-propelled grenades raged from sundown Thursday to dusk Friday. Syrian troops in charge of Baalbek's security massed in battle formations around the town, apparently bracing to intervene to quell the fighting, the spokesman added. Syrian forces control most of Lebanon after intervening under a 1976 Arab League mandate. The Iranian-backed Hezbollah and the pro-Syrian Amal have been battling on and off for the last three years to lead the 1.2 million Shiites who make up the largest sect among Lebanon's 4 million population. By police count, at least 1,094 people have been killed and 3,218 wounded in the power struggle. It was the first time the two factions engaged in such ferocious fighting in Baalbek, the largest Shiite urban center in east Lebanon's Bekaa Valley 38 miles east of Beirut. The main sites of previous fighting were in southern Lebanon and Beirut's southern slums.

DOC.HEAD: More Mohawk Barricades Lifted At Bridge to Montreal
DOC.TEXT: Mohawk protesters on Friday allowed more barricades to be dismantled at a Montreal bridge, but they kept up their armed standoff in this town to the west. After a week of seesaw efforts to settle the 52-day land dispute, the status of talks were unclear. A provincial go-ahead for the Canadian army to take down barricades in Oka remained in effect, but troops were apparently waiting in the hope a negotiated settlement could be reached. The standoff began July 11, when the Quebec provincial police attempted to storm a Mohawk barricade at Oka, 18 miles west of Montreal. One officer was killed, but it is still not clear by whose gunfire. The Indians are protesting a plan to expand a golf course on land they claim as theirs. Later on July 11, fellow Mohawks set up the blockade in sympathy at the Mercier bridge, a major link between Montreal and its southern suburbs. On Friday, an army spokesman said work continued at the Mercier bridge to remove barricades with the consent of Mohawks from the local Kanewake reserve. By Friday afternoon, all the main barricades on the five routes leading to the bridge were removed, said army spokesman Lt. Francois Rousseau. ``There was a lot of co-operation and nobody was nervous. I'm surprised to see the work going so fast,'' he said. ``For now, things are running pretty smoothly.'' Serge Forest, a Quebec Transport Department spokesman, said it will be several more days before the bridge can be opened to traffic. The local army commander, Lt. Col. Robin Gagnon, worked out an agreement with Mohawk representative Jack LeClaire for both sides to start tearing down the barricades there Wednesday. However, Mohawks said Thursday that authorities were harassing them, and work was abruptly halted. The bridge blockade has forced thousands of commuters on the south shore of the St. Lawrence River to make long detours to Montreal, which is on an island. Angry residents have protested and thrown rocks at Mohawks. At Oka, armed and masked Mohawks stayed behind their barricades Friday. But only two or three members of the Mohawk Warrior's Society lounged in lawn chairs or on the grass there, chatting with reporters and ignoring the army down a hillside 100 yards away. Army Maj. Richard Larouche said he had indeed received orders to tear down the barricades, but he said no deadline for action was set. Quebec Premier Robert Bourassa has cut off the broader talks between Mohawks and officials to end the standoff, but Mohawk spokesman Jerry Pelletier said Friday the Indians were ready to resume them. The Canadian minister of Indian Affairs, Tom Siddon, said the federal government was talking with the Mohawks.

DOC.HEAD: Fitzwater Doesn't Knock Down Bush-Gorby Meeting Rumor
DOC.TEXT: The White House said Friday it had ``nothing to announce'' on speculation that President Bush would meet Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev next week. ``We're looking at a lot of things. We have nothing to announce,'' said Bush's press secretary Marlin Fitzwater when asked if there was any substance to the speculation. He refused to elaborate or to say if any announcement might be forthcoming later. Bush's chief of staff, John Sununu, is due back on Saturday from a week-long trip to Moscow. He and several top White House aides had accepted an invitation from Gorbachev to visit the Soviet Union and explain the technical workings of the executive branch in Washington as Moscow revamps its own political structure. Earlier, Fitzwater's deputy, Roman Popadiuk, had dismissed the matter out of hand when The Associated Press approached him Friday afternoon with a rumor out of Moscow that Bush and Gorbachev would meet Sept. 8 in Helsinki. Popadiuk said then there was no substance to the rumor ``as far as I know.'' Popadiuk later told the AP, ``We have nothing to announce.'' There was no word on whether Sununu may also have been involved in discussions on an upcoming potential meeting between Bush and Gorbachev.

DOC.HEAD: Cosmonauts Deny Oxygen Crisis
DOC.TEXT: Two cosmonauts who made emergency repairs outside their damaged spacecraft said Friday that the job demanded a cool head, but they denied earlier reports they had risked running out of oxygen. The 179-day mission by Alexander Solovyev and Alexander Balandin, which ended with their return to Earth on Aug. 9, is expected to show a $21 million profit, the deputy mission chief said. He said it is the first in the 33-year history of the Soviet space program. The two cosmonauts walked in space for seven hours on July 17 to repair insulation surrounding the space capsule that would take them back to Earth. Before finishing the repairs, they discovered a problem with the porthole leading back to the orbiting space station Mir, forcing them to return through an emergency hatch. Soviet media reported their life support supplies were running dangerously low by the time they returned to Mir. Solovyev told a news conference Friday each cosmonaut had 10 hours of oxygen in their main tank, plus reserve supplies. ``We consumed only two-thirds of our main balloon of oxygen ... so we had reserves,'' he said. He said the spacewalk was one of the hardest moments of the mission, but that cosmonauts train for such crises. ``I'm sure that men who are not prepared, who do not expect such situations, will not cope with it,'' Solovyev said. ``In that situation, we were quite calm, even cold-blooded, if I may say so, about the decisions we were taking.'' The cosmonauts made a second space walk on July 26 to finish the repairs and retrieve some equipment they left behind, attached to the capsule's exterior. Deputy mission chief Viktor Blagov told the news conference that the mission, the sixth to the orbiting space station, cost $134 million. But he forecast revenue of $155 million through the sale of high-definition photographs of the Earth's surface and of pure crystals developed in space for use in semiconductors and computer chips. ``So from a program of scientific investigation, it is being turned into a program for economic benefit,'' Blagov said. The Soviet space program, for decades a source of national pride, has come under increasing pressure in recent years to prove its worth as the country grapples with consumer shortages and other economic woes. For the last two years, the program has suffered from docking equipment malfunctions, mistakes by cosmonauts and budget cuts. Blagov said the space program will continue to put even more emphasis on commercial activities. The Soviets have also agreed to take a paying customer into space in December. Two employees of the Tokyo Broadcasting System are vying for the seat.

DOC.HEAD: Family Reveals Identity of Hostage Who Died of Apparent Heart Attack
DOC.TEXT: The American who died while being held captive in Iraq was a banking consultant who had been in the middle of his second year in Kuwait, relatives say. An autopsy, performed in Iraq with an American doctor present, showed James L. Worthington Jr., 53, died of a heart attack, the State Department said Friday. ``He didn't have high blood pressure, but he was at risk by some other things,'' said Tim Neilson, son-in-law of the banker who lived in Woodstock when he was not working overseas. ``He smoked cigarettes and drank a lot of coffee.'' Worthington had signed a second year-long contract as a consultant for the Alahi Bank of Kuwait in January, relatives told the Kingston Freeman. ``He was taken hostage in Kuwait and moved to Basra where he died of a heart attack,'' said Worthington's daughter, Maggie Jean Neilson. Worthington may have been moved to a strategic location near an Iraqi oil field in the southern port of Basra as part of Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's ``human shield,'' she said. ``Now that he's not coming home, we'll never really know what happened,'' said Ms. Neilson, 27. She said her family had no reason to fear for her father's safety, until the notification from the State Department of his death. ``We'd get letters every week and Mom would have phone calls. She could call there. There was a direct line,'' Neilson said. ``There was no indication of danger. He didn't feel any differently about it than anyone else over there. They were all caught with the same degree of suprise. ... We spent our whole lives overseas, so it was just another post.'' Before moving to Kuwait, Worthington worked for 28 years in various foreign branches of Citibank. He and his family were stationed in Colombia, Brazil, Liberia, Indonesia, Singapore, India, and at the main branch in New York City just prior to his tenure in Kuwait, Ms. Neilson said. ``We moved around every five years,'' she said. Relatives and friends told the Kingston Freeman they did not want to divulge too much about what they learned about Worthington's death. ``The reason nothing much is being said now is that we're at the mercy of Saddam Hussein. The family won't speak to other media because this is a precious personal thing. All the facts as of this interview is all there will be,'' said Don Badgley, a family friend. The State Department said the fact that a heart attack killed Worthington ``in no way diminishes the inhumane treatment which may have contributed to his death.'' ``He was clearly under stress,'' said Margaret Tutwiler, the department's press secretary. ``He didn't have access to decent medical facilities. We want to make clear to Iraqi officials that we hold them responsible for the safety and well-being of all Americans.'' Worthington's wife, Katharine W. Worthington, was notified of her husband's death by a phone call from the State Department on Monday night, Ms. Neilson said. Mrs. Worthington and her mother, Katharine Rosen Warner, were in seclusion at the family home in Woodstock, about 90 miles north of New York City, she said.

DOC.HEAD: Fastest-Growing City in Nation
DOC.TEXT: Annexations, relatively low-cost housing and a swelling immigrant population contributed to making Fresno the quickest growing of the nation's top 50 cities over the past decade. In 1980, there were 218,202 people in Fresno. The preliminary 1990 census figures push the population to 350,794 _ a 61 percent growth rate in just 10 years. That boosted Fresno from the nation's 65th-largest city to 47th. Mayor Karen Humphrey said the numbers did not exactly surprise her _ but they do present some challenges to the city in California's central valley, about 180 miles southeast of San Francisco. ``I think that this is a dynamic exciting community with a very good lifestyle,'' she said. ``The rapidity of the growth challenges us to preserve that quality of life.'' Since 1980, the city has annexed 21,951 acres with 14,457 housing units. Beedle said. The estimated population increase from the annexation is 38,300 people. Yet an even larger population shift in the city has come from the influx of Southeast Asian refugees. ``Approximately 47,000 refugees have been absorbed,'' city planner Donn Beedle said. ``That's a large chunk of people coming in.'' The refugees are attracted to Fresno by both the area's agriculture and low housing costs, he said. ``A lot of these people know about agriculture, and they would gravitate to an area that they could get jobs and property,'' Beedle said. Central valley towns traditionally also have attracted many immigrants from Mexico and Central America. Another reason people come here is the attractive housing market. While all of California's cities are growing quickly, it is the valley communities that are the most affordable. Fresno's average home costs around $100,000 compared to $250,000 in the San Francisco or Los Angeles areas. Although the census data is only preliminary, Beedle said the city is already rechecking the numbers to see if they tally with city figures. ``Historically speaking, the census undercounts us,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Islanders Vote For Democratic Change
DOC.TEXT: The people of Sao Tome e Principe voted overwhelmingly to back the West African nation's transition to democracy, referendum results showed Friday. It was the latest in a series of moves in several African nations away from traditional one-party rule. More than 81 percent of voters in the Aug. 22 referendum backed a government-proposed constitution ending rule solely by the Movement for the Liberation of Sao Tome e Principe, said official figures cited by Portugal's Lusa news agency. The archipelago has been ruled by the leftist party since independence from Portugal in 1975. The proposed constitution enshrines a multiparty system, a mixed economy, an independent judiciary, freedom of expression and the right to strike. Both the ruling party and fledgling opposition groups urged the islands' 52,000 voters to approve the changes. However, 20.1 percent abstained from voting, according to Friday's results. Recently, the movement has dropped much of its Communist-inspired ideology. According to Portuguese news reports, the ruling party is soon to change its name to the Social Democratic Party. The National Assembly has already approved the new constitutional text, which was drawn up by a Portuguese legal expert. According to a Lusa report from island capital of Sao Tome, the new constitution will come into force within the next few days. It will be followed by laws authorizing the creation of new parties, Lusa said. Multiparty elections are scheduled for the end of the year.

DOC.HEAD: Dole Extends U.S. Invitation to Romanian Leader
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Senate Minority Leader Robert Dole expressed ``strong reservations'' about the government's human-rights record Friday but extended an invitation to Prime Minister Petre Roman to visit Washington. The Kansas Republican, leading a delegation of seven senators on an eight-nation, 11-day tour, told reporters Roman should have a chance to ``talk to congressmen'' about the rights situation in the country. State radio quoted Roman as responding that he would be ``happy to go to the U.S. ... (to) hold a very open dialogue with all those interested in Romania.'' He said such a visit would have ``exceptional importance.'' The United States has strongly criticized the Romanian government for its conduct during a June demonstration and its aftermath. Six people were killed as police acted to end anti-government violence. Thousands of miners, responding to a call by President Ion Iliescu to help quell street opposition, subsequently terrorized the capital for several days. Roman and Iliescu have been in power since the December revolution that ousted Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu, first on an interim basis, then as part of a democratically elected government after their National Salvation Front scored an overwhelming victory in May. Speaking after meeting with Roman, Iliescu, and opposition and labor leaders, Dole said that ``We know there have been great changes since last Dec. 22, but we think additional changes could be made and should be made. ``We have strong reservations,'' he continued. ``Obviously compared to Ceausescu anything in the world is better, but that doesn't mean that it's the way it should be.'' He said he was concerned about mass arrests made after anti-government demonstrations, delays in issuing passports and the continuing state monopoly over the mass media. Dole insisted that Congress will have to be satisfied that ``the human rights record in this country is exemplary'' before restoring Romania's Most Favored Nation trading status _ lost in 1988 _ and allocating large-scale humanitarian and other aid. Sen. Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York said he would probably support restoration of the clause after being told by opposition leaders here that they would welcome such a step. The Senate delegation also includes John Warner of Virginia, Jake Garn of Utah, Steven Symms of Idaho, Don Nickles of Oklahoma, and Connie Mack of Florida. They left for Czechoslovakia Friday. They already visited Yugoslavia and plan stops in Italy, Bulgaria, Bahrain, Egypt and the Soviet Union.

DOC.HEAD: CDC Stops Monkey Breeding at L'ville, 2 Months After Heat Deaths
DOC.TEXT: The national Centers for Disease Control has discontinued the research monkey breeding program at its suburban Lawrenceville facility after 14 primates died there of heatstroke. The Atlanta-based CDC is keeping open the Lawrenceville research station, which performs rabies research and raises other animals. But 116 monkeys bred at the facility were shipped this week to a federally funded primate center at Covington, La., CDC Public Affairs Director Don Berreth said Friday. Fourteen rhesus monkeys died of heatstroke on July 9, after handlers placed them outside to recover from anesthesia on a day when temperatures reached 96 degrees. CDC researchers said the deaths were puzzling, as rhesus monkeys are routinely found in hot areas of India and Asia. CDC's decision to phase out its monkey breeding program was made before the heatstroke deaths, but ``it was clearly accelerated'' by controversy over the deaths, Berreth said. With wider commercial availability of laboratory monkeys in recent years, ``we simply no longer have the kind of need for monkeys we had before,'' Berreth said. CDC officials said the July 9 mishap was the worst loss of primates in the agency's history. The monkeys had been anesthetized so handlers could de-worm them and test them for a primate AIDS virus and for tuberculosis. They had not yet been placed into research projects.

DOC.HEAD: Typhoon Abe Kills 5, Leaves Thousands Homeless
DOC.TEXT: Five Chinese have been killed and thousands forced from their homes by Typhoon Abe, the sixth major storm to hit China's southeastern coast this summer, an official report said Saturday. Abe, packing 100 mph winds, left two people missing and 15 injured in Taiwan before sweeping over China's Zhejiang province Friday. It was headed northward toward Jiangsu province and Shanghai, China's largest city, the China Daily reported. In addition to the five deaths, the typhoon caused widespread damage and disrupted communications and power over a large area of Zhejiang, it said. It said the typhoon was expected to cause substantial damage to major harbors. China's southern coast already has been buffeted by five typhoons this summer. Earlier this month, Typhoon Yancy swept through northern Taiwan and killed 20 people before moving on to China's southern coast, where it caused at least 216 deaths.

DOC.HEAD: Shevardnadze Begins Asian Tour to Mend Fences with Neighbors
DOC.TEXT: Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze left Friday on a weeklong Asian tour to shore up relations with three of the Soviet Union's neighbors. His first stop is China, whose Communist leaders have criticized reforms initiated by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Shevardnadze will meet Chinese Foreign Minister Qian Qichen in the northeastern city of Harbin to discuss events in the Persian Gulf, Cambodia and cuts in weapons and armed forces along the 5,000-mile Soviet-Chinese border. Gorbachev's 1989 visit to China, the first by a Soviet leader in 30 years, encouraged pro-democracy demonstrators camping out in Beijing's Tiananmen Square. A few days after Gorbachev's departure, Chinese army troops crushed the movement, killing hundreds of students and others. Deputy Foreign Minister Igor Rogachev said Shevardnadze's visit comes at a ``very critical period in international politics, when tension in the Persian Gulf has come to a head.'' ``The Soviet Union and the United States, for example, regularly exchange views, whereas there are no regular consultations between the Soviet Union and China,'' Rogachev told the official Tass news agency. ``Therefore such consultations will be very important.'' Shevardnadze said in a Tass interview before leaving Moscow that the Soviet Union and the United States, as permanent members of the U.N. Security Council, ``bear certain responsibility'' for resolving the crisis sparked by Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. On Sunday and Monday, Shevardnadze planned to visit North Korea, a longtime Soviet ally that also has been critical of the political changes in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe. The talks will focus on ``ways to lower military confrontation on the Korean Peninsula'' and elsewhere in Asia, Shevardnadze told Tass. North Korea, one of the world's last hard-line Communist countries, is especially unhappy over Gorbachev's overtures to its bitter enemy, South Korea. Gorbachev met with South Korean President Roh Tae-woo in San Francisco in June and the two countries have been working to establish diplomatic ties. Shevardnadze is scheduled to arrive Tuesday in Japan to resolve what he called ``issues that have piled up for decades.'' Foreign Ministry officials said he would lay the groundwork for a visit by Gorbachev next year and push for a peace treaty formally ending World War II. Relations between the two countries have long been strained over Japan's demand that the Soviet Union return the Kuril islands, a small chain off northern Japan seized by the Soviets in the last days of the war. Moscow claims them historically as Russian territory.

DOC.HEAD: Secret Police Say Terrorism Decreasing in Colombia
DOC.TEXT: Terrorist attacks and murders around Colombia have decreased sharply in recent weeks, according to a report by the secret police published Friday. Officials have attributed the decline in violence to a government crackdown on drug trafficking and peace talks with rebel groups. ``In Colombia, there is a new climate of peace,'' Defense Minister Oscar Botero told reporters earlier this week. The report published Friday said there were 321 murders in Colombia during August, compared to 678 in June, according to El Tiempo, the country's leading newspaper. The murders included street killings and domestic brawls, but in the past Colombia's high murder rate has been attributed to leftist guerrillas, right-wing death squads and drug traffickers. There were 21 terrorist attacks in August, down from 94 in March, the report said. The report was presented to President Cesar Gaviria's administration by the Department of Administrative Security, Colombia's secret police, El Tiempo said. In July, the Medellin cocaine cartel, the world's largest cocaine supplier, declared a unilateral truce in its campaign of bombings and assassinations in response to the anti-trafficking policy. In the 11 months before the cease-fire, drug traffickers were blamed for killing more than 550 Colombians, including about 250 policemen and three presidential candidates. In a meeting Friday with senior government officials, Gaviria said judges trying drug cases will be able to keep their identities secret. In the past, drug traffickers have bribed or threatened judges into releasing them. Judges who refused were often murdered.

DOC.HEAD: Children of Deployed Soldier Placed in Foster Home
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, `The father...' with 4 grafs to CORRECT spelling of father's name, CLARIFY that Army unable to reach him; picks up 5th graf pvs, `Police officer..; CORRECTS spelling of last name throughout
DOC.TEXT: Three children, found at home alone, hungry and dirty after their soldier-father was sent to the Middle East last week were placed in a foster home Friday, officials said. ``The children are fine,'' said Charles Wilson, director of child welfare for the state Department of Human Services. Two boys, 13 and 9, and their 12-year-old sister were without food or hot water when they were found Wednesday at their home. Their father, stationed at Fort Campbell, Ky., had been deployed to Saudi Arabia, police said. The father, Staff Sgt. Faagalo Savaiki of the 501st Signal Battalion, could face charges when he returns from military duty, authorities said. Public Affairs officer Bill Harralson said Friday that Army officials had not been able to reach Savaiki, who left Saudi Arabia for American Samoa Thursday after learning that his mother was ill. ``We don't know if he's still en route or if he's at the hospital,'' Harralson said. ``Once the emergency is over they are directing him to return to the base instead of Saudi Arabia.'' Harralson said the Army would not file charges against Savaiki because it is a civilian matter. Police officer Joe Goff said the youngsters' mother divorced Savaiki and returned to Hawaii three weeks ago. Police were called in Wednesday night after a member of Savaiki's company checked on the children. The children, who had been attending school, were alone in a house almost bare of furniture, Goff said. They wore dirty clothing because they hadn't learned how to do the laundry. Savaiki had tacked a note to a wall, explaining how to get money out of the bank with an automatic teller card and telling the children which bills to pay. ``They didn't have any money at the time. They hadn't bought anything. There was nothing in the house for them to eat. The house was quite a mess,'' Goff said. Wilson would not discuss the specifics of the case, but said normally officials would try to locate relatives to care for such children. ``We try to keep them in a similar environment,'' he said. Peggy Jones, a neighbor of the Savaikis, said she had seen the children leaving for school and returning in the afternoon. ``Nothing looked wrong,'' she said. ``Bless their hearts, they're good children. They always played well together. This is just a complete shock to us.'' Police notified the Clarksville-Montgomery County Humane Society after finding a starving dog chained outside to a tree. Inside the house, a cat had given birth to kittens that had just opened their eyes. The animals are now in the care of the Humane Society.

DOC.HEAD: Korean Meeting Augurs Better Relations Between Rival Nations
DOC.TEXT: The prime minister of North Korea will visit South Korean President Roh Tae-woo next week in what is viewed as a first step toward mutual recognition by the rival nations. North Korean Premier Yon Hyong Muk will pay a courtesy call on Roh during four days of talks with South Korean officials on easing tension on the divided Korean peninsula, officials said. In their official declarations, capitalist South Korea and Communist North Korea, bitterly divided since 1945, each claims sole representation for the entire peninsula. The North Korean premier, accompanied by about 90 aides and reporters, will cross the heavily armed border Tuesday for unprecedented talks with his South Korean counterpart, Kang Young-hoon. He is scheduled to return home Friday. The prime ministers' talks will be the highest level meeting ever between the hostile nations. The meeting will focus on easing more than four decades of military and political enmity. An official itinerary released Friday did not include any schedule for Yon's courtesy call on Roh but government officials said it will take place Thursday. In earlier working negotiations, the two Koreas agreed to hold a second round of prime ministers' talks in the North Korean capital of Pyongyang on Oct. 16-19. The prime ministers' talks in Seoul will be held at a luxury hotel near the Olympic Stadium with about 3,000 police deployed for security, officials said. South Korean officials attach great significance to the talks, but longtime observers doubt that any substantial progress can be made because the premiers of both nations are mostly figureheads without policy roles. North Korea has said the talks should deal mainly with ways to ease political and military tensions. South Korean officials insist that priority be given to non-political exchanges to promote mutual confidence. North Korea has proposed drastic arms reductions, cutting the troop level of both sides to 100,000 each. North Korea has more than 1 million troops, while South Korea has 650,000. The North Koreans also demand withdrawal of the 43,000 U.S. troops stationed in South Korea under a mutual defense treaty. But South Korea opposes any drastic measures like arms cuts before an extended period of confidence building. The two nations fought a three-year war in the early 1950s. Their border is sealed without mail or direct communication. They have held talks on and off since the early 1970s but failed to make major progress.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Attend Funeral; Banned Military Group Continues to Surrender
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of Armenians attended funeral services Friday for a member of the republic's parliament and another man who were shot this week, witnesses said. The shootings intensified the the crisis in the republic. Crowds lined the streets of the capital, Yerevan, for the funeral procession of slain lawmaker Viktor Aivazian and Gehavnik Manukyan, said Raffi Hovannisian, Yerevan representative of the Armenian Association of America. The deaths of the two men early Wednesday morning prompted the Armenian parliament to declare a state of emergency later in the day and to ban the Armenian National Army, which was blamed for the shootings. The fighting in Armenia appeared to die down as members of the banned Armenian National Army continued to surrender to local authorities, the state news agency Tass reported. More than two dozen bands of the banned paramilitary organization have turned themselves in, along with 50 automatic weapons, the report said. The Armenian National Army was created last winter as a vigilante group to protect the mostly Christian population of Armenia from mostly Moslem population of Azerbaijan. The neighboring republics have been battling for two years over jurisdiction of Nagorno-Karabakh, a largely Armenian enclave inside Azerbaijan. Last week, Armenia declared idepedendence from the Soviet Union, becoming the fifth Soviet repubic to do so. Azerbaijani nationalists attempted to declare independence last winter, but Soviet troops intervened and much of the republic has been under virtual military rule since then. Although the Armenian National Army and the Armenian government share many aims, they have been fighting each other.

DOC.HEAD: Voice of America to Broadcast Around the Clock to Gulf
DOC.TEXT: The Voice of America will begin around-the-clock broadcasts to the Middle East next week, despite Iraqi efforts to jam the programming, the government announced Friday. The broadcasting service, an arm of the government's United States Information Agency, is already beaming 9 3@4 hours daily of broadcasting in Arabic to the region. Beginning Wednesday at 7 a.m. EDT, that will increase to 13 hours a day. The remaining 11 hours of programming each day will be in English. ``In times of crisis we redouble our efforts to pierce the information barriers surrounding closed societies,'' Voice of America Director Richard W. Carlson said. Iraq is jamming Voice of America broadcasts to the Persian Gulf with 500-kilowatt transmitters. To get its programming through, the Voice of America has been sending its radio signals over short- and medium-wave frequencies, varying them in an effort to evade the Iraqi jamming. It is also sending audio signals that can be picked up by satellite dishes. The agency is beaming news programming, as well as State Department advisories meant for Americans in Iraq and Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Carbon Monoxide Exposure During Exercise Linked to Heart Problems
DOC.TEXT: People with heart disease who exercise in air laden with carbon monoxide are likely to suffer irregular heartbeats, a precursor to sudden death, according to a published study. The research, by the University of North Carolina and the Environmental Protection Agency, expands on earlier findings that even low levels of carbon monoxide are dangerous for the estimated 9 million Americans with heart disease. An editorial accompanying the report in Saturday's Annals of Internal Medicine said the EPA's carbon monoxide regulations should be better enforced rather than tightened. About one-third of the U.S. population, almost 78 million people, live in areas that exceed the outdoor carbon monoxide limits of 9 parts per million in eight hours or 35 parts per million in one hour, the EPA says. Carbon monoxide reduces the blood's ability to carry oxygen by binding to hemoglobin, a protein that ferries oxygen from the lungs to the heart. The pollutant changes the protein's structure to a form called carboxyhemoglobin, which can't transport oxygen. The average level of carboxyhemoglobin in non-smokers is about 1.5 percent, while the EPA regulations are designed to protect against a 3 percent level. The study examined the heartbeats of 41 non-smokers with heart disease who were exposed to two concentrations of carbon monoxide before riding exercise bicycles. The study was designed to raise the level of carboxyhemoglobin to either 4 percent or 6 percent, a level commonly found in smokers. At levels of 6 percent, the number of multiple irregular heartbeats during exercise was three times greater than normal, the researchers found. The heart irregularities can lead to sudden death. The researchers were surprised to find that the volunteers showed little effect on their heartbeat at the 4 percent level, said the lead author, Dr. David S. Shep of the University of North Carolina. But Shep cautioned against politicizing the study's findings, saying that previous studies found that men with blocked arteries suffered chest pains while exercising when exposed to levels of only 2 percent carboxyhemoglobin. ``The fact that we didn't find effects at 4 percent shouldn't be taken to mean that we should liberalize our (air quality) regulations,'' he warned. The editorialists, Dr. Sandra Walden and Dr. Sidney Gottlieb of the Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine, said the study's implications for environmental regulations are ``complex.'' ``A simplistic solution may appear to be tighter restrictions of automobile and other industrial emissions; however, without equally serious consideration of enforcement issues, the effect of tighter restrictions alone would be limited,'' they wrote. Gottlieb said it was ``frightening'' that low levels of carbon monoxide can apparently be dangerous to so many people with heart problems or heart disease. Jim Raub, a health scientist for the EPA, said the study will contribute to a current evaluation of carbon monoxide regulations. He said the study's results will add to the debate over whether tighter restrictions are needed to protect more people. People who exercise outdoors _ whether afflicted with heart disease or not _ should exercise early or late in the day to avoid peaks in the air's level of carbon monoxide, and shun traffic-congested areas, said Dr. Phillip Marone, director of Thomas Jefferson University's Sports Medicine Center.

DOC.HEAD: AT&T Crisis Management Center Got Employees Out of Kuwait
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf, `A telephone ...' to show phone lines to Kuwait cut after 24 hours; SUBS 11th graf, `Linnen would...' with 2 grafs to CLARIFY that caravan did not include other companies' employees; SUBS 16th graf, `In AT&T's...' to CLARIFY that AT&T not saying it feared interception of plans
DOC.TEXT: While White House officials scrambled for information during the initial hours of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, AT&T's own crisis management center was plotting an escape for dozens of employees. An undisclosed number of American Telephone & Telegraph Co. employees were among a group of U.S. nationals working in Kuwait whose companies had security measures in place for such a crisis. ``Our security director was awakened about 3 o'clock in the morning by our people in a location in Kuwait City,'' AT&T spokesman Herb Linnen said Friday from Washington. The security director and his staff had the crisis center went into action in an hour, he said. Eighteen people have been staffing it around the clock ever since. At the direction of the crisis center, carloads of company employees in Kuwait City formed a caravan within a week of the invasion, and confronted Iraqi tanks and soldiers on a 20-hour trek through the desert to Saudi Arabia. The center, at an undisclosed location in northern New Jersey, is a converted conference room stocked with computers, maps, telephones and other communications equipment. ``Clearly our people in Kuwait City who were hearing reports of violence against people were nervous,'' Linnen said. ``There were reports of violence and of rapes.'' A telephone line from Kuwait City to the crisis center in New Jersey was left open until it was cut about 24 hours later. ``We kept the line open literally as a psychological lifeline to those individuals,'' Linnen said. ``They wanted to have assurance that AT&T's top management was looking out for their interests.'' AT&T officials were in contact with other companies, he said, including Chiquita Brands International in Cincinnati, Westinghouse Electric Corp. in Pittsburgh, and Boeing Co. in Seattle. Linnen said more than 20 AT&T employees fled Kuwait in two caravans. Spokesmen from Westinghouse and Chiquita said they could not comment on evacuation efforts or employees who may be in Kuwait or Iraq. Boeing spokesman Paul Binder said the company had no employees in Iraq and only two in Kuwait, who are still believed to be there. However, all three companies said they have procedures to take care of overseas employees when and if trouble erupts. ``We have a crisis board that meets when something like this happens, and they monitor the situation as best they can and are in contact with various government agencies and other companies when appropriate,'' Binder said. Families of Boeing workers in Saudi Arabia flew home Aug. 10 aboard a new 747-400 sent to evacuate them. In AT&T's case, employees in Kuwait were given general instructions for reaching safety. Specific plans were not discussed, Linnen said. The workers formed a caravan about one week after the Aug. 2 invasion and headed toward the Saudi border, but were turned back by Iraqi troops. ``It was a polite but a firm word that they couldn't pass the checkpoint,'' Linnen said. ``So they went back and they tried again and they got out.'' A second caravan made it across the border a week later. Linnen said security reasons prevented him from discussing how many people made it to Saudi Arabia or how many AT&T employees are still in Iraq or Kuwait. He also declined to identify the route the employees traveled or whether it has since been closed. The center's last contact with AT&T workers still in Iraq and Kuwait was last week, he said. The crisis center was created about two years ago, he said. ``There was a recognition that in the world in which we live there are regrettably situations that could plunge employees into some kind of jeopardy,'' Linnen said. ``It was decided instead of everybody scampering in different directions that there should be a system to react when employees are put in harm's way.''

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Air Force Chief Says Forces On Alert for Any Iraqi Clash
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Air force chief Maj. Gen. Avihu Bin-Nun said Friday that Israel's air force is on alert following Iraqi threats, and he urged the United States to ``remove the Iraqi dictator from the stage'' if war breaks out. But Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir was quoted as saying Israel was not interested in getting involved directly in the Persian Gulf crisis and was not giving advice to anyone. Bin-Nun, interviewed on Israel Television, was asked if fighting between the United States and Iraq would help Israel. ``A violent confrontation is never good for anyone. But in this case, apparently there is no other choice but to harm Iraq's dictator in such a way that would keep the region quiet for a long time,'' he responded. ``Any other action . . . that would not, in the end, remove the Iraqi dictator from the stage, will in the long run harm us, and the whole Arab world and the region.'' The state-run television also broadcast an unusual report showing training flights of a squadron of U.S.-made F-15 jets and a special room where pilots engaged in computer analysis of mock air battles conducted earlier in the day. Bin-Nun, interviewed in front of an F-15, said: ``The air force is on a high level of alert in order to give an answer to any threat or any hint of a threat to Israel. It's on alert every day of the year and especially in these days . . . It's ready and continues to prepare itself for response to any threat that (Iraqi President) Saddam Hussein dares to make.'' The interview was broadcast a day after an unidentified Iraqi air force commander threatened to respond to a U.S. military action with ``smashing blows to the nests of the Israelis.'' Shamir warned Saddam ``any aggressor would live to regret his actions.'' But he told visiting British parliamentarians of the Friends of Israel group that Israel was determined not to become involved in the crisis. ``He emphasized and re-emphasized that Israel had no interest whatever in getting involved, that Israel was not giving advice to anyone, that Israel would of course react if attacked, but it hoped it would not be,'' Labor parliamentarian Greville Janner said on Israel radio after a meeting with Shamir. An Israeli military source, who briefed reporters Friday on condition of anonymity, said Israel believed Iraq was unlikely now to initiate military action against the Jewish state but could do so if attacked by U.S. and other forces from Saudi Arabia. He said the Iraqis may believe an attack on Israel would give them widespread support by Arab nations, most of which have opposed the Iraqi invasion and annexation of Kuwait. He added there was no proof Iraq could reach Israel with missiles armed with chemical warheads.

DOC.HEAD: Medicines Added to Shortages of Food, Gasoline, Tobacco
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6 grafs for 13-15 pvs, `Felix Sarnov...' to ADD reports of cigarettes from Afghanistan and Albania, other quote from Trud. Pickup 16th pvs, `Reasons for...'
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union is swiftly running out of essential medicines, angering consumers already beset by shortages of gasoline, tobacco and food. ``As early as next February, the country may run out of drugs completely, because the pharmaceutical industry is crumbling even more rapidly than the rest of the economy,'' Health Minister Igor Denisov warned Thursday. ``We have already seen tobacco riots,'' the workers' newspaper Trud commented. ``Shall we now prepare for aspirin riots?'' Soviets are accustomed to permanent shortages of some goods, such as winter boots and automobile parts, and occasional shortages of many others, ranging from toothpaste to coffee. But as President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's reforms have inched the Soviet Union toward a market economy, the resulting inflation and hoarding have worsened many of the perennial shortages and created new ones. Drugs have never been plentiful, and Denisov said the industry is falling further behind. He told Trud the country met 52 percent of the domestic demand for medicine in 1985, but expects to meet only 39 percent this year and 30 percent in 1991. In addition, the newspaper Moskovskaya Pravda said Thursday that Moscow faces a potential ``bread panic'' because bakeries are unable to keep up with the spurt in demand as residents return to the city after August vacations. Gasoline has long been rationed in some Soviet cities, and even in Moscow supplies have rarely been ample. But the situation has grown acute in recent days as car owners have made a run on gas stations. The evening television news program Vremya said drivers were reacting to rumors the Soviet Union may export more oil to take advantage of higher prices caused by the Persian Gulf crisis. In the Central Asian republic of Uzbekistan, Vremya said people were waiting in line all night to buy small amounts of fuel _ even if it wasn't the right kind for their cars. ``Car owners are panicking,'' the announcer said as the television showed people asleep in a line of cars. A tobacco shortage that began in early summer has fueled street protests in half a dozen cities and rioting in Siberia. In Moscow, where rationing will limit residents to five packs a month starting Sept. 1, jars of cigarette butts are being sold by street vendors for $16. ``What are we worth?'' a reporter for Trud wrote indignantly. ``I don't think there's another country in the world, much less one that claims the title of a great power, where cigarette butts are sold in the markets of the capital _and where people would buy them!'' Felix Sarnov, a 35-year-old chain smoker, said he spent a week without cigarettes and felt so ill he could hardly get out of bed. ``We've never been without tobacco before,'' he said. ``You can do without vegetables, various foods and things like that. But if you're a smoker, cigarettes are your No. 1 need.'' On Wednesday, Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev publicly berated five senior officials for allowing the tobacco crisis to develop. On Thursday, he fired First Deputy Prime Minister Vladilen Nikitin, who headed the state commission on foodstuffs and purchases. Earlier this week, President Najibullah of Afghanistan sent a special plane with 4 million packs of cigarettes to the Soviet people, the government newspaper Izvestia reported. Tass on Friday said cigarettes are among the items Moscow soon will purchase from Albania, ending a 29-year-old break in trade with that nation. Reasons for the shortages are varied and murky, but they show that the old central planning system is in a state of collapse. In the case of tobacco, harvests have dwindled, and a shortage of foreign currency in Soviet coffers forced a reduction in cigarette imports this year. The health ministry has said of the medicine shortage only that the pharmaceutical industry is crumbling. But observers say the Soviet Union has concentrated on producing a large volume of a few drugs, such as polio vaccine, that it can sell abroad for hard currency, while neglecting the needs of its population for birth control pills, stomach medications and headache remedies. Those items, as well as antibiotics and more specialized drugs, are in chronic short supply.

DOC.HEAD: Argentina Announces Layoffs, Other Austerity Moves
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with changes announced officially. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: The government steeply increased utility rates Friday and announced plans to lay off thousands of public employees in an effort to cut the financial deficit and stimulate an economy in deep recession. Hours earlier, President Carlos Menem asked his countrymen to have patience with his 13-month-old government, which took office amid hyperinflation and recession. Economy Minister Antonio Gonzalez said many public employees under contract would be laid off beginning in September, and civil servants would be forced to retire early. He gave no figure, but analysts said the total would reach at least 80,000 of a public workforce of 3 million. Gonzalez said gasoline prices for cars would go up 35 percent as of Saturday, and other public service rates would increase by an average 12 to 15 percent, or about the rate of inflation projected for August. He said his ministry will oversee the 13 biggest state companies, which until now reported to the Public Works Ministry, and the major factories that until now were part of the Defense Ministry. The state airline, railroad, telphone and other companies must pay their debts from their revenue and budgets because the Central Bank no longer will make up their deficits, he announced. The Central Bank will require all banks that owe it money to clear up their accounts. Those that cannot will be forced out of business, he said. ``Argentina is undertaking a profound transformation of the public sector,'' Gonzalez said in a address on state radio and TV. The goal ``is a state that is austere and efficient . . . (and capable) of all the tasks of a modern state.'' The measures were imposed by decree. Menem's solution to Argentina's economic straits has been to reduce the role of the state in the economy and spur private enterprise. ``We're looking from the national government to restructure the state, to do serious surgery on the state, and for that sacrifice and understanding are needed,'' Menem told reporters. ``The party is over.'' The Menem government removed controls on prices and foreign exchange, linked public service rates and their costs, reduced import tariffs and export taxes, cut the 1990 budget by $4 billion, encouraged foreign investment and partially deregulated the oil industry. The government also has proposed tax reform and reorganizing the Central Bank to make it more independent. As a result, the increase in the monthly cost of living fell to near single digits in July from 197 percent 12 months earlier. The exchange rate has held steady for six months. The fiscal deficit narrowed. The cost has been a deep recession, however. Unemployment and underemployment at a combined rate of 18 percent is a record. Real wages have not kept up with inflation. Many families are hard pressed to make ends meet. Wage strikes and public protests about the pending sale of public firms like the airline and phone company are increasing. Teachers have boycotted public classrooms for a month. Political leaders openly worry about the prospect of social upheaval, such as the food riots of May and June 1989 which killed 16 people, wounded more than 200 and resulted in nearly 2,500 arrests.

DOC.HEAD: U.N. Chief Meets Iraqi, Baghdad Says More Men Will Be Taken To Sites
LaserPhotos LON1,2,3; XSAV2
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout, UPDATING with Japanese plane en route, Kuwaiti U.S. embassy travail, Schwartzkopf quotes, other. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: The U.N. chief tried for five hours Friday to get Iraq to think twice about its occupation of Kuwait, and Baghdad announced it was sending more foreign men to be serve as shields at potential military targets. ``Every place, every town that has a vital installation will host our guests,'' an Iraqi government spokesman said. Iraq calls ``guests'' the thousands of Westerners it has detained since it invaded Kuwait Aug. 2. Army Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, commander of U.S. forces in the Persian Gulf, did some tough talking of his own. He called Iraqi generals ``a bunch of thugs,'' but said war can be averted if Iraqi troops stay out of Saudi Arabia. He also said he could not let the fate of hostages in Iraq affect his strategy. About 21,000 Westerners _ including 3,000 Americans and 4,500 Britons _ have been prevented from leaving Iraq and Kuwait. U.S. Embassy diplomats in Kuwait are resisting Iraqi orders to close the mission and said water was running low, food was spoiling and they were sleeping outdoors to escape the heat because electricity also was cut off, according to a report in the Saturday edition of The New York Times. The report from Kuwait quoted Ambassador Nathaniel Howell as remarking ``it isn't a very pleasant way'' to live. Baghdad also tied the release of 237 foreign women and children to the return of Iraqis it said were stranded in Britain and France as a result of international trade sanctions. U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar met twice with Iraq's foreign minister, Tariq Aziz, in Amman, Jordan, trying to negotiate a solution to the gulf crisis. The two will meet again Saturday. Aziz told reporters later all foreigners in Iraq could leave if Perez de Cuellar could produce guarantees against a military attack from the West. Iraq made a similar offer to Washington on Wednesday, through its U.S. ambassador. The United States rejected any conditions for releasing hostages. Perez de Cuellar called the talks a ``step forward,'' but said nothing about guarantees and said he had no immediate plans to go to Baghdad to meet President Saddam Hussein. A senior Jordanian official had said the two would meet if the Amman meetings yielded results. Aziz said upon arrival that Iraq ``will achieve victory despite the international conspiracy against it.'' But later he also said Iraq ``has no intention of igniting the explosive situation.'' More than 50,000 supporters of the fundamentalist Moslem Brotherhood marched through Amman's streets on Friday demanding holy war against ``U.S.-Zionist aggression'' on Arab soil. Sources in Baghdad, meanwhile, said nationwide food rationing would begin Saturday, a result of U.N.-ordered sanctions against Iraq. Coupon books were issued and food distribution centers were set up, the sources said in telephone interviews. Long lines formed at bakeries in the capital, and similar queues were reported outside food shops in smaller towns. In Washington, the White House said President Bush telephoned Saudi Arabia's King Fahd, British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and French President Francois Mitterrand on Friday on the crisis. Bush wants wealthy allies to help foot the $1 billion-a-month cost of deploying U.S. forces in Saudi Arabia and the gulf region. Administration sources said some allies and congressmen were pressuring the White House to move militarily against Saddam, but that the pressure by no means constituted a consensus. In Moscow, Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev blamed Saddam for the ``very dangerous'' situation in the gulf, but noted his nation still favors a diplomatic solution. He said ``we have to act responsibly, all of us, to prevent a large-scale military conflict.'' About 60,000 U.S. combat troops have moved to battle stations and their number is expected to hit 100,000 soon, facing an estimated 265,000 Iraqi troops stationed in and around Kuwait. Japanese Foreign Ministry officials said a government-chartered passenger plane left Saturday for Amman to airlift Japanese women and children from Iraq. An official, speaking anonymously, said 80 Japanese, mostly women and children, will be flown home. The Office of the U.N. Disaster Relief Coordinator appealed in Geneva for more shelters, food and sanitary equipment for about 90,000 people _ mostly Bangladeshis, Pakistanis, Sri Lankans and Filipinos _ it says have taken refuge in Jordan after fleeing Iraq and Kuwait. About 20,000 new evacuees are arriving daily, it said. U.S. State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said an American woman was granted an exit visa and allowed to leave for Jordan. A U.S. diplomat in Baghdad said no Americans had been granted exit permits by Friday. There was no explanation for the discrepancy. Nineteen Italians _ 16 women and three children _ arrived safely in Jordan Friday. They were believed to be among the first Westerners to go free under Iraq's offer Tuesday to release women and children. Three Finnish women left Iraq for Turkey, the Finnish government said. Greece, Sweden and Britain all reported some of their women and children receiving exit visas. On Thursday, Iraq assembled more than 200 foreign women and children at Baghdad's Menia Hotel after promising to release them. Some were held earlier at Iraqi military and civilian targets, used as human shields by Saddam to discourage possible U.S. attacks. Most of the foreigners at the hotel were from the United States, Britain, France, Japan and Australia. Iraq has said the women and children will need exit visas. Since Friday was the Moslem sabbath, exit visas were not expected before Saturday. Iraqi government spokesman Naji al-Hadithi said more than 200 foreign women and children were waiting to leave for London and Paris on Iraqi Airways. He said Iraq wanted the same planes used to bring back Iraqis he said were stranded in the two cities by the ``brutal American sanctions.'' The proposal was not a condition for the release of the 237 foreingers, but without Iraqi planes the group might have to travel overland, he said. The trade sanctions placed no restrictions on Iraqis living overseas. Britain's Foreign Office said it had no objections to the Iraqis leaving. France said it was not officially informed of the Iraqi demands. France has put 26 Iraqi military or civilian defense personnel under police surveillance since canceling their training programs after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. It was not immediately clear whether al-Hadithi was referring to the 26. About 1,700 Iraqis, many of them exiled opponents of Saddam, live in France. More foreign men have been taken to potential military targets all over Iraq, al-Hadithi said. ``We're relocating the foreign men all over the country at airports, air bases, military bases, industrial plants, communications centers, power centers and oil refineries _ wherever Iraq considers it has a vital installation, one exposed to the American threat in Saudi Arabia,'' he said. In other developments: _Arab foreign ministers ended a two-day emergency session in Cairo with a new condemnation of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait and a call for Iraq to immediately release foreign hostages, conference sources said. _The Kota Wirama, the first freighter to be stopped, searched and boarded by the U.S. Navy during the gulf crisis, is trying to find a port that will accept its cargo bound for Iraq, Lloyd's List International said Friday. Also Friday, the Pentagon said that an Iraqi tanker had been boarded in the Red Sea by a party from the USS Biddle. ``The vessel was determined to be empty and allowed to proceed,'' a Pentagon official said. _Six more warships from the United States, Britain and the Netherlands entered Egypt's Suez Canal en route toward the Persian Gulf, joining dozens already there. Norway said Friday it will send a coast guard vessel to the multinational force. _An Israeli military source said Jordanian military planes are flying spy missions along the Saudi border to supply Iraq with information on troop movements.

In American eyes, the United Nations has come a long way since those days a generation ago when signs sprouted along the nation's highways carrying a succinct message: ``The U.S. Out of the U.N. and the U.N. Out of the U.S.'' That was a time when the U.N. was a target of widespread ridicule, seemingly incapable of doing much to keep the peace. The image of the grim-faced Soviet envoy casting veto after veto was a topic of many a political cartoon. But the ability of Washington and Moscow to get along has breathed new life into the long-beleaguered world body, which is coming off one of the best months of its 45-year history. Without much fanfare, the Security Council this week laid the groundwork for an end to the 11-year-old civil war in Cambodia. Such agreement had been impossible beforehand because three of the five Security Council members _ the United States, the Soviet Union and China _ had been backing different factions in that conflict.

A broken electronic part caused NASA to scrub Saturday's scheduled launch of space shuttle Columbia, extending the bad luck that has dogged the space agency all year. NASA officials waited until late Thursday night before halting the countdown for a scientific mission that was to last nine or 10 days. Another attempt won't be made before Wednesday. The culprit was in an electronic box that routes electrical power and telemetry between the spacecraft and an X-ray telescope mounted at the rear of its cargo bay. The launch control center had been unable to issue commands to the telescope since the shuttle's cargo bay doors were closed Wednesday evening.

Police said they still didn't have a ``hot suspect'' in the slayings of five college students, but investigators were dispatched across the state to track down leads. About 600 law enforcement officials are involved in a hunt for the killer, who investigators have said is a ``methodical maniac'' with a sick grudge against petite brunettes with shoulder-length hair. The victims _ students at either the University of Florida or Santa Fe Community College _ were stabbed to death in off-campus apartments in three attacks discovered since Sunday. Police said three of the women were mutilated. Funeral services were scheduled for four of the victims in their hometowns today. They are Christina Powell, 17, of Jacksonville; Christa Hoyt, 18, of Newberry; Tracy Paules, 23, of Coral Gables; and Manuel Taboada, 23, of Miami. On Thursday, more that a thousand friends and family members gathered at a Pompano Beach church to mourn Miss Powell's roommate, 18-year-old Sonja Larson.

Political storm clouds are gathering over the Philippines, creating the perception that President Corazon Aquino's government faces a grave and perhaps final crisis. Such fears have long plagued the Aquino government, which came to power in the heady days of the 1986 ``people power revolution'' that deposed the late President Ferdinand Marcos. But in the past three weeks, public confidence has plummeted. Rumors of a new coup attempt are rampant. Commentators believe the nation is facing a political showdown that may spell the end of Philippine democracy. ``Four years after its restoration, constitutional democracy in the Philippines is heading toward collapse ahead of the end of President Aquino's term in 1992,'' wrote Amando Doronila, editor of the pro-government newspaper, The Manila Chronicle.

Residents of the nation's capital finally are focusing attention on who will be their city's next leader after spending months preoccupied with the drug and perjury trial of outgoing Mayor Marion Barry. While Barry's trial dominated the news, the mayor's would-be successors did little or no campaigning, saving their efforts for a time when they would have the voters' full attention. Five Democrats and one Republican are running for mayor, with the winner of the Sept. 11 Democratic primary considered the prohibitive favorite in a city where Democrats outnumber Republicans by almost a 9-1 margin. ``Until last week, the press wasn't paying any attention to this campaign,'' said City Council Chairman David Clarke, who is one of the Democratic contenders. ``Finally, we can get the issues out before the voters.''

Connecticut has rediscovered a relic from its Puritan past: Police this summer have charged four people with adultery.
