DOC.HEAD: Gardeners Urged To Avoid Buying Endangered Wildflowers
Laserphoto
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Faith Campbell is not related to Charlie Campbell
DOC.TEXT: Endangered species pop up in the strangest places. Like flowerbeds. Plant-protection activists say some species of bulbs bought to decorate American and European gardens are being collected by the millions in the wild, threatening to wipe out those flowers in their home turf. ``The world would lose an irreplaceable treasure,'' said Marjorie Arundel of Warrenton, Va., an adviser to the Garden Club of America's horticulture committee. ``They're the ancestors of all of our spring bulbs today.'' Mrs. Arundel and other activists are urging American gardeners to buy only commercially propagated plants, which experts say make up at least 99 percent of the flower trade anyway. ``Wild-collected flowers are a small percentage of the trade, but a large percentage of certain kinds of plants,'' said Faith Campbell, director of the plant conservation program for the Natural Resources Defense Council, an environmental group. Working with the World Wildlife Fund and the Garden Club of America, the NRDC has produced leaflets calling on gardeners to avoid most kinds of cyclamen, sternbergia and galanthus, or snowdrops, which they say are collected in the wild in Turkey. Those three species are listed as endangered in the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora, or CITES. But this treaty _ effective in fighting trade in some endangered animal skins, horns and tusks _ has had little effect on the flower trade, Ms. Campbell said. Snowdrops are greatly depleted in Turkey's Mediterranean regions, forcing traders to seek out sources in more remote regions. The popular ``Angel's Tears'' narcissus are being collected in the wild, but experts are not sure if the source is Portugal or somewhere else. Other wildflowers, such as trillium, are being collected from the wild in the United States and Canada. Japan, China, India and the Soviet Union appear to be the sources for still other rare flowers. Some species of these plants may be produced by growers in the United States or Europe, but buyers are being counseled to check the origins as carefully as they can. This may become easier, as a result of the decision last May by the Dutch Commodity Board for Ornamental Horticultural Products to require exporters to use a ``Bulbs from Wild Sources'' label to identify wild-collected plants. Under the negotiated agreement, Dutch exporters will also label their cultivated bulbs, beginning in 1992 for minor species and in 1995 for such major bulb varieties as tulips and hyacinths. Because the Netherlands has long dominated the world flower trade, the action by the Dutch regulatory body should have a major impact, Ms. Campbell said. It is not binding, though, on dealers in the United States or other countries. Also, the agreement was reached too late for most of this fall's catalogs. So even if American gardeners order from Dutch dealers covered by the rules, they might not know they were buying wild-collected flowers until the bulbs arrive in the mail, labeled ``wild sources.'' ``We can just hope they won't order those again,'' Ms. Campbell said. ``It is a messy phasing-in.'' The long-range solution, she said, could be in helping people in Turkey and elsewhere who make money from collecting wild flowers to start propagating the rare flowers in or near the native habitat, she said. Gardeners shouldn't think they're aiding nature by keeping alive a species that might be disappearing in its native habitat. ``We don't consider that a contribution to conservation in any way,'' Ms. Campbell said. ``It's not playing its role in the ecosystem in which it evolved.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Tuesday AMs, Sept. 4
$Adv02
For Release Sunday, Sept. 2, and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Arctic Island Becomes Hot _ Er, Lukewarm _ Issue
DOC.TEXT: Wrangel Island is 2,800 square miles of freezing, windswept tundra off the Siberian coast. Soviets have been camped there for six decades, but Carl Olson calls it 100 percent American. And the same goes for four other islands flung across hundreds of miles of ocean at the edge of the polar icecap. ``There's no question that the five islands belong to Alaska,'' declares Olson, a crusading Los Angeles teacher. Olson wants the government to reassert American claims abandoned 66 years ago _ if they ever existed. The State Department says this country has never claimed ``Ostrov Vrangelya,'' as its current occupants call it. The U.S.-Soviet Maritime Boundary Treaty signed in June places Wrangel and the four other islands squarely in the Soviet economic-interest area. The Alaska legislature, however, has approved resolutions saying Wrangel should be part of the state and calling for state representation in any negotiations on future ownership. Wrangel is 83 miles across the Long Strait from Siberia, 200 miles from the Alaskan mainland. Bennett Island, the farthest out of the four others, is about 800 miles from Alaska. The others are Herald, Henrietta and Jeannette. July temperatures on Wrangel soar to a high of 36 degrees Fahrenheit and the mean reading for February is 13 below. A recent estimate put Wrangel Island's human population at 50. A colony of Eskimos and Chukchis transplanted from the Siberian mainland was established by the Soviets in 1926. Walruses, seals and polar bears and herds of lemmings live there, too. And Olson recalls an old flickering documentary film showing reindeer prancing in the frozen mists. One of the prime attractions of Wrangel and the shallow seas around it, however, has been the unproven belief that vast oil reserves lie beneath the island and the icy waters off Northeast Siberia. ``Looking beneath the surface of the Arctic waters gives us another vital reason not to give up the area to the Soviets,'' says Olson. ``Oil and gas. Literally billions of barrels.'' Olson has created an organization, State Department Watch, to press the case for making Wrangel and the four other islands part of the United States. Appeals from Olson, a former executive director of the Washington-based Conservative Caucus Inc., have created ripples on Capitol Hill, although not lately. Rep. William Dannemeyer, R-Calif., offered legislation that would bar signing away the island without submitting such a treaty to the Senate. But the bill has been stuck in committee for two years and, despite a new sponsor, Rep. Dan Burton, R-Ind., appears headed for oblivion. A similar measure was introduced in the Senate last year by Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C. Conservatives, however, are not promising to make a fight of it. ``We can't fight every battle,'' says Conservative Caucus leader Howard Phillips. ``We try to fight battles where it can make a difference.'' He says Wrangel and the waters around it could not only yield a petroleum bonanza but prove militarily vital. Tales of a large island off Northeast Siberia circulated in Russia as early as the 18th Century and fired the imagination of explorer Frederick Petrovich von Wrangel. He searched in 1824 but apparently never found it. Its barren shores may first have been sighted by Captain Henry Kellett of then Royal Navy in 1849 after he discovered Herald Island. But an American skipper, Captain Thomas Long, is often credited for discovering Wrangel on a voyage of the barque Nile in 1867. The U.S. Revenue Marine steamer Corwin under captain Calvin L. Hooper visited Wrangel in 1881. Among those who went ashore was the explorer John Muir whose book, The Cruise of the Corwin, told of the expedition. Wrangel and four other islands that amount to pinpoints in the Arctic Ocean were visited in 1881 by Navy Commander George Washington De Long aboard the vessel Jeannette and surveyed for the United States Coast and Geodetic Survey. The survey placed all five islands in the District of Alaska as did the United States Geological Survey starting in 1900. But the island remained unoccupied until 1914 when survivors of an expedition led by Vilhjalmar Steffanson lived there for six months. Ten years later, the Soviets staked their claim and it was not disputed by the United States, Britain or Canada.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, Sept. 2

DOC.TEXT: Bank of New England stock tumbled after a congressional candidate said _ and the government later denied _ that federal regulators had recommended liquidating the struggling bank. Rumors of the institution's demise have circulated on Wall Street in recent days and gained impetus with the statement Thursday, pushing Bank of New England's share price down 62{ cents to $1 on the New York Stock Exchange. Brokers and regulators repeatedly denied the rumors that the bank was about to be taken over, which surfaced again Wednesday. Analysts said such rumors are not uncommon before a long weekend.

Oil prices settled higher as traders focused on tensions instead of the possibility of peace in the Middle East. Light sweet crude for October delivery closed up 85 cents at $26.77 per barrel Thursday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. At one point, crude had moved up to $27.50 as traders began doubting there could be any immediate diplomatic resolution of the Persian Gulf crisis. But a slight sell-off took over after President Bush praised the promise of higher OPEC production and indicated no immediate need to tap into the nation's strategic crude reserves.

Orders to factories for manufactured goods grew 1.6 percent in July, the government reported, but analysts said the zigzag performance so far this year suggested an anemic industrial economy even before the Persian Gulf crisis. The Commerce Department said Thursday that orders for both durable and non-durable goods rose $3.8 billion to a seasonally adjusted $240.3 billion after declining 1.9 percent in June.

The financial conditions of more than 200 savings and loans have worsened since the Office of Thrift Supervision made its last report in May, the agency said. At least 246 S&Ls are expected to fail and are likely candidates for government takeover, the OTS said Thursday.

General Motors Corp. and the United Auto Workers union are close to agreement on a national workplace safety contract provision, UAW and company officials say. Negotiators for both sides have been working in subcomittees with about two weeks to go until UAW contracts with GM, Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp. expire. The agreements cover more than 450,000 active workers nationwide.

Savings and loan prosecutions would be hobbled by spending cuts taking effect if Congress and the White House don't agree on ways to cut the deficit, the Justice Department said. The Dallas S&L Task Force, which has obtained more than 50 convictions since 1987, would be virtually shut down as a result of a 32.4 percent spending cut that would take effect when the new fiscal year begins Oct. 1, the department said Thursday.

Plants that process red meat will be the first to test government guidelines aimed at reducing repetitive motion trauma in the workplace, Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole said. Repetitive motion trauma, a sometimes crippling disorder of the musculoskeletal and nervous system, accounts for nearly half of all occupational disorders in the United States. Dole made the announcement Thursday.

Gannett Co. said it will consolidate its two newspaper divisions, with Gary Watson as president of the new group, effective Oct. 1. Watson, 45, a 21-year veteran at Gannett, will oversee all of Gannett's daily papers, except USA Today, Gannett said Thursday. Gannett is the nation's largest newspaper chain, with 137 daily and non-daily papers. Watson has been president of Gannett's 60-member community newspaper division since December 1985. The division will be combined with Gannett's metropolitan newspaper group.

Texas billionaire Harold C. Simmons, who lost a proxy battle with Lockheed Corp. this spring, has increased his stake in the defense contractor and wants to buy 10 million more shares, documents said. In a filing Thursday with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Simmons disclosed that companies he controls hold 19.8 percent of Calabasas, Calif.-based Lockheed _ up from an 18.94 percent stake in March.

Stock prices fell sharply Thursday in response to higher oil prices and rising interest rates. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 39.11 to 2,593.32. The dollar gained against major foreign currencies. Gold moved mostly higher. Bonds closed mostly lower. Energy futures were higher; grain and soybean futures fell; cocoa prices surged; and livestock and pork futures were mostly lower.

DOC.HEAD: Politician Wrong: Bank Not Flopping, But Tell That to Stockholders
DOC.TEXT: All week rumors swirled on Wall Street that federal regulators might take over the troubled Bank of New England. All week regulators denied they were true. But when a congressional candidate Thursday flatly stated that the government had recommended liquidating the institution, the rumors gained new weight, dragging down Bank of New England's stock price. The episode demonstrated how rumors can move the nation's financial markets, and how, like a game of telephone, rumors can change enough to threaten a company's stability. ``The problem is that irresponsiblity like this press release can kill a bank,'' said Ellen Stockdale, a spokeswoman for the Comptroller of the Currency in Washington, which regulates federally chartered banks. Democratic congressional hopeful Ted Dimauro issued a news release based on rampant rumors the bank would be seized by federal regulators. Dimauro learned of the rumors from a financial wire service report. Dimauro wanted to take a shot at his opponent, Rep. Richard Neal, D-Mass., a member of the House Banking Committee, whom he accused of ignorance about the bank. But he got the facts wrong. ``This is a sad day for Massachusetts as the FDIC has recommended the liquidation of Bank of New England,'' a statement from Dimauro said. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. recommended nothing of the sort. Dimauro later apologized, saying his statement should have noted the wire service report concerned speculation that shouldn't have been presented as fact. He blamed an aide for releasing the statement without his approval. Too late. The bank and federal regulators had to scramble to shore up the bank's reputation, saying it was solvent and denying that a takeover was pending. Already fighting to recover from New England's depressed real estate market that left it holding millions of dollars in bad loans, the bank's stock plummeted 38.5 percent to $1 a share from $1.62{ in New York Stock Exchange trading Thursday. The bank's chairman and chief executive, Lawrence K. Fish, said the ``surprising and harmful rumors that have been circulating about Bank of New England during the last several days are completely untrue.'' ``The facts are that we ... have been fully liquid since mid-June, operating expenses have been sharply reduced and our plans for a recapitalization are well advanced,'' Fish said in a statement. ``Our recovery program is on track.'' Bank of New England has operated under federal orders since early this year. The bank came under heightened government scrutiny when a downturn in the economy and the real estate market exposed mountains of bad loans. The bank lost close to $80 million in the first half of 1990, on top of more than $1 billion in losses last year. Under an operating plan with federal regulators, Bank of New England plans to sell off assets and slash its work force to reduce costs and raise money. Against that backdrop, rumors have circulated occasionally about the bank's future. Analysts said such speculation typically increases before a long holiday weekend. The rumors in this case were so persistent they were likely to have an impact on the bank's stock, said Don Kauth, an analyst with First Albany Corp. ``It's been a distressed bank for some time and the continued deterioration in economic fundamentals in New England made their recovery that much more difficult,'' he said. Kauth, like other analysts, gave credence to the notion of a federal takeover. ``Whether it's this weekend or a month from now or two months from now, it is inevitable,'' he said. Nonetheless, the politician's statement led the bank to drop a policy against commenting on market rumors and regulators to drop theirs on a bank's status. ``Officially we do not comment on the condition of the bank,'' Stockdale said. But she said the incident was ``so weird that we are saying the bank will be open after the (Labor Day) holiday. It will still be the Bank of New England on Tuesday. The press release is not true.'' On top its major error, Dimauro's statement got an important fact wrong: Bank of New England is not regulated by the FDIC. A federally chartered institution, its regulator is the Comptroller of the Currency. Stockdale said her office decides when a bank becomes insolvent, and when that happens the FDIC handles liquidation. ``So,'' she said, ``the press release doesn't even talk about a situation that is real.''

DOC.HEAD: Simmons Seeks 10 Million Lockheed Shares from ESOP
DOC.TEXT: Texas billionaire Harold C. Simmons wants Lockheed Corp. to sell him 10 million shares of common stock and to amend its antitakeover defense to facilitate the sale. NL Industries Inc., a Simmons-controlled Houston chemicals concern, has asked Lockheed to sell 10 million shares in Lockheed's employee stock ownership plan for $35 per share. NL also agreed not to vote those shares for three years to allay management fears that the 10 million additional shares would give away control of the company to Simmons who lost a proxy battle with the defense contractor in March. Simmons' offer was disclosed Thursday in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, in which he also reported that companies he controls hold 19.8 percent of Calabasas, Calif.-based Lockheed _ up from an 18.94 percent stake in March. ``We have received the letter and have no further comment until we can review the proposal,'' Scott Hallman, a Lockheed spokesman, said Thursday. Lockheed closed down 37{ cents Thursday to $26.37{ in trading on the New York Stock Exchange. According to the SEC filing, Simmons companies spent more than $14 million between Aug. 15 and Wednesday buying 510,700 Lockheed shares at prices ranging between $28.75 and $26.25. That put 12.5 million Lockheed shares under the Dallas billionaire's control. Simmons, who has been increasing his Lockheed holdings since March 1989, lost a proxy fight with the aviation concern in March, after Lockheed Chairman Daniel M. Tellep rebuffed his request for board representation. In addition to trying to oust Lockheed's board of directors at the annual shareholders meeting, Simmons sought to eliminate a shareholder rights plan, also known as a poison pill defense. The poison pill would make it prohibitively expensive for anyone to buy 20 percent or more of the company's common stock. In a letter to Tellep, NL President J. Landis Martin asked Lockheed to amend the poison pill to allow the purchase of 10 million shares from the Lockheed ESOP. That would increase his stake in Lockheed to more than 35 percent. Analysts have said the ESOP, which held 17 percent of Lockheed's stock when created, effectively blocks a Lockheed takeover because in Delaware _ where the company is incorporated _ a buyout must be approved by holders of 85 percent of a company's stock. The company created the ESOP last year shortly after Simmons revealed, as required by the SEC, that he held more than 5 percent of Lockheed's shares. Simmons reduced his holdings from 5.9 percent to 4.2 percent after the ESOP was created. In his letter to Tellep, Martin claimed the ESOP ``added approximately $500 million in debt to the company's balance sheet,'' as well as increased interest payments. If Lockheed management objected to the sale of ESOP shares, then it should amend the poison pill to allow NL to buy 10 million shares on the open market, Martin wrote.

DOC.HEAD: Congressional Agency Questions Benefits of Capital Gains Tax Cut
DOC.NOTE: Eds: This was included in PM-Washington in Brief
DOC.TEXT: A capital gains tax reduction ``could not be counted on'' to give a significant boost to American economic growth, the Congressional Budget Office said Thursday. ``It is unlikely that the increase in income would generate enough additional tax revenue'' to offset losses to the Treasury, said the report requested by the congressional tax- and budget-writing committees. During his campaign for the presidency in 1988, President Bush called cutting the tax rate on capital gains one of his top priorities. But the Democratic-controlled Congress has refused to enact the proposal. The administration has pressed for a reduction in the capital gains tax rate during this year's budget negotiations with lawmakers. Rep. Dan Rostenkowski, D-Ill., chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, called the study ``an objective assessment'' of previous reports on the capital gains tax cut Bush proposed in his fiscal 1991 budget. Rostenkowski has been a foe of reducing the capital gains tax rate.

DOC.HEAD: Gas Prices High, But Europe Should Weather Oil Crisis
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 22nd graf pvs, The rises . . . to CORRECT to 5 percent rise in Italy sted 8 percent.
DOC.TEXT: In Rome, gasoline has shot to almost $5 a gallon since Iraq invaded Kuwait. Many Swedes are paying $75 to fill 'er up. But analysts say despite exorbitant price hikes, Western Europe will be less damaged than the United States by rising energy prices. ``The picture that I draw is of a Europe that is not as dependent on oil as it was at the beginning of this decade,'' said Peter Bogin, the assistant director for oil markets at Cambridge Energy Research Associates in Paris. Oil and gas prices have increased worldwide since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. The price of a barrel of light sweet crude hit $32 in New York before receding this week, following OPEC's decision to boost production to make up for lost Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil. Analysts expect the oil crisis to push up inflation and slow growth in Western Europe. But there is little talk about an imminent recession, as in the United States. That's because of the factors in Europe's favor: relatively good economic health; a drop in oil use; and the cheapness of the dollar, the currency used for oil purchases. Western Europe and the United States import about the same amount of crude oil per person, Bogin said. But in addition to the imports, Americans use an equal amount of domestically produced oil. ``We're gas guzzlers. That's the problem,'' said Paul Horne, an American who is chief international economist for Smith Barney International in Paris. Europeans have always relied less on cars than Americans. With traditionally lower incomes, Europeans bought fewer, more gas-efficient cars. Many governments developed extensive train systems. Western Europe was still hit hard economically by the energy crises of 1973-74 and 1978-80. But when gas prices started falling, many governments kept them artificially high through taxation, aiming in part to cut consumption. Thus, even though many Western Europeans now are as wealthy as Americans, they don't buy cars that are as big or use them as much. ``People can't afford to run a Cadillac when the price of gas goes to a dollar a liter,'' said Jacques Michaux, the deputy head for oil and gas at the European Community's energy division. There are roughly four liters to a gallon. In Italy, for example, the best-selling car is the compact Fiat Uno, which gets about 47 miles to the gallon at 55 mph. The most popular U.S. car last year was the mid-sized sedan Honda Accord, which gets about 28 mpg on the highway. In the past decade, Western Europe has also followed the United States in slashing its reliance on oil to produce electricity. France, for example, has become the world's leader in reliance on nuclear energy, getting more than 80 percent of its electricity from nuclear plants. England and West Germany have switched to coal to produce some of their power, while Norway exports electricity from its numerous hydroelectric plants. One glaring exception is Italy, which still gets nearly half its electricity from oil. European industries have made a ``huge effort'' to reduce their use of oil, said Michaux. He cited steel, cement, petrochemical and paper plants in particular. The effects are dramatic. Between 1980 and 1989, France became 35 percent less oil-reliant, while England dropped 37 percent and West Germany 31 percent, according to figures compiled by the Cambridge Energy Research Associates. By comparison, the United States became 20 percent less oil-intensive in that period. While Western Europe is not expected to suffer the economic damage it did from previous oil crises, there is still concern about price hikes at the pump since the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. The increases have varied widely, ranging from no rise in pump prices in Portugal, to 5 percent in Italy, to as much as 22 percent in Greece. The increases have prompted France to slap on price controls and West Germany and Britain to investigate oil companies' pricing policies. Italy plans to freeze prices of petroleum products for three months. NAF, Norway's largest auto association, boycotted Shell stations for a week after they became the first to raise prices before old supplies had been used up. However, many Europeans have also grown used to stiff gas costs. ``I didn't like it, obviously,'' said one man as he filled his gray Fiat Uno at a Rome gas station. ``But here, the price is always going up. For different reasons, but it's always going up.''

DOC.HEAD: Goodyear Lays Off 800 at Plants in Tennessee, Quebec
DOC.TEXT: Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co., citing sluggishness in the auto industry and concerns about inventory, will lay off 800 employees at manufacturing plants in Tennessee and Quebec. Goodyear said Thursday in a brief statement that the layoffs were temporary and the duration would depend on ``the economy and market demand.'' The layoffs will occur over the next several weeks. Goodyear said 270 workers would be laid off in Union City, Tenn., and 530 layoffs would occur in Valleyfield, Quebec. The layoffs will include both white- and blue-collar workers. Union City has Goodyear's second-largest U.S. tire plant, which employs 3,100 people who make automobile and light truck tires. Valleyfield has Goodyear's largest Canadian plant. The temporary layoffs follow Goodyear's recent announcement of plans to lay off 360 workers there indefinitely by year's end because the plant is discontinuing production of medium- and heavy-duty truck tires. Goodyear has built a new plant in Napanee, Ontario, that will produce 14,000 passenger tires a day at full capacity sometime next year. In addition, Goodyear said it would reduce production for one week at its Danville, Va., medium radial truck tire plant. The temorary layoffs follow Goodyear's announcement in June that it will eliminate 1,100 jobs and take a $35 million charge against second quarter pre-tax profits as part of a restructuring of its U.S. tire sales and support staff. Those job cuts were to be phased in through layoffs and early retirements.

DOC.HEAD: Scott Paper Selling Share Of Brazilian Company
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf pvs, Scott owns . . . to CORRECT spelling of Companhia sted Campanhia.
DOC.TEXT: Scott Paper Co. and a Brazilian company have signed an agreement to sell a Brazilian tissue operation they own jointly for about $40 million, Scott Paper said. Scott owns 49 percent of Companhia de Papeis, which manufactures bathroom tissue, paper towels, facial tissues and paper napkins. The company is based in Rio de Janeiro. Scott Worldwide, a Scott subsidiary, and Companhia Auxilar de Empresas de Mineracao are selling COPA to a subsidiary of Industrias Klabin de Papel e Cellulosa SA. The agreement is for approximately $40 million in cash and notes. ``Our Brazilian affiliate has been and remains profitable,'' J. Richard Leaman Jr., a Scott executive vice president who is president of Scott Worldwide said Thursday in a prepared statement. ``However, we have determined that this tissue market does not meet the business criteria and long-term strategy we have established for the growth of our personal care and cleaning business,'' he continued. Leaman said Scott will use the net proceeds to invest in businesses worldwide that have the greatest growth opportunities and to reduce debt. The sale, subject to the approval of the Scott Paper Co. board of directors, is expected to be completed by the end of September.

DOC.HEAD: Kellogg Files Suit after Texas Threatens to Seize Heartwise
DOC.TEXT: Kellogg Co. has filed a lawsuit against the Texas attorney general's office and health department after the agencies threatened to seize its controversial psyllium-based cereal, Heartwise. The move comes one week after the Battle Creek-based cereal maker sued the Iowa attorney general's office, contending it has harassed the company for two years over health claims on Special K, 40+ Bran Flakes (now called Bran Flakes) and Frosted Flakes. In the Texas case, the state health department has threatened to order Heartwise pulled from store shelves if the company does not alter the product's labeling and include potential risks of the grain psyllium, which the company maintains can help lower cholesterol. Assistant Texas Attorney General Stephen Gardner said the product may be ``detained'' as early as Tuesday unless the company agrees to the changes. Kellogg is challenging that in a suit filed Thursday in U.S. District Court in Dallas. The U.S. Food and Drug Administration asked Kellogg last year to provide data showing that psyllium, a soluble fiber that is used in laxatives, is safe in foods and to back up its health claims. The agency has not ruled yet. ``The only people who view psyllium as safe in food is Kellogg,'' Gardner said. ``We notified them that they violated the law in failing to warn of potential risks, such as allergic reactions in some people, and by making claims about lowering (the) risk of heart disease.'' Gardner said he didn't know if there had been any consumer complaints about the cereal, which was introduced last year. General Mills Inc. pulled its psyllium-based cereal, Benefit, in January, citing poor sales. Kellogg maintains it never claimed Heartwise alone could reduce risk of heart disease, but that as part of a complete nutritional diet it may reduce elevated cholesterol, spokesman Joseph Stewart said. He termed Texas' criticism of the product's name, a heart symbol and mention of two hospitals on the box as ``nit-picking.'' ``It's a disservice for these people to be harassing and nit-picking in an attempt to keep this information from the public on the basis it is misleading,'' Stewart said. ``The assistant attorney general's threat is an irresponsible and politically motivated attack on our right to communicate scientifically supported health information about our products to consumers.'' Gardner denied Stewart's allegations of political motivation and said neither he nor Attorney General Jim Mattox were running for office. Gardner said that in discussions earlier this week, Kellogg refused the state's proposal that the company pay a $25,000 fine without having to admit any violation of the law. Only Texas has questioned the Heartwise advertising. But the same cereal health claims in question in Iowa are also being questioned in seven other states, Stewart said. Stewart would not say whether the company had plans to file any more lawsuits. ``Instead of being involved in this harassment, it's best to let the courts decide,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Federated and Allied to Negotiate $585 Million Tax Claim
DOC.TEXT: Federated Stores Inc. will contest Internal Revenue Service tax claims totaling $585.6 million. The retailing company, parent of the Federated and Allied department store operators, said Thursday that the claims were based on an IRS audit of the company for 1984 to 1988. The claims are being sought as part of Federated's Chapter 11 bankruptcy reorganization. Federated will dispute the claims and attempt to negotiate a settlement, said spokeswoman Carol Sanger. ``In most cases such as this, you find that what the IRS initially asks for and what the end resolution is are pretty far apart,'' she said. ``There is usually a significant reduction in the end amount that is agreed upon, and that would be our expectation.'' Negotiations with the IRS have begun and probably will continue through the autumn, Ms. Sanger said. The claims mainly involve issues related to the acquisition of Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp. by the Canadian company, Campeau Corp. The issues under dispute include tax deductibility of merger and takeover expenses, deferral of taxes on properties sold after the acquisitions, and some items not related to the takeovers, Ms. Sanger said. The pre-acquisition claims total $141.5 million against Federated, $118.7 million against Allied, and $325.4 million against the parent FSI, formerly known as Campeau Corp. (U.S.) Inc. Interest on the claims totals $125 million. But Ms. Sanger said that could be reduced if there is a negotiated settlement. The name of the U.S. holding company for Toronto-based Campeau's U.S. interests was changed after the bankruptcy petition was filed last January. Companies filing for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the federal Bankruptcy Act are given the opportunity to resolve their financial difficulties while continuing to operate. Federated's retailing chains include Abraham & Straus and Bloomingdale's of New York, Burdines of Miami, Lazarus of Cincinnati, Rich's of Atlanta and Goldsmith's of Memphis, Tenn. Allied's units include The Bon Marche of Seattle, Jordan Marsh of Boston, Stern's of Paramus, N.J., and Maas Brothers-Jordan Marsh of Tampa, Fla. Both Federated and Allied are based in Cincinnati.

DOC.HEAD: Chrysler Merit Pay Reinstatement Riles UAW
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp. reinstated merit raises for some executives, riling the United Auto Workers now bargaining a national labor contract with the automaker. Chrysler spokesman Lee Sechler said Thursday the raises were resumed after being frozen last October. About 27,000 salaried employees are eligible for the pay increases based on performance evaluations. The program was suspended as part of a cost-cutting plan designed to trim $1.5 billion in costs from the automaker's $26 billion annual budget by the end of this year. ``We determined we had to become competitive or we'd begin losing people,'' Sechler said, declining to say how much money was involved. ``You've got to stay competitive to stay in business.'' That didn't sit well with the UAW. The Detroit News quoted an unidentified UAW official in today's editions as saying, ``Chrysler's crying they ain't got any money. Where's all that money coming from for raises for their salaried people? Why would they give them raises now when they say they're doing so bad?'' Chrysler and the UAW began bargaining a national contract covering about 60,000 workers on July 20. The union's contracts with General Motors Corp., Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler cover more than 450,000 active workers and expire Sept. 14. On Tuesday, the union chose GM as its negotiating target. The UAW plans to use a contract ratified by GM workers as a pattern for agreements with the other two automakers.

DOC.HEAD: International Energy Agency Meets to Discuss Oil Supply
DOC.TEXT: The governing board of the International Energy Agency plans to discuss the world's dwindling oil supply today in the wake of the United Nations-imposed global boycott of oil from Iraq and Kuwait. The meeting was originally scheduled for a week ago but was postponed to allow governments to assess the outlook for oil supplies and pursue consultations with the oil industry. The oil-watchdog body is unlikely to call for emergency oil-sharing measures or the use of strategic petroleum stocks, a senior agency official said last week. Existing commercial oil stocks are probably sufficient to cover the estimated 4.5 million to 5 million barrels a day shortfall caused by the absence of Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil on the market, said the official, who spoke on condition he not be named. But some members could tap into emergency stockpiles if war breaks out in the Middle East, he said. The energy agency comprises 21 oil-consuming nations and includes the United States, Canada, Japan, Australia and most Western European nations. The United Nations imposed an embargo on Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil exports after Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. A multinational naval force is imposing a virtual blockade on shipping to those countries, and is prepared to use force to stop tankers from transporting oil from them. The IEA's standing group on emergency questions two weeks ago to discuss worldwide oil stockpiles, prospects for saving oil by switching to other forms of fuel, reigning in demand and spare production capacity. But only its governing board can make policy decisions for the group.

The stock market inched ahead today in slow, indecisive trading on the eve of the long Labor Day weekend. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose .24 to 2,593.56 in the first half hour of trading. Gainers outnumbered losers by about 5 to 4 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 465 up, 376 down and 466 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board totaled 12.85 million shares as of 10 a.m. on Wall Street. Analysts said it was difficult to read much significance into the market's meanderings today, noting that many investors were getting an early start on the end-of-summer holiday. Among the traders who were present, there appeared to be little inclination to make any major commitments. The potential for surprises in news from the Persian Gulf or elsewhere appeared substantial before the markets reopen for business on Tuesday. Among actively traded blue chips, Philip Morris rose \ to 44}; Exxon gained \ to 49[; International Business Machines dropped { to 101\, and American Express was down \ at 23[. On Thursday the Dow Jones industrial average fell 39.11 points to 2,593.32. Declining issues outnumbered advancers by more than 2 to 1 on the NYSE, with 467 up, 995 down and 507 unchanged. DOC.HEAD: State Allows Production of 20,000 More Barrels Daily
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf pvs, Railroad commission . . . to CORRECT spelling to Sharp sted Sharpe.
DOC.TEXT: Texas oil producers can pump about 20,000 extra barrels a day because of the Persian Gulf crisis, but that's still only a fraction of the state's 1.7 million barrel daily capacity. The Texas Railroad Commission on Thursday allowed the increased production at federal energy officials' request to help offset potential oil losses from an international trade embargo against Iraq and Kuwait. The commission, however, refused to increase production in the large East Texas Field, saying it wanted more time to consider arguments between independent oil producers and major oil companies. By comparison with the 20,000-barrel increase, OPEC this week allowed production hikes expected to cover most of 4 million barrels daily lost from Iraq and Kuwait. ``In today's circumstance ... we're asking everybody to pitch in and help in this effort,'' said Michael McElwrath, a principal deputy assistant secretary with the federal Energy Department. Railroad commission chairman Kent Hance conceded that the increase was insignificant compared to the amount of oil used daily, but added: ``It's a step in the right direction.'' Commisioner John Sharp said: ``This is 20,000 barrels more than any other state has provided.'' The major battle was over the East Texas Field, which has been restricted to 86 percent production to avoid depleting the oil reservoir. Major oil companies wanted to increase the allowable production to 100 percent, which would have raised daily production by up to 13,000 barrels per day. Current production is approximately 93,000 barrels per day. The smaller independents, though, rely on the East Texas Field and fear a rapid depletion that potentially could destroy their businesses while not affecting major companies, which have fields worldwide. Commission members said they will again consider whether to raise the allowable production rate in that field at their next meeting Sept. 20. Independent producers and state lawmakers said major oil companies were driven by greed to increase production. They also said there was no need to boost production because the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries has agreed to supply more oil. Independents and major oil companies have fought over production in the field since it was discovered in 1930. By 1931, 1 million barrels of oil were being produced daily, causing the price of oil to fall, and then-Gov. Ross Sterling sent the National Guard to shut down production for three weeks.

DOC.HEAD: Japan's Current Account Surplus Falls 63 Percent in July
DOC.TEXT: The surplus in a key Japanese trade indicator fell 63.3 percent in July from a year earlier, the Finance Ministry said Friday. The surplus in Japan's current account, the widest measure of a nation's trade in goods and services, fell to $2.02 billion in July from $5.50 billion a year earlier. Ministry officials said the current account surplus was continuing a downward trend despite some fluctation during the past few months. In June, the surplus climbed 12.2 percent to $4.78 billion from a year earlier. Officials attributed July's decline primarily to the country's shrinking trade surplus in goods as well as to a large deficit in invisible trade, which includes transactions in insurance, shipping, tourism and other services. On an unadjusted basis, the trade surplus fell 22.9 percent to $5.42 billion in July from $7.03 billion a year earlier. Exports inched up 1.3 percent, while imports leapt 12 percent. Economists said the rise in imports was due largely to increased purchases of gold and art. Exports and imports in the current account are measured when contracts are settled and are different from the customs-clearance trade figures which are announced separately by the ministry each month. The current account does not include breakdowns of trade figures by country or region. Also Friday, the Ministry of Finance announced that Japan's seasonally adjusted unemployment rate dipped to 2.1 percent in July from 2.2 percent the month before. The jobless rate has been moving between 2.0 percent and 2.2 percent since June 1989. The low rate has been supported by the continuous expansion of the Japanese economy over the last 45 months.

DOC.HEAD: Canadian Bonds Offer Attractive Returns
DOC.TEXT: It's the land of the northern Rockies, big moose and cities so clean and efficient people say they must be run by the Swiss. But for investors, Canada also is home to some of the highest-yielding government securities the world has to offer these days. Canadian interest rates have been on the rise since 1988, according to Lloyd G. Atkinson, chief economist at the Bank of Montreal in Toronto. ``The spread relative to the U.S. has been rising since that time, and it has attracted an awful lot of capital.'' Yields on 30-day Canadian Treasury bills are running at about 13 percent. That's 5.45 percentage points higher than the comparable U.S. rate. While yields are similarly high in Australia and Britain, Canada provides American investors with a certain comfort level _ albeit psychological _ because of its proximity and likeness to the United States. Plus, American investors aren't hit with foreign tariffs, only U.S. capital gains taxes. Typically, American investment houses that offer clients Canadian securities participate in the Bank of Canada's regular weekly auction of securities. The brokerages then resell the bonds to the public. Because of bookkeeping responsibilities and costs, brokerages must sell the bonds in higher denominations than are available through the Canadian government. Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., for example, requires a minimum investment of $10,000 in a 90-day bond even though a Canadian dealer could offer it at $1,000, said Elaine Williams, a Dean Witter broker in Washington who specializes in Canadian bonds. Smaller denominations are available through Canadian brokerages, but U.S. investors would have to open an account in Canada. Investment houses also handle currency exchanges at both ends of the transaction.Rather than charge a commission, Dean Witter covers its costs by reducing the yield on the security. Williams said she would offer between 12.25 percent and 12.50 percent for a Canadian bond yielding 13 percent. Despite the attractive yields, there are risks. The major vulnerability lies in the Canadian dollar, which could have weakened by the time the bond has matured. Experts say a one-cent decline in the Canadian dollar would wipe out the benefit of the high yield. Canadian bonds ``look very attractive on the surface, but when you do the math, you have to look at it more closely,'' said David Kuhn, a manager at Toronto Dominion Bank's office here. ``Even though you're picking up a wide interest-rate differential, it's easy to give it back with a half-cent movement in the currency,'' he said. Still, the Canadian dollar historically has been less volatile than other major currencies, experts say. And it has fluctuated in a relatively narrow band. Since 1989, the Canadian dollar has cost between 82.52 cents and 88.60 cents, the rate it touched in August, which was a 12-year high. There is a growing sentiment that John Crow, governor of the Bank of Canada, would not permit a sharp decline in the value of the Canadian dollar, Atkinson said. But he noted that much of the currency's recent strength is associated with the crisis in the Middle East. If the dollar ``were to go back to where it was at the end of July (roughly 86 cents), . . . the Bank of Canada would shrug its shoulders,'' he said. Though Canada has a fairly stable political climate, economically things aren't too bright. ``It's not an economy tossing out very much profit,'' Atkinson said. The country suffers from a large budget deficit and is on the verge of recession. Although investors are demanding a ``pretty sizable premium'' to put their funds into Canada, economists expect interest rates to come down to promote economic growth. Many experts say Canadian securities should be viewed as a diversification tactic. And only large investors would need to diversify to the extent of buying foreign bonds, they say. ``For everyday investors, this is a hard sell,'' Dean Witter's Williams said. ``People feel uncomfortable because it's foreign or they don't get the concept of the exchange rate. I try to target people who travel and have been abroad.''

DOC.TEXT: The dollar finished higher today against most major currencies in trading in Europe. Gold prices fell in Zurich and London. Dealers said the dollar's rise reflected technical adjustments in the market, as traders squared their positions before the Labor Day weekend that will close U.S. financial markets on Monday. In London, the dollar rose sharply against the British pound, which fell to $1.8900 from $1.9225 R-Okla., a member of the House GOP leadership. When the House and Senate return to regular session beginning the week of Sept. 10, there will be a round of hearings that will include reviews of U.S. foreign policy in the Middle East, military deployment and energy policy, and the impact of all of them on the federal budget. Secretary of State James A. Baker III will be among the first to testify Wednesday before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. ``The members of our delegation will be making decisions over the next several weeks ... all of which are affected by the crisis in the gulf,'' said House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., who was leading the 22-member House delegation. Leaving about the same time in a matching blue-and-white Air Force version of the Boeing 707 was a 14-member Senate delegation led by Foreign Relations Committee Chairman Claiborne Pell, D-R.I. The separate delegations had similar itineraries: briefings by U.S. officials in Saudi Arabia, including military commanders, and visits with U.S. troops in the field at Dhahran and Air Force units stationed in Bahrain. On Sunday the two groups were to meet in Jiddah, Saudi Arabia, for discussions with Kuwaiti and Saudi officials. On Monday, both groups were scheduled to meet in Cairo with Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak. The House delegation is scheduled to return to the United States on Monday, while the senators were to meet with officials in Oman and the United Arab Emirates and return Tuesday. ``We may be there for a long time, and the morale of our troops is absolutely critical,'' said Sen. Carl Levin, D-Mich., a member of the Armed Services Committee. Referring to alternately raised and lowered hopes for the release of hostages by the Iraqi president, Levin added: ``We cannot be used as a yo-yo by Saddam Hussein, and that means our willpower must remain strong.'' Lawmakers said they were interested in assessing what additional troops allies might commit to the military buildup and progress toward cost-sharing by countries that benefit from the continued flow of Middle East oil. Concern also was voiced about Arab solidarity against Saddam. ``I'm particularly anxious to learn ... what the impact of a long-term standoff would be, to what degree Saddam Hussein has the ability to create dissension within the Arab world,'' said Sen. John Kerry, D-Mass. Another goal, said Sen. William Cohen, is to deter a flood of members of Congress to the region that might distract U.S. forces from their primary mission. ``It would be very inconvenient for them to have to deal with'' such an influx, Cohen said. This group will share what it learns with colleagues on Capitol Hill and hope to discourage further congressional travel, he said. DOC.HEAD: President Signs Secondary Oil Field Contracts
DOC.TEXT: President Carlos Menem signed contracts leasing Argentina's secondary oil fields to private companies, newspapers reported Friday. The government accepted 107 offers from 25 companies totaling $260 million. More than two dozen local and foreign companies had bid on the fields, which for decades have been controled by the state oil company YPF. The bids were made in June. Menem had put off signing the contracts until Thursday, however, partly because the price of oil soared following Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. The deregulation of the oil industry, including the lifting of price controls next Jan. 1, is a key part of the 13-month-old government's program to reorient Argentina's economy toward free markets and away from state control.

DOC.HEAD: State of Colorado Begins Criminal Investigation of Coors
DOC.TEXT: State prosecutors have begun a criminal investigation into alleged groundwater pollution by the Adolph Coors Co., according to a report. The Rocky Mountain News carried the state's confirmation in Friday editions. It said investigators were reviewing allegations that plant officials knowingly concealed leaking pipes at a Golden can plant that tainted at least two and as many as five underground springs with the toxic chemical solvent TCA in the 1970s and early 1980s. Brewery president Peter Coors released details of the pollution in February, along with a five-year, $1 million clean-up program. Officials said there was no current health threat. Coors officials on Thursday declined comment on the allegations. ``Since we first brought the problems to the attention of the regulatory agencies early this year, we've made an effort to cooperate fully with those agencies and have made an effort to be open with the public,'' said Coors spokesman Jon Goldman. ``But with the legal actions now being considered, we really can't comment further.''

DOC.HEAD: Crisis Makes Shipping Market Even More Volatile
Graphic
DOC.TEXT: The Persian Gulf crisis has not been kind to the shipping industry, whose stocks have tumbled on fears tankers will be idled as insurance companies impose war-zone premiums and sailors demand hazardous duty pay. Analysts in world shipping capitals say the market, complex and highly sensitive at best, now also is confused. In some cases, it's nearing panic. ``We can't predict anything,'' said Michael Kokkinis, president of the Greek Shipbrokers Association. ``Everyone is in a state of alert, both those who are buying and those who are selling ships. People are waiting.'' Stock market shipping indexes have slumped about 25 percent worldwide since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, said a spokesman for Lloyd's List International in London. The spokesman, who asked not to be named, said Norwegian and U.S. shipping companies have been hit hardest. An Oslo business newspaper reported that some Norwegians saw their shipping fortunes halved on paper within two weeks of the invasion. Other Norwegian reports last week predicted a 30 percent decline in tanker rates. Loukas Hadjioannou, the Greek owner of the world's largest independent tanker fleet, said 30 percent of all tankers could be laid up by the crisis. ``The main thing that this crisis has done is once again stress the volatility of the shipping market, how open it is to outside influences,'' said David Glass, editor of Naftiliaki, a shipping magazine in Piraeus, Greece. London experts said 60 ships, mostly tankers, were awaiting orders near the Persian Gulf late last week at considerable cost to owners. But they said there was some increase in chartering, where ships are hired for specific voyages. Compounding a decline in tanker activity are increasing costs for shipping companies because of the dangers caused by the crisis. Crews want cash bonuses for sailing in the Gulf. Greek shipowners and the Panhellenic Seamen's Federation have agreed to define the Gulf as a danger zone. Insurance costs have increased as much as tenfold, though more often by three times, for ships in high-risk Gulf areas, according to Norwegian reports. Jane Vidler of Lloyd's Insurance in London said war insurance rates for ships have been raised three times since Aug. 2. But the highest premiums are still just one-tenth of the 7.5 percent of a ship's value some owners paid during the 1980-88 Iran-Iraq war. ``The current situation in the Middle East has led to natural fears and a good deal of short-term inability to act,'' said Jarle Hammer, an analyst with Fearnlet AS in Oslo. ``Some are clearly on the verge of panic, panic built on uncertainty. Anxiety has pushed the paper value of Norwegian ships down by $1.3 billion, or 19 percent, since Aug. 1, according to Oslo's stock exchange. Mark Jenkins, senior consultant at Lloyd's Maritime Information Service, said losses reflect the jittery tone of the world stock market. ``If this crisis goes on we'll be in trouble,'' Glass said. ``Because the developed nations will enter a recession and they will have a smaller demand for oil.'' He said ships that can carry either oil or dry cargo then could enter the dry cargo market, causing problems there. Also, expensive tankers ordered a few years ago are being delivered now and ``those who ordered them are going to be in trouble,'' Glass said. The shipping industry expects some relief as other nations, including some OPEC members, are expected to replenish up to 90 percent of the 4 million barrels of Iraqi and Kuwaiti crude lost to the market. Also, some tankers have won longer contracts to sail farther for alternate oil cargoes because Turkey closed an overland pipeline from Iraq. Uncertain oil supplies could increase demand for coal cargoes from stable suppliers such as the United States and Australia. And higher crude prices would stimulate offshore oil exploration. Eventually, though, the size of the world's tanker fleet could decline. Higher energy costs tend to increase scrap metal values because reclaiming scrap uses less power than producing steel from ore, which could encourage some shipowners to retire vessels. Other analysts said a depressed market could encourage shipowners to try to sell a large number of ships. If they do, buyers could be the Greeks, known for buying second-hand ships when prices are down and selling when times are good, analysts said.

DOC.HEAD: Bond Prices Narrowly Mixed in Abbreviated Trading
DOC.TEXT: Bond prices were narrowly mixed in a quiet, abbreviated session Friday amid signs the manufacturing economy improved in August in the Midwest. The price of the Treasury's bellwether 30-year bond fell [ point, or $1.25 per $1,000 face amount. Its yield, which rises when the bond's price falls, edged up to 8.98 percent from late Thursday's 8.97 percent. Other long-term issues were down, but short-term Treasury bonds were narrowly higher. Analysts said a survey of Chicago purchasing managers, which indicated a slight improvement in the manufacturing sector, brought prices lower. The Chicago index of business activity rose to 49.2 in August from 48.3 percent in July. Traders fear that the Fed would be less likely to relax its policy and allow interest rates to fall if the economy appears to be expanding. The bond market tracks regional and national purchasing managers reports for clues about the strength of the economy and the Federal Reserve's credit policy. The National Association of Purchasing Management is scheduled to release its monthly report on the economy on Tuesday. Oil prices, which can portend a higher inflation rate, also helped put a damper on bond trading Friday. The near-term price for light sweet crude rose 55 cents to $27.32 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Trading was extremely light Friday in advance of the Labor Day weekend, and the bond market closed several hours early. The U.S. financial markets will be closed on Monday. In the secondary market for Treasury bonds, prices of the short-term governments ranged from 1-16 point to [ point higher, intermediate maturities ranged from 1-32 point lower to [ point higher, and long-term issues were unchanged to [ point lower, Telerate Inc., a financial information service, reported. The movement of a point equals a change of $10 in the price of a bond with a $1,000 face value. Longer-term issues fared worse than shorter maturities Friday because the 30-year bonds tie up money for longer periods and are more vulnerable to the effects of inflation. The Lehman Brothers Daily Treasury Bond Index, which measures price movements on all outstanding Treasury issues with maturities of a year or longer, rose 1.13 to 1,143.88. Yields on three-month Treasury bills fell to 7.59 percent as the discount fell 7 basis points to 7.36 percent. Yields on six-month bills fell to 7.74 percent as the discount fell 2 basis points to 7.36 percent. Yields on one-year bills fell to 7.76 percent as the discount fell 2 basis points to 7.24 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The yield is the annualized return on an investment in a Treasury bill. The discount is the percentage that bills are selling below the face value, paid at maturity. The federal funds rate, the interest rate banks charge each other on overnight loans, was quoted at 8 1-16 percent, up from 8 percent late Thursday. In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds was unchanged at 89\. The average yield to maturity was also unchanged at 7.64 percent.

DOC.HEAD: International Group Agrees It Can Avert Oil Shortages
DOC.TEXT: Members of the International Energy Agency agreed Friday to work together to avert oil shortages from the Persian Gulf crisis, but they said the threat to supplies had eased. Senior officials of the IEA, comprised of 21 industrialized nations, said they expected production hikes by OPEC countries to counter the effects of the U.N. boycott of Iraq and Kuwait. ``The situation is much more manageable than would have been the case if there hadn't been the increase in OPEC production,'' said John Easton, a U.S. Energy Department official. Their meeting came two days after the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries agreed that Saudi Arabia, Venezuela and others can pump more oil to make up a shortfall of 4 million barrels a day lost to world markets by the boycott. The United Nations imposed the sanctions after Iraq invaded Kuwait Aug. 2. When the IEA governing board met two weeks ago, industrial nations feared OPEC might be unable to raise production. ``These increases have not only been confirmed by some OPEC countries, but they are already taking place,'' Easton said, noting oil producers have ``a certain amount of self-interest'' to do so. ``They are getting a pretty good price these days,'' Easton said, with light sweet crude selling above $27 a barrel. The watchdog body said it reserves the option of calling for emergency oil-sharing measures or the use of strategic petroleum stocks if the situation worsens. Officials also renewed their call for conservation. The IEA's standing group on emergency questions met two weeks ago to discuss worldwide oil stockpiles, prospects for saving oil by switching to other forms of fuel, reining in demand and spare production capacity. French Foreign Ministry spokesman Daniel Bernard meanwhile announced France will open talks with the IEA about becoming a full member. He did not say when they would begin. The agency presently includes all 24 members of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development except France, Iceland and Finland. France decided not to join when the group was founded in 1974, fearing the IEA would simply be used to attack OPEC. Its interest has been raised by the group's efforts to limit fallout from the embargo. French Industry Minister Roger Fauroux said Friday that France must adopt measures to help the economy through a potentially difficult period ahead. ``We must control the different factors in economic balance. We must control salaries, money and prices,'' Faroux said in an interview on the radio network Europe 1. Faroux said state-owned Gaz de France would soon sign a contract with Norway to purchase 70.6 billion cubic feet of natural gas.

DOC.HEAD: Sportsmen Take Aim at Clothes Tags with Anti-Hunting Messages
LaserPhoto LJ4 of Aug. 31
DOC.TEXT: Michigan's largest conservation and sportsmen's group took aim Friday at J.C. Penney Co. Inc. for marketing boys' clothing with an anti-hunting message. ``The message that kids will pick up from this _ that the traditional hunting sports are wrong and that anyone who enjoys hunting is somehow dangerous and evil _ is simply outrageous,'' said Thomas Washington, executive director of the Michigan United Conservation Clubs. Washington said the tags on the shirts and pants were ``a slap in the face to more than one million Michigan men and women who enjoy hunting.'' His organization sent a letter to the Dallas-based company urging it to discontinue the line of clothing. Penney spokesman Duncan Muir said the company would make a decision on the merchandise next week. But it may not matter for long. The head of the company supplying the clothing said in a letter that the tags have been discontinued. A card attached to each shirt in the ``Environmental Protection Department'' line of clothing shows a sketch of a bird hunter aiming a shotgun over which a large red ``X'' has been marked. Under that are the words: ``Absolutely No Hunting of Wild and Free Animals While Wearing This Garment.'' Pants have a larger card with the message: ``Wild life protected by man surround the world with pure thoughts.'' Tags in the clothing indicate it was made in Hong Kong. Muir said Penney's, the nation's largest department store chain, hasn't taken a stand on hunting. ``It's not our position to do that and I understand that obviously is the message that does come across. We are well aware of that now, but certainly don't take a position like that,'' he said. ``We didn't produce this merchandise. It came in from a supplier and we certainly don't endorse this position at all. ``We'll be making a decision on the disposition of the merchandise sometime next week,'' he said. Muir said he didn't know how many pieces of the clothing Penney's had bought from the supplier, H. Cotler Co., or how many of the company's 1,330 stores were carrying them, but distribution was nationwide. Some local store managers in the St. Louis area and in Oregon already have pulled the clothes from their shelves, he said, adding he didn't know how many stores were involved. A switchboard operator at New York-based Cotler said offices were closed Friday afternoon for the Labor Day holiday weekend. Calls to the home of the head of the company, Howard Cotler, went unanswered. However, in a letter to the National Rifle Association dated Tuesday, Cotler wrote that the tags were added to the clothing as a marketing tool and had been discontinued. He wrote the company ``neither condemns nor supports anti-gun or anti-hunting legislation'' and it was trying to appeal to the environmental awareness of young people. NRA researcher Trey Hodgkins said he contacted the company after the NRA's Washington headquarters received dozens of complaints about the tags. ``They were blatantly anti-hunting. There's no other way to construe it. We're pleased to see he's decided to drop that from his marketing of the line of clothing,'' he said. Washington said MUCC _ which represents more than 450 clubs with 140,000 members _ sent its letter of protest Friday after getting a complaint on Thursday. ``This kind of stuff is the worst possible stuff because it tries to persuade youngsters that hunting is bad. Kids are a prime target for anti-hunting messages,'' he said. ``Hunters in general are fairly complacent and we need to make them aware of these kinds of things or they'll wake up one day and find there's no hunting.''

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mostly Up, Gold Down
DOC.TEXT: The dollar advanced against most major currencies Friday except the Japanese yen as buyers added to their dollar holdings ahead of a long holiday weekend in the United States. With problems still unresolved in the Middle East, currency dealers decided to keep their portfolios balanced in favor of dollars, analysts said. The dollar, regarded as a safe haven, has gotten a boost since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2 The dollar's rise also reflected technical maneuvers coinciding with the end of the month. Activity slowed in afternoon trading in New York because market participants left early for the holiday weekend. U.S. financial markets will be closed Monday for Labor Day. The most dramatic move of the day was made by the British pound, which weakened substantially. In New York, the pound was quoted late at $1.8905, compared to $1.92235 Thursday. Earlier, in London, the dollar also rose sharply against sterling with the pound falling to $1.8900 from $1.9225 Thursday. The selloff in sterling represented an acceleration of the profit-taking that began Thursday when dealers judged the time was right to collect gains made during the British currency's recent advance. The dollar had a mixed day against the Japanese yen. It began the trading day in Tokyo by rising 0.40 yen to a closing 144.50 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at 143.70 yen. At the end of New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 143.785 yen, down from 144.10 yen on Thursday. Late dollar rates in New York, compared with Thursday's late quotes included: 1.5755 German marks, up from 1.5640; 1.30835 Swiss francs, up from 1.2950; 5.2865 French francs, up from 5.2445; 1,170.00 Italian lire, up from 1,159.75; and 1.15625 Candian dollars, up from 1.14695. Other late dollar rates in Europe compared with late levels Thursday were: 1.5758 German marks, up from 1.5561; 1.3075 Swiss francs, up from 1.2950; 5.2825 French francs, up from 5.2492; 1.7685 Dutch guilders, up from 1.7645; 1,169.00 Italian lire, up from 1,160.50, and 1.1552 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1455. Precious metals prices pulled back on most markets. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for September delivery settled at $382.30 a troy ounce, down $4.40 from Thursday's settlement. The Republic National Bank in New York quoted a bid of $382.75 for an ounce of gold bullion, off $4.75 from Thursday's 4 p.m. EDT bid. Gold fell to $384.45 a troy ounce in London from $389.60 late Thursday and dropped to $384.00 in Zurich from $389.05 late Thursday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose $2.52 to close at $387.80 an ounce. Silver headed down on New York's Comex where the contract for September delivery closed at $4.760 compared to the Thursday settlement of $4.807. In London, silver fell to a late bid of $4.81 a troy ounce, from $4.86 late Thursday.

DOC.TEXT: Stock prices rose, but trading set its slowest pace of the year Friday as the market coasted into the long Labor Day weekend. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials gained 21.04 to 2,614.36, finishing the week with a net gain of 81.44 points. Advancing issues outnumbered declines by about 3 to 2 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 885 up, 595 down and 472 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 96.48 million shares, down from 120.89 million Thursday and the lightest total since a 77.61 million-share day last Dec. 26. Analysts said it was difficult to read much significance into the market's meanderings, noting that many investors were getting an early start on the end-of-summer holiday. Among the traders who were present, there appeared to be little inclination to make any major commitments. The potential for surprises in news from the Persian Gulf or elsewhere appeared substantial before the markets reopen for business on Tuesday. In addition, a series of reports is due next week on the state of the economy, any of which could shed new light on the debate over whether a recession looms. One that seems certain to get close scrutiny is the Labor Department's monthly report Friday on the employment situation. Some observers feel the data could play a pivotal role in determining the Federal Reserve's next move in setting monetary policy. Energy stocks were strong. Exxon gained 1[ to 50; Atlantic Richfield 1] to 134~; Mobil ~ to 63~, and Amoco 1 to 55. Among other actively traded blue chips, Philip Morris rose | to 45[; General Motors { to 39}; American Express } to 24[; Merck 1| to 81|, and International Business Machines [ to 101~. Bank of New England jumped 1[ to 2[. The Comptroller of the Currency's office denied rumors circulating Thursday that federal regulators were about to close down the holding company's main banking operation. Toys R Us ranked high on the list of volume leaders, down [ at 25] following news that a group of Japanese toy retailers was forming an association to protect themselves against expansion plans by the U.S.-based company. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 115.81 million shares. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market increased $28.23 billion, or 0.35 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks gained 1.74 to 176.97. Standard & Poor's industrial index rose 4.34 to 382.03, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was up 3.85 at 322.56. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market added 2.53 to 381.21. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 323.39, up .48.
