DOC.HEAD: The AP
Oil Prices Up, But Don't Recover From Week's Big Hits
DOC.TEXT: Wholesale gasoline and crude oil prices moved higher in the futures market Friday, but failed to recover all the ground lost earlier in the week. Traders said buying picked up as the stalemate in the Middle East dragged on. Early waves of selling this week had been inspired by hopes for a quick negotiated settlement to the crisis, which has threatened the world's oil supplies. Light sweet crude oil rose 55 cents on the New York Mercantile Exchange to end the week at $27.32 per barrel on contracts for October delivery. ``The general perception in the market is continued concern or anxiety that the diplomatic solutions don't look like they're coming through,'' said Ann-Louise Hittle, senior oil analyst with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. Friday's strongest move was in unleaded regular gasoline, which rose 7.25 cents to 96.32 cents per gallon for September contracts in their last day of trading on the New York Merc. Home heating oil was up .35 cent to 75.89 cents per gallon, also on the last day of trading for September delivery. ``There is a shortage of refining capacity in the world, and the situation in the Middle East has really affected those refineries,'' said Bernard Picchi, an analyst with Salomon Brothers Inc. A daily refining capacity of 1.3 million barrels has been taken off the world market because of the embargo of Iraq and Kuwait, he said. ``The Middle East is not just a big crude oil exporting region. It's also a big products exporting region,'' Picchi said. The stock market has tended to move in opposite directions from petroleum prices since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, but it gained ground Friday in slow, indecisive trading. Analysts said it was difficult to read much significance into the market's meanderings, noting that many investors were getting an early start on Labor Day. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 21.04 to 2,614.36, finishing the week with a net gain of 81.44 points. Oil was down for the week. Crude futures took a hit of $4 per barrel on Monday and nearly $2 per barrel on Wednesday. Gains on other trading days were more modest, leaving the per-barrel price down $3.59 from the previous Friday, which had capped a string of three trading days above the $30 mark. Gasoline was down 8.4 cents per gallon for the week. Heating oil was down 15.05 cents per gallon for the week. Natural gas futures closed at $1.500 per 1,000 cubic feet for October contracts on Friday, down from $1.537 a day earlier and $1.525 a week earlier. Analysts said some traders were keeping prices up as they bought futures Friday to avoid getting caught short over the long Labor Day weekend. New York financial markets are closed Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Companies Plan New Satellite Service
DOC.TEXT: COMSAT Aeronautical Services and Sony Trans Com Inc., Friday announced that they will collaborate on the development of a new satellite service that will provide news updates and other information for international airline passengers. A worldwide communications link for aircraft equipped for satellite reception will be available beginning in 1991 to keep travelers abreast of breaking news and international developments, according to a joint statement by the companies. The news and information will initially be targeted at international travelers and will be displayed as text and graphics. An additional feature that will be available could allow travelers to receive messages from home or office because of the service's ability to send directly to specific aircraft tail numbers. Sony Trans Com will provide cabin display equipment and other hardware for the planes to receive the service, while COMSAT will transmit the service through its ground earth stations and satellite system.

DOC.HEAD: Grain, Soybean Prices Drop in Light Trading
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices were lower Friday in quiet trading on the Chicago Board of Trade. On other markets, energy futures rose; precious metals were lower; cocoa futures gained; orange juice retreated; and livestock and pork futures were mixed. Wheat prices were lower on technical factors involving deliveries for September contracts. Also weighing on futures prices was the cost of wheat being delivered in other parts of world. ``Wheat is being sold around the world at giveaway prices, which is hurting the Chicago market,'' said John Frazier, an analyst with Gerald Inc. in Chicago. There were reports earlier in the week that the European Community is heavily subsidizing wheat sales. Corn and soybean futures received some support following a sharp drop in prices through the week. But gains were eliminated by near-perfect weather in the Midwest, which is helping crop maturity and improving the size of yields. Wheat settled 4\ cents to 6{ cents lower with the contract for delivery in September at $2.62{ a bushel; corn was 2 cents lower to } cent higher with September at $2.43\ a bushel; oats were 2\ cents to 4 cents higher with September at $1.05 a bushel; soybeans were a { cent to 3} cents lower with September at $6.01 a bushel. Crude oil futures were steadily higher on the New York Mercantile Exchange, which analyst Robert Baker of Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. in New York attributed to continued concern over the crisis in the Middle East. ``Some traders may have thought the chances were greater for some kind of action over the weekend,'' he said. Gasoline prices were sharply higher, which could reflect tight supplies, Baker said. Light sweet crude was 12 cents to 55 cents higher with October at $27.32 a barrel; heating oil was .01 cent lower to 1.04 cents higher with September at 75.89 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .20 cent to 7.25 cents higher with September at 96.32 cents a gallon. Precious metals futures fell on New York's Commodity Exchange. Peter Cardillo, an analyst with Jesup, Josephthal & Co. in Chicago called the market disappointing in the wake of Thursday's price increases. Contributing to the decline in prices was the liquidation of holdings by small speculators before the start of the three-day Labor Day weekend, Cardillo said. Gold was $4.40 to $4.90 lower with September at $382.30 a troy ounce;; silver was 4.7 cents to 5.3 cents lower with September at $4.76 a troy ounce. The price of orange juice futures fell on the New York Cotton Exchange. Prices were pressured by a perception that the Florida crop would recover better than expected from last year's freeze damage, said Judith Ganes, a Merrill Lynch & Co. analyst in New York. Ms. Ganes also attributed the market's weakness to a large supply of Brazilian orange concentrate. She said it is likely the Brazilians will have to cut to price of their product to stimulate purchases. Orange juice was 1 cent to 1.60 cents lower with September at $1.5925 a pound. Cocoa prices were higher in trading on New York's Coffee, Sugar & Cocoa Exchange in the wake of protests in the Ivory Coast, the world's largest cocoa producer. Cocoa was $3 to $23 higher with September at $1,274 a ton. A protest march in Abidjan against the one-party government was broken up by police using tear gas. Ms. Ganes said there was concern in the market the unrest might cause shipment delays or other problems. Livestock futures were higher and pork lower on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle were .03 cent lower to .22 cent higher with October at 76.32 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .10 cent to .38 cent higher with September at 86.77 cents a pound; hogs were .18 cent to .42 cent lower with October at 48.30 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .95 cent to 2 cents lower with February at 49.87 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Bank Assures Customers Doors Will Stay Open
DOC.TEXT: Bank of New England officials hastened to assure customers their money was secure Friday, a day after a political candidate mistakenly announced the institution was slated for liquidation. The statement, although quickly retracted, raised already circulating rumors to fever pitch. And some analysts said the likelihood of federal intervention with the bank remained, even though the immediate rumor had been debunked. ``Whether it's this weekend or a month from now or two months from now, it is inevitable,'' said Don Kauth, an analyst with First Albany Corp. Bank of New England has operated under federal orders since early this year. The bank came under heightened government scrutiny when a downturn in the economy and a sour real estate market exposed mountains of bad loans. The bank lost close to $80 million in the first half of 1990, on top of more than $1 billion in losses last year. Massachusetts congressional hopeful Ted Dimauro ignited speculations about the bank's future late Thursday when he issued a news release based on rumors the bank would be seized by federal regulators. Regulators announced that the release was wrong, bank officials demanded a retraction and Dimauro apologized. Charles N. Cranmer of Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. said the political statement probably didn't have much effect on the bank's basic options of promptly working out bad loans and realizing as much as possible through foreclosure or auction of those properties. ``It's just as precarious as it ever was,'' Cranmer said. He said the bank is to minimize the bad loans, but it ``just doesn't have much time. I think that everybody, the regulators and everybody else are going to do everything in their power to nurse it along as long as they possibly can.'' Dimauro made reference Friday to the circulating rumors when he apologized at a news conference in Springfield. He said the former campaign manager Terry Weldon was to blame for the blunder. ``I may have done the Bank of New England a favor. I may have done the depositors a favor, and by talking about this issue we have brought the situation to light. What happens after today, that's someone else's problem,'' Dimauro said. ``He just doesn't get it,'' said Bank of New England spokesman James Dorsey, who added that the bank hasn't decided yet what it might do about Dimauro's statement. At the main Springfield branch of the bank Friday morning, bank employees assured callers that the institution was open for business. ``Yesterday afternoon when these rumors were going on our customers called concerned. Today they're calling up and they're very supportive and they're angry,'' Dorsey said. Dorsey said the episode won't sway the bank from its operating plan with federal regulators, which calls for the bank to sell off assets and slash its workforce. ``We're making progress on a number of fronts. This is a recovery that is going to be measured in years and it's certainly not one that's for the faint of heart, but we are making progress,'' he said. The bank, which has already sold its credit card operations, is getting control of its credit portfolio and has streamlined management, Dorsey said. ``At some point in time a tough decision will have to be made with the regulators,'' said Gerard Cassidy, an analyst with Boston-based Tucker Anthony. He said some observers believe if liquidation is considered, the bank company would be broken up and sold off in pieces, while others theorize another bank could come in and buy it whole. ``Right now it's really up to the economy,'' he said. Bank of New England's stock did recover somewhat Friday on the New York Stock Exchange. It closed at $2.12{, up $1.[ from Thursday. The stock had plummeted almost 40 percent the day before, and employees quickly mobilized to quash the rumors, answering calls and assuring customers that their deposits were safe, Dorsey said. Dimauro said he hoped voters in the Democratic primary would forgive him. ``To err is human,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: GM Buying Xerox Insurance Subsidiary
DOC.TEXT: A General Motors Corp. subsidiary will buy an insurance holding company subsidiary of Xerox Financial Services for an undisclosed sum, the companies said Friday. Motors Insurance Corp., a subsidiary of GM's General Motors Acceptance Corp. unit, will acquire NAVCO Corp., a subsidiary of Xerox's Crum and Forster Inc. organization, the companies said. The deal faces regulatory approval and a vote from each company's board. NAVCO provides automobile insurance mainly to members of associations. It had annual premiums of about $147 million last year. Motors Insurance had revenues of $1.1 billion in 1989 and insures personal and commercial coverages and plans. Crum and Forster, based in Basking Ridge, N.J., also said it wants to sell its Viking Insurance Co. of Wisconsin. That company provides personal automobile insurance.

DOC.HEAD: Chrysler Announces Incentives on '91 Models
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp. on Friday announced it would continue incentive programs for a wide variety of its 1991 cars and light trucks. The incentives, with cash rebates ranging from $500 to $1,000, are available on all domestically produced vehicles except for minivans, convertibles, standard-size vans and wagons and some import models. As an alternative to rebates, a consumer may choose low-interest financing plans with interest rates keyed to the term of the loan.

DOC.HEAD: Newmont Mining Offering Stock
DOC.TEXT: Newmont Mining Corp., a gold mining corporation 49 percent owned by Hanson PLC of Britain, plans to sell 3.6 million new common shares in a public offering. Newmont is the largest gold producer in North America, and many investors have turned to gold as a relatively safe investment because of tensions in the Middle East. Hanson said Thursday its United States affiliate, Hanson Industries, intends to sell 8.4 million of its Newmont common shares and 4.2 million warrants to reduce its stake in the company. Newmont also announced it will adopt a shareholder rights plan aimed at making it too expensive for a hostile takeover. Earlier this summer, Newmont sold its 54.9 percent stake in Peabody Coal Co. to Hanson for $725 million, and it sold a 19.9 percent stake in Newmont Australia to Poseidon Gold of Australia for $137 million.

DOC.HEAD: Tisches Disclose Stakes in Three Banks
DOC.TEXT: CBS Inc. executive Laurence A. Tisch and his brother Preston R. Tisch disclosed Friday that they have acquired sizeable stakes in three bank holding companies: Baybanks Inc., Equimark Corp. and Continental Bank Corp. In separate filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the brothers and other family members stated they have acquired 9.5 percent of the common stock of Baybanks Inc. of Boston; 6.8 percent of Equimark, a Pittsburgh-based bank holding company; and 5.6 percent of Chicago-based Continental. In all three filings, Laurence, who is chairman and co-chief executive of Loews Corp. with his brother, as well as chief executive of CBS, said they bought the stock for investment purposes and have no intention of seeking control of the companies. The Continental filing noted that in June the Tisch brothers were negotiating with the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. and Continental to buy 2.9 million Continental shares but the deal was never consumated. According to the filings, Laurence Tisch's four sons _ including Lorillard Inc. chairman Andrew H. Tisch _ participated in the stock acquisition. The filing said the Tisches: _ Spent $41.8 million on 1.04 million Continental shares between Aug. 1 and Aug. 21 at prices ranging from $11.75 to $9 per share. _ Paid $4.7 million for 630,700 Equimark shares between July 2 and Aug. 30 at prices ranging from $5.63 to $3.38 per share. _ Spent $19.2 million buying 1.35 million Baybanks shares between July 2 and Aug. 24 at prices ranging from $16 to $11.25.

DOC.HEAD: Coca-Cola Ships Ice-Cold Soft Drinks to Gulf Troops
DOC.TEXT: The Coca-Cola Co. is helping cool off soldiers stationed in the Saudi Arabian desert by distributing nearly half a million cans of free Coke. Refrigerated trucks late this week distributed the first loads of 20,000 cases of canned Coke to base camps in Saudi Arabia, according to the Atlanta-based company. ``Since World War II, Coca-Cola has made a commitment to have its products available to American servicemen wherever in the world they may be,'' said Jim Harting, Coca-Cola Gulf region manager. The Coke was canned in the United Arab Emirates and shipped from warehouses in Saudi Arabia.

DOC.HEAD: Former Consolidated Natural Gas Chairman Dies
DOC.TEXT: Herbert C. Johnson, a retired chairman of Consolidated Natural Gas Co., has died of congestive heart failure, the company said Friday. He was 81. Johnson, who retired in 1974, died Wednesday in New York. He had been with Pittsburgh-based Consolidated since the company was formed in 1943 and also served as director, treasurer and president during his career. Johnson also had been a director and treasurer of the American Gas Association and was a member of the National Petroleum Council. Johnson is survived by his wife, May, of New York; two sons, Keith of New York, and Douglas of Appleton, Wisc.; and two sisters, Ethel Lambert of New York, and Betty Lentz of Timonium, Md. Services were set for Saturday in New York.

DOC.HEAD: Shearson Lehman Indicted for Securities Violations
DOC.TEXT: Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. and two former employees in Cleveland have been indicted on charges of defrauding investors by making unauthorized trades, state officials said Friday. The Cuyahoga County grand jury Thursday issued 42 indictments each against Shearson; Sheldon Strauss, a former account executive; and Stephen Weinberg, former branch manager of the firm's Cleveland office, Ohio Division of Securities Commissioner Mark Holderman said. The indictments charge Strauss with violating the Ohio Securities Act through fraud and false representation in the sale of securities. The corporation and Weinberg also are named in the indictments for their alleged complicity, Holderman said. Strauss allegedly placed investors' funds in highly speculative stocks without their knowledge, Holderman said. ``Strauss was gambling quite a bit with other people's money,'' Holderman said. The state has investigated about 150 complaints filed by investors against Strauss during the last two years, he said. Many of the alleged violations were discovered during the stock market crash in October 1987, Holderman said. He said Shearson already has settled more than $4.9 million in claims by Strauss' former clients. Weinberg and Shearson were charged because they ``knew there were problems'' with Strauss' accounts but didn't try to put a stop to the practices, Holderman said. The company will not comment until it has fully reviewed the indictments, said Steve Fagan, a spokesman for Shearson in New York.

Wholesale gasoline and crude oil prices moved higher in the futures market but failed to recover all the ground lost earlier in the week. Traders said buying picked up Friday as the stalemate in the Middle East dragged on. Early waves of selling this week had been inspired by hopes for a quick negotiated settlement to the crisis, which has threatened the world's oil supplies. Light sweet crude oil rose 55 cents on the New York Mercantile Exchange to end the week at $27.32 per barrel on contracts for October delivery.

Members of the International Energy Agency agreed to work together to avert oil shortages from the Persian Gulf crisis, but they said the threat to supplies had eased. Senior officials of the IEA, comprised of 21 industrialized nations, said Friday they expected production hikes authorized by OPEC nations on Wednesday would counter the effects of the U.N. boycott of Iraq and Kuwait.

Driving to the family barbecue this Labor Day weekend will cost more than it has in years, but higher gasoline prices apparently aren't keeping fuel-thirsty Americans off the road. ``If it would be $5 a gallon, I'd still go away for the weekend,'' Bud Case said as he shelled out $26.13 to fill up his camper Friday in Charleston, W.Va. The American Automobile Association said gasoline prices were averaging $1.307 a gallon for self-serve regular unleaded. That's up from $1.084 over the July 4 holiday and $1.062 on last Labor Day. The AAA predicted a 2 percent decrease in Labor Day travel, but said higher gasoline is not the culprit.

The Resolution Trust Corp. plans to hire a special group of employees to watch for possible corruption as it sells hundreds of failed savings and loans. The RTC hopes to set up a team of 20 to 30 ``contractor cops'' this fall to oversee the sale of billions of dollars of S&L assets, spokeswoman Kate Spears said Friday.

Hundreds of Chrysler Corp.'s union workers punched out for the last time, accepting buyouts from the automaker designed to reduce the need for layoffs. The reduction Friday in the company's work force, expected to involve about 600 employees, comes as Chrysler negotiates a new national labor contract with the United Auto Workers union and as the financially struggling company seeks ways to cut costs.

The Persian Gulf crisis has not been kind to the shipping industry, whose stocks have tumbled on fears tankers will be idled as insurance companies impose war-zone premiums and sailors demand hazardous duty pay. Analysts in world shipping capitals say the market, complex and highly sensitive at best, now also is confused. In some cases, it's nearing panic. Stock market shipping indexes have slumped about 25 percent worldwide since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, said a spokesman for Lloyd's List International in London.

When many travel agents around the country tried to lock in tickets for airline customers earlier this week, their computers balked. A deadline for cheap autumn fares combined with a new charge for higher jet fuel costs threw the nation's airline reservation system into what agents and airlines described as unprecedented gridlock Wednesday. As tens of thousands of Americans jammed phone lines seeking to book tickets, computers were so slow that getting reservation information often took 30 minutes or more. Some systems crashed.

Michigan's largest conservation and sportsmen's group has taken aim at J.C. Penney Co. Inc. for marketing boys' clothing with an anti-hunting message. ``The message that kids will pick up from this _ that the traditional hunting sports are wrong and that anyone who enjoys hunting is somehow dangerous and evil _ is simply outrageous,'' said Thomas Washington, executive director of the Michigan United Conservation Clubs. Penney spokesman Duncan Muir said Friday the company would make a decision on the merchandise next week.

While White House officials scrambled for information during the initial hours of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, AT&T's own crisis management center was plotting an escape for dozens of employees. An undisclosed number of American Telephone & Telegraph Co. employees were among a group of U.S. nationals working in Kuwait whose companies had security measures in place for such a crisis. ``Our security director was awakened about 3 o'clock in the morning by our people in a location in Kuwait City,'' AT&T spokesman Herb Linnen said Friday.

Stock prices rose, but trading set its slowest pace of the year Friday as the market coasted into the long Labor Day weekend. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials gained 21.04 to 2,614.36, finishing the week with a net gain of 81.44 points. Bond prices were narrowly mixed in a quiet, abbreviated session. The dollar advanced against most major currencies except the Japanese yen. Gold prices slipped. Grain and soybean futures prices were lower; energy futures rose; precious metals fell; cocoa futures gained; orange juice retreated; and livestock and pork futures were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Editors: Financial Page Editors: Due to technical difficulties, some of the net changes in the National Market OTC daily tables are incorrect. The prices are correct as shown. AP Markets
Genentech, Pharmaceutical Companies Start Merger
DOC.TEXT: Genentech Inc. and Roche Holding Ltd. of Switzerland said their $2.1 billion merger will go ahead as the result of an agreement Friday with the Federal Trade Commission. The California biotechnology company and Swiss pharmaceutical giant expected to complete the merger _ in which Roche will acquire 60 percent of Genentech's stock _ on or about Sept. 7. The companies said they entered into a consent decree with the FTC, which conducted an antitrust law review of the merger announced in February and approved by 97 percent of Genentech's shareholders in June. The decree requires that Genentech and the Basel-based Roche divest themselves of certain holdings or technologies similar to the other's. Under the merger agreement, Roche, parent of F. Hoffman-LaRoche & Co., will pay $36 a share for 50 percent of the shares into Genentech and inject $492 million of capital into the company for the other 10 percent. Genentech, maker of the heart attack drug TPA, will have a cash balance of $600 million, which it hopes will help it get new products on the market. Roche also has the option to buy another 15 percent of Genentech on the open market. It also may buy the rest of Genentech over the next five years at fixed prices ranging from $38 to $60. Shareholders will get $36 each for half of their shares and new redeemable common stock in exchange for the other half _ a windfall of $65 million plus stock. Genentech's stock closed at $29 on the New York Stock Exchange on Friday, up $1 from Thursday. The stock had hovered at about $27 since the announcement of the merger. Genentech, founded in 1976, is a world leader in the development of biotechnology products and has been profitable every year but one since 1979. In 1989, it had earnings of $44 million, or 51 cents a share, on revenues were $400 million. Roche Holdings, a health care company specializing in pharmaceutical development and vitamin and chemical manufacturing, had worldwide sales of $6.5 billion last year. The terms of the consent decree with the FTC will appear in the U.S. Federal Register and be subject to public comment for 60 days. The FTC will then decide whether to make the decree final, but the public comment period will not prevent Genentech and Roche from putting the deal into effect. Under the decree, Genentech must divest its 50 percent interest in GLC Associates, a partnership formed with Lubrizol Inc. of Cleveland, Ohio, _ but currently without employees _ to develop a recombinant process to produce vitamin C. Roche has a large share of the worldwide vitamin C market. The decree requires Roche to divest its technology with respect to human growth hormone releasing factor. Genentech developed and markets human growth hormone, which is used to treat children with pituitary dwarfism. Roche also must grant non-exclusive licenses under its American patent rights with respect to CD4-Igm, a potential AIDS drug in the early research stage. Genentech currently has a similar potential AIDS drug, CD4-Iig, in early clinical trials. Officials from both companies have said that Genentech's management and research will remain independent. Two Roche executives _ Armin M. Kessler, Roche chief operating officer and director, and Jurgen Drews, head of Roche corporate research _ will hold two seats on Genentech's 13-seat board of directors.

DOC.HEAD: Argentina Announces Layoffs, Other Austerity Moves
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with changes announced officially. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: The government steeply increased utility rates Friday and announced plans to lay off thousands of public employees in an effort to cut the financial deficit and stimulate an economy in deep recession. Hours earlier, President Carlos Menem asked his countrymen to have patience with his 13-month-old government, which took office amid hyperinflation and recession. Economy Minister Antonio Gonzalez said many public employees under contract would be laid off beginning in September, and civil servants would be forced to retire early. He gave no figure, but analysts said the total would reach at least 80,000 of a public workforce of 3 million. Gonzalez said gasoline prices for cars would go up 35 percent as of Saturday, and other public service rates would increase by an average 12 to 15 percent, or about the rate of inflation projected for August. He said his ministry will oversee the 13 biggest state companies, which until now reported to the Public Works Ministry, and the major factories that until now were part of the Defense Ministry. The state airline, railroad, telphone and other companies must pay their debts from their revenue and budgets because the Central Bank no longer will make up their deficits, he announced. The Central Bank will require all banks that owe it money to clear up their accounts. Those that cannot will be forced out of business, he said. ``Argentina is undertaking a profound transformation of the public sector,'' Gonzalez said in a address on state radio and TV. The goal ``is a state that is austere and efficient . . . (and capable) of all the tasks of a modern state.'' The measures were imposed by decree. Menem's solution to Argentina's economic straits has been to reduce the role of the state in the economy and spur private enterprise. ``We're looking from the national government to restructure the state, to do serious surgery on the state, and for that sacrifice and understanding are needed,'' Menem told reporters. ``The party is over.'' The Menem government removed controls on prices and foreign exchange, linked public service rates and their costs, reduced import tariffs and export taxes, cut the 1990 budget by $4 billion, encouraged foreign investment and partially deregulated the oil industry. The government also has proposed tax reform and reorganizing the Central Bank to make it more independent. As a result, the increase in the monthly cost of living fell to near single digits in July from 197 percent 12 months earlier. The exchange rate has held steady for six months. The fiscal deficit narrowed. The cost has been a deep recession, however. Unemployment and underemployment at a combined rate of 18 percent is a record. Real wages have not kept up with inflation. Many families are hard pressed to make ends meet. Wage strikes and public protests about the pending sale of public firms like the airline and phone company are increasing. Teachers have boycotted public classrooms for a month. Political leaders openly worry about the prospect of social upheaval, such as the food riots of May and June 1989 which killed 16 people, wounded more than 200 and resulted in nearly 2,500 arrests.
